site_title: Tencent to restructure as it faces tighter regulations
summary: Chinese internet giant Tencent Holdings announced its first restructuring in six years, amid increased government regulations and market challenges. The company will consolidate content business groups and create a new group for cloud and smart industries. This move aims to improve its cloud-based data offering services and boost content capabilities for WeChat, music, games, and other services. The restructuring also seeks to integrate social, content, and technology, promoting the upgrade from consumer Internet to industrial Internet.

site_title: Dozens hurt as typhoon Trami hammers Japan
summary: Typhoon Trami made landfall in Japan, causing widespread disruption and injuries. At least 84 people were injured, with one man reported dead and another missing. The storm brought fierce winds and torrential rain, halting transport and causing power outages. Bullet train services were suspended, over 1,000 flights were cancelled, and Tokyo's evening train services were scrapped. The typhoon's maximum gusts reached 216 km/h, with potential flooding and landslides forecasted. The storm is the latest in a string of extreme natural events in Japan, which has suffered recent typhoons, flooding, earthquakes, and heatwaves.

site_title: Global banks in Singapore tap Belt and Road opportunities
summary: Global banks in Singapore are expanding their China desks and hiring experienced bankers to capitalize on Belt and Road Initiative (BRI) projects and Asean growth. Citi and HSBC are among the banks increasing their presence in the region, with Citi's "China to Asean corridor" revenue growing 66% year-on-year. HSBC has added a regional head of BRI and increased headcount across its commercial and global banking businesses. The banks are seeking bankers with local knowledge and regulatory expertise to help clients navigate the region's infrastructure boom and BRI opportunities.

site_title: Moscow car crash that turned into an US$80m AR concept
summary: Vitaly Ponomarev, 30, turned a 2012 Moscow car crash into an $80 million opportunity after he realized drivers are distracted by gadgets while driving. His company, WayRay, has raised $80 million from investors like Porsche and Alibaba for an augmented reality concept that projects directions onto the windshield, increasing safety and usefulness for drivers. The system is smaller, less than 3 liters in volume, and uses a light-activated resin to reflect virtual images onto the windshield, allowing for larger projections than existing head-up displays.

site_title: Stocks to watch: China Environment, Keppel, Healthway Medical, Datapulse, Alpha Energy
summary:
Here's a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

China Environment has authorized a creditor to take over management of its unit Anhui Dongyuan Environmental Protection Co. Keppel Corp's property arm has entered into a joint venture to develop its first commercial project in India. Healthway Medical Corporation is divesting its entire stake in CLAAS Medical Centre for S$150,000. Datapulse Technology reported a net profit of S$34.48 million for the full year ended July 31, 2018. Alpha Energy is placing out 46 million new shares to raise up to S$5.175 million. These developments may impact trading of the listed companies' shares.

site_title: Indonesia rushes in aid as death toll from quake, tsunami passes 840
summary: A 7.5 magnitude earthquake struck Sulawesi, Indonesia, on Friday, triggering a tsunami that has killed 844 people, with the death toll expected to rise. Indonesian authorities are rushing to provide aid and rescue equipment to the quake-hit island, with a focus on burying the dead and evacuating survivors. The disaster has left thousands without food, shelter, or medical supplies, with concerns raised about the effectiveness of Indonesia's warning systems and why more people in coastal areas did not move to higher ground. International aid has begun to arrive, with Australia, Thailand, China, and the US offering assistance.

images.alt_text: Indonesian authorities scrambled to get food, aid and equipment into quake-hit Sulawesi island on Monday as the death toll from the disaster soared to 832 and looked certain to rise as rescuers struggled to reach devastated outlying communities.

site_title: Rio Tinto, Japan partners to invest US$1.6b on Australian iron ore
summary: Rio Tinto has partnered with Japan's Mitsui & Co and Nippon Steel & Sumitomo Metal to invest US$1.55 billion in two iron ore projects in Western Australia. The projects, worth US$820 million, will maintain production capacity and sustain Rio's Pilbara Blend and Robe Valley products. The investments follow similar announcements by rivals BHP Billiton and Fortescue Metals, and are expected to create 1,200 jobs. The move aims to sustain current production rates from 2020 onwards, amid record iron ore shipments to China.

site_title: UK minister optimistic about Brexit deal after Toyota warning
summary: UK Business Secretary Greg Clark expressed optimism about a potential Brexit deal, citing a warning from Toyota that leaving without an agreement would harm production. Toyota's Burnaston plant in central England could see a hit in output due to potential border delays. Clark stated that the UK is determined to reach an agreement, and there are grounds for optimism. This comes as talks between the UK and EU remain at an impasse, with Prime Minister Theresa May's "Chequers" proposals deemed unacceptable by EU leaders.

site_title: Healthway Medical to sell loss-making medical centre
summary: Healthway Medical Corporation is selling its entire stake in the loss-making CLAAS Medical Centre in Singapore for S$150,000. The sale includes 499,993 shares, representing 99.9% of the company's ownership. The loss on disposal is expected to be S$68,000. As part of its business optimization strategy, Healthway is exiting the wellness business to improve operational efficacy. The net asset value of CLAAS and its subsidiary BCNG is approximately S$200,000.

site_title: Keppel in joint venture for first commercial project in India; to buy land for 4.05b rupees
summary: Keppel Land, a property arm of KEPPEL Corporation, has entered a joint venture with Puravankara Limited to develop its first commercial project in India. The project, worth 4.05 billion rupees (S$81 million), will feature a 160,000 square foot retail-cum-office facility and a Grade A office tower in Bangalore. Keppel owns a 51% stake in the venture, while Puravankara holds the remaining 49%. The project aims to capitalize on Bangalore's growing office market, with the city recording the highest office space absorption in the Asia-Pacific region over the past five years.

site_title: Australia, New Zealand dollars edge up against weaker greenback
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars edged up against the weakened US dollar on Monday, despite low trading volumes due to a state holiday in Australia. The Australian dollar rose to A$0.7240, while the New Zealand dollar gained 0.14% to NZ$0.6624. Analysts attributed the gains to relief over robust GDP data and improved business sentiment in New Zealand, as well as ongoing global jitters weighing on the greenback.

site_title: Shanghai Turbo names 4 new independent directors; 3 independent directors quit
summary: SHANGHAI Turbo Enterprises has appointed four new independent directors: Wee Liang Hiam, Leng Yew Chee Philip, Ong Sing Huat, and Seet Chong Tong. The appointments aim to provide a fresh perspective and follow the Singapore Court of Appeal's order to postpone the extraordinary general meeting. Three independent directors, Jack Chia Seng Hee, Raymond Lim Sian Heong, and Cheung Hok Fung, have resigned. The new directors will take on various roles, including lead independent director and chairman of committees.

site_title: Certis' Aussie buy aims to conquer security market down under
summary: Singaporean security firm Certis has acquired Australian security services firm SNP Security, with plans to integrate SNP with Certis' other Australian security firm, Business Risks International Group Holdings (BRI). SNP aims to become the market leader in five to seven years, with a goal of snagging 50-60% of the aviation security market. Under new country managing director Thomas "Tom" Roche, SNP plans to expand into retail, land transport, and critical infrastructure installations, while avoiding contracts in pubs, hotels, prisons, and immigrant detention centers.

site_title: From Orwell to 'The Little Mermaid', Kuwait steps up book banning
summary: Kuwait has stepped up book banning, targeting works by notable authors such as George Orwell, Gabriel García Márquez, and Maya Angelou. The government has banned over 4,390 books since 2014, with 700 more banned in the past 11 months. Banned books include children's stories, works by Kuwaiti authors, and government-published materials. Despite claims that only 2% of books are banned, Kuwaiti readers have taken to social media to protest, and some have even stockpiled banned books in their homes. The country's book fair is scheduled for November, but officials have pushed back on book banning.

site_title: Speculators' scepticism is a sign for the bulls
summary: Speculators' extreme short selling of gold, with a net positioning of -10,844 contracts, indicates a potential short squeeze, which historically has lifted the gold price by an average of 25% or to around $1,500. The current price is near the $1,212 range high, and a break above it could kick-start the short squeeze process, potentially leading to a significant rally in gold.

site_title: FLASH: URA private home price index up 0.5% q-o-q in Q3 2018
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) private home price index rose 0.5% quarter-over-quarter in Q3 2018. This marks a slight increase in the property market following a period of decline. The Q3 wave of condo launches is expected to test demand for Singapore's prime projects above the S$3,000 per square foot benchmark.

site_title: Tokyo's Nikkei index closes at 27-year high
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei 225 index reached a 27-year high on October 1, 2018, closing at 24,245.76, driven by a weak yen and a breakthrough in US-Canada trade talks. The Topix index also rose, edging up 0.04%. The gains were seen as a positive sign for the Asian market, despite ongoing US-China trade tensions and global economic uncertainty.

images.alt_text:
merc8 - Mercedes interior




Source: Mercedes-Benz Singapore##########merc3##########Mercedes-Benz Singapore

site_title: Hong Kong, Shanghai: Markets closed for public holidays
summary: Markets in Hong Kong and Shanghai are closed for public holidays. The Hong Kong market resumes trading on October 2, while the Shanghai market resumes trading on October 8 due to China's "Golden Week" holiday.

site_title: Ex-banker's startup wants to help democratise Wall Street hiring
summary: A startup called The Lobby aims to democratize Wall Street hiring by connecting recent graduates with insiders at top finance companies. Founded by a former investment banker, the platform offers anonymous 30-minute phone calls to discuss job opportunities and provides mock interviews and career advice. With $1.2 million in seed funding, The Lobby seeks to level the playing field for those without elite school connections or family ties. The company aims to create a meritocracy by expanding access to elite jobs.

site_title: US, Canada in last-minute Nafta deal: media
summary: US and Canadian negotiators reached a deal late Sunday to reform the North American Free Trade Agreement (Nafta), following over a year of talks triggered by US President Donald Trump's discontent with the 24-year-old pact. A joint statement is expected, with significant sections of a new Nafta deal reportedly agreed upon. The deal follows an emergency cabinet meeting by Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau and comes ahead of a Washington-imposed midnight deadline for Congress to receive the revised agreement.

site_title: Green marine fuel standard making some players uneasy
summary: The International Maritime Organization's (IMO) 2020 global sulphur cap, which limits marine fuel to 0.5% sulphur content, is expected to disrupt the shipping and refining sectors, potentially costing the world economy $1 trillion. Industry players, including shipping companies and refineries, are concerned about the costly transition to low-sulphur fuel, which may lead to higher shipping costs and potentially passed on to consumers. Despite the industry's support for the regulation, uncertainty remains over fuel availability and compatibility.

site_title: Uber clampdown in Spain hurts refuge for long-term unemployed
summary: Spain's Socialist government has introduced new rules requiring Uber and Cabify drivers to seek a permit from local authorities to operate in urban areas, aiming to address tensions between taxi and hailing-app drivers. The move is seen as a victory for taxi companies, but ride-hailing services claim it will hurt independent drivers, many of whom are middle-aged workers who lost their jobs due to long-term unemployment and are now relying on ride-hailing to re-enter the workforce.

site_title: China manufacturing slows in September as trade war worsens
summary: China's manufacturing sector slowed in September, with the official manufacturing purchasing managers index (PMI) falling to 50.8, and the Caixin manufacturing PMI declining to 50, the lowest since May 2017. The trade war with the US is expected to worsen, with potential tariffs on $250 billion of Chinese goods. Despite this, domestic demand for services and construction remains strong, and the government is expected to implement targeted stimulus measures to support growth.

site_title: May faces Tory fire over Brexit as Johnson lays down challenge
summary: Theresa May faces a test of her leadership as a succession of senior Conservative politicians give lukewarm endorsements of her Brexit plan, with some calling it "deranged." Former Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson criticized her plan, while former Brexit Secretary David Davis blamed her for the lack of success in talks with the EU. May's proposal to keep close to the EU's single market in goods has been rejected by European leaders, and euroskeptic Tories led by Johnson want a quick, clean split from the bloc. The next few days will be critical for May's position as the party's leader.

site_title: CAAS clocks S$78.05m net surplus for FY17/18
summary: CAAS reported a net surplus of S$78.05 million for FY17/18, up from S$76.44 million a year ago. The aviation regulator's income rose to S$469 million, driven by higher aviation levies and fees, while expenditure increased to S$461.68 million. Non-operating income rose to S$17.96 million, and the surplus before government grants was S$29.09 million. The regulator highlighted robust air traffic growth and plans to strengthen air traffic management capabilities through technology advancements and partnerships.

site_title: Oil advances as Trump, Saudi king discuss market stability
summary: US President Donald Trump and Saudi King Salman bin Abdulaziz discussed market stability, amid oil's longest quarterly rally in a decade. Oil prices rose 0.6% as the US slowed drilling, and Brent crude reached a 4.1% gain from the previous quarter. Despite concerns over supply disruptions, oil majors warned of a possible unsustainable rally due to escalating trade tensions. The market is awaiting American sanctions on Iran, which may impact oil prices above $100 per barrel.

site_title: US, Canada agree to Nafta replacement that will include Mexico
summary: US President Donald Trump is set to sign a successor to the North American Free Trade Agreement (Nafta), replacing it with the US-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA), after US and Canadian negotiators reached a deal. The pact, signed by late November, includes improved access to Canada's dairy market, stronger intellectual property provisions, and tighter rules of origin for auto production. The agreement aims to ease uncertainty for companies reliant on tariff-free commerce and provides some cover for Canada and Mexico from US tariffs on car imports.

site_title: 'Let's come together': PM May appeals to Tories to unite behind Brexit plan
summary: UK Prime Minister Theresa May appealed to her Conservative Party to unite behind her Brexit plan, which includes a free trade deal with the EU, at her annual conference. Her plan, known as Chequers, has been met with criticism from former ministers Boris Johnson and David Davis, who argue it would split Northern Ireland from mainland Britain. May remains committed to her plan, despite growing pressure and criticism, and has vowed to deliver a Brexit deal that respects the UK's vote and protects jobs.

site_title: Private home price index gain slows to 0.5% q-o-q in Q3: URA flash estimate
summary: Singapore's private residential property price index rose 0.5% in Q3 2018, a slowdown from 3.4% in Q2 and 3.9% in Q1, according to the URA's flash estimate. Landed homes increased 1.7% and non-landed private homes 0.2% in the quarter. Despite the slowdown, prices are still up 8.8% from a year ago. Experts attribute the slowdown to the recent property cooling measures, expecting an 8-10% increase in the index for 2018.

site_title: General Motors' China unit recalls 3.3 million cars
summary: General Motors' Shanghai joint venture, SAIC GM, will recall over 3.3 million Buick, Chevrolet, and Cadillac vehicles manufactured between Sept 2013 and Sept 2018 due to system defects. The recall, starting October 20, will be handled by contacting car owners for free repair services. The move comes after complaints from consumers over an extended period, following regulator inspections.

site_title: GCB deals hit S$220m in third quarter
summary: Singapore's Good Class Bungalow (GCB) market saw a surge in transactions in the third quarter, with 11 deals worth S$220 million, exceeding Q2's S$169.1 million and Q3 2017's S$123.1 million. The increased activity is attributed to some owners accepting offers on the table after the July cooling measures, while others are holding on to their asking prices due to the buyer-seller price gap widening. New buyers, particularly those in their 20s, are also entering the market, with several caveats lodged for properties along prime roads like Nassim Road and Lornie Road.

site_title: China's Xi tells new Maldives president he wants to deepen cooperation
summary: China's President Xi Jinping has expressed a desire to deepen cooperation with the newly elected Maldives president, Ibrahim Mohamed Solih. This comes as China and India compete for influence in the Indian Ocean nation. The Maldives opposition had vowed to review Chinese projects, citing concerns over terms, but Xi's message emphasizes a long-standing friendship and mutual benefit. China's Foreign Ministry had previously urged "continuity and stability" in the Maldives after the election.

site_title: French transport group trains its sights on Singapore MRT, public bus services
summary: French transport group RATP Group, aiming to gain a foothold in Singapore's public transport sector, has established a regional headquarters in Singapore. The company, which has previously failed to secure contracts in the city-state, plans to focus on the upcoming Jurong Region and Cross Island lines and future public bus package tenders. RATP Dev's CEO, Laurence Batlle, stated that the company will bring its expertise in metro assets management and demand-responsive services to complement Singapore's existing transport know-how, aiming to become a trusted partner in the city's Smart Mobility 2030 vision.

images.alt_text: Ms Batlle doesn't think RATP Dev must necessarily compete against SMRT or SBS Transit in order to make inroads into Singapore.

site_title: South Korea's factory activity rebounds, fastest growth in 5-1/2 years
summary: South Korea's factory activity rebounded in September, with the Nikkei/Markit purchasing managers' index (PMI) rising to 51.3, its fastest growth in 5-1/2 years. Output increased at the fastest pace in 10 months and new orders picked up pace. The job creation rate also grew at the strongest rate since May 2013. However, export sales contracted for the second month due to fewer orders from Japan and China amid global trade tensions. The survey suggests the South Korean manufacturing sector showed resilience despite intensifying trade tensions.

site_title: Quiet week ahead, but watch out for EM currencies
summary: A quiet week ahead for the local equity market is expected, with few major announcements in the first week of October. The Reserve Bank of India is expected to raise interest rates, while the Reserve Bank of Australia is expected to keep its policy rate unchanged. Emerging markets, particularly Indonesia and India, are expected to feature in headlines due to volatility. The Indian rupee has been the worst performer in Asia this year, and the Indonesian rupiah has lost another 1.14% in September.

site_title: Suso ends goal drought as AC Milan defeat Sassuolo
summary: AC Milan defeated Sassuolo 4-1, with Spanish midfielder Suso scoring a brace to end his Serie A goal drought. The win moved Milan to 10th place in the standings, four points off Inter Milan, who occupy the final Champions League berth. Sassuolo dropped to fifth, while Fiorentina moved third with a 2-0 win over Atalanta. The victory also marked AC Milan's first win in three consecutive draws.

site_title: Money launderers are taking EU to the cleaners
summary: Money launderers are exploiting the European Union's lack of coordination in anti-money laundering efforts, according to recent scandals. The EU boasts the world's most stringent rules, but criminals are finding ways to circumvent them. Recent cases include Danske Bank's Estonian branch, Dutch bank ING, and Latvia's ABLV, with ties to Russia, North Korea, and UK corporate entities. The EU's new anti-money laundering directive aims to improve transparency, but analysts say it's no match for determined criminals who can exploit gaps in implementation.

images.alt_text: An inquiry has found that probably many billions of euros were laundered through the Estonian branch of Denmark's biggest lender, Danske Bank.

site_title: US dollar's share of global foreign reserves hits lowest since 2013
summary: The US dollar's share of global foreign reserves fell to 62.3% in the second quarter, its lowest level since 2013, according to IMF data. China's yuan rose to 1.84% as a share of allocated reserves, its fourth consecutive quarter increase. Despite a 5% jump in the value of the US dollar, the decline occurred due to shifting reserves away from the US, with possible implications for US economy and trade.

images.alt_text: The US dollar's share of global central bank reserves fell to the lowest level since 2013 while holdings of the Chinese yuan rose for a fourth consecutive quarter, International Monetary Fund (IMF) data showed Friday.

site_title: Money FM podcast: The Hot Seat: Marcus Wong, CCO at Capitol Optical
summary: Marcus Wong, CCO at Capitol Optical, discusses his experience in the industry and shares insights on the company's growth and expansion. He highlights the importance of innovation and customer satisfaction in the optical sector. Wong also touches on Capitol Optical's partnerships and collaborations, emphasizing the company's commitment to delivering high-quality products and services.

site_title: What US$100-a-barrel oil would mean for the world economy
summary: Rising oil prices are forecasted to push Brent crude to US$100 a barrel for the first time since 2014, benefiting exporters and governments but potentially hurting consuming nations. This could lead to inflation, especially in Europe and China, and impact global growth. Economists predict that the impact will be smaller than in 2011 due to the shale revolution, lower energy intensity, and higher general price levels. However, the US dollar's gain and geopolitical factors, such as US sanctions on Iran, may affect the market, with emerging economies like Saudi Arabia, Nigeria, and Colombia likely to benefit, while countries like India, China, and Turkey may be negatively impacted.

site_title: Malaysia shares open higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 3.62 points, or 0.2%, to 1795.99 on Monday, driven by gains. Volume reached 65.8 million lots worth RM20.78 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 132 to 72.

site_title: Target iPhones instead of rates to support rupee, says Modi's adviser
summary: India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi's adviser, Rathin Roy, suggests restricting luxury imports to support the rupee and tackle a widening current-account deficit. Roy recommends targeting luxury goods like iPhones instead of raising interest rates. The government has raised import taxes on $12 billion worth of goods, including electronic goods and gold, to pare the deficit. This move follows similar steps taken by Indonesia, which has delayed import-heavy projects and boosted taxes on luxury goods. The central bank has also successfully warded off attempts to short the rupee.

site_title: Iran says it is close to oil deal with Europe
summary: Iran's Foreign Minister Mohammad Javad Zarif announced on Saturday that Tehran is close to a deal with European nations to sell oil despite US sanctions. The agreement, which would allow for barter and local currency transactions, could constitute the most significant break between President Donald Trump and European allies who oppose his decision to pull out of the 2015 nuclear deal. Several European nations, including Britain and France, have expressed doubts about the arrangement, but Iran and its allies, including Russia, have vowed to stand by the agreement.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Monday afternoon at 3,263.75, up 0.21%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.21% to 3,263.75 on Monday, driven by gains in Ezion Holdings and Rex International Holding. Active index stocks included DBS Group Holdings and Sembcorp Marine. A total of 552 million securities worth S$385 million changed hands, with 185 gainers outnumbering 122 losers. The Straits Times Index (STI) has been on a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: 3 office floors of The Octagon at Cecil Street up for bulk sale with S$45.5m indicative price
summary: Three office floors of The Octagon at 105 Cecil Street are up for bulk sale with an indicative price of S$45.5 million (S$2,450 per sq ft). The tender closes on Nov 1, 2018. The building offers prime location, freehold tenure, and limited strata office floors available. The sale price is higher than recent transactions of nearby freehold or 999-year strata office space, indicating a comeback in the strata titled office market, driven by strong occupier demand and limited new supply.

site_title: Britain's Theresa May, a survivor under constant pressure
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May, under constant pressure from party divisions and Brexit negotiations, has proven a remarkable survivor. She took office after the 2016 EU referendum and has navigated the turbulent Brexit process, despite losing her majority in the House of Commons. May, 62, has a steady image and a background in finance, but has faced criticism for her handling of issues like police budgets and immigration. Her legacy is likely to be her Brexit tenure, which has dominated her time in office.

site_title: Busy weekend for condo hunters with new launches
summary: A busy weekend for condo hunters in Singapore saw 40 units of The Jovell at Flora Drive sold at average prices of S$1,200-S$1,400 psf, out of 250 units launched. The 428-unit condominium, developed by Tripartite Developers, offers one- to four-bedroom apartments with prices starting from S$585,000 for a one-bedroom unit. The Jovell is located near Tampines East MRT Station and offers access to Changi Airport and other amenities.

site_title: SPH unveils digital photo marketplace Photonico
summary: Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) has launched Photonico, a digital photo marketplace featuring Asian contemporary culture and heritage photography. The platform, which went live on October 1, 2018, boasts over 12,000 images available for purchase and aims to become a go-to destination for high-quality stock images on Asia. Photonico's content is curated from SPH's archives and a network of local contributors, and is organized into categories such as Singapore heritage and food.

site_title: Singapore shares rise at Monday's open; STI up 0.27% to 3,265.87
summary: Singapore stocks opened higher on Monday, with the Straits Times Index rising 0.27% to 3,265.87. The index saw 86 gainers for every 45 losers, with Singtel and Hutchison Port Holdings Trust leading the gains. The rally follows a 5-day streak ahead of GDP data, with investors remaining positive despite tariff uncertainty and split Federal Reserve views.

site_title: White House denies 'micromanaging' inquiry into high court pick
summary: US President Donald Trump denied accusations of "micromanaging" the FBI investigation into Supreme Court nominee Brett Kavanaugh, after ordering a new investigation into sexual assault allegations against him. Trump claimed Democrats were trying to obstruct the process, while the White House said the investigation's scope was set by the Senate, not the president. However, reports suggest the White House is limiting the witnesses the FBI can question, and some witnesses, including Julie Swetnick, have been excluded from the inquiry. The FBI has contacted Deborah Ramirez, a Yale University classmate of Kavanaugh's, who has accused him of sexual misconduct.

site_title: OCBC Bank cancels sale of stake in Hong Kong Life Insurance for HK$2.4b
summary: OCBC Bank has canceled the sale of its 33.33% stake in Hong Kong Life Insurance Limited for HK$2.4 billion, due to unsatisfied closing conditions by the September 30 long stop date. The buyer, First Origin International, forfeited its deposit of HK$710 million, which will be divided among the sellers. The sale would have resulted in Hong Kong Life ceasing to be an associated company of OCBC Bank and its subsidiary OCBC Wing Hang Bank Limited. The deal is now terminated, and OCBC Bank will retain its stake in Hong Kong Life.

site_title: Singapore-KL agreement to suspend high-speed rail project a 'fair arrangement': Khaw Boon Wan
summary: Singapore and Malaysia have agreed to suspend the High-Speed Rail (HSR) project for two years, with trains now set to start running in 2031 instead of 2026. The deal, signed last month, protects Singapore's interests while accommodating Malaysia's request. Malaysia will reimburse Singapore $15 million for the deferment, covering contract breakage costs. The agreement allows for discussions on the project's future, with Singapore open to reducing costs. The suspension period will not impact development plans for the Jurong Lake District, and the project will be deemed terminated if Malaysia does not proceed by May 31, 2020.

site_title: US, Canada hold last-minute Nafta talks as deadline looms
summary: US and Canadian negotiators held last-minute Nafta talks on September 30, 2018, as a deadline loomed. The talks were conducted over the phone, with US adviser Peter Navarro stating that both sides were negotiating in good faith. A deal is close, with Canada's Globe and Mail citing sources as saying most substantive work was completed and final details were being finalized. The US wants to push the deal through Congress by Sunday, while Canada's Prime Minister Justin Trudeau's office indicated ongoing negotiations without any announcements. A 60-day review period must be respected in the US.

site_title: A phone box revival has London saying enough
summary: London is facing a battle over its public space as phone companies push to install digital ad screens and surveillance-enabled phone booths, dubbed "InLink kiosks," every 50 feet. Critics argue these high-tech booths are eyesores and enable private surveillance, while local councils and residents object to the proliferation of these advertisements and data collection. The phone companies claim they comply with planning laws and provide modern navigation tools, but experts say the law is being bypassed to profit from Britain's public space, sparking a broader debate over the sell-off of public space.

site_title: Argentina nears new currency swap deal with China: central bank
summary: Argentina's central bank has "nearly closed" a new currency swap deal with China, adding $9 billion to the country's reserves. The deal, which was first reported in August, is aimed at boosting Argentina's dwindling reserves amid a 50% slide in the peso and rising inflation. New central bank chief Guido Sandleris said the deal will help contain volatility and bring inflation down in coming months, with the bank aiming to eliminate growth in the country's monetary base by next June.

images.alt_text: Argentina and China first agreed to a swap programme in 2009 to boost the South American country's dwindling reserves under former President Cristina Fernandez.

site_title: May plans to hike UK property tax for foreign buyers
summary: UK Prime Minister Theresa May plans to increase stamp duty on foreign property buyers, with a rate ranging from 1-3% for individuals and companies not paying tax in the UK. The move aims to curb inflation in the property market, which has been affected by Brexit uncertainty. A no-deal Brexit could lead to a 35% drop in house prices, according to Bank of England Governor Mark Carney. The policy change is expected to add pressure on the UK's property market, which is already experiencing a decline in London house prices.

site_title: Hong Kong's new fight against fast fashion
summary: A growing movement against fast fashion is emerging in Hong Kong, with clothes-mending workshops and pop-up swaps gaining popularity. Designers such as Jesse Lee are showcasing creations made from recycled materials, including old umbrellas and curtains. The movement is part of a global shift towards sustainability, with the global average consumer purchasing 60% more clothing in 2016 than in 2000. Hong Kong alone sends 343 tonnes of textiles to landfills daily, but initiatives like the new upcycling spinning mill aim to reduce waste and promote sustainable fashion practices.

images.alt_text: Fashion designer Jesse Lee (right) making final adjustments to a model wearing a jacket he designed and made with material from discarded umbrellas.

site_title: Boosting Singapore's data connectivity
summary: NetLink NBN Trust CEO Tong Yew Heng discusses growth opportunities for Singapore's data connectivity, citing a changing industry landscape. In unrelated news, NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was oversubscribed 9.8 times, while companies like Creative Technology and OCBC face revenue and operating loss concerns. Additionally, Singapore stocks rallied for a fifth consecutive day ahead of GDP data, and the MAS and PBOC announced plans to deepen cooperation in green and transition finance.

site_title: Dollar rises on euro woes, Fed rate outlook
summary: The US dollar rose to a two-week peak versus a currency basket on Friday, driven by concerns over the Italian budget and an outlook for multiple US interest rate hikes until 2020. The euro slipped below US$1.16 for the first time in two weeks after Italy agreed on a budget seen as defying Brussels. US data supported a stable growth path, with consumer spending and inflation remaining steady. The dollar rose to a nine-month high against the yen, while the euro faced pressure due to Italy's high debt levels.

site_title: Two-thirds of US business economists see recession by end-2020: poll
summary: Two-thirds of US business economists expect a recession by the end of 2020, with 56% citing 2020 as the year of the next contraction. Trade policy is seen as the greatest risk to the expansion, followed by higher interest rates and a substantial stock-market decline. Despite this, economists are slightly more optimistic about the economy this year, with a median forecast for inflation-adjusted GDP growth of 2.9%. The Federal Reserve has raised its 2018 growth estimate to 3.1% and boosted interest rates, with expectations for further rate hikes in 2019.

images.alt_text: Two-thirds of business economists in the US expect a recession to begin by the end of 2020, while a plurality of respondents say trade policy is the greatest risk to the expansion, according to a new survey.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights report for the week ending September 30, 2018, shows a mixed market for tankers and dry bulk ships. Tanker rates rose, with VLCCs firming at WS 59/59.5 for 270,000mt from the Middle East Gulf to China and Singapore. Suezmax rates increased, with West Africa gaining five points to WS 77.5 for 130,000mt to the UK-Continent. Aframax rates rose, with the Mediterranean market increasing by 7.5 points to WS 107.5 for 80,000mt. Panamax rates dropped, with the ARA to the US Gulf market falling by 7.5 points to WS 112.5 for 55,000mt.

site_title: Doomsayers begin to see cracks in a healthy world economy
summary: Prominent investors and economists are warning of potential issues that could trigger the next recession, citing voracious corporate and emerging market borrowing as a key concern. Experts, including Martin Feldstein and Stanley Druckenmiller, warn that rising interest rates could lead to a debt-fuelled Wall Street bubble, gutting investment portfolios and consumer confidence. The US economy is seen as "Goldilocks," but analysts predict a slowdown in consumer spending and a potential recession, with some warning of an "average" recession rather than a severe one.

site_title: China Environment authorises subsidiary's creditor to run unit, collect rental income
summary: China Environment has authorized a creditor, Lin Qun Bin, to take over management of Anhui Dongyuan Environmental Protection Co and collect rental income at its property. The authorization follows allegations of rental income misappropriation by Anhui's existing management. The rental agreements amount to 265,000 yuan per month, with 50,000 yuan paid to China Environment and 100,000 yuan to Lin. This move aims to address suspected misappropriation and recover rental income.

site_title: Facebook's worst security breach batters user trust once again
summary: Facebook has suffered its worst security breach, with hackers exploiting software bugs to gain login access to 50 million accounts. The breach, which occurred in September, allowed the hackers to impersonate users and post misleading information. The company has since fixed the vulnerability but remains uncertain about the hackers' intentions and their potential connection to election interference. The breach has raised concerns about user trust and may limit Facebook's ability to generate revenue from user activity, undermining the company's efforts to rebuild trust after a previous privacy scandal.

site_title: China factory sector hurt in September as trade frictions bite
summary: China's manufacturing sector growth stalled in September, with exports falling the fastest in over two years, according to two surveys. The factory sector's growth in exports contracted, with new export orders dropping at the fastest pace since February 2016. The official manufacturing Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) fell to a seven-month low of 50.8, while the Caixin/Markit PMI fell to 50.0. The slowdown is attributed to trade frictions and US tariffs, which are expected to continue to weigh on the Chinese economy, prompting policymakers to roll out growth-support measures.

images.alt_text: Workers checking pet beds that will be exported at a factory in Tancheng in China's Shandong province. Some companies have been rushing out shipments to the US to beat successive rounds of tariffs.

site_title: Asia factory activity sputters as trade woes hit export orders
summary: Asia's factory activity weakened in September due to trade woes and rising raw material costs. Trade-reliant economies, including China, Vietnam, Taiwan, and Indonesia, saw a slump in export orders, while Japan and South Korea's headline activity readings held up but suffered declines in export orders. India was a rare bright spot, with its factory activity expanding due to strong domestic and export order growth. The US-China trade dispute is expected to hit global economic growth, with analysts predicting a slowdown in global growth and increased risks in 2019.

site_title: Canadian dollar jumps after Nafta trade deal reports
summary: The Canadian dollar surged to a five-month high after reports of a deal reached between Canada and US negotiators on reforming the North American Free Trade Agreement (Nafta). The Canadian dollar rose 0.7% against the US dollar, its strongest level since May, following a joint statement expected by Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau. The news came after an emergency cabinet meeting and a review of the 1994 trade pact by US President Donald Trump. The deal is seen as a positive development for Canada's economy.

images.alt_text: The Canadian dollar jumped Monday to a five-month high in Asian trade after reports Ottawa had reached a deal with US negotiators on reforming the North American Free Trade Agreement (Nafta).

site_title: StarHub secures broadcast rights for Champions League, Europa League
summary: StarHub secures broadcast rights for Champions League and Europa League, marking the first telco in Singapore to do so. The matches will be shown live on beIN Sports HD on StarHub TV Channel 213, with simultaneous matches screened on Hub Sports channels. Existing StarHub TV subscribers can access the Sports Group at S$21.40 per month, while non-subscribers can subscribe to Go Sports at S$9.90 per month. The agreement comes after Singtel announced it would broadcast 10 Champions League matches on October 3 and 4.

images.alt_text: Paris St Germain's Juan Bernat (left) in action with Liverpool's Mohamed Salah (right) in a recent Champions League group stage (Group C) match.

site_title: China's total tax cut to exceed 1.3 trillion yuan this year, above target
summary: China's total tax cut for 2018 is expected to exceed 1.3 trillion yuan, surpassing the target. This move aims to ease economic headwinds amid Sino-US trade tensions. Finance Minister Liu Kun stated that China is studying further tax cuts and fee reductions. The total cuts in taxes and fees this year will be over 1.1 trillion yuan.

site_title: 48 dead, hundreds injured in tsunami-hit Indonesian city: disaster agency
summary: At least 48 people were killed and 356 injured in a quake-tsunami in Palu, Indonesia, on Sulawesi island. Waves as high as 1.5 meters hit the city of approximately 350,000 people. This is the first official death toll announced by Indonesia's disaster agency.

site_title: Strong quake, tsunami in Indonesia's Sulawesi island kill at least 30
summary: A 7.5 magnitude earthquake struck Indonesia's Sulawesi island, triggering a tsunami that killed at least 30 people in the bay city of Palu. Authorities struggled to coordinate rescue efforts due to a power outage and disrupted communications. Initial reports showed some dead victims in the rubble of collapsing buildings, with 12 injured needing orthopedic surgery.

site_title: HDB resale prices back on down slope with 0.2% dip in Q3; 3,800 BTO flats for launch in November
summary: HDB resale prices declined 0.2% in Q3, marking a return to the downtrend after a brief increase in the previous quarter. Prices are down nearly 1% from the same period last year. Experts attribute the decline to the cooling measures and concerns about declining leases, with some speculating that HDB upgraders may be holding off from selling their flats due to limited new supply. Meanwhile, about 3,800 Build-to-Order flats will be offered in November.

site_title: Autumnal woe: A 'mean reversion' on cards?
summary: The US stock market is facing a potential downturn as warnings from Wall Street suggest the recent rally may be due for a "mean reversion." Strategists at Bank of America Merrill Lynch Global Research and Prudential Financial warn that excess returns from recent years may be over, citing a tendency for asset classes to underperform after long periods of outperformance. Strong economic data and jobs reports may help sustain the market, but factors such as trade tensions, interest rate hikes, and European politics pose risks.

site_title: China's environment watchdog warns polluters not to flout winter smog plan
summary: China's environment ministry has warned heavy industry polluters not to flout the country's winter smog plan, despite relaxed production cuts in northern China. The Ministry of Ecology and Environment stated that companies must adhere to emission standards, with consequences including shutdowns and capacity cuts if they exceed limits. This warning follows the drop of blanket production cuts and the adoption of flexible measures based on regional emission levels. Improved air quality in 2017 showed the effectiveness of production restrictions, and the government aims to reduce PM2.5 readings by 3% this winter.

site_title: Gold slips as US dollar firms on Fed rate hike outlook
summary: Gold prices slipped 0.2% to US$1,189.22 on Monday, as the US dollar remained firm following the Federal Reserve's plans for multiple interest rate hikes by 2020. This marks the sixth straight monthly decline for gold, its longest losing streak since 1997. Gold had fallen 0.8% in September, with a low of US$1,180.34 on Friday.

site_title: Alpha Energy to place 46m new shares for up to S$5.175m
summary: Alpha Energy is placing 46 million new shares for up to S$5.175 million at S$0.1125 each. The placement will strengthen its financial and working capital position, primarily to fund its consolidation plans for the Mustang Project in Alaska. The deal will bring Alpha Energy's working interest in the project to 90.1%. The company will also acquire other assets and issue share options to raise funds.

site_title: Datapulse posts net profit of S$34.48m in FY2018, mostly due to gains from disposal of property
summary: Datapulse Technology, a former media storage business, posted a net profit of S$34.48 million for FY2018, largely due to a S$44.55 million gain from the disposal of its leasehold property. Revenue was S$716,000, mainly from its haircare business. The group declared a dividend of one Singapore cent per share and reported an earnings per share of 15.74 cents. Datapulse is diversifying into haircare and is reviewing its option to acquire Wayco Manufacturing, which it acquired in December 2017.

site_title: Typhoon Trami closes Kansai Airport
summary: Typhoon Trami brought strong winds to south-west Japan, causing power cuts at nearly 400,000 buildings and flight cancellations. Kansai International Airport closed two runways, affecting 70,000 passengers with over 900 cancellations. The typhoon, classified as a "very strong" typhoon, may approach central Japan, impacting Tokyo. Power outages occurred in Okinawa and Kyushu, and the bullet train service was halted. The typhoon's impact is expected to continue, with the Japan Meteorological Agency monitoring its progress.

images.alt_text: Trami has swept the southern islands of Okinawa and Kyushu on Sunday morning, with wind gusts of up to 222 kmh.

site_title: AnnAik unit clinches additional concession rights for China's Changxing wastewater plant
summary: AnnAik's 60% unit, ChangXing AngWei Environmental & Ecological Engineering Co, has secured additional concession rights for China's Changxing wastewater plant. The plant's capacity will increase to 30,000 tonnes from 20,000 tonnes, with a guaranteed minimum treatment of 60% in the first two years and 80% from the third year onwards. The concession rights will last for 30 years, with completion expected by end-2019 and a total investment estimated at up to 29 million yuan, funded by internal resources and bank borrowings.

site_title: When data replaces cash
summary: Singapore is pushing towards becoming an e-payments society, but experts warn of risks and pitfalls, including concerns over privacy, security, and exclusion of the poor and elderly. Collaboration and education are key to success, with industry players and government bodies working together to co-create a nationwide e-payments infrastructure. A standardized SGQR code is seen as a positive step, but cybersecurity and data protection remain major concerns. Experts urge the government to ensure safeguards are in place and that all levels of society can access e-payments safely and easily.

site_title: Meat labs pursue once-impossible goal: kosher bacon
summary: Rabbi Gavriel Price of the Orthodox Union is investigating kosher certification for lab-grown meat, known as clean meat, which could lead to kosher bacon. Clean meat is grown in laboratories from animal cells, and startups are working to produce commercially available products. Price is addressing questions about the kosher status of the product, including the sourcing of cells and the growth solution. He has met with companies, including Mission Barns, and has discussed potential kosher designations, such as pareve, which would allow observant Jews to eat clean meat with dairy products. The technology has sparked debate, with some arguing it could make kosher meat more affordable and reliable.

site_title: Fur-ever friends
summary: Animal welfare organizations in Singapore are urging the public to adopt pets from shelters instead of buying from pet shops or breeders. Experts say that rabbits can live up to 10 years, but are often abandoned due to misconceptions about their care. Cat Welfare Society Executive Director Laura Ann Meranda notes that stray cats are often the result of irresponsible breeding and abandonment, and that education is key to responsible pet ownership. Save Our Street Dogs President Siew Tuck Wah advocates for stricter enforcement of animal welfare laws and increased education on the importance of spaying/neutering and microchipping pets.

images.alt_text: Bunny Wonderland Singapore, Co-founders Jackie Fang (right), Lynne Tan (left).
Cat Welfare Society, Executive director, Laura Ann Meranda.
Save Our Street Dogs, President Siew Tuck Wah.

site_title: Japan's trade minister to retain post in cabinet reshuffle: Nikkei
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe is set to reappoint Trade Minister Hiroshige Seko in a cabinet reshuffle, which is expected to take place next week. Other key ministers, including Chief Cabinet Secretary Yoshihide Suga and Economy Minister Toshimitsu Motegi, will retain their posts. Seko's reappointment comes as Japan faces pressure to open up its markets under US President Donald Trump's bilateral trade talks. Abe will become Japan's longest-serving premier after winning a ruling party leadership vote last week.

images.alt_text: Japan's Minister of Economy, Trade and Industry Hiroshige Seko speaks during the 24th ASEAN Economic Ministers - Ministry of Economy, Trade and Industry, Japan Consultations meeting in Singapore on August 30, 2018.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei index opens higher
summary: Tokyo's benchmark Nikkei index opened higher on Monday, rising 0.19% or 44.85 points to 24,164.89, driven by a weak yen hovering around a 27-year high. The Topix index, however, fell 0.21%. The strong yen boost was attributed to a weaker US dollar, which had a positive impact on the Nikkei index.

site_title: Elon Musk ousted as Tesla chairman in SEC deal, but remains CEO; company to pay US$20m fine
summary: Elon Musk has agreed to a settlement with the US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC), relinquishing his role as Tesla chairman in exchange for a $20 million fine. He will remain CEO and continue on the board but cannot be re-elected as chairman for three years. The settlement eases uncertainty over Tesla's future and removes Musk from a key role at the company, which has become one of the most valuable in the world. Musk will also purchase $20 million worth of Tesla stock and the company will appoint two new independent directors.

site_title: Google CEO will testify before US House on bias accusations
summary: Google CEO Sundar Pichai will testify before the US House Judiciary Committee later this year over accusations of bias against conservatives. Pichai also agreed to attend a White House roundtable with President Trump and other internet stakeholders. Republicans want to question Google about search algorithm bias, privacy, and human rights issues. Google has denied accusations of bias, with Pichai stating that suggestions of political interference in search results are "absolutely false." The hearing is set to take place after the midterm congressional elections in November.

site_title: Amal Clooney appeals to Suu Kyi for reporters' release
summary: Human rights lawyer Amal Clooney appealed to Aung San Suu Kyi, the de facto leader of Myanmar, to pardon two Reuters journalists imprisoned for seven years over reporting on a Rohingya massacre. Clooney said Suu Kyi has the power to release the journalists and that her response will be judged by history. The journalists' families have already submitted a request for a pardon, and Clooney emphasized that Suu Kyi's actions will determine the fate of the journalists and the future of democracy in Myanmar.

images.alt_text: Reuters Editor-in-Chief Stephen Adler and attorney Amal Clooney participate in the Press Behind Bars: Undermining Justice and Democracy event during the 73rd session of the United Nations General Assembly at UN headquarters in New York, September 28, 2018.

site_title: South Korea's LG Display to cut jobs through voluntary retirement
summary: LG Display, a South Korean company and Apple supplier, plans to cut jobs through voluntary retirement for the first time since its founding. The company aims to reduce its workforce by 65% in production areas due to automation and a shift to OLED screens, which require fewer personnel. The move is driven by decreased LCD prices due to Chinese competition, and the company plans to increase the proportion of R&D workers and engineers to secure competitiveness. Applications for voluntary redundancy will be accepted in October.

site_title: HDB households to get GST vouchers of up to S$95 for October utilities
summary: About 900,000 Singaporean HDB households will receive Utilities-Save (U-Save) rebate vouchers of up to S$95 in October to offset utilities expenses. The rebate, part of the permanent GST voucher scheme, helps families reduce expenses by offsetting part of their utilities bills. The amount received depends on the HDB flat type, with one- and two-room flats receiving the highest rebate of S$95 and executive or multi-generation flats receiving the lowest of S$55. The rebate is distributed every three months and costs the Government around S$280 million annually.

site_title: "We'll know in 48 hours": Mexico sees new hope of trilateral Nafta
summary: Mexico has expressed new hope of saving the North American Free Trade Agreement (Nafta) as a trilateral pact between the US, Mexico, and Canada, after the Trump administration and Canada made "serious efforts" to resolve trade policy differences. Mexico and Washington have halted the publication of their own two-way trade deal, giving Canada more time to join. The Nafta text is due by Sunday night, but multiple deadlines have already been broken during the renegotiation process. Mexican President-elect Andres Manuel Lopez Obrador said he would keep pushing for all three countries to be part of Nafta, while Canadian officials reiterated that they would not bow to US pressure to sign a quick deal.

site_title: Chief Justice calls for Asian insolvency laws to keep pace with region's growth
summary: Chief Justice Sundaresh Menon of Singapore emphasized the need for Asian insolvency laws to keep pace with the region's growth. He noted that Asia's insolvency laws have not developed at the same pace as the region's growth, leading to inadequate restructuring efforts during the 1997-1998 Asian financial crisis. Menon called for more progress to secure an insolvency and restructuring regime equal to the task, citing the anticipated flow of investment in Asia and the need for modern insolvency laws to address default risk.

site_title: GM will recall more than 3.3m vehicles in China: market regulator
summary: General Motors will recall over 3.3 million vehicles in China due to a suspension system defect. The recall affects cars produced between 2013 and 2018, including Buick, Chevrolet, and Cadillac models. GM will contact affected owners and repair the vehicles free of charge. The recall is expected to begin on October 20.

site_title: Trump orders Kavanaugh FBI probe after Senate delays confirmation vote
summary: US President Donald Trump ordered an FBI investigation into sexual assault allegations against Supreme Court nominee Brett Kavanaugh, following a request by Senate Republicans. The probe, which must be completed in less than a week, will focus on current credible allegations, including claims by Christine Blasey Ford and two other women. The move comes after a raucous Senate hearing where Kavanaugh forcefully denied the allegations. The FBI investigation may take less than a week to complete, depending on the scope of the inquiry.

site_title: May backs joint UK-Ireland World Cup bid in 2030
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May has expressed full support for a potential joint UK-Ireland bid to host the 2030 FIFA World Cup. This move challenges a Latin American bid led by Argentina. The joint bid would not require significant infrastructure investments, as seen in the record-breaking costs of the 2018 Russia World Cup, which reached $13.5 billion. May's support is seen as a challenge to the US-led bid for the 2026 tournament.

site_title: Powerful typhoon batters Okinawa, churns to Japan mainland
summary: A powerful typhoon, Typhoon Trami, battered Japan's southern island of Okinawa, causing at least 5 injuries and widespread damage. The storm, packing 216 km/h gusts, is forecast to hit the mainland early Sunday, potentially causing extreme weather across Japan. Over 121,000 homes lost electricity, and 386 flights were cancelled. The typhoon is the latest in a series of extreme natural events to strike Japan, following deadly record rains and a magnitude 6.6 earthquake earlier this year.

site_title: No cutoff date for Canada to join Nafta 2.0: Mexico president-elect
summary: Mexico's president-elect Andres Manuel Lopez Obrador says there's no cutoff date for Canada to join the US-Mexican Nafta 2.0 deal. The final text of the deal is set to be submitted to legislators, but talks with Canada are stalled due to issues like the Canadian dairy industry and trade dispute provisions. Lopez Obrador has expressed his preference for a trilateral deal, but considers the US-Mexican agreement's substance to be final. Canada's Prime Minister Justin Trudeau described negotiations as "difficult" and hinted at a counter-proposal from the US.

site_title: The best in-flight Wi-Fi - if you're lucky
summary: Airlines are investing in next-generation Wi-Fi systems, leading to improved in-flight connectivity. Traveloka ranked 50 international carriers based on Wi-Fi availability, speed, and cost, with Qatar, Emirates, and Delta topping the list. However, the survey's methodology only considered top-ranked carriers by SkyTrax, omitting tech-friendly airlines like United. New satellite launches and technological enhancements are expected to increase speeds and coverage, making reliable Wi-Fi a global perk, rather than a US-only domain.

images.alt_text: According to Traveloka findings, the top three airlines to prioritise for in-flight efficiency are Qatar, Emirates, and Delta, in descending order. But take that with a grain of salt, though. If reliable (or reliable-ish) Wi-Fi was previously the domain of US airlines, it's now becoming a global perk.

site_title: No Nobel Literature Prize as Academy's bell tolls
summary: The Swedish Academy has postponed the 2018 Nobel Literature Prize due to the #MeToo scandal surrounding Frenchman Jean-Claude Arnault, who was accused of rape and had conflicts of interest with the institution. The Academy, which has been deeply divided, has been left without a quorum, and its members have exchanged jibes in the media. The 2018 laureate will be announced alongside the 2019 prize, which has sparked criticism and concern about the institution's ability to reform and regain public trust.

site_title: Facebook discloses security breach affecting 50 million users
summary: Facebook disclosed a security breach affecting 50 million users, with hackers gaining digital login codes to access up to 50 million accounts. The breach, discovered in September, was caused by a complex flaw that existed since 2017 and was triggered by the "view as" feature. Facebook has reset digital keys and temporarily disabled "view as" for 40 million users, with 90 million people needing to log back into their accounts. The company has notified authorities and is under pressure to clarify the breach and risk to users, with lawmakers calling for data privacy legislation.

site_title: Rescuers scramble to reach tsunami-hit Indonesian city
summary: A 7.5 magnitude earthquake struck central Indonesia on Saturday, triggering a tsunami that hit the city of Palu on Sulawesi island, causing widespread destruction and panic. The quake, which was more powerful than previous quakes on Lombok, resulted in no immediate reports of deaths or injuries, but buildings collapsed and people fled their homes. Rescue teams have been dispatched to affected areas, and the main airport in Palu was shut due to damage. The disaster-prone nation of Indonesia, located on the Pacific "Ring of Fire", is no stranger to devastating quakes and tsunamis.

site_title: Brent hits 4-year high as US sanctions on Iran tighten supply
summary: US sanctions on Iran have led to a tightening of supply, causing oil prices to rise over 1% and reach a four-year high for Brent crude at $82.72 a barrel. US West Texas Intermediate crude futures also rose, settling at $73.25 a barrel. Analysts predict a potential supply shock due to declining oil production in Iran and Venezuela, supporting bullish sentiment on oil prices. Hedge funds have raised their combined futures and options position, while China's Sinopec Corp is halving loadings of crude oil from Iran.

site_title: STI rebounds 1.8%, Vividthree debuts and buybacks tally declines
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) rebounded 1.8% over the five trading sessions ended Sep 27, with the Nikkei 225, Hang Seng, and S&P/ASX 200 Indices averaging a 0.3% gain. The STI declined 1.7% in total return for the 2018 year to Sep 27. Notable transactions included Vividthree Holdings' debut on Catalist with a 49.15% ownership by mm2 Asia, and share buybacks totaling S$6.7 million led by Oversea-Chinese Banking Corporation, Silverlake Axis, and City Developments. Director and substantial shareholder transactions included Han Seng Juan's increase in Centurion Corporation's stake to 56.896%, and Mohamed Ismail Gafoor's increase in PropNex's stake to 63.58%.

site_title: Fed's 'neutral rate' guru downplays theory as rates rise
summary: Federal Reserve President John Williams downplays the concept of a "neutral" interest rate, which has guided monetary policy decisions. As interest rates continue to rise, Williams suggests shifting focus away from normalizing policy relative to this benchmark. He believes gradual interest rate hikes will support the economy, which is experiencing a "very strong" outlook, through at least next year. This stance echoes recent comments by Fed Chair Jerome Powell, who has also downplayed the relevance of monetary models. Williams' remarks imply a more flexible approach to interest rate policy.

site_title: Chefs in New York whip up support for ending food waste
summary: Celebrity chefs in New York demonstrated the impact of reducing food waste with a cooking challenge, showcasing recipes like potatoes au gratin and highlighting the issue's global significance. According to the United Nations, one-third of produced food is discarded annually, equivalent to nearly $1 trillion, and could feed 815 million people. Chefs, including Sam Kass and Eric Ripert, partnered with food giants and restaurants to promote sustainable cuisine and encourage policy-makers to adopt measures to halve global food waste by 2030.

site_title: WAGC 2018
summary: Over 60 amateur golfers from Singapore will compete in the World Amateur Golfers' Championship next weekend, with the top finishers representing the country at the finals. The event, held in 2018, aims to crown the best amateur golfer in the region.

site_title: Dim prospects for Macau ahead of China's Golden Week
summary: Macau's casinos face dim prospects ahead of China's Golden Week holiday due to a weakening yuan, economic slowdown, and trade tensions. About 40% of rooms in 3-to-5-star hotels are fully booked, compared to 80% last year. Analysts have cut estimates for gaming revenue, with some forecasting a 5% growth in October, down from previous expectations. The Bloomberg Intelligence gauge of Macau casino stocks is down 35% since May, with hopes for a positive surprise if actual results beat consensus.

site_title: Europe: Italian banks and stocks suffer worst day since Brexit vote after government budget deal
summary: Italian banks and stocks suffered their worst day since the Brexit vote, with the Italian FTSE MIB index falling 3.7% and euro zone banks index dropping 3.9%. The government's budget deal, which sets a higher-than-expected budget deficit target, led to selling pressure, with shares in Italian banks sinking 7.3% and government bonds selling off. Analysts warn that a potential downgrade of Italy's credit rating could pose risks to the sovereign investment grade and additional charges to CET1 ratios.

site_title: US: Facebook's slide stalls Intel-led advance on Wall Street
summary: US stocks ended flat on Friday, with the S&P 500 losing 0.5% for the week, despite gains from Intel, real estate companies, and utilities. Facebook's decline after a security breach affected 50 million accounts weighed heavily on the market. The tech sector rose 0.43%, with Intel's 3.08% jump driving the gains. The Dow Jones Industrial Average ended 0.07% higher, while the Nasdaq Composite added 0.05%. The S&P 500 is up 7.2% for the third quarter, its best quarterly performance since 2013.

site_title: US trade judge declines to block iPhone imports
summary: A US trade judge declined to block the importation of Apple iPhones with Intel chips, handing a defeat to Qualcomm in its patent dispute. The judge found Apple infringed on one Qualcomm patent but denied a ban, citing "public interest factors." Apple accused Qualcomm of unfair patent licensing practices, while Qualcomm claimed Apple infringed on its technology. The decision will be reviewed by other judges, with another patent case pending against Apple.

site_title: Are humans ready for longer lives?
summary: A panel discussion at the Singapore Week of Innovation and Technology explored the potential of innovative technologies to extend human lifespan. Experts discussed various advancements, including antioxidant-rich foods, cryogenics, and improved medical technologies. They also debated whether humans are ready for immortality, with some predicting a potential increase in population and others warning of environmental damage. The panelists emphasized the need for accelerated development of technologies to improve human life and achieve the United Nations' Sustainable Development Goal 3 (SDG3) targets by 2030.

site_title: 2.8m Singaporeans to get SG Bonus totalling S$700m by December
summary: Singaporeans aged 21 and above will receive a one-off SG Bonus of up to S$300 by December, totaling S$700 million. The bonus is part of the government's budget surplus, which is expected to be S$9.6 billion. Eligible citizens can use their SingPass to view their payout online and receive SMS notifications. The bonus will be given on top of the Goods and Services Tax voucher scheme and Service and Conservancy Charges rebate.

site_title: US pull diplomats from Iraqi city, citing threats from Iran
summary: The US has announced it will effectively close its consulate in Basra, Iraq, and relocate diplomatic personnel due to increasing threats from Iran and Iran-backed militia. The decision follows recent rocket attacks on the consulate, with US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo warning that the US will respond promptly and appropriately to any future attacks. Pompeo also reiterated that the US will hold Iran directly responsible for attacks on Americans and US facilities in Iraq. The move adds to mounting tension between the US and Iran, with the US imposing economic sanctions on Iran.

site_title: Tried & tested
summary: Titleist introduces its TS range, a late entry into the metal woods market, but may be the last to laugh. The TS range is available just as the golf world has seen a significant release of metal woods.

site_title: Sweet on agility
summary: Mars Inc, the world's largest confectionery company, is taking a principles-based approach to business, prioritizing quality, responsibility, mutuality, efficiency, and freedom. Under the leadership of regional president Ehab Abou-Oaf, the company is empowering employees and focusing on local consumer needs. Mars Inc has a decentralized approach, allowing associates to make decisions and act with full responsibility. The company is also committed to sustainability, investing in cocoa research and supporting farmers in West Africa, South-east Asia, and the Americas. Abou-Oaf believes in transparency and consumer choice, rather than relying on taxes to curb sugar consumption. Mars Inc has pledged $1 billion over five years to support cocoa sustainability and has made significant investments in manufacturing capabilities and R&D to create relevant products for diverse markets.

site_title: Twitter is on pace to be biggest loser in S&P 500 for third quarter
summary: Twitter Inc. has become the worst performer in the S&P 500 Index for the third quarter, with shares plummeting 35% in third-quarter trading. The decline was attributed to a disappointing earnings report, which revealed a 1 million drop in monthly users in the second quarter and predicted further declines due to spam, fake accounts, and malicious rhetoric. The stock's performance was also marred by concerns over expense reporting.

site_title: Industrial sites find favour in auction market
summary: Investors in Singapore have shifted their focus to industrial sites after the cooling measures for the private housing segment in July. In the third quarter, nine properties were sold at a total value of S$10.44 million, with four industrial sites fetching S$2.67 million and five residential units selling for S$7.78 million. Experts believe the industrial and office property market remains optimistic due to strong performance in manufacturing and business services sectors. The number of industrial and commercial properties sold has increased since the cooling measures took effect, with more owner sales expected in the immediate term.

site_title: Hong Kong home prices fall for first time in 29 months
summary: Hong Kong private home prices fell 0.076% in August, marking the first decline in 29 months, according to government data. Despite a 11.7% surge this year, prices have softened due to rising interest rates and a US-China trade war affecting the city's economy. Ultra-low interest rates and limited housing supply previously drove prices up 165% over a decade, prompting warnings about an asset bubble. The latest UBS Global Real Estate Bubble Index ranks Hong Kong as the city with the greatest bubble risk.

site_title: Wong Kim Yin to helm SkillsFuture Singapore
summary: SkillsFuture Singapore (SSG) appoints Mr Wong Kim Yin as its new chairman, effective October 1, replacing Tan Pheng Hock. Meanwhile, six other HDB board members were also re-appointed. No other significant global news were reported in this article.

site_title: Singtel to carry all of Discovery's channels in Singapore from Friday
summary: Singtel has agreed to carry all Discovery channels in Singapore, starting from Friday, after telco rival StarHub dropped the channels due to a price dispute. The 10-channel suite will be available on Singtel TV, including HGTV, Asian Food Channel, and Food Network. This comes after StarHub shed its Discovery channels in June. Singtel's move is seen as a boost to the telco, with shares rising 3 cents to close at S$3.24.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Nam Cheong, a Singaporean shipbuilder, has completed a debt revamp by converting 35% of its unsecured debt into equity and issuing new shares. The move raised S$22 million in net proceeds. Meanwhile, Thomson Medical Group has sold its hospitality unit Ariva to Gordon Tang's private vehicle for S$3.38 million. Sembcorp Industries faces a potential fine of up to S$100 million for an alleged environmental offense at one of its overseas joint ventures.

site_title: Reits
summary: Realty investment trusts (REITs) are experiencing fluctuations in the market, with US mortgage rates climbing after five weeks of declines. The Q3 wave of condo launches in Singapore is expected to test demand for prime projects above the S$3,000 psf benchmark. Manhattan rents reached a record high, with more increases anticipated. In the UK, homebuyer demand rebounded to a six-month high, while New World is selling China property assets after a loan deal. WeWork secured new tenants and filled more space at 21 Collyer Quay after its bankruptcy.

site_title: Fintech is growing, and continues to evolve
summary: Fintech has experienced unprecedented growth since 2010, with global investments increasing 800% to a peak of US$26 billion in 2015. The industry is evolving through four stages: Naysayers, Charlatans, Early Adopters, and Believers. In the banking industry, technology giants are encroaching on financial services, and banks are adopting fintech technologies. However, the investment management industry has yet to grasp the impact of fintech, with most asset managers still in the Naysayer or Charlatan stages. Fintech requires knowledge of programming and advanced econometrics, and banks and investment managers must adapt to these processes.

site_title: Completed condominium prices rise 0.5% in August
summary: Completed condominium prices in Singapore rose 0.5% in August, reversing a July decline. This marks the first month-on-month increase since January. The non-central region saw a 4.7% increase, while the central region rose 8.7% year-on-year. Overall, prices have risen 7.8% year-on-year, with a 4.4% increase so far this year.

site_title: More consumer protection for third-party e-payment errors
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore has revised its guidelines for consumer protection in case of third-party e-payment errors. Under the revised guidelines, consumers will be assured of getting up to S$1,000 back if the errors are caused by the financial institution or third parties, such as retailers. The initial proposal to cap liability at S$100 has been scrapped due to concerns from financial institutions about the burden of proving recklessness. The revised guidelines will take effect from January 31, 2019, and do not apply to scams or unauthorised payments made on credit cards.

site_title: Revamped Funan mall to open by June 2019, months ahead of schedule
summary: Singapore's revamped Funan mall and office complex is set to open in June 2019, months ahead of schedule. The new mall will feature facial recognition technology to offer personalized recommendations to shoppers, as well as a smart directory and video analytics to study shopper traffic. CapitaLand, the mall's owner, aims to create a "online and offline mall" experience, with plans to expand the technology to other malls and integrate it with the CapitaStar loyalty program.

images.alt_text: The new six-storey Funan mall will utilise video analytics to study shopper traffic and crowd density, which will help CapitaLand to adjust tenant mix and placement.

site_title: What are China's growth prospects in an all-out trade war?
summary: China's growth prospects in a full-scale trade war with the US are uncertain, but estimated to be manageable. A 25% tariff on all Chinese exports to the US could lead to a 17.5% decline in US imports, resulting in a $46.7 billion drop in exports, equivalent to 0.4% of China's GDP. However, China can offset this impact by expanding exports to other markets, such as the Belt and Road Initiative (BRI) countries. The estimated ultimate impact on China's growth could be between 1 and 1.5% of GDP per year. Despite the limited direct impact, the market's bearish sentiment on China is driven by concerns about escalating trade tensions and the US's intention to contain China's economic ascent.

site_title: In a quieter property market, small is no longer beautiful
summary: Singapore's property market is experiencing consolidation as smaller agencies, such as ERA Realty, strike deals with larger players like CBRE Realty Associates and HSR International Realtors. ERA's collaborations aim to boost its scale, speed, and scope of business operations, while also sharing costs with its new partners. Industry experts say the weaker market outlook following cooling measures has catalyzed these collaborations, which may lead to more consolidation in the market.

site_title: Proposed Amos merger will make us stronger together: Gaylin
summary: Gaylin Holdings proposes to acquire Amos International Holdings, aiming to strengthen the combined entity. The acquisition is expected to significantly boost Gaylin's equity, asset value, and revenue. If approved by shareholders on Oct 3, the deal will make Gaylin a wholly-owned subsidiary of Amos. The merger is seen as a strategic move to capitalize on rising market optimism.

images.alt_text: Amos founder and MD Danny Lien says there is "very little overlap" in the customer bases of Amos and Gaylin.

site_title: Crossbridge Capital eyes doubling of assets
summary: Crossbridge Capital, an external asset manager, aims to double its assets under management from US$4.5 billion to US$10 billion over the next five years. The firm plans to achieve scale through acquisitions, new markets, and investments in its digital business, Connect. Crossbridge has applied for a licence to operate in Hong Kong, which will give it a "North Asia focus". The firm has already identified a team of nine to work on the licence and has offices in London, Singapore, Monaco, and Malta. Its digital business, Connect, provides a hybrid model combining robo portfolios with human advice, and has combined assets under management of about US$300 million.

site_title: Bank lending recovers to post gains in August
summary: Bank lending in Singapore increased 0.4% in August to S$670 billion, reversing the 0.9% decline in July. Business lending rebounded, rising 0.6% to S$405 billion, driven by a 2.5% increase in lending to the building and construction segment.
