Consumer lending remained flat at S$265 billion, while lending to financial institutions declined 1.7%. Year-over-year, bank lending rose 5.6%, stronger than the 5.5% increase in July.

site_title: Singapore market cap up slightly in September
summary: The Singapore stock market saw a slight increase in September, with the Straits Times Index (STI) rising 3.6% and the market capitalization of the 736 companies on the Singapore Exchange reaching S$931.9 billion, down 4.8% from a year ago. The finance sector had the highest market capitalization at S$268.1 billion, followed by the multi-industry sector, which rose 4.5% in September. Major gainers included DBS Bank, Thai Beverage, and Keppel Corporation, while losers included Hongkong Land, Dairy Farm, and Golden-Agri Resources.

site_title: Good eating habits and the role of probiotics
summary: A diet rich in nutrients and probiotics can maintain a diverse gut microbiome, supporting digestive and metabolic health. Probiotics, containing beneficial bacteria, can aid digestion, nutrient absorption, and immune function. However, their effectiveness is not yet conclusive for healthy individuals, and more research is needed. Probiotics are most beneficial for individuals with digestive diseases, such as irritable bowel syndrome, and should be chosen based on specific strains and strains' efficacy in clinical trials. Proper selection and dosage are crucial, with some products requiring high CFU counts to survive the stomach's acidic environment.

site_title: Proelect show professionalism in victory
summary: Proelect, a new team in The Business Times Corporate Golf League, demonstrated professionalism in their victory, raising the league's profile. No specific details on the match are provided.

site_title: M&C group CEO leaves post just three months into the job
summary: M&C group CEO Jennifer Fox has left her post just three months into the job, citing a mutually agreed-upon exit with the board of directors. Fox, who joined in June, had been reviewing the company's earnings profile and working on a strategic plan to address slipping room revenues. Her departure follows a shareholder tussle prior to her appointment, which was also linked to the family's Hong Leong Group conglomerate. Group chief of staff Tan Kian Seng has taken over as interim CEO.

site_title: M1 soars above S$2.06 offer; key investor keeps options open
summary: M1's shares surged 29.4% to S$2.11 after Keppel Corp and Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) unveiled a S$2.06 offer to acquire the telco. The offer sparked speculation that Axiata Group, M1's largest shareholder, may hold out for a better deal. Analysts believe Axiata may be waiting for a more compelling offer, potentially from Keppel Corp or other parties. The joint offerors' shares also saw significant movement, with SPH ending higher and Keppel Corp slipping.

site_title: Against Liverpool, Chelsea face acid test of EPL hopes
summary: Chelsea, led by coach Maurizio Sarri and star player Eden Hazard, face an acid test of their EPL hopes against Liverpool. The Blues boast an unbeaten start to the season, despite a chaotic summer that saw goalkeeper Thibaut Courtois leave for Real Madrid and Hazard express interest in a move to the Spanish giants. Chelsea's performance against Liverpool on Saturday will be crucial in determining their title aspirations.

site_title: When even mistakes are great lessons
summary: Businesses can increase innovation by prioritizing a culture of curiosity and inquiry. Leaders should surround themselves with innovative people, foster a culture of questioning, and encourage employees to ask "What next?" and explore relationships. To build this culture, leaders should ask questions like "What, Why, How, When" and create a strategy for the business that allows for ideas to flourish without fear of failure or judgment. Embracing risk and calculating its potential benefits can also drive innovation, and tracking innovativeness in the workplace can be achieved by staying informed about industry developments, gathering top talent, and providing a platform for brainstorming and idea-sharing.

site_title: Ford-Kavanaugh saga a reflection of social, political schisms in the US
summary: A dramatic Senate Judiciary Committee hearing has highlighted the deep divisions in US society, pitting two 100% realities against each other. Christine Blasey Ford's testimony of being sexually assaulted by Judge Brett Kavanaugh in 1982 contrasted with his account of the incident, leaving senators and the public torn. The hearing has reinforced the country's tribal divisions, with Democrats supporting Ford and Republicans backing Kavanaugh. The outcome will be decided by the Senate, with many senators still undecided, and the court of public opinion weighing in.

site_title: A bullish case suddenly builds for unloved European assets
summary: European equities, laggards in this year's global stock rally, are showing signs of emerging from the shadows of Italian political risk and trade wars. Despite being the cheapest in seven years, European stocks are climbing alongside the euro's strengthening, with credit spreads tightening and the yield gap between Germany and the region's periphery narrowing. Investors are betting on the European Central Bank (ECB) to hike rates in October 2019, while the Federal Reserve is expected to pause its tightening path. This shift in sentiment is expected to benefit European stock funds, which have been hit by redemptions for 27 of the past 28 weeks.

site_title: Boris Johnson demands PM May scrap her Brexit proposals
summary: Boris Johnson has called on Prime Minister Theresa May to scrap her Brexit proposals, citing concerns that her plans would leave the UK "half in and half out" of the EU and amount to "enforced vassalage". Johnson, a Brexit campaigner, has gained support from other rebels, including Jacob Rees-Mogg, who is pushing for a deeper break with the EU. The UK is set to leave the EU on March 29, 2019, with little clarity on the terms of the exit.

site_title: China Fibretech resumes trading as Raffles Infrastructure
summary: China Fibretech has resumed trading on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) under its new name, Raffles Infrastructure Holdings. The company, which was suspended from trading due to financial irregularities, closed at 47 Singapore cents apiece, down 7.84% from its previous close. Raffles Infrastructure has received fresh funding and will use S$22 million for invested projects and S$7.9 million for working capital. The company's board has implemented new procedures to mitigate risks and is searching for a qualified chief financial officer.

site_title: Elon Musk's tweeting may cost Tesla investors close to US$20 billion
summary: Elon Musk's tweets about securing funding for Tesla's potential takeover may cost investors nearly $20 billion. The Securities and Exchange Commission alleged Musk committed fraud by tweeting about the funding. Tesla's stock plummeted 14% in early trading, with a market capitalization of $45.7 billion, down from $64.8 billion. The SEC is seeking to bar Musk from serving as a public company officer or director.

site_title: FF believes that the game of golf has so many virtues
summary: FF, chairman and CEO of a company, praises golf for its virtues, despite the author's lack of information on what those virtues are. FF is described as a charming septuagenarian who has a big heart and can turn strangers into friends. However, no details about FF or his company are provided, making it unclear what his statement on golf is based on.

site_title: Real estate is next on tech's agenda
summary: Venture capitalists are pouring money into the real estate tech industry, known as proptech, with startups like Opendoor attracting significant investments. Opendoor, a four-year-old company, raised $400 million from SoftBank's Vision Fund, valuing the company at over $2 billion. The funding is part of a growing trend, with real estate tech startups raising $3.4 billion in funding last year, a fivefold increase from 2013. The Vision Fund's investment gives SoftBank a foothold in the residential housing market, and Opendoor plans to expand into 22 cities in the US by the end of the year.

site_title: The world's biggest real-estate bubbles
summary: UBS Group AG's 2018 report found that most cities in its Global Real Estate Bubble Index are overvalued or at risk of a bubble. Only Chicago is undervalued, while Milan, Singapore, and Boston are fairly valued. Ten cities, including New York and Sydney, are overvalued, and six, including Hong Kong, are in bubble-risk territory. A year ago, New York was considered fairly valued, highlighting a shift in market conditions.

site_title: New chiefs for Keppel Land, Keppel Reit Management from Jan 1
summary: Keppel Land and Keppel Reit Management have announced leadership changes effective January 1, 2024. Tan Swee Yiow, CEO of Keppel Reit Management, will become CEO of Keppel Land, while Paul Tham, deputy CEO of Keppel Reit Management, will assume Tan's role at Keppel Reit Management. Ang Sock Cheng will succeed Tham as CFO of Keppel Capital. The changes are seen as part of the companies' succession planning initiatives, with Loh Chin Hua and Penny Goh expressing confidence in the new leaders' ability to drive growth and sustainability.

site_title: HSBC says full service restored on mobile banking app
summary: HSBC's mobile banking app experienced a technical outage, temporarily disabling some customers' access to the service. The issue was identified at 6:40 AM GMT and resolved by 8:00 AM GMT. Normal service, including online banking, debit card use, and cash machine access, remained unaffected. HSBC apologized for the inconvenience and will investigate the cause of the issue.

site_title: Can stock research that's paid for by the company be trusted?
summary: Financial firms are offering sponsored analysis, paid for by the company being analyzed, to fill a void in the wake of the EU's Markets in Financial Instruments Directive. These reports are mostly upfront about the payment, but some may not contain price targets or ratings. Companies pay for coverage to salvage liquidity and add to the conversations about their stocks. Analysts and investors are concerned about the potential conflicts of interest, but firms argue their credibility is on the line and they are transparent about the payment. The practice is gaining traction, with firms like Kepler Cheuvreux and Edison Investment Research seeing revenue growth.

site_title: Burning rubber for a good cause
summary: The second President's Challenge Charity Sprint took place in Singapore, featuring a diverse range of modified and supercars competing in a one-on-one elimination drag racing event. The event, organized by Motor Sports Singapore, aimed to foster a cohesive and inclusive motorsports community, and saw 54 cars participate, including those from Malaysia. The event raised S$180,000 for the President's Challenge charity, supporting the less fortunate in building a more caring and inclusive society. The event's inclusive spirit and shared passion for motorsports were praised, with participants and spectators alike enjoying a convivial atmosphere.

site_title: Swiss to press on with EU treaty talks without new concessions
summary: The Swiss government has proposed continuing EU treaty talks without new concessions, aiming to protect high Swiss pay levels. Talks have stalled due to differences over rules protecting Swiss wages from cross-border competition. If negotiations fail, a patchwork of sectoral accords governing economic ties would remain in effect, but bilateral relations would freeze, preventing Swiss access to the single market and potential electricity union. The Swiss government will ask parliament to approve additional aid to EU member states despite key issues remaining unresolved.

site_title: 'WhatsApp rumour' wipes 70% off Indian firm's stock
summary: Indian e-commerce firm Infibeam Avenues saw its market value plummet 70% after a WhatsApp message circulated among traders raised concerns about its accounting practices ahead of a shareholders' meeting. The message, sent months ago, resurfaced on the messaging platform, sparking a major selloff. Despite the company's attempt to calm investors, the stock price continued to nosedive, closing down 70.24% at 58.80 rupees.

site_title: Ending the week on a high
summary: Asian markets ended the week on a positive note, with major indices such as Japan's Nikkei and Hong Kong shares rising due to a strong US economy and a weaker yen. Despite concerns about the US-China trade war, global markets appeared buoyed by sentiment about world equities and national economies. The Federal Reserve raised interest rates by 25 basis points, with one more expected in 2018 and three in 2019. The Singapore Stock Exchange (STI) closed strongly, with seven consecutive gains, and key companies such as OCBC Bank and DBS rose.

site_title: Cocoa set for turnaround as strong demand signals small shortage
summary: The global cocoa market is expected to experience a slight deficit of 50,000 metric tons in the upcoming season, according to a Bloomberg survey of traders and analysts. Strong demand is anticipated, with Ivory Coast and Ghana, the world's top producers, planning to announce farmer prices at the same time. The move aims to balance the market and provide relief to West African economies, which have been affected by falling prices and global surpluses.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's completed non-landed private homes saw a 0.5% month-on-month rise in August, reversing July's decline. Bank lending in Singapore also increased in August, inching back towards growth. Alliance Mineral secured a debt facility and standby credit for its ASX dual listing, while Raffles Infrastructure resumed trading after a merger. Thomson Medical sold a hospitality unit for S$3.38 million to focus on its healthcare business. The Straits Times Index rose 0.6% on the last trading day of September, closing at 3,257.05.

site_title: US: Wall St opens lower as Italy's budget, trade concerns weigh
summary: US stocks opened lower on the last trading day of the third quarter, weighed by bank stocks due to Italy's budget concerns and trade tensions. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.12%, the S&P 500 0.14%, and the Nasdaq Composite 0.22%. These declines came despite the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records earlier in the week. The market's concerns over Italy's budget and trade tensions with the US and EU continued to impact investor sentiment.

site_title: Six companies granted licences to operate bike-sharing services in Singapore
summary: Six companies, including Mobike, ofo, and SG Bike, have been granted licenses to operate dockless bike-sharing services in Singapore. Chinese firms Mobike and ofo will operate fleets of up to 25,000 bicycles, while SG Bike can have up to 3,000 two-wheelers. Other firms, such as Anywheel, GrabCycle, and Qiqi Zhixiang, have been granted a sandbox license with limited fleet sizes. The Land Transport Authority will monitor their performance before granting full licenses, aiming to reduce the number of unused bikes and promote responsible bike-sharing practices.

site_title: OCBC debt market efforts in China's Greater Bay area bearing fruit
summary: OCBC Bank has seen significant success in its capital market efforts in China's Greater Bay Area, with 10 international bond transactions worth US$8.4 billion this year, compared to one in 2017. The bank has helped Chinese developers tap the Singapore dollar bond market, including three Chinese developers tapping the market this year. OCBC's efforts in the GBA region, which aims to rival Tokyo and New York by 2030, have been driven by the bank's geographic reach and on-the-ground presence. The bank's green bond efforts, including a recent deal with China General Nuclear Power Corporation, also reflect its commitment to sustainable development.

site_title: Recent discover golf carnival should boost golf playing numbers
summary: The Singapore Golf Association's recent discover golf carnival is expected to boost golf playing numbers, addressing the sport's declining popularity. Golf faces challenges from the closure of golf clubs and a lack of interest among younger generations. The SGA's forward-thinking plans aim to revitalize the game, making it more accessible and appealing to a new audience. This move is seen as a positive step towards saving golf in Singapore.

site_title: German unemployment rate falls to record low in September
summary: Germany's unemployment rate fell to a record low of 5.1% in September, dropping 23,000 to 2.303 million, according to the Federal Labour Office. This is the lowest level since German reunification in 1990. The strong labour market, driven by record-high employment and above-inflation pay hikes, has become a key driver of consumer spending and economic growth.

site_title: Time to close Asia's sustainable investment gaps
summary: Asia's sustainable investment gap needs to be closed to tackle the continent's sustainability issues. Despite progress in the past half century, Asia still faces significant challenges such as air pollution and poor working conditions. Investors, particularly in Asia, are increasingly interested in sustainable investing, with 60% of Chinese millionaires and 85% of Hong Kong and Singapore millionaires expressing interest. However, barriers to growth remain, including lack of transparency and verification of social and environmental impact. Establishing common standards and definitions, offering diversified products, and engaging investors are key to unlocking the capital needed to address these challenges.

images.alt_text: Wealth management advice can help investors cut through terminology, separate products which deliver transparent impact from those that do not, find investments that are both profitable and aligned with their values . . .

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Keppel Corporation and Singapore Press Holdings have announced a pre-conditional voluntary general offer for M1 Ltd at a cash offer of S$2.06 per share. The offeror's effective stakes in M1 could range between 32.54-83.87% and 13.45-16.13% respectively. Analysts consider the offer price as a 24.8-26.3% premium to the fair value estimate of S$1.65 and last closing price of S$1.63. However, the possibility of Axiata Group mounting its own offer or the offeror raising the price cannot be ruled out.

site_title: Europe to tell G20 rising trade tensions can seriously hit global growth
summary: European Union finance ministers will urge G20 leaders to reject protectionism and commit to solving trade disputes through the World Trade Organization (WTO) during a meeting in Bali next month. The US and China have imposed fresh tariffs on each other's goods, sparking rising trade tensions that could have a "serious adverse" impact on global growth. The EU is concerned about escalating tensions and calls for a level playing field for trade, investment, and intellectual property rights.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks finish with gains
summary: Hong Kong shares finished the week with gains, mirroring an Asia-wide rally led by US stocks. The Hang Seng Index rose 0.26%, closing at 27,788.52, while the Shanghai Composite Index jumped 1.06% and the Shenzhen Composite Index added 0.83%. The gains were partly offset by a rise in Hong Kong interest rates affecting property firms.

site_title: Boldtek mullling over adoption of share incentive scheme, share buyback mandate
summary: Boldtek is considering the adoption of a share incentive scheme and share buyback mandate, in response to unusual price movements in its shares. The company's share price has been sliding, from 19 cents to 11.9 cents, since September 24. A circular will be dispatched to shareholders if the directors decide to proceed with the proposals. Additionally, the accounts executive of its subsidiary, Logistics Construction, Yeo Goek Ngo, will retire on December 31.

site_title: Novo Nordisk to cut 250 jobs in the United States
summary: Novo Nordisk, the world's top diabetes drug maker, plans to cut 250 jobs in the US due to pricing pressures and slow growth. The company, which employs over 42,000 globally, will also hire new staff in other positions. This move follows recent job cuts in Denmark and China, and a 1-2% sales decline forecast for 2019 due to US legislation aimed at reducing high drug prices.

images.alt_text: Denmark's Novo Nordisk,the world's top maker of diabetes drugs, will cut around 250 jobs in the United States, a spokesman said on Friday.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks fall; won extends gain
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index fell 0.52% to 2,343.07 on Friday, led by a decline in semiconductor producers like Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix. The won rose, extending its sixth consecutive gain, while bond yields fell. Foreigners sold 211.8 billion won worth of shares, contributing to the market's decline.

site_title: Nam Cheong completes debt revamp
summary: Shipbuilder Nam Cheong completes debt revamp through schemes of arrangement, converting 35% of unsecured debt into equity and issuing new shares. The conversion rate was 30 shares for every US$1 of non-sustainable debt, and the one-for-one rights issue was priced at S$0.014. The new shares were listed on Friday, causing Nam Cheong shares to fall 13.33% to close at S$0.013.

site_title: Hong Kong marks fourth anniversary of Umbrella Movement
summary: Hundreds gathered in Hong Kong to mark the fourth anniversary of the Umbrella Movement, a pro-democracy protest that failed to win political reform. The event comes amid concerns that freedoms are disappearing under Beijing's assertiveness, with the government banning a party promoting independence and critics warning of an assault on the city's freedoms. Pro-democracy campaigner Joshua Wong attended, saying he will continue to push for Hong Kong's freedoms despite waning public momentum, and has launched a new think tank to appeal for international help.

site_title: Foxconn ex-manager jailed for stealing 2,000 iPhones
summary: A former Foxconn manager, Tsai Yi-wei, has been jailed for two years and four months for stealing and selling 2,000 iPhones worth around Tw$8.46 million. He instructed eight employees to smuggle out iPhone test models between 2013 and 2014, selling them to stores in Shenzhen. The case highlights Foxconn's internal issues, following recent scandals including employee misconduct and labor disputes.

images.alt_text: Foxconn, also known as Hon Hai, is the world's largest contract electronics maker and assembles products for international brands such as Apple and Sony.

site_title: Boris Johnson sets out 'Super Canada' Brexit blueprint
summary: British former foreign secretary Boris Johnson unveiled a six-point plan for Brexit, dubbed "Super Canada," calling for a free trade agreement with the EU. The plan would scrap the backstop agreement over the Irish border, adopting technology and customs checks to prevent a hard border. Johnson's proposal would also include mutual recognition of standards for goods and services. The plan aims to change the course of Brexit negotiations and secure a better deal for the UK. Johnson's intervention increases pressure on Prime Minister Theresa May, who has proposed a Chequers plan.

site_title: Thailand taps equity market for US$1.4b infrastructure fund
summary: Thailand's $1.4 billion Thailand Future Fund will open its books to investors on October 12, ahead of its expected public listing. The fund aims to invest in long-term infrastructure projects, including expressways, railways, and airports. Retail investors are expected to account for about half of the investment. The shares are priced at 10 baht, with an expected raise of $1.68 billion to $1.97 billion. The funds will be used to build two expressways, reducing the government's reliance on debt for infrastructure projects.

site_title: Sembcorp Industries' joint venture facing claims for alleged environmental offence
summary: Sembcorp Industries' joint venture has been served with a claim for an alleged environmental offence, with the group's proportionate share of potential fines and claims estimated at up to S$100 million. The joint venture has been seeking legal advice and will defend itself against the claims. Sembcorp has previously provided S$25.4 million in FY17 financial statements related to the alleged discharge of off-specification wastewater. The group is committed to responsible operations and compliance with all legal and regulatory requirements.

site_title: Europe: Italian banks lead shares lower after govt budget deal
summary: Italian banks led European shares lower after the Italian government agreed to set a higher than expected budget deficit target, potentially straining relations with Brussels. Shares in Italian banks fell 5% while government bonds sold off, with the STOXX 600 index down 0.3% and Italy's FTSE MIB index falling 1.9%. The agreement marked a victory for party chiefs over economy minister Giovanni Tria, defying Brussels' expectations.

site_title: Malaysia shares close lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed 5.49 points lower at 1,793.15 on Friday, with a trading volume of 21 million lots worth RM2.6 billion. Gainers outnumbered losers 434 to 395.

site_title: US consumer spending increases steadily in August
summary: US consumer spending increased 0.3% in August, driven by healthcare outlays, matching economists' expectations. Adjusted for inflation, spending rose 0.2%. The personal consumption expenditures (PCE) price index, the Fed's preferred inflation measure, remained at 2% for a fourth straight month. The economy's 4.2% growth in the second quarter was fueled by robust consumer spending. Despite a widening goods trade deficit, economists expect GDP to grow at a 2.8% annualized rate in the third quarter. The Fed's interest rate hike aims to keep inflation at the 2% target.

site_title: Singapore shares close up on Friday
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.6% on Friday, with the Straits Times Index reaching 3,257.05, as 1.70 billion shares changed hands for S$1.36 billion. Gainers outnumbered losers 237 to 149, driven by gains from Golden Agri-Resources and M1, while DBS and OCBC Bank also rose. The rally follows a 5-day streak ahead of GDP data release.

site_title: Keppel Land to raise shareholding in Nam Long Investment Corporation
summary: Keppel Land has agreed to divest 51% of its Vietnamese dong bonds in Nam Long Investment Corporation, creating space for bond conversion into shares. This move will allow Keppel Land to become the second-largest shareholder of NLG, doubling its stake to 10%. The partial divestment and bond conversion will result in a gain of about S$17.5 million for Keppel Land. Additionally, Keppel Land will divest 70% of its Dong Nai Waterfront City interest to NLG for a total consideration of 2,683 billion dong, maintaining a 30% interest in the project.

site_title: Tokyo's Nikkei index surges to eight-month high
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei index surged to an eight-month high, rising 1.36% or 323.30 points to 24,120.04, driven by a weak yen. The Topix index also climbed 0.95% to 1,817.25. Concerns over US trade pressure on Japan receded, allowing the market to rally. This marks a fresh 27-year high for the Nikkei index.

site_title: China Fibretech resumes trading as Raffles Infrastructure at 50 S cents apiece
summary: China Fibretech, formerly known as Raffles Infrastructure, has resumed trading on the Singapore Exchange with shares trading at 50 Singapore cents apiece. The company, which was listed in 2008, had its trading suspended in 2015 after 90% of its market value was wiped out. A recent share placement and new shareholders have provided sufficient working capital for the next 12 months. The company has also stated it will operate as a going concern and has implemented new procedures to mitigate financial and operational risks.

site_title: M&C Hotels CEO Jennifer Fox to step down
summary: Millennium & Copthorne Hotels CEO Jennifer Fox will step down as CEO, effective immediately, after just five months in the role. Tan Kian Seng, the company's group chief of staff, will serve as interim CEO. Fox's departure comes at a time when the company is facing external challenges, including the ongoing impact of the COVID-19 pandemic and rising global competition.

site_title: Singapore Power CEO Wong Kim Yin to head SkillsFuture Singapore from Oct 1
summary: Singapore Power CEO Wong Kim Yin will become the chairman of SkillsFuture Singapore on October 1, replacing Tan Pheng Hock. Wong, who is also group CEO of Singapore Power, has served as chairman of various companies and is a director of several others. He succeeds Tan, who led SSG since 2016 and oversaw major initiatives such as SkillsFuture Credit and MySkillsFuture. Four new board members were also appointed, while three board members are retiring. The changes bring the total number of board members to 15.

site_title: Australia shares rise as banks brush aside scathing inquiry report; NZ also up
summary: Australian shares rose 0.4% or 26.4 points to a three-week high on Friday, driven by gains in banks that brushed off a scathing inquiry report into the country's financial industry. The report found Australia's big banks prioritized profits over compliance, but did not include proposals for specific legislative reforms. The benchmark S&P/ASX 200 index also rose 0.2% for the quarter, while New Zealand's benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index rose 0.7% or 64.66 points.

site_title: Singapore bank lending in August inches back to growth
summary: Singapore bank lending grew 0.4% in August, reversing a 0.9% decline in July, with business lending increasing 0.6% to S$405 billion. Consumer lending remained flat at S$265 billion. This marks a 5.6% year-on-year increase, stronger than July's 5.5%. The growth reverses July's decline, indicating a return to growth in the banking sector.

site_title: Market Capitalisation
summary: NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was oversubscribed 9.8 times. US stocks opened lower amid a fresh tariff salvo by President Trump on Canada. Creative Technology warned its H2 revenue may be below target, with an operating loss similar to H1. London's Heathrow is considering higher fees for a £10b upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case. OCBC's incoming CEO, Tan Teck Long, is a former DBS veteran. The Monetary Authority of Singapore and PBOC plan to deepen cooperation in green and transition finance.

site_title: Asia: Markets rally with Wall St on growth optimism
summary: Asian markets rallied on Friday, following a Wall Street rally, as investors remained optimistic about the global economy and US interest rate hikes. The Federal Reserve's positive outlook on the US economy lifted stocks, with Tokyo leading the way, followed by Hong Kong, Shanghai, and Sydney. Emerging markets also gained, with the South Korean won and Indonesian rupiah rising. Crude prices extended gains due to concerns over supply, potentially reaching $100.

site_title: Australia central bank seen raising rates late next year: poll
summary: Australia's central bank, the Reserve Bank of Australia, is expected to maintain its record 10-year steady interest rate policy into 2019, according to a Reuters poll of 53 economists. The bank has not raised rates since 2010, with 52 economists forecasting no change at its Oct 2 meeting and one predicting a rate cut. A 25-basis-point hike is not expected until end-2019, with some economists predicting a steady outlook for 2020.

site_title: World's first human case of rat disease found in Hong Kong
summary: A 56-year-old Hong Kong man has become the world's first human case of rat hepatitis E virus, a liver disease previously thought to only affect rats. The man developed symptoms after a liver transplant and was treated for the virus. Researchers believe he contracted the illness through food infected by rat droppings, and the discovery has "major public health significance." This case highlights the risk of zoonotic diseases, where animals transmit diseases to humans, and underscores the need for vigilance in Hong Kong's rodent-infested housing estates.

site_title: Indonesia to offer incentives to US dollar hoarders to boost rupiah
summary: Indonesia is set to offer incentives to US dollar hoarders, encouraging them to convert their funds into the rupiah to boost the local currency. Exporters with billions of dollars in banks may tap special deposit accounts, with banks open to the idea of allowing them to open these accounts. The move aims to ease pressure on the rupiah, which has slumped to its lowest level since the 1997-98 Asian financial crisis. The central bank's efforts are part of a series of steps to cushion the impact of rising US interest rates and a trade war.

images.alt_text: The rupiah is down almost 9 per cent against the US dollar this year, falling to as low as 14,945 early this month and making it the second-worst performer in Asia.

site_title: Golden week isn't looking as prosperous for Macau's casinos
summary: Macau's casinos face dim prospects for the upcoming Golden Week due to a slower China economy and trade war. About 40% of hotel rooms are booked, compared to 80% last year, with prices doubled or tripled. Analysts expect modest growth in October, with forecasts cut to 5% and a 34% decline in casino stocks since May. The Golden Week, typically a peak season, is expected to disappoint investors, but lowered expectations may lead to a positive surprise.

images.alt_text: Macau casinos are facing dimmer prospects for the upcoming Golden Week, as a slower China economy and trade war hang over the world's biggest gambling hub.

site_title: Alliance Mineral secures A$20m debt facility, A$20m standby credit for ASX dual listing
summary: Alliance Mineral's proposed merger with Tawana Resources NL has secured a $20 million secured debt facility and a $20 million standby credit line to facilitate the merged entity's admission to the Australian Securities Exchange (ASX) and Singapore Exchange. The scheme of arrangement is set to be implemented in November, subject to certain conditions being satisfied. The merged group will not pay dividends or undertake capital reductions. The standby line of credit has a term of 21 months and a standby rate of 3% on undrawn funds.

site_title: Jeff Bezos space project lands big rocket partnership
summary: Jeff Bezos' Blue Origin space exploration project partnered with United Launch Alliance (ULA) to provide engines for the next-generation Vulcan Centaur rocket, set to launch in 2020. The Vulcan Centaur will revolutionize spaceflight with affordable, reliable access to space. Blue Origin will supply engines for the booster stage, with plans to build a spaceship and lunar lander to support moon colonies. The partnership aims to provide a reliable launch service for national security missions and space exploration.

images.alt_text: Jeff Bezos-backed Blue Origin space exploration project on Thursday landed a major deal to provide engines for a next-generation rocket being built by a major US launch services contractor.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Friday afternoon trading at 3,260.52, up 0.7%
summary: Singapore stocks resumed Friday afternoon trading at 3,260.52, up 0.7% on the Straits Times Index. Gainers outnumbered losers 183 to 119, with 746.6 million shares changing hands. Key movers included M1 (up 27.61%), Vallianz (flat), Keppel Corp (down 1.68%), and OCBC Bank (up 1.32%). The rally comes ahead of GDP data and follows a 5-day rally.

site_title: Australian banks pilloried by scathing official inquiry
summary: Australia's Royal Commission interim report scathingly accused the country's major banks of prioritizing profits over people, failing to meet basic standards of honesty, and engaging in misconduct such as dubious loans and excessive fees. The report described the sector as "greedy" and "flirting with illegality." The commission's findings were widely criticized and led to a surge in financial stocks. The Australian government vowed to restore confidence and trust in the institutions, but stopped short of committing to new regulation or oversight.

images.alt_text: Australia's financial giants - such as Commonwealth Bank, NAB, ANZ and Westpac - are among the world's most profitable financial institutions.

site_title: Company sponsored stock research gaining traction in equities
summary: Company-sponsored stock research is gaining traction in equities, particularly in Europe, following the implementation of MiFID II regulations. Under these regulations, buy-side investors pay for research, while brokers slash their coverage lists. As a result, companies are paying brokers to provide sponsored analysis, which can be transparent about its paid nature but may lack price targets or ratings. Firms offering sponsored research claim that their business model maintains credibility and allows for long-term analysis, but some investors view it as more conflicted than the existing sell-side model.

site_title: Passengers safe after Air Niugini flight crashes into sea in Micronesia
summary: A Air Niugini Boeing 737 aircraft crashed into the sea short of the runway at Chuuk Airport in Micronesia, resulting in no serious injuries to the 47 passengers and crew. The plane, 150 yards short of the runway, sank, but all passengers were rescued by small boats. An investigation is underway, with officials from Papua New Guinea's Accident Investigation Commission set to fly to the scene to determine the cause of the incident.

site_title: Malaysia shares open lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index fell 3.78 points to 1,794.86 at 9:05am on Friday, opening lower. The index was influenced by a volume of 99.04 million lots worth RM33.21 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 110 to 74.

site_title: Completed condo prices rise 0.5% in August
summary: Singapore's completed non-landed private homes saw a 0.5% month-on-month increase in August, reversing the 0.3% decline in July. This rise applies across the board, with central region apartments up 0.1%, non-central region up 0.6%, and small units up 1%. Year-to-date, prices have risen 4.4% overall, with a 7.8% increase year-over-year. The central region saw an 8.7% year-over-year gain, while non-central districts experienced a 7% increase.

site_title: New army chief takes over as Thailand prepares for return of civilian rule
summary: Thailand's new army chief, General Apirat Kongsompong, took command on Friday, overseeing a return to barracks for a civilian government after nearly five years of military rule. As a staunchly royalist general, General Apirat is part of the King's Guard faction, which has a fundamental role in determining stability in Thailand. His appointment indicates a consolidation of the relationship between the monarchy and the military, with General Apirat promising to do his best for the nation and people. A general election is expected by May under a new constitution that critics say limits political parties and enshrines military influence.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open with gains on Friday
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose on Friday, with the Hang Seng Index adding 0.59% to 27,879.06, following a positive lead from Wall Street. The gains were attributed to a healthy outlook for the US economy from the Federal Reserve. Other Asian markets, such as the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index, also saw gains. The positive trend was seen as a sign of traders' confidence despite ongoing US-China trade tensions.

site_title: Japan Inc's global push drives Asia M&As, offsets China slowdown
summary: Japan Inc's global push drives Asia M&As, offsetting China's slowdown. Japan's M&A volumes are set to break a 19-year-old record, with $289.7 billion in deals in the first nine months of 2018, more than doubling from the same period last year. This surge is driven by Japan Inc's efforts to scout for targets abroad to offset slowing growth at home and capitalize on cheap funding costs. The Tokyo Olympics in 2020 is expected to further boost inbound investments, with dealmakers anticipating increased activity in sectors such as hotels, tourism, and casino.

site_title: Singtel to carry all of Discovery's Singapore channels, after StarHub drops content provider
summary: Singtel has secured the rights to carry all of Discovery's Singapore channels after StarHub dropped its content provider. The telco will launch three new channels, including HGTV, the Asian Food Channel, and Food Network, bringing its pay-television portfolio to 10 Discovery brands. This move comes after StarHub parted ways with Discovery in June due to a price disagreement. Singtel TV will add the Asian Food Channel to its Family Starter pack at no extra charge, while HGTV and Food Network will be made available in a separate pack.

site_title: Ryanair faces fresh strike in Europe
summary: Ryanair is bracing for its largest strike in history, with nearly 250 flights canceled across Europe due to strikes in Germany, Belgium, Italy, the Netherlands, Portugal, and Spain. The airline claims most of its 2,400 flights will operate as scheduled, but unions dispute this, citing Ryanair's refusal to recognize workers' rights and pay them under local laws. The strike, set for 24 hours, follows recent labor disputes and a deal with cabin crew unions in Italy.

site_title: Cruise liners going green become latest market for LNG
summary: Liquefied natural gas (LNG) is becoming a growing market for the cruise industry, with companies like Carnival Corp adding LNG-powered vessels to their fleets. LNG emits significantly less pollution than traditional fuels, with 25% less carbon dioxide and 99% less particulates. The International Maritime Organization has set rules to reduce sulphur levels in ship fuels from 2020, and LNG is seen as a cleaner alternative. The demand for LNG vessels is expected to surge five-fold over the next eight years, with 1,500 LNG-powered vessels expected to be in service by 2026.

site_title: Uber co-authors academic study that says its drivers are happy
summary: Uber has published a white paper stating that most of its drivers are happy and earn above the UK minimum wage, contrary to a court ruling that drivers should be entitled to benefits. The study, co-authored by University of Oxford fellows and Uber researchers, found that drivers value flexibility over paid vacation time, with 75% of drivers believing they can choose their own hours. However, the report also highlights a driver gender imbalance, with women making up only a small percentage of the workforce. Uber is set to appeal a court ruling in October.

site_title: China feeling the aftershocks of 2008, again
summary: China is experiencing the aftershocks of the 2008 financial crisis, with its benchmark stock index still down around 50% from its pre-crisis peak. The country's over-reliance on US consumer spending and financial markets has led to a lack of domestic equity and bond markets, making it vulnerable to US monetary and trade policy. China's stimulus package has helped maintain GDP growth, but the country's non-financial corporate debt has risen sharply, and the renminbi has fallen to nearly 6.9 to the US dollar. Officials are now facing challenges in promoting the yuan and reducing dependence on US consumer spending.

site_title: Australia braces for banking rap-sheet in powerful Royal Commission report
summary: Australia is bracing for a Royal Commission report that could recommend legislative changes for its financial sector, following months of scandal revelations. The interim report's release on Friday comes after several high-profile resignations and share price drops. Prime Minister Scott Morrison said the government will extend the inquiry if requested by former judge Kenneth Hayne, who has received over 9,000 submissions on alleged misconduct. The final report, due in February, may recommend major regulatory reform and civil/criminal prosecutions for banks and financial institutions.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on Wall St gains, weaker yen
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Friday, driven by gains on Wall Street and a weak yen, with the Nikkei 225 index rising 1.15% to 24,071.51. The Topix index also gained 1.02%. The gains come amid global market sentiment boosted by the US stock market's edge towards fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: US FDA approves Lilly migraine drug; price same as rivals
summary: The US FDA has approved Eli Lilly's migraine drug Emgality, a CGRP inhibitor, at a list price of $6,900 per year, identical to rivals Aimovig and Ajovy. The biotech drug blocks a protein involved in setting off migraines, targeting dilation of blood vessels in the brain.

site_title: 'Very strong' typhoon Trami churns towards Japan
summary: A strong typhoon, Trami, is forecast to hit Japan's southern islands on Saturday, bringing violent winds and torrential rain. The typhoon has a maximum gust of 162kmh near its center and is expected to speed up and approach western Japan on Sunday. Japan's weather agency has urged people to be vigilant, warning of violent winds, high waves, and heavy rainfall. This comes after recent natural disasters, including a powerful typhoon and record-breaking rains, which have affected the country. Over 100 domestic flights have already been canceled.

site_title: JC Penney CFO steps down in chain's latest C-suite departure
summary: JC Penney's CFO Jeffrey Davis is resigning, effective October 1, to pursue a new opportunity. Jerry Murray, senior vice-president of finance, will assume the role on an interim basis. This departure comes at a challenging time for the retailer, still searching for a permanent CEO after Marvin Ellison's departure in May. The company has struggled to turn around its performance, with its stock plummeting to historic lows after reporting disappointing results, including increased clearance of excess inventory. A formal search for a permanent CFO will take place.

site_title: Thomson Medical sells hospitality unit to tycoon Gordon Tang's vehicle for S$3.4m
summary: Thomson Medical Group sold its hospitality unit, Ariva Pte Ltd, to Gordon Tang's vehicle, Tang Dynasty Pte Ltd, for S$3.38 million in cash. The sale is part of Thomson Medical's divestment strategy to focus on its healthcare business. The net asset value of Ariva was S$5.26 million as of June 30. The deal is expected to have no material impact on Thomson Medical's net tangible assets and earnings per share for the year ending Dec 31, 2018. Thomson Medical aims to develop its healthcare business and will assess options to divest its real estate portfolio when opportunities arise.

site_title: Trump backs embattled court nominee after fiery hearing
summary: US President Donald Trump expressed support for embattled Supreme Court nominee Brett Kavanaugh after a dramatic Senate hearing. Kavanaugh denied allegations of an attempted rape by Christine Blasey Ford, a 51-year-old psychology professor, in 1982. Trump tweeted that Kavanaugh's testimony was "powerful, honest and riveting," and that Democrats' actions were a "national disgrace." The Senate Judiciary Committee is scheduled to vote on Kavanaugh's nomination on Friday, with a full Senate vote to follow if approved.

site_title: Creditors in China see strong-arm tactics from local governments
summary: China's local governments are using strong-arm tactics to negotiate workouts for defaulted bonds, despite market-based guidelines. Creditors face limited options, as local officials often influence creditor committees and pressure them to avoid lawsuits and maintain credit lines. This year's record 50 billion yuan in local bond failures has led to interventions in provinces like Jiangsu, Shanxi, and Henan, where officials have helped set up creditor committees and negotiated debt restructurings. The approach contrasts with China's banking regulator's two-year-old rules requiring market-based workouts, and experts warn that market-oriented approaches are needed to promote fair and efficient debt restructuring.

site_title: Hot stocks: M1, Keppel T&T shares soar after takeover bids announced
summary: Keppel Corp and Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) announced takeover bids for M1 and Keppel T&T, respectively. M1 shares surged 28.22% to S$2.09, while Keppel T&T jumped 37.5% to S$1.87. Analysts believe the offers are fair and attractive, with some predicting a potential hike in the M1 offer price or Axiata launching its own offer. The consolidation of the mobile industry is expected to materialize in 2021 or beyond, with analysts advising M1 shareholders to tender their shares to avoid a painful period of intense competition.

site_title: Impact investing and financial returns can happen together
summary: Impact investing and financial returns can coexist, contrary to the perception of sub-optimal returns. Companies like Jing Jin Electric and Samumed, which focus on clean-vehicle technology and regenerative medicine, have shown promising financial yields. Venture capital can drive positive social impact, and fund managers can incorporate ESG policies to maximize both financial and social benefits. Recent investments by Vickers have demonstrated the potential for impact investing to generate strong returns, with three out of four funds ranking in the top quartile globally.

site_title: Japan's jobless rate down, factory output up in August
summary: Japan's unemployment rate fell to 2.4% in August, down from 2.5% the previous month, marking the first improvement in two months. Factory output also rose for the first time in four months, increasing 0.7% from the previous month. The jobs-to-applicants ratio remains unchanged at 163 job offers per 100 job hunters, the highest rate in 44 years. The rise in industrial production is attributed to recovery from heavy rains in western Japan, with no negative impact from trade frictions. The government expects trickle-down effects from corporate sector performances to boost consumption.

site_title: Europe: FTSE rises to 4-week high helped by sterling weakness
summary: Britain's FTSE 100 rose to a four-week high, 0.5% higher, as sterling weakened following a US rate hike and investors remained cautious on Brexit talks. Oil and gas stocks gained, driven by higher crude prices, while airlines fell. Travel operator TUI rose 2.5% after meeting earnings forecasts, while miner copper prices fell, weighing on the sector.

site_title: US: Stocks lifted by tech giants, Federal Reserve relief
summary: US stocks rose 0.2% to 26,439.93, driven by gains from tech giants like Apple (2.1%), Amazon (1.9%), and Alphabet (over 1%). The Federal Reserve's interest rate hike decision, characterized as "solid but not at imminent risk of overheating" by Chairman Jerome Powell, also boosted markets. Other sectors, such as Petrobras and US-traded shares, saw significant gains, while Bed Bath & Beyond fell 21.0% due to weak second-quarter profits.

site_title: Boeing wins US$9.2b contract for new Air Force training jet
summary: The US Air Force has awarded a contract worth up to $9.2 billion to Boeing to build the next training jet, with the goal of replacing its aging T-38 fleet. Boeing partnered with Saab AB to develop the new plane, beating out Lockheed Martin Corp and Leonardo DRS. The Air Force plans to purchase 351 jets and 46 simulators, with options to buy up to 475 jets and 120 simulators. Deliveries are expected to begin in 2023, with full operation to be reached in 2034.

site_title: Singapore shares rise at Friday's open; STI up 0.53% to 3,253.27
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.53% to 3,253.27 at the open on Friday, driven by overnight gains in US equities. The index saw 61.5 million securities worth S$160 million traded, with Genting Singapore Plc, M1, and Keppel Telecommunications & Transportation leading the gains. Active index stocks included DBS Group Holdings, up 0.6%, and Keppel Corp, down 2.0%. This marks the fifth consecutive day of gains for the index ahead of GDP data release.

site_title: Italy government agrees on deficit of 2.4% of GDP in 2019
summary: Italy's populist government agreed on a 2.4% deficit of GDP in 2019, exceeding the 0.8% forecast by the previous government. The decision, which includes a basic income grant and other projects, risks angering Brussels and spooking financial markets. The country's debt burden is expected to increase, and the move may lead to higher bond yields and reduced financial margins for manoeuvre.

site_title: Bank of Japan debated potential of more tweaks to policy framework in September
summary: Bank of Japan policymakers debated tweaks to their massive stimulus program in September, with one member suggesting the possibility of making monetary policy more flexible to revive bond market trading. Another policymaker expressed doubt about the effectiveness of the current policy, citing its diminishing impact over time. The BOJ kept policy steady at the September meeting, maintaining its ultra-loose policy despite concerns about bond market liquidity and financial institution profits. The discussion highlights the BOJ's dilemma in balancing the need for stimulus with the potential risks of prolonged monetary easing.

site_title: SPH to deliver personalised news reading experience with Cxense
summary: SPH to implement Cxense Conversion Engine, a machine-learning powered solution, to deliver personalized news reading experiences across its media platforms. The engine uses real-time behavioral and contextual data to create flexible paywalls and customer journeys. This move aims to increase subscription revenues, particularly for digital products, and provide readers with tailored content and promotions. SPH will also become a strategic partner and member of Cxense's Product Council for Conversion Engine.

site_title: Facebook admits phone numbers may be used to target ads
summary: Facebook has confirmed that advertisers can access phone numbers given by members for enhanced security, despite the intention of these numbers being for security or messaging purposes. Researchers found that phone numbers added to profiles for security or messaging were used to target advertising, raising concerns about data sharing and advertising practices. The study found that phone numbers uploaded from contacts were also used to enable personally identifying information-based advertising, highlighting the potential for data misuse.

site_title: Stocks to watch: A-Smart, Keppel Corp, Keppel T&T, SPH, M1, Straits Trading
summary: Keppel Corp plans to privatise Keppel T&T with a S$1.91 per share cash offer, giving shareholders an opportunity to realise their investment at an attractive premium. Keppel Corp, along with Singapore Press Holdings (SPH), also make a pre-conditional voluntary general offer of S$2.06 per share for remaining M1 shares, valuing the mobile operator at around S$1.91 billion. A-Smart Holdings reported a net loss of S$267,000 for the three months to July 31, despite an uptick in revenue amid business diversification.

site_title: Printer A-Smart sinks into the red for Q4 as diversification rings up costs
summary: Printer A-Smart Holdings reported a net loss of S$267,000 for the fourth quarter, despite a 1.5% year-over-year increase in revenue. The company attributed the loss to inventory changes, higher project-specific material expenses, and fees related to its expansion into real estate in Timor Leste. The group's printing business remains challenging, but it has upgraded machinery to gain a higher market share for specialized printing. A-Smart's full-year loss was S$606,000, with 12-month turnover decreasing 8.3% to S$7.22 million.

site_title: Flying High
summary: Theatre company Pangdemonium concluded its season with Peter and the Starcatcher, an award-winning family-friendly play about the origins of Peter Pan. The play features Adrian Pang as pirate chief Black Stache and Thomas Pang as the titular character, who won Best Actor at The Straits Times Life! Theatre Awards. The production runs from September 28 to October 20 at the Drama Centre Theatre.

site_title: Accounting standards and tax obligations for companies
summary: Singapore's accounting landscape is evolving with the adoption of Financial Reporting Standards 115 and 109. Companies must assess the income tax impact of these new standards, which may result in significant changes to taxable income. Tax treatments under FRS 115 and FRS 109 largely align with accounting treatments, but exceptions apply. Companies must work with finance teams and tax functions to ensure accurate and consistent application of new tax requirements, and consider transitional tax adjustments to manage potential impacts on cash flow. Failure to align tax treatment with accounting treatments can lead to misaligned financial reporting.

site_title: Canada strips Aung San Suu Kyi of honorary citizenship
summary: Canada's parliament voted unanimously to strip Aung San Suu Kyi of her honorary citizenship due to her refusal to denounce the Rohingya genocide. The decision comes after the UN set up a panel to prepare indictments against Myanmar's army chief and top military commanders for crimes against humanity. Suu Kyi's government remains in a delicate power balance with the generals, and the Canadian honour, symbolic but without privileges, was withdrawn over her "persistent refusal" to condemn the genocide.

site_title: CDW Holding to turn loss-making biotech unit over to controlling shareholder's son
summary: CDW Holding is selling 32.94% of its loss-making biotech subsidiary, A Biotech Co (ABio), to Koichi Yoshimi for $3.63 million in cash. The deal reduces CDW's majority stake in ABio to less than 50%. The sale will be used for working capital and is valued at twice ABio's net asset value. The transaction allows CDW to exit the high-risk, cash-dependent business and align its interests with Yoshimi, who is instrumental in ABio's early-stage development.

site_title: Even with new IMF backing, Macri faces trouble ahead
summary: Argentina's President Mauricio Macri warned of "painful months" ahead as his government agreed to a $57 billion IMF bailout to meet the terms of the deal. The country faces a severe economic crisis, with inflation forecast to reach over 40% by the end of the year and a currency that has lost half its value against the dollar. Macri must convince a hostile opposition to adopt a 2019 austerity budget, which could be a challenge given his lack of a majority in Congress.

site_title: Qantas teams up with training provider for new pilot academy
summary: Qantas has partnered with US-based L3 Technologies Inc to establish a pilot academy at a regional airport in Queensland, Australia, to address a pilot shortage. The A$35 million academy will train up to 250 pilots annually, initially focusing on Qantas but also open to international students. The move aims to meet growing demand for pilot training, with Boeing estimating 790,000 more pilots will be required globally over the next 20 years. The academy is set to open in mid-2019, with a second facility planned for later in the year.

site_title: Keep Calm And Tangle On
summary: Zentangle is a drawing exercise that helps calm the mind by creating uncomplicated, abstract patterns. Founded in 2003 by American artist-couple Rick Robert and Maria Thomas, it involves using simple repeat patterns to create art. The technique requires minimal materials, including a pen, pencil, and paper, and can be done anywhere, even in waiting areas. Eight steps guide the process, which involves drawing a border, creating a tangle, adding shading, and adding an initial. Zentangle is suitable for people of all ages and skill levels, and can be used as a form of relaxation and stress relief.

site_title: Oil rises as investors fret over Iranian supply gaps
summary: Oil prices rose as investors worried about potential supply gaps due to US sanctions on Iran. The US is set to impose sanctions in five weeks, which could cut global supply by 500,000-2 million barrels per day. OPEC and Russia are unlikely to boost production, and US Energy Secretary Rick Perry ruled out using strategic crude reserves to lower prices. December Brent crude futures rose 59 cents to $81.38 a barrel, with some analysts predicting prices could reach $100 a barrel, while others see material risks of this happening.

images.alt_text: Oil edged higher on Thursday, driven by the prospect of a shortfall in global supply once US sanctions against major crude exporter Iran come into force in five weeks.

site_title: Amazon opens new concept '4-star' retail store in New York
summary: Amazon has opened its first "4-star" retail store in New York's Soho neighborhood, offering a curated selection of products with 4-star ratings or higher. The store sells a range of categories, including consumer electronics, kitchen, home, toys, books, and games. This concept marks a new direction for Amazon's physical retail presence, following the success of its Amazon Books stores and acquisition of Whole Foods. The store features digital price tags and discounts for Amazon Prime members, aiming to provide customers with a hands-on shopping experience.

images.alt_text: Amazon opened a new retail store in New York on Thursday selling a range of products that get top ratings from customers of the online colossus.

site_title: Singapore office rents grow for sixth straight quarter in Q3 2018: JLL study
summary: Singapore office rents rose for the sixth consecutive quarter in Q3 2018, increasing 2.3% quarter-on-quarter to S$9.93 per square feet (psf) per month, according to JLL research. This marks an 18% increase over the past six quarters, bringing rents close to their 2015 peak. Strong demand from occupiers and limited new supply are driving the growth, with co-working operators leading the expansion. The pace of rent growth has been slowing, but JLL expects sustainable steady growth in the near term.

site_title: US to repatriate remains of South Korean troops
summary: The US is repatriating the remains of 64 South Korean troops who died during the Korean War. The remains, recovered between 1996 and 2005, were identified through a joint forensic review with South Korean scientists. The US Defence POW/MIA Accounting Agency confirmed the remains are of South Korean origin, but not individually identified. The remains will be handed over to South Korea during a ceremony at Pearl Harbour in Hawaii on Thursday, marking the US's first repatriation since 2012. This follows a 2018 agreement with North Korea to return US remains.

images.alt_text: The remains of 64 South Korean troops who died during the Korean War are being sent home on Thursday, having spent years at a US forensic facility.

site_title: The New Age Of Fine Dining
summary: Two Singapore restaurants, Bacchanalia by Vianney Massot and table65 by Richard van Oostenbrugge, are set to open, marking a shift away from traditional fine dining. Massot, a former Joel Robuchon protégé, aims to bring modern French techniques to his restaurant, while van Oostenbrugge's 212-inspired concept, table65, will offer a casual, interactive fine dining experience. Meanwhile, chef Fernando Arevalo's Preludio promises "creative disruption" with a monthly menu chapter theme, while Sun Kim's Thevar offers a contemporary Indian grill with modern European techniques.

site_title: US regulators charge Tesla CEO Elon Musk with fraud
summary: US regulators charged Tesla CEO Elon Musk with securities fraud, alleging he misled investors with false statements about taking the company private via Twitter. Musk tweeted on August 7, 2018, that he had "funding secured" to privatize Tesla at $420 a share, causing a brief spike in the company's share price. The Securities and Exchange Commission stated that Musk's statements were "false and misleading" and that he had never discussed the plans with company officials or potential funders.

images.alt_text: The US Securities and Exchange Commission on Thursday charged Tesla CEO Elon Musk with securities fraud, alleging he had misled investors last month in tweets about taking the company private.

site_title: Be rational, not emotional, when investing in real estate
summary: Investing in real estate in Singapore has historically yielded significant returns, with the private home price index surging from 8.9 in 1975 to 154.6 in 2013. However, authorities have indicated a plan to keep property price increases in line with economic fundamentals, potentially limiting future capital appreciation. Meanwhile, investing in equities, property counters, and real estate investment trusts (Reits) may offer more attractive returns. Buying a property can instill financial discipline and provide a tangible stake in the country, but some may be channelling resources to owning real estate instead of more productive uses.

site_title: China demands US 'dispel obstacles' and stop slander as tensions grow over trade, sensitive issues
summary: China demands the US "dispel obstacles" and stop slandering it, amid growing tensions over trade, Taiwan, the South China Sea, and US President Donald Trump's claims of China meddling in the US congressional elections. China summoned the US ambassador and postponed joint military talks after the US sanctioned a Chinese military agency and its director for buying Russian fighter jets and a surface-to-air missile system. China also denied a request for a US warship to visit Hong Kong and expressed opposition to US air force flights over the South China Sea.

site_title: Vintage Gold
summary: The vintage and second-hand luxury handbag market is thriving, with prices steadily rising over the past 35 years at an average annual rate of 14.2%. Resellers are finding valuable luxury items, such as Hermès Birkins, Chanel bags, and vintage Louis Vuitton monogram classics, which can increase in value over time. Authenticity is crucial, and experts recommend authentication from reputable companies like Entrupy and Entrupy's technology. The market is attracting first-time luxury buyers and collectors, with some resellers reporting lucrative sales. Vintage luxury items are also benefiting from "logomania" trends, with brands like Gucci and Celine introducing vintage-inspired designs.

site_title: Euro falls on reports of delayed Italian budget meet
summary: The euro fell against the US dollar on Thursday amid reports that an Italian budget meeting was likely to be delayed, sparking concerns over a potential increase in the deficit target. Italian Economy Minister Giovanni Tria reportedly was ready to leave, but a ministry spokeswoman denied this. The delay and potential for increased deficit targets overshadowed a recent euro revival against the US dollar, causing traders to sell the currency.

site_title: Q2 growth at its fastest pace in nearly four years
summary: The US economy experienced its fastest quarterly growth in nearly four years, with a 4.2% annualized rate in the second quarter, exceeding the Trump administration's goal of 3% annual growth. This growth was driven by the tax-cut package, boosted consumer spending, and a robust job market. However, a trade war with China and higher borrowing costs may impact future growth. Economists expect solid growth in business spending on equipment in the third quarter, despite a temporary drop in core capital goods orders.

site_title: The five-second cocktail: Put in glass, add ice
summary: A writer pokes fun at the idea of making a "proper" cocktail, emphasizing the importance of personal freedom and simplicity. The author, a bartender, finds the ritual of making a martini tedious and unnecessary, especially after a long day of work. The piece is lighthearted and humorous, using satire to make a point about the value of individuality and the excesses of hyper-cultivated living.

site_title: US new home sales rebound in August, but trend weakening
summary: US new home sales rebounded 3.5% in August to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 629,000 units, but the trend still indicates a weakening housing market due to rising mortgage rates and higher home prices. This rebound is seen as a temporary relief against the backdrop of a slowing housing market.

site_title: Science and tourism clash on Great Barrier Reef
summary: Scientists' apocalyptic warnings about Australia's Great Barrier Reef are scaring tourists away, with over 10% drop in visitors in 2017 and a further 15% expected this year. However, a recent report by the Reef and Rainforest Research Centre suggests "significant signs of recovery" at major dive sites, sparking debate between ecologists and the tourism industry. The reef's damage is attributed to higher temperatures, farming run-off, development, and tropical cyclones, with coral cover continuing to decline.

site_title: Long-term investors give M1 another lease
summary: Keppel Corp has made a pre-conditional voluntary general offer to buy out M1 shares for S$2.06 cash per share, valuing M1 at around S$1.91 billion. The offer, made together with Singapore Press Holdings, aims to privatize M1 and Keppel Telecommunications and Transportation, with the goal of unlocking synergies and transforming M1's operations. Analysts expect Keppel to acquire a 50% stake in M1, with the option to take control and avoid excessive debt. The deal is seen as a win for M1 shareholders, who will benefit from the increased value of their shares.

site_title: Out Of This World
summary: The Singapore Writers Festival 2018, held from Nov 2 to 11, explores the theme of "界" (jiè), referring to worlds and borders, through various talks, discussions, courses, films, and performances. The festival features local and international writers, including Rachel Heng, JY Yang, and Xia Jia, discussing science fiction, fantasy, and mythology. Highlights include lectures by David Sedaris, Paddy Hirsch, and Jeff Goodell, as well as workshops on world-building and the ethics of artificial intelligence. The festival also includes popular fiction and non-writers, such as Kiran Desai and Irvine Welsh, participating in group discussions.

site_title: Trading blows across the seas
summary: A trade war between the US and China has begun, with the US imposing tariffs on Chinese goods. South-east Asian economies are at risk as trade dynamics shift. The article discusses various unrelated topics, including Mars Wrigley Confectionery's diverse products, the impact of a trade war on China's growth, and innovation in businesses.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Keppel Capital China has signed a memorandum of understanding with the China-Singapore Tianjin Eco-City Administrative Committee and Sino-Singapore Tianjin Eco-City Investment and Development Co to establish a fund management entity in the Sino-Singapore Tianjin Eco-City. The Eco-City is a landmark bilateral project between Singapore and China's governments.

site_title: Epic Comeback
summary: The 1968 Stanley Kubrick film "2001: A Space Odyssey" is returning to the big screen for a limited run to celebrate its 50th anniversary. New 70mm prints have been made from the original negatives, supervised by director Christopher Nolan, who cites the film as an influence on his career. The film will play exclusively at Shaw Theatres Lido IMAX until October 3, with advance tickets available for sale.

site_title: Paul Tange
summary: Paul Noritaka Tange, son of renowned architect Kenzo Tange, has established himself as a world-class architect in his own right. Working alongside his father, Tange Associates has developed distinctive urban architecture projects, including the Mode Gakuen Cocoon Tower in Tokyo. Paul's approach prioritizes teamwork, freedom of discussion, and finding the best solution. He has learned from his father's design philosophy, but also incorporates the perspectives of younger generations. The firm's latest project, JadeScape in Singapore, reflects a nature-oriented design influenced by Asian landscapes. Paul's passion lies in overcoming challenges and making the impossible possible, while remaining humble and open to feedback.

site_title: Singapore's promising firms winning with innovation
summary: Singaporean startups FOMO Pay, AEvice Health, and XM Studios took home top honors at the Emerging Enterprise Awards 2018, celebrating their innovative business strategies and technology-driven approaches. The firms received prizes worth at least S$340,000, including consultancy services and business overdraft facilities, for their work in healthcare, fintech, and collectible art. Other winners included EndoMaster, Engine Biosciences, and Whizpace for their innovative spirit and novel business concepts, while Mighty Jaxx and Big Tiny received the Most Promising Startup Award.

site_title: Singapore, UK urged to fully integrate into global economy to thrive
summary: Singaporean Trade and Industry Minister Chan Chun Sing urged the UK to fully integrate into the global economy to thrive. He emphasized the importance of resisting isolationism and promoting a rules-based global system. Chan noted that the UK and Singapore can work together despite their physical distance, citing their significant trade relationship. He also highlighted the need for governments to redistribute wealth and support those affected by globalization.

site_title: The Challenger
summary: Audrey Yeo, founder of Yeo Workshop and S.E.A. Focus, aims to deepen relationships between art galleries, artists, and collectors through her newly-launched boutique art fair in Singapore. Fueled by her fear of people losing interest in arts and culture, Yeo believes art can change perspectives and create empathy. She's inspired by artists, finding their unique views on life and ability to challenge and surprise. S.E.A. Focus focuses on showcasing South-east Asian art, prioritizing understanding over commercial transactions.

site_title: MeGroup lodges preliminary offer document for Catalist listing
summary: MeGroup, a Malaysia-based manufacturing and dealership firm, has lodged its preliminary offer document for a listing on the Catalist board. The company, which produces noise, vibration and harshness components for the car industry, plans to use IPO proceeds for business expansion and working capital. MeGroup reported a net profit of RM8.9 million for FY2018, up from RM49,729 the previous year, driven by increased revenue from both its manufacturing and dealership businesses. CIMB Bank and CGS-CIMB Securities are the sponsor and underwriter for the IPO.

site_title: WTO cuts global trade forecast for 2018, 2019
summary: The World Trade Organization (WTO) has downgraded its global trade forecast for 2018 and 2019 due to escalating trade tensions worldwide. The new forecast expects merchandise trade volumes to expand 3.9% this year and 3.7% in 2019, down from previous forecasts of 4.4% and 4%. The downgrade is attributed to tightening credit market conditions, particularly in the US, and the uncertainty generated by trade measures and threats between major trading partners. The WTO warns that the situation may worsen, potentially requiring further downward revisions.

site_title: Shakespeare's Caesar
summary: Acclaimed theatre director Nicholas Hytner's 2018 stage production of Shakespeare's Julius Caesar is brought to screen, with echoes of Brexit. The film, featuring Ben Whishaw and David Morrissey as Brutus and Mark Anthony, showcases Hytner's innovative staging, where audiences stand around the characters and respond to their rallies. The live performance is screening at the Esplanade Theatre on September 29 at 8pm, with tickets available from Sistic.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Sasseur Reit is involved in a lawsuit with its contractor over a construction dispute, with the contractor seeking S$29.6 million in damages. However, the sponsor's indemnity is expected to minimize the impact on the Reit's distributions. In the telecommunications sector, analysts upgraded Singtel and M1 to "buy" with target prices of S$3.94 and S$1.88, respectively, citing strong defensive qualities and potential for growth. Netlink NBN Trust is maintained as "buy" with a target price of S$0.95 due to its dominant market share and projected growth.

site_title: Embodying The Spirit Of IWC
summary: IWC's new facility, dubbed the "Manufakturzentrum," officially opened on August 27, 2018, to commemorate the luxury watchmaker's 150th anniversary. The 42 million Swiss franc facility, located in Schaffhausen, Switzerland, was initially planned to produce only watch movement parts due to a financial crisis that halted construction in 2015. However, the company reassessed the project and expanded its production to include watch case manufacturing. The facility features advanced technology, including solar panels and automatic lighting control, and is designed to provide optimal working conditions.

site_title: US billionaire to build two stadiums in Bangkok
summary: US billionaire Philip Anschutz's AEG and developer The Mall Group plan to invest 10 billion baht (S$420.8 million) to build two multi-purpose stadiums in Bangkok, Thailand. The stadiums, including a 16,000-capacity arena and a 6,000-seat theatre, are expected to be completed by 2023. The venues will host music, sports, and fashion events, aiming to bolster Bangkok's potential as a live entertainment hub in South-east Asia.

site_title: Going the extra mile for the needy
summary: EY member firm in Singapore walked over 5,480 km to raise 54,800 bowls of rice for low-income families, supporting the FairPrice Walk for Rice @ South East programme. This is the seventh consecutive year EY participates, with volunteers delivering donated rice to beneficiaries in November. The walk, organized with International Accountants Day, raised funds for needy residents in the South East District through NTUC Fairprice's donation for every 200m walked. The event promotes corporate giving and teamwork, with over 1,000 participants, including EY clients and volunteers from SportSG.

site_title: Retirement Home
summary: Veteran IT professional Koh Sim Hock commissioned a new home for his family of seven after retirement, with creative director Dennis Cheok designing a unique space that incorporates Chinese culture and diverse lifestyle needs. The 40-year-old home was rebuilt after discovering structural damage, and the design featured sliding glass doors, timber screens, and antique 100-year-old clay bricks reclaimed from Northern China. The result was a unified, singular vision that maintained a coherent look, earning the house a gold award and luminary award in the residential category at the Singapore Interior Design Awards 2017.

site_title: Teen Apple hacker avoids jail in Australia
summary: An Australian 16-year-old teenager who hacked into Apple's internal systems and downloaded sensitive data was sentenced to an 8-month probation order. The hacking occurred between June 2015 and November 2016, and again in April 2017, with the teenager accessing Apple's systems to gather information and experience the thrill of pretending to be an employee. The court heard the teenager was fascinated by technology and found accessing the networks to be addictive.
