summary: UK Prime Minister Theresa May will meet US President Donald Trump in New York to discuss Brexit and a bilateral trade deal. The meeting aims to secure a post-Brexit trade agreement and address economic uncertainty. Trump has previously expressed support for a strong UK-US free trade deal, which could boost May's government and soothe financial markets. May will also use the opportunity to warn against the normalisation of chemical weapons use and promote free markets.

site_title: Cosby risks sentence of up to 10 years on Tuesday
summary: Bill Cosby risks a maximum 10-year sentence after a Canadian woman he sexually assaulted appealed for justice in a US court. Cosby, 81, was convicted of drugging and molesting Andrea Constand in 2004. Prosecutors demand the maximum sentence, while defense lawyers argue Cosby should be restricted to house arrest due to his age and frailty. Cosby, once known as "America's Dad," faces a possible classification as a violent sex offender, which would require him to register with state police and submit to counseling.

site_title: Builders slump as US housing market shifts to the slow lane
summary: The US housing market is experiencing a slowdown, with homebuilder stocks down 21% year-to-date, the largest annual drop since 2008. Despite low unemployment and tax cuts, rising interest rates and labor shortages are contributing to the decline. New-home inventory is increasing, but becoming more expensive, and investors worry about affordability. Housing permits have dropped, and sales of previously-owned homes have slowed. Experts predict a "fairly tepid" housing recovery, with some analysts warning of a potential downturn, citing the need for an affordability tipping point.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Nico Steel, Metech, Noble, First Ship Lease Trust
summary: Nico Steel is expected to see a significant increase in six-month earnings due to higher revenue and margins from its metal alloy materials. Metech International has proposed a share consolidation, causing its shares to double. Noble Group has agreed to swap out convertible notes for a package of cash, shares, and options. First Ship Lease Trust has settled a lawsuit against its former CEO, Alan Hatton, with both parties withdrawing allegations.

site_title: Dior leads Paris fashion on a dance as Gucci goes for gags
summary: Dior kicked off Paris Fashion Week with a sensual dance performance, featuring models and modern dance pieces by choreographer Sharon Eyal. The show's designer, Maria Grazia Chiuri, described it as "an act of liberation" to break free from traditional fashion norms. Meanwhile, Gucci's Alessandro Michele showcased an eclectic and playful collection, complete with Mickey Mouse-inspired accessories and wacky 1970s kitsch. Chiuri's Dior collection featured flesh-toned dresses and nifty headwear, while Gucci's show was a humorous contrast, with Birkin singing her hit song "Baby Alone in Babylone" in a Paris theater.

site_title: UK warns flights could be grounded in case of no-deal Brexit
summary: The UK government warned that flights could be grounded if the EU doesn't grant reciprocal approvals to its planes and airlines in a no-deal Brexit scenario. The UK will recognize EU aviation safety certifications for two years after March 29, but there's no guarantee that UK-issued certificates will be recognized by the EU. Airlines will need to apply to EU states to continue flying, and the UK is in negotiations with 17 non-EU countries to secure deals. The warning is considered a contingency, with negotiations "progressing well" and a positive deal sought.

site_title: Instagram founders clash with Zuckerberg, leave Facebook
summary: The founders of Instagram, Kevin Systrom and Mike Krieger, are leaving Facebook Inc. due to growing tensions with CEO Mark Zuckerberg over the direction of the photo-sharing app. Systrom and Krieger, who were acquired by Facebook in 2012, were frustrated with Zuckerberg's increasing involvement in the app's day-to-day operations. The duo confirmed their departure in a blog post, citing their desire to focus on their own projects. The move is seen as a significant shift in the leadership of Instagram, which is now reliant on Zuckerberg for growth.

site_title: US violent crime rate fell in 2017: official data
summary: The US violent crime rate declined by 0.2% in 2017, with 1.25 million cases reported, including 18,000 homicides. This marks a return to a long-term trend of decline after two years of increases. The murder rate of 5.3 per 100,000 inhabitants is still higher than the 1998 level, but lower than the 2014 level. Guns were used in three-quarters of all murders, and property crimes fell 3% in 2017, resulting in estimated losses of $15.3 billion.

images.alt_text: The United States saw a 0.2 per cent fall in overall violent crime in 2017, returning to a long-term trend of decline after two years of increases, according to data published by the FBI on Monday.

site_title: Q&M Dental says Aidite's proposed delisting not part of restructuring
summary: Q&M Dental Group has stated that Aidite's proposed delisting from China's New Third Board is not part of a restructuring exercise, despite Aidite's announcement of exploring strategic business development opportunities. Aidite, a dental supplies manufacturing business, was spun off from Q&M Dental in 2016. Q&M Dental will provide further details on the business development opportunities when Aidite makes further announcements. The company is also satisfied with Aidite's recent performance and business plans, and has not proposed reinstating a profit guarantee.

site_title: Metech proposes 50-to-1 share consolidation
summary: Metech International, an e-waste management company, has proposed a 50-to-1 share consolidation to reduce volatility and increase market interest in its shares. The consolidation will result in 90 million shares, with each share being traded in lots of 100. The move is expected to boost the share price, as the theoretical adjusted six-month volume weighted average price per share will increase from 0.3 Singapore cents to 15 Singapore cents. The proposal is subject to in-principle approval from the Singapore Exchange Securities Trading and shareholder approval at an extraordinary general meeting.

site_title: Thousands protest in Argentina ahead of general strike
summary: Thousands of protesters in Buenos Aires marched ahead of a general strike against an austerity budget proposed by Argentine President Mauricio Macri, who secured a $50 billion IMF loan to combat a currency crisis. The strike, scheduled for Tuesday, aims to reject the budget and express opposition to IMF influence. Macri vowed to avoid default and secured additional IMF funding, but analysts say the government wants more flexibility to access funds sooner. The strike is expected to disrupt public services, including transportation, schools, and hospitals.

site_title: Virtual reality studio Vividthree opens in Catalist debut at S$0.225 a share
summary: Virtual reality studio Vividthree Holdings made its debut on the Singapore Exchange's Catalist board at S$0.225 per share, 10.1% lower than its IPO price of S$0.25. The studio, known for its work in the Ah Boys to Men movie franchise, raised S$12.95 million through a placement. After the listing, mm2 Asia, a mainboard-listed company, will be the controlling shareholder with about 41.53% stake. Vividthree plans to use the proceeds for general working capital and intellectual property acquisition. The company's managing director, Charles Yeo, believes in "substantial growth" in the digital content market.

site_title: Political systems of advanced countries have broken down
summary: The Economist magazine marks its 175th birthday by highlighting the present breakdown in the world's political order, a collapse exacerbated by US President Donald Trump but not caused by him. The magazine notes that the past 175 years have seen significant progress in global life expectancy, poverty rates, and civil rights, but the future is uncertain. A global backlash against liberal elites has led to a rise in populism and nationalism, with politicians evading the hard work of resolving conflicts. The magazine concludes that the political systems of many advanced countries have broken down, and a new, more collaborative approach, "Liberalism 3.0," is needed.

site_title: Do economic risks lurk as US interest rates rise?
summary: The US economy is experiencing robust growth, low unemployment, and a soaring stock market, but rising interest rates pose economic risks. Despite healthier mortgages, consumer debt, including auto and student loans, is a concern due to rising defaults and low credit scores. Corporate bonds, particularly speculative grade, are also vulnerable to market fluctuations. Sovereign and currency risks are heightened as emerging markets face increased borrowing costs and potential capital outflows. Experts warn of a potential "wall" for corporate bonds and a risk of accelerated capital outflows if investors become risk-averse, putting growth in some emerging markets at risk.

site_title: Noble agrees to swop Australian miner's notes for cash, shares and options
summary: NOBLE Group has agreed to cancel debt-ridden Australian miner Sundance Resources' A$32 million convertible notes in exchange for A$27.6 million in cash, shares, and options. The agreement, reached on Monday, will see the notes fully impaired and cancelled by Sundance. Noble Resources International Pte Ltd will receive the package for the cancellation of the notes.

images.alt_text: NOBLE Group has agreed to stand down as a noteholder of debt-ridden Australia-listed miner Sundance Resources, the Singapore-listed commodities trader said in a bourse filing on Tuesday morning.

site_title: UK's May tells ministers to hold their nerve over Brexit: Downing St
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May told her ministers to hold their nerve in the Brexit negotiations, stating her plan is the only viable option and she remains confident of securing a deal with the EU. The government will also sensibly plan for a no-deal scenario, according to May.

site_title: UK would allow EU airlines to fly in no-deal Brexit, would keep EU safety rules
summary: Britain has released technical papers stating it will allow EU airlines to continue flying into the UK in a no-deal Brexit scenario. The government plans to stick to EU aviation safety rules and has acknowledged the risk that flights could be grounded. Some pilot and safety licenses issued by the UK may no longer be recognized in the EU. Britain also plans to continue participating in the European Aviation Safety Agency (EASA), which may be complicated without a Brexit deal.

site_title: Drivers for Uber, Lyft see incomes fall as participation jumps
summary: US ridesharing drivers for Uber, Lyft, and other services have seen their average monthly revenues drop by 53% between 2013 and 2017, from over $1,500 to less than $800. The decline is attributed to increased participation, with more people getting behind the wheel. A study by JPMorgan Chase found this trend, despite leaving questions unanswered about the gig economy's impact. The drop in income is a sobering note on the platform economy, with drivers facing lower earnings despite higher participation.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on investor caution
summary: Tokyo's benchmark stock index opened lower on Tuesday, slipping 0.19% or 44.56 points to 23,825.37, amid investor caution following six days of gains. The move comes as investors wait for the outcome of Japan's trade talks with the US. In contrast, the broader Topix index rose 0.07% or 1.33 points to 1,805.35.

site_title: Sears chief warns of bankruptcy danger
summary: Sears chief executive Edward Lampert warned the company faces bankruptcy danger due to a large loan payment due next month. His hedge fund, ESL Investments, proposed a series of deals to reduce Sears' US$5.6 billion debt load, including selling stores and exchanging loans for equity stakes. The proposal aims to free up cash for the company's struggling retail operations and avoid a Chapter 11 bankruptcy filing. If enacted, Sears' debt would fall to US$1.2 billion, but lenders may not accept the offer due to uncertainty about Sears' future in retailing.

site_title: US approves possible sale of military parts to Taiwan
summary: The US State Department has approved a possible $330 million sale of military parts to Taiwan, including spare parts for F-16 fighter jets and C-130 cargo planes. The sale is seen as a demonstration of the US commitment to Taiwan's defense, despite China's objections. The move comes amid escalating tensions between the US and China, with President Trump's latest tariffs on Chinese imports taking effect. The sale requires congressional approval within 30 days, but it is unlikely to be blocked given the State Department's assessment that Taiwan continues to be a "key force for stability" in the region.

site_title: Global spending on digital marketing nears US$100b: study
summary: Global spending on digital marketing has reached nearly US$100 billion, according to a study. In the US and Britain, spending grew by 44% last year to US$52 billion, driven by brands seeking greater control over marketing technology and targeting consumers directly. This shift reflects a desire to avoid intermediaries and online ad fraud, with 63% of US technology budgets now spent in-house. The trend is expected to continue, with brands investing in "martech" to remain competitive and build in-house strength.

site_title: SiriusXM buys Pandora to step up streaming music wars
summary: SiriusXM has agreed to acquire Pandora for $3.5 billion, creating the world's largest audio entertainment company with $7 billion in revenues. The deal aims to expand SiriusXM's presence beyond vehicles into homes and mobile areas, creating a strong competitor to Spotify and Apple in the streaming music market. Pandora's CEO Roger Lynch said the combined firm would be better positioned to capitalize on opportunities in audio entertainment, including growing its advertising business and expanding subscription offerings.

site_title: Europe: Trade fears and hawkish Draghi dent sharess
summary: European equities markets retreated 0.6-0.56% due to trade fears and hawkish comments from Mario Draghi. The US and China imposed fresh tariffs on each other's goods, escalating a bitter trade dispute. Investors expect this to impact global economic growth and exacerbate regional economic differences. The euro rose against the dollar, while oil prices surged to a four-year high. Brexit negotiations stalled, adding to market uncertainty.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Coffee with Claressa - Destination Switzerland, more reasons to visit
summary: Switzerland Tourism CEO Martin Nydegger discusses a new Stopover Programme to attract long-haul Singaporean travelers to the Alpine Nation. The programme aims to entice visitors to explore Switzerland beyond its popular destinations. Nydegger highlights the country's unique experiences, such as its picturesque landscapes, rich culture, and high-quality services. The programme is part of Switzerland's efforts to increase tourism and boost the local economy.

site_title: US: Dow, S&P 500 fall on latest US-China trade barbs
summary: US stocks fell on Monday, with the Dow and S&P 500 declining 0.7% and 0.4% respectively, due to the latest escalation in the US-China trade row. New US tariffs on $200 billion of Chinese imports took effect, prompting retaliatory tariffs from Beijing on $60 billion in American goods. Analysts also await the Federal Reserve's interest rate decision on Wednesday.

site_title: Oil prices surge as Saudis, Russia won't open spigots
summary: Oil prices surged 3% to a four-year high above $80 a barrel as Saudi Arabia and Russia ruled out immediate production increases, despite US President Trump's demand. Global benchmark Brent crude settled at $81.20 a barrel, with some traders predicting prices could reach $90 by Christmas and $100 in early 2019 due to supply gaps and US sanctions on Iran. The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries and non-Opec states failed to recommend additional supply boosts to counter falling supply from Iran.

site_title: Ford executive says may boost production in China to avoid tariffs
summary: Ford is considering increasing production of Lincoln models in Chinese plants to avoid US tariffs amid the growing trade war. Executive Vice-President Joseph Hinrichs stated that he doesn't foresee an easy resolution to the trade dispute between the US and China. President Trump imposed $200 billion in tariffs on Chinese goods, prompting Beijing to retaliate with $60 billion in US products. This move aims to boost Ford's production in China and minimize the impact of the tariffs.

site_title: Cosby sentencing reduces 'America's Dad' to convicted felon
summary: Bill Cosby, the 80-year-old comedian, will face sentencing in a Pennsylvania courtroom for his conviction on aggravated indecent assault. Cosby was found guilty in April and faces up to 10 years on each of three counts. State sentencing guidelines recommend 2-4 years, but prosecutors are expected to seek a lengthy sentence. Defence lawyers will argue for leniency citing Cosby's age and frailty. The sentencing hearing is expected to last two days, with Judge Steven O'Neill deciding Cosby's fate.

site_title: Sabana Reit collects overdue rent on Changi property
summary: Sabana Reit, a Singapore-based Shari'ah compliant industrial real estate investment trust, has received overdue rent of S$2.15 million on a Changi property. The payment is expected to have no material adverse financial impact on distribution per unit (DPU) for the property this year. A lease termination notice was earlier issued, but the Reit trustee and tenant, Adviva Distribution, have reached a deal to vary the lease terms, allowing the trustee to mitigate occupancy risks and maintain the fixed rent.

site_title: Taking technology out of the lab
summary: Lucence Diagnostics, a genomic medicine company, was founded in 2016 as a spin-off from A*Star's Institute of Bioengineering and Nanotechnology. The firm's technology, developed by oncologist and cancer researcher Dr. Tan Min-Han, focuses on blood sampling for late-stage lung, colon, and pancreatic cancer testing. This approach is less invasive, less painful, and yields results within a day instead of 10 days. Lucence has received significant funding, expanded its services to include genetic testing for cancer risk assessment, and has partnered with local and international organizations.

images.alt_text: Lucence founder Tan Min-Han said that the fresh capital will enable the startup to provide its liquid biopsy technology to more patients across Asia and North America.

site_title: Upper East Coast landed homes launch S$26m collective sale
summary: A group of neighbours in Singapore's Upper East Coast have launched a collective sale of their two semi-detached houses for S$26 million, or S$914 per sq ft. The 28,449 sq ft freehold site is zoned for mixed landed housing and can be redeveloped as various types of housing. The sale price is considered "palatable" by developers, and the tender closes on October 31. The site is located near two upcoming MRT stations and several primary schools, making it a desirable location for redevelopment.

images.alt_text: The two pairs of semi- detached houses in Jalan Haji Salam lie between the upcoming Bedok South and Sungei Bedok MRT stations.

site_title: PurpleClick paves the way for smarter digital marketing innovations
summary: PurpleClick Media, a digital market agency, is revolutionizing digital marketing with its performance-driven solutions, specializing in Search Engine Marketing (SEM) and Search Engine Optimization (SEO). The company has launched Digital-in-a-Box (DIAB), a marketing solution supported by Google, to help Small and Medium Enterprises (SMEs) launch e-commerce websites and digital marketing campaigns. PurpleClick is also exploring innovative technologies, such as Virtual Reality, to enhance customer experience and deliver better results for its clients.

site_title: Borrowing spike shows manufacturers in China stressed even before tariffs
summary: China's manufacturing sector is under stress before US tariffs are implemented, with corporate borrowing reaching 41% of firms, the highest since 2012. The sector's revenue and profit growth are declining, and the government's efforts to steer economic activity towards consumption may not be enough to mitigate the impact. Analysts warn that the situation will likely deteriorate if a trade deal is not reached, and the government may need to reverse its stance on fiscal deficit and monetary stimulus to address the economic slowdown.

site_title: Singapore investors are picking REITs over developers
summary: Singapore investors are shifting their focus to REITs over developers amid the recent cooling measures. Since July 5, REITs have outperformed developers, with the FTSE Straits Times REIT Index rising 0.7% and the developer benchmark declining 5.4%. Analysts attribute this shift to the cooling measures, which include stricter borrowing limits and increased buyer's stamp duty, expected to impact home sales and prices. REITs are seen as a safe haven and a better bet due to their commercial focus, with office and industrial trusts being top picks.

site_title: Woods ends five-year drought with Tour Championship win
summary: Tiger Woods won his first title in five years at the Tour Championship in Atlanta, capturing the event with a two-stroke victory. At 42, Woods led throughout the final round, finishing at 11-under-par 269, and moved within two victories of Sam Snead's all-time record of 82 PGA Tour titles. Woods' victory caps off a remarkable season, his first full season since spinal fusion surgery in 2017, and cements his status as the best frontrunner in golf history.

images.alt_text: Tiger Woods upon making a par on the 18th green to win the Tour Championship at East Lake Golf Club in Atlanta, Georgia on Sunday.

site_title: In London, electric trucks help UPS make 'eco-friendly' deliveries
summary: UPS has successfully converted a third of its diesel vehicles to electric power in London, with the goal of replacing them entirely. The company's central London fleet of 170 vehicles will be electrified, reducing CO2 emissions and air pollution. UPS has developed a "smart grid" system to manage charging vehicles, allowing it to spread out electricity demand throughout the night. The British government has provided £2.6 million (US$3.4 million) to support the project, which aims to make electric vehicles economically viable for businesses.

site_title: Indonesia has 2,000 banks, and eyes foreign firms for more mergers
summary: Indonesia, with 2,000 banks, is seeking foreign mergers to consolidate institutions due to a lack of experienced finance staff. The country's lenders have withstood the weakening rupiah, with capital adequacy ratios at 22% and nonperforming loans at 2.7%. Foreign firms, particularly Japanese banks, are showing interest, with Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group and Sumitomo Mitsui Financial Group announcing plans to acquire local banks. The government has warmed to the idea of foreign takeovers, and regulations now allow for foreign banks to invest up to 40% in local lenders.

site_title: Thin trading signals tough week ahead
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) ended 0.05% up, or 1.48 points, to finish at 3,219.16, touching a four-week high, despite thin trading due to the Mid-Autumn Festival. The Sino-US trade dispute continues to keep markets on tenterhooks, with both nations imposing fresh tariffs on each other. Investors worry that the trade war may enter "phase III", leading to potential market volatility, particularly if the US imposes further tariffs on Chinese imports.

site_title: Gripping vision of the future
summary: SODA Vision, a Singapore-based company, showcased a robotic bin picking technology at the TechInnovation event in Singapore, a collaboration with Photoneo. The machine uses a 3D scan to recognize objects and automate sorting without human intervention, saving time and costs. Founded in 2012, SODA Vision aims to develop more efficient technologies for the region's factories, reducing reliance on human labor. The company plans to further develop the technology, potentially incorporating 3D scanning and robotic arms for package sorting in the e-commerce and logistics industry.

images.alt_text: Eng Chin Jack of SODA Vision says the company has its robotic bin picking technologies ready to show at this year's TechInnovation. The application will showcase random bin picking technology without human intervention.

site_title: Changi Airport Group unit inks MOU for China projects
summary: Changi Airport Group's international arm, Changi Airports International, has signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) with Hunan Airport Management Group to cooperate on airport consultancy projects in China. The agreement aims to enhance Changsha Huanghua International Airport's passenger experience and develop a talent pipeline. Changi Airports International, with extensive experience in China, will provide consultancy services, customized training programs, and knowledge sharing platforms. The partnership marks Changi Airport Group's growing footprint in China, with the company having consulted in over 20 of the country's airports.

site_title: Architect defends vision for Bangkok Airport, says it's not a fire hazard
summary: Bangkok's Suvarnabhumi international airport plans to build a $1.3 billion terminal with extensive wooden cladding and a forested landscape, sparking concerns about fire risk. Architect Duangrit Bunnag defends the design, saying the structure will be covered in metal and treated with fire-resistant wood. The terminal aims to give travelers a unique Thai experience and is expected to boost annual passenger capacity by 30 million by 2021. Construction is set to start next year, with a tropical-forest landscape spanning 16,000 square meters between two buildings.

site_title: mm2 Asia: Overindulging can lead to indigestion
summary: mm2 Asia, a local movie producer, is undergoing a strategic review to enhance shareholder value after failing to acquire 50% of Golden Village's Singapore cinema business. The company aims to lift its corporate profile in North Asia and explore a foreign listing of its key assets. Despite having a cinema business with a 12.3% ebitda margin, mm2's cinemas did not generate efficient cash flow, and attendance has declined since 2015. The company plans to improve metrics in six to nine months and has appointed Haitong Securities as its financial adviser.

site_title: Harley is winning in Europe - without a trade war
summary: Harley-Davidson is experiencing significant success in Europe without a trade war, with the company almost doubling its market share in Germany to 6.4% in 2017. Despite US President Donald Trump's claims that European trade restrictions are to blame for American car companies' struggles, Harley-Davidson's success in Europe suggests that high-quality products can compete without a trade war. The company has tailored its products to European tastes, offering slimmer bikes and customization options, and has built a strong network of dealerships. In contrast, American car companies such as Cadillac and Chrysler have struggled to gain traction in the European market.

site_title: Rough waters for California's not-so-public beaches
summary: California's coastline is at the center of a battle over public access, with high-tech billionaire Vinod Khosla's efforts to limit access to his private beach, Privates Beach, and Martin's Beach, sparking concerns that it could set a bad precedent for the state's landmark 1976 Coastal Act. Khosla, a co-founder of Sun Microsystems, has taken the fight to the US Supreme Court, arguing that visitors produce litter, vandalize property, and are a nuisance. If successful, it could allow wealthy individuals to purchase land adjacent to the coast and turn public resources into private goods, according to surfers and advocacy groups.

site_title: KL says no to Malaysian property projects solely aimed at foreigners
summary: Malaysia's Finance Minister Lim Guan Eng announced that the government will no longer allow real estate developers to build projects solely for foreign buyers. The decision aims to benefit the country and its citizens, as townships built exclusively for foreigners do not contribute to the local economy. Foreigners are still allowed to buy and own properties in Malaysia, but the new policy seeks to promote more inclusive and equitable property development.

site_title: From lab work to impacting patients' lives
summary: Molecular biologist Yukti Choudhury, chief technology officer of Lucence Diagnostics, has transitioned from research-focused work to developing scalable technology that makes a difference in patients' lives. Her team uses next-generation DNA sequencing technology to enhance data analysis and improve data quality. Choudhury's work involves determining what genetic information is needed for specific tests and developing cost-effective methods. Lucence aims to harness the data gathered from its tests to make future discoveries and improve clinical purposes.

site_title: Revised corporate governance code principle-based
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore has issued a revised corporate governance code for companies listed on the Singapore Exchange, effective for financial years commencing January 1, 2019. The revised code, which underwent an 18-month process, aims to strengthen fundamentals and foster better communication and transparency between companies and shareholders. Key changes include a 50% reduction in page count, a new requirement for independent directors to make up at least one-third of the board, and a more principle-based approach to governance. The revised code also encourages companies to establish investor relations policies and dividend policies, and to consider the needs and interests of material stakeholders.

site_title: Tiny device makes huge advance for heart failure treatment
summary: Researchers have made a significant breakthrough in treating severe heart failure, with a tiny device called the MitraClip sharply reducing death rates and hospitalizations in patients. The device, which clips together the mitral valve, was found to improve blood flow and reduce symptoms in a large clinical trial. The results, published in The New England Journal of Medicine, show that patients who received the device had a significantly lower risk of death and hospitalization compared to those who received standard medical treatment. The device is expected to be approved by the FDA and is estimated to cost around $30,000, with insurers likely to cover it.

site_title: Trade war heats up as US, China lash out with biggest sets of tariffs yet
summary: The US and China have escalated their trade war with the largest sets of tariffs yet, with the US imposing levies on $200 billion in Chinese imports and China retaliating with tariffs on $60 billion in American goods. Neither side has shown signs of backing down, with no further trade talks scheduled to resolve the dispute. The tariffs, which could cost consumers up to 10% on goods such as food, clothing, and furniture, are expected to trigger layoffs across industries in both countries. Economists warn that the trade war could hinder China's economic progress and boost exports in overseas markets.

site_title: EU palm oil ban sows bitter seeds for S-E Asian farmers
summary: The European Parliament is set to ban the use of palm oil in biofuels by 2030, threatening the livelihoods of millions of small farmers in Indonesia and Malaysia, the world's top two palm oil producers. The ban could lead to retaliatory sanctions on European products, with Indonesian farmers warning that their livelihoods will be under attack. Environmentalists argue that the palm oil industry contributes to deforestation, climate change, and the destruction of indigenous communities. The move has sparked a diplomatic row, with Malaysian farmers denying that they are responsible for the environmental damage.

site_title: Proelect team crowned 2018 champions
summary: Proelect team crowned 2018 champions in The Business Times Corporate Golf League, defeating Team Boss by 9 points. Team captain Tan Lee Hong attributed their success to consistency and careful player selection. The team's strategy paid off, with all four players contributing well in the final leg, led by Eric Tan, David Soh, Lau Wing Cheok, and Tan Lee Hong. The win marked a milestone for the league, which will celebrate its 10th anniversary in 2019.

site_title: California urges Trump administration to drop fuel rule plan
summary: California's top air regulator, Mary Nichols, urged the Trump administration to drop a plan to freeze fuel efficiency standards through 2026, calling it a step backward in reducing emissions. The plan would also revoke California's authority to set its own emissions rules and mandate electric vehicle sales. California and 19 other states plan to challenge the rollback in court. The Trump administration claims the rules would save up to 12,700 lives, but Nichols dismissed these claims as "absurd and not supportable by fact."

site_title: Saudis set to triple mall space in Mecca by 2025
summary: Saudis plan to triple mall space in Mecca by 2025, addressing the city's under-served retail market due to plot shortages and high costs. The expansion aims to boost foreign pilgrims to 30 million per year by 2030, contributing to the kingdom's non-oil economy. Developers, including Jabal Omar and the kingdom's wealth fund, are investing heavily in the project, which is expected to generate US$2.1 billion annually. Spending by pilgrims during the Hajj season is projected to reach US$5.6 billion by 2022.

site_title: Singapore lab to work on big changes for commodity marts
summary: S&P Global Platts is setting up an innovation lab in Singapore to digitalize commodity markets, partnering with Enterprise Singapore to leverage blockchain, alternative data sets, and new computational methods. The lab aims to provide market participants with robust and timely information. This move reflects the long-term commitment to Singapore and aims to power the commodities markets of the future, with the goal of streamlining business processes and opening up access to financing.

site_title: Changing hands
summary: Singapore's NTT DC Reit's public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and operating loss similar to H1. London's Heathrow is considering fee hikes for its £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case. OCBC's incoming CEO, Tan Teck Long, is a former DBS veteran. The Monetary Authority of Singapore and the People's Bank of China agreed to deepen cooperation in green and transition finance. Singapore stocks rose for a 5th consecutive day ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Stock manipulators, beware the MAS AI arsenal
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) is enhancing its efforts to combat market manipulation through the use of machine-learning algorithms and data-analysis tools. The agency has developed a tool to detect syndicated market manipulation and is working on a "robo-expert" that can analyze trades and predict prosecution outcomes. The MAS has also published an enforcement monograph outlining its investigation and enforcement processes, including criteria for prioritizing cases and investigative powers. The move aims to improve detection and enforcement of market manipulation syndicates in Singapore's financial sector.

site_title: In pressing China on trade, Trump should embrace TPP, not tariffs
summary: US President Donald Trump's third round of tariffs on Chinese imports, set to take effect this week, aims to force China to change its commercial policy. The tariffs on $200 billion of Chinese goods will rise to 25% from 10%, with another $267 billion worth of goods at risk of tariffs if China retaliates. China's economic growth is slowing, while the US economy is expanding at its fastest pace since 2014. The tariffs have given the US more room to maneuver, with the US buying significantly more from China than vice versa.

site_title: Losing its lustre: The Golden Mile dilemma
summary: The Golden Mile Complex in Singapore, a post-independence national landmark, is facing a collective sale decision that could lead to its demolition. While most commercial unit owners support the sale, some residents, including a few long-time business owners, are unwilling to sell. Architects and historians hope the building will be conserved, citing its historical significance and cultural relevance. A potential win-win solution could involve voluntary conservation efforts, but a 100% consensus among owners is required. The government has expressed openness to exploring conservation options, and the building's revitalization has already begun with the emergence of creative entrepreneurs and businesses.

images.alt_text: The physical decline of Golden Mile Complex stems from its status as a strata-title leasehold property, which means that the building has hundreds of individual owners.

site_title: Trump's disdain has eroded the US's soft power and generated backlash
summary: US President Donald Trump's disdain for international organizations and treaties has eroded the country's soft power, sparking backlash worldwide. Trump's upcoming speech at the UN General Assembly and chairing of a Security Council meeting provide significant agenda-setting power, but his administration's withdrawal from various international bodies and refusal to sign key agreements have damaged US standing globally. A Pew Global poll found that three-quarters of surveyed countries have little or no confidence in Trump's global leadership, making him the least popular US president overseas in modern times.

site_title: US bourses can take a leaf from Singapore DCS framework: SEC commissioner
summary: US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) Commissioner Robert Jackson Jr. praises Singapore's dual-class share (DCS) framework for its safeguards, suggesting it could serve as a model for US stock markets. Jackson notes that Singapore's oversight and restrictions on DCS help mitigate corporate governance risks, whereas Hong Kong's approach limits the structure to the founder. He warns US exchanges against a "race to the bottom" and emphasizes the importance of oversight to protect minority shareholders, urging the US to follow Singapore's lead to prevent abuse of minority shareholders.

site_title: Oil jumps 2% as market tightens on US sanctions against Iran
summary: US sanctions on Iranian crude exports led to a 2% rise in oil prices, with Brent crude reaching its highest since May at $80.47 per barrel. Saudi Arabia ruled out immediate output increases, contributing to the market's tightening. Some traders forecast a potential spike in crude to $100 per barrel.

site_title: BIS sounds warning against high-risk, leveraged lending
summary: The Bank for International Settlements (BIS) has sounded a warning about high-risk, leveraged lending, citing a surge in debt and a decline in investor concerns about potential losses. Leveraged loans and high-yield bonds have doubled to $2.65 trillion since the financial crisis, with growth outpacing sales of securities. This trend has raised concerns about distress among indebted borrowers, which may affect the broader economy. The BIS warns that investors may be getting complacent about falling default rates and that covenant-lite lending, which waives protections for investors, is becoming increasingly common.

site_title: Chinese debt-laden builders' funding at risk in crackdown
summary: Chinese authorities consider scrapping pre-sales, a key funding source for debt-laden developers, to curb risk in the real estate market. The system allows developers to receive sale proceeds before construction is complete, fueling excessive investment and speculation. A potential overhaul could lead to a third of small developers disappearing and intensify funding pressure. Authorities aim to reduce the sector's high leverage and tackle financial risks, following a record $23 billion maturity wall in 2019.

site_title: Game-changing pact against illicit tobacco trade kicks in
summary: A global pact against the illicit tobacco trade took effect on Tuesday, aiming to eliminate health-hazardous and criminal activity. The World Health Organization calls it "game-changing," creating an international tracking and tracing system to halt tobacco smuggling and counterfeiting. The treaty seeks to combat widespread illicit tobacco trade, a major public health concern.

site_title: India pledges action as default worries rock its markets
summary: India's government has pledged to support financial markets amid growing concerns of defaults by shadow banks. Finance Minister Arun Jaitley announced the provision of adequate liquidity to mutual funds and non-bank financial companies. The move comes after Infrastructure Leasing & Financial Services Ltd missed debt payments, rattling investors. Analysts warn that India's shadow banking sector could face a cash crunch, and the Reserve Bank of India may conduct open market bond purchases to add liquidity. The government aims to calm investors' nerves and prevent a spiral of defaults.

site_title: Market abuzz over ownership of Keppel T&T, M1
summary: Keppel Corp is considering a potential transaction involving its stake in Keppel T&T, its logistics and data centre arm, and Singapore Press Holdings' (SPH) stake in M1, Singapore's third-largest telco. Analysts predict that Keppel Corp may privatise Keppel T&T and sell its stake in M1, citing low valuations and potential for growth in data centres and logistics businesses. The conglomerate has asked SPH to participate in the possible transaction, with some analysts suggesting that Malaysian telco Axiata Group could be a potential buyer.

site_title: Hong Kong's surging dollar sends warning on housing market
summary: Hong Kong's currency surged 0.6% last Friday, its largest gain in 15 years, due to concerns that borrowing costs will catch up with US rates as the Federal Reserve hikes interest rates. This may signal the end of a decade-long liquidity party and a reversal in the city's housing market, where home prices have risen over 170% in the past decade. Experts warn that rising prime rates will bring pressure to the property market and leveraged home buyers, potentially leading to a decline in demand.

site_title: Dollar erases early gains, extends 2-week losing streak
summary: The US dollar slipped 0.2% to 94.07 against a basket of rivals, extending a 2-week losing streak, as investors awaited a US interest rate hike this week. Despite earlier gains, the dollar rally is seen as needing fresh legs, with analysts citing only strong data as a potential change to bets on further rate hikes. Speculators have increased bets on the dollar, with net speculative long positions reaching $25 billion, while the euro rose 0.2% and the pound gained 0.7% against the dollar.

site_title: Keppel-KBS US Reit hunkers down in Seattle with 3rd asset
summary: Keppel-KBS US Reit has agreed to acquire the Westpark Portfolio in Seattle for US$169.4 million, its third asset in the area. The portfolio, comprising 21 freehold buildings, has a 97.7% occupancy rate and a weighted average lease expiry of 4.3 years. The acquisition is expected to increase the Reit's aggregate valuation by 20.8% to US$985.5 million and its net lettable area by 24.2% to over 4 million square feet. The deal is expected to be yield accretive and benefit from steady rent growth in the Seattle office market.

site_title: How Singapore's food industry is shaking things up
summary: Singapore's food industry is experiencing a surge in innovation, driven by growing demand for healthier options and eco-friendly packaging. Despite its limited landmass and agricultural output, the industry contributes $4.3 billion to Singapore's GDP and employs over 48,000 workers. Multinational companies have chosen Singapore as their Asia-Pacific headquarters due to its strong food safety and quality reputation, as well as its thriving innovation climate. Food producers are embracing trends such as plant-based proteins, sugar alternatives, and texture-modified foods, with initiatives like FoodInnovate and the High Pressure Processing Resource Sharing Facility supporting innovation and collaboration.

site_title: Najib's brother to step down as chairman of CIMB
summary: NAZIR Razak, brother of Malaysia's former prime minister Najib Razak, is stepping down as chairman of CIMB Group Holdings Bhd by the end of this year. After 29 years, Razak cited the need to pursue other opportunities, particularly in Asean integration. The bank's succession plan will be activated to pick its next chairman, with the goal of finalizing its strategic blueprint before his departure. Razak may focus on a private equity fund, Ikhlas Capital, which he recently set up.

site_title: Hopes of higher offer price for Wheelock Properties (S) crushed
summary: Wheelock Properties' parent company, Wheelock and Co, has locked in its offer price of S$2.10 a share, crushing hopes of a higher offer price. The counter fell 3.23% to S$2.10, with the offer remaining open for one more week until Oct 2. If the offeror fails to win over enough minority shareholders, long-term investors may consider waiting or holding out for another buyout attempt. Analysts estimate that up to half of retail shareholders have taken profit, and institutional investors may be left holding the baby due to higher investment and holding costs.

site_title: Sirius to acquire Pandora in $3.5 billion online radio deal
summary: Sirius XM Holdings Inc is acquiring Pandora Media Inc in a $3.5 billion all-stock deal, giving the satellite-radio operator an online-music service to compete with Spotify Technology SA. The acquisition values Pandora at $10.14 a share, 12% higher than the closing price on Friday. Sirius XM will expand its audience beyond satellite radio and optimize cross-promotion across platforms, with CEO Jim Meyer seeing the biggest opportunity in this area. The deal is expected to be completed in the first quarter of next year, with a breakup fee of $52.5 million if Pandora takes a superior proposal.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed 10.47 points lower on Monday at 1,800.17, with volume reaching 1.6 billion lots worth RM1.5 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 530 to 304.

site_title: Why the US will lose this trade war with China
summary: The US cannot win its tariff war with China, according to experts. Despite President Donald Trump's confidence in the US economy's strength, China's vast market and growing economy give it an advantage. China has already shown resilience to US tariffs, and its Belt and Road Initiative provides an alternative to Western trade. The US may try to limit China's rise, but China's strategic objectives and economic might make it difficult for the US to prevail in the trade war. China's global influence and market size make it a formidable opponent in the conflict.

site_title: H&M accused of failing to ensure fair wages for global factory workers
summary: H&M, the world's second-largest fashion retailer, is accused of failing to ensure fair wages for its global factory workers, with many employees forced to work excessive hours to survive. A report by the Clean Clothes Campaign found that workers in H&M supplier factories in Bulgaria, Turkey, India, and Cambodia earn less than half the estimated living wage, with some workers being paid below the minimum wage for overtime hours. The company has not met its 2013 commitment to pay a living wage to 850,000 textile workers by 2018, prompting campaigners to urge H&M to take immediate action to stop poverty wages and workers' rights violations.

site_title: Google looking to future after 20 years of search
summary: Google celebrated its 20th anniversary, marking two decades of growth from a simple search engine to a ubiquitous part of daily life. Founded by Larry Page and Sergey Brin, Google has expanded into various offerings such as Maps, Gmail, and Android, and has become a major player in artificial intelligence. Despite efforts to diversify, Google still generates most of its revenue from online ads, and has faced regulatory scrutiny over concerns about data privacy and misinformation. The company has also made significant investments in emerging technologies like self-driving cars and high-altitude balloons.

site_title: Volkswagen's Porsche drops diesel in push for electric car
summary: Porsche, a unit of Volkswagen, announced it will stop offering diesel versions of its cars, shifting focus to hybrid and battery-powered vehicles. The decision comes as the company faces criticism over its handling of the diesel crisis and its image. Porsche CEO Oliver Blume stated that while diesel is an important technology, the company aims to be diesel-free, citing declining demand and a need to invest in electric mobility. The move is part of Porsche's $9.71 billion investment in electric vehicles by 2022.

images.alt_text: A diesel version of the Porsche Cayenne. Porsche has sold diesel versions of its cars for nearly 10 years. But next year, it will launch the Taycan, which it says is its first fully-electric sports car.

site_title: DBS sets sights on China for debt capital markets blitz
summary: DBS Group Holdings, the largest lender in South-east Asia, is expanding its debt capital market business in China to attract more first-time bond issuers to the offshore market. The bank has set up a debt capital market product and advisory team in China, focusing on getting local clients. DBS expects China's debt financing needs to continue growing, driven by factors such as rising bank capital and infrastructure financing. The move aims to bring the bank closer to Chinese firms and capitalize on China's demand for foreign funding amid a deleveraging campaign.

images.alt_text: DBS Group Holdings, South-east Asia's largest lender, is expanding its fixed-income business in China in a bid to bring more first-time bond issuers to the offshore market.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: CapitaLand maintains a "buy" rating with a target price of S$4.00, citing its capital recycling efforts and asset mix diversification. The company's recent US multi-family asset acquisitions are expected to boost recurring income. Raffles Medical Group also received a "buy" rating, as its collaboration with China Taiping Insurance Group enhances its healthcare offerings and strategic positioning. Both companies' share prices are well-supported by buybacks and dividend yields remain attractive.

site_title: Tuan Sing buys stake in mixed development on Hainan island
summary: Singaporean company Tuan Sing Holdings has purchased a 7.8% stake in Sanya Summer Real Estate in Hainan, China, for S$15 million. The mixed-use project, valued at 1.6 billion yuan, will feature commercial, residential, hotel, and retail components, and is expected to be completed by end-2021. Tuan Sing aims to increase its stake in the project, with the option to do so through a subsidiary. The company has also secured a S$20 million loan to fund the acquisition.

site_title: Cosby back in court Monday for start of sentencing
summary: Bill Cosby, the 81-year-old US television icon, returned to court in Pennsylvania on Monday for sentencing after being convicted of drugging and molesting Andrea Constand at his Philadelphia mansion in 2004. He faces a maximum 30-year sentence, with prosecutors seeking prison time and his lawyers arguing for house arrest due to his frailty. The first celebrity sentenced for a sex crime since Harvey Weinstein, Cosby maintains his innocence and risks becoming one of the most famous Americans sent to prison.

site_title: Come to pray, stop to shop, Saudis set to triple malls in Mecca
summary: Saudi Arabia plans to triple the number of shopping malls in Mecca by 2025, with a total of 804,000 square meters of space. The move is part of the government's plan to boost foreign pilgrims to 30 million per year by 2030, generating significant revenue from non-oil sources. Developers and retailers are investing heavily, with companies like Jabal Omar Development Co. and the Saudi wealth fund contributing billions of dollars to the project. Spending by pilgrims during the Hajj season is expected to reach $5.6 billion by 2022.

site_title: British, EU airlines could see flights grounded in no-deal Brexit
summary: British and EU airlines may face flight disruptions if the UK leaves the EU without a divorce deal, with automatic flying rights potentially lost. The UK and EU's "Open Skies" agreements, covering flights within the EU, to and from the US, and between the two, would no longer be in effect if no deal is reached by March 2019. This could lead to flights being grounded, affecting thousands of passengers and airlines.

site_title: Maybank Singapore raises S$500,000 for President's Challenge
summary: Maybank Singapore raised S$500,000 for the President's Challenge 2018 at its Global Corporate Responsibility Day at the Marina Barrage. The event, held for the ninth time, featured 20 carnival booths set up by Maybank employees to promote social causes and raise funds. The bank's CEO, John Lee, presented the cheque to Speaker of Parliament Tan Chuan Jin, who was the guest of honour. This year, over 20,000 Maybank employees globally participated in the event, which also included a charity carnival and night walk.

images.alt_text: Guest of honour for the Global CR Day, Speaker of Parliament and adviser to the Community Chest,Tan Chuan Jin (third from right), was presented the cheque by Maybank's country CEO John Lee (fourth from right) and his team.

site_title: Rosenstein resigns after reports he considered taping Trump, source says
summary: Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein has verbally resigned to White House Chief of Staff John Kelly, reportedly due to his suggestion to secretly record conversations with President Donald Trump. The resignation comes after reports that Rosenstein discussed invoking the 25th Amendment and potential covert taping of Trump. The move has significant implications for the Russia investigation led by Special Counsel Robert Mueller. Senate leaders warn against using the report to fire Rosenstein and interfere with the investigation, and Solicitor General Noel Francisco could potentially assume control of the investigation.

site_title: GE aspires to be a force in Europe's offshore wind market
summary: General Electric (GE) is expanding its presence in the European offshore wind market, aiming to become a major player. The company is investing $400 million in research and development to build a new turbine, the Haliade X, which is expected to be capable of generating 12 megawatts of power. The turbine's design and construction are being done at a factory in France, and GE hopes to begin shipping it in the next decade. With advances in technology and decreasing costs, offshore wind power is becoming increasingly competitive with fossil fuels, and GE's entry into the market is seen as a significant move to capitalize on this trend.

site_title: Michael Kors is close to buying Versace for US$2b
summary: Michael Kors Holdings Ltd is nearing a deal to buy Versace SpA for approximately US$2 billion, according to people familiar with the plans. Donatella Versace, the company's creative director, will continue to have a role under the agreement. Blackstone Group LP, which owns 20% of Versace, plans to sell its stake in the deal. The Italian fashion house, known for its baroque designs, had been working towards an initial public offering but market conditions have hindered progress. The Versace family will retain 80% ownership under the agreement.

site_title: US: Wall St opens lower on trade woes, tech drop
summary: US stocks opened lower on Monday, led by declines in technology stocks, amid the latest round of US-China tariffs. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.14%, the S&P 500 dropped 0.27%, and the Nasdaq Composite fell 0.60%. The US-China trade tensions continue to weigh on the markets, with investors seeking stability despite a recent edge to fresh records for the S&P 500 and Nasdaq.

site_title: North Korea looking for investments, from South, says business chief
summary: North Korea is seeking investments from South Korean companies to modernize the country, according to Sohn Kyung Shik, co-chairman of CJ Group. Following last week's summit between Kim Jong Un and Moon Jae-in, North Korea wants economic cooperation and technical assistance, with a focus on investments to set up industries. Despite optimism, hurdles remain due to ongoing war and UN sanctions. Key players, including Samsung Group and LG Group, have expressed interest in North Korea's food and logistics industries, with a potential meeting to discuss steps towards denuclearization and economic projects.

site_title: Kavanaugh-Ford clash to weigh on midterms
summary: The sexual assault claims of Prof Christine Blasey Ford against Supreme Court nominee Brett Kavanaugh in the #MeToo era could significantly impact the 2018 midterms. Ford, who moved to Washington, DC 27 years ago, is sharing her experience of being sexually assaulted by Kavanaugh in high school. This echoes the 1991 Anita Hill-Clarence Thomas hearings, highlighting a long-standing issue in the Supreme Court confirmation process. The controversy could deal a blow to the Republican party ahead of the midterms, with many expecting a shift in the balance of power in Congress.

site_title: S$13m fines for Grab, Uber, and a market share debate
summary: The Competition and Consumer Commission of Singapore (CCCS) has fined Grab and Uber S$13 million for their merger, with Uber paying S$6.58 million and Grab S$6.42 million. The CCCS has set a 30% market share threshold for a new player to lift restrictions on Grab, sparking debate on its fairness. Industry watchers argue the bar is too high, while Go-Jek, a well-funded Indonesia-based ride-hailing platform, welcomes the move, saying it will have a significant impact on the Singapore market.

images.alt_text: The Competition and Consumer Commission of Singapore (CCCS) on Monday slapped fines of S$13 million on Grab and Uber for their merger, and immediately sparked a debate on whether it set a fair condition for lifting all curbs on Grab.

site_title: FSL Trust's manager and ex-CEO reach settlement over legal spat
summary: FSL Trust Management has settled a legal suit against its former CEO, Alan Hatton, alleging he breached his duties. The parties have withdrawn all allegations, bringing an end to the dispute. The terms of the settlement were not disclosed. This follows a counterclaim filed by Hatton. The resolution marks a positive outcome for FSL Trust Management.

site_title: Trump says he will have second meeting with North Korea's Kim Jong Un 'quite soon'
summary: US President Donald Trump announced he will have a second meeting with North Korean leader Kim Jong Un "quite soon," expressing optimism about denuclearization talks. Trump said the talks are "moving very well" despite growing concerns over North Korea's nuclear advancements. The president's remarks mark a shift in tone, following a year of warning North Korea over its nuclear program. Trump cited a letter from Kim requesting a second meeting, and noted that the two sides are making "tremendous progress."

site_title: Siemens to cut 2,900 German jobs as part of 500m euro cost-saving plan
summary: Siemens to cut 2,900 German jobs as part of a 500 million euro cost-saving plan. The restructuring aims to boost competitiveness in the Power and Gas division and the Process Industries and Drives division. The company will achieve 270 million euros in efficiency gains, down from the initially announced 3,400 jobs. Sites in Goerlitz and Berlin will continue operations, while a site in Leipzig will be sold, and another in Erfurt will be restructured. This move follows Siemens' broader effort to slim down its conglomerate structure.

site_title: Suntec Reit's manager hires CapitaLand veteran as COO
summary: Suntec Reit's manager has appointed Dawn Lai, a veteran from CapitaLand, as chief operating officer, effective October 1, 2018. Lai, with over 30 years of experience, was previously head of global marketing and leasing at CapitaLand Commercial Management, overseeing prime Grade A offices in Singapore. She will assist the CEO on operational matters, including asset management, investment, and strategic planning.

site_title: Singapore shares close flat on Monday
summary: Singapore stocks finished flat on Monday, with the Straits Times Index adding 0.05% to 3,219.16. Losers outnumbered gainers 212 to 165, with 1.05 billion shares changing hands. Notable movers included Rex International, Nico Steel, and ThaiBev, with DBS Group Holdings and OCBC Bank also showing slight changes.

site_title: Swedish PM Lofven faces ouster on Tuesday with no clear government in waiting
summary: Swedish Prime Minister Stefan Lovfen faces a confidence vote in parliament on Tuesday, with no clear indication of who will replace him after an inconclusive election. The Social Democrat bloc holds 144 seats, one more than the centre-right Alliance, while the far-right Sweden Democrats, with 62 seats, are expected to side with the Alliance to remove Lofven. A new government may take weeks or months to form, and analysts say a fresh election is possible if no cooperation between mainstream blocs can be reached.

site_title: India reassures equity investors as liquidity fears grow
summary: Indian Finance Minister Arun Jaitley assured equity investors that the government will ensure credit is available to non-banking financial companies (NBFCs), amid growing liquidity fears. The reassurance came after a large fund manager sold short-term bonds issued by Dewan Housing Finance Corp at a sharp discount, sparking concerns of a wider liquidity problem among NBFCs. The government, Reserve Bank of India, and Securities and Exchange Board of India have sought to calm investors, with the benchmark Nifty Index recovering from a sharp decline on Friday.

site_title: CIMB chairman Nazir Razak to step down
summary: CIMB Group Holdings Bhd Chairman Nazir Razak, the brother of former Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak, will step down by the end of the year after nearly three decades at the bank. Nazir, 52, led CIMB's growth through rapid acquisitions and a strong presence in Southeast Asia. He will leave on completion of the bank's four-year recalibration plan, launched in 2014, and will continue to work in the region following his departure. This move comes amid a management shake-up at Malaysian companies following the general election.

images.alt_text: CIMB Group Holdings Bhd Chairman Nazir Razak is to step down by the end of the year after almost three decades at Malaysia's second biggest bank, he said on Monday.

site_title: European investors are hungry for a taste of pot stocks
summary: European investors are increasingly interested in the Canadian cannabis market, driven by the country's full legalization of recreational weed in October 2018. Canadian cannabis-related stocks have seen significant growth, with projected annual sales of $40 billion. Experts predict that a full European market legalization could generate annual sales of $25 billion, with potential for even higher figures. Short sellers are already targeting Canadian weed stocks, fueling concerns of a bubble.

site_title: ECB's Draghi sees vigorous pickup in core Euro-area inflation
summary: ECB President Mario Draghi expects a "relatively vigorous" pickup in underlying euro-area inflation, signaling potential interest rate hikes in late 2019. Despite a projected 1.7% average annual headline consumer-price growth, Draghi notes underlying inflation will increase further due to a tightening labor market and rising wage growth.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks sink on new trade frictions
summary: Hong Kong shares fell 1.62% on Monday after the US imposed tariffs on $200 billion of Chinese imports and Beijing cancelled planned talks between the two sides. The Hang Seng Index closed at 27,499.39, marking a 454.19-point decline. Mainland Chinese markets were closed for a public holiday. The US move and cancelled talks heightened trade frictions between the two countries.

site_title: UK's Raab says confident of clinching a Brexit deal
summary: UK Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab expressed confidence in clinching a Brexit deal with the EU, stating they will negotiate in good faith and get the best deal possible. Prime Minister Theresa May had previously said Brexit talks had hit an impasse, but Raab remained optimistic, emphasizing the UK's determination to move forward. He also defended the government's approach, saying they won't throw their toys out the pram and will hold their nerve.

site_title: PODCAST: How SMEs can use cryptocurrencies to raise capital (Money Hacks, Ep 22)
summary: A podcast episode, "Money Hacks Ep 22 - How SMEs can use cryptocurrencies to raise capital," was published on September 24, 2018. The episode discusses how small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) can use cryptocurrencies to raise capital, but no specific details or events are mentioned from the article.

site_title: 'Dramatic' slide in sentiment seen hitting Hong Kong home prices
summary: Hong Kong home prices are expected to decline over the next three months and then stagnate, according to a Royal Institute of Chartered Surveyors survey. Buyer demand fell in August for the first time in two years, citing concerns over a potential increase in the prime rate. Despite this, the survey predicted a 0.2% decline in home prices over the next year, including a 0.9% fall on Hong Kong Island. The market's cooling sentiment is attributed to factors such as trade wars, higher borrowing costs, and dear valuations.

site_title: Green loan behind plush tower with its own park and roof gardens
summary: Singapore-based Frasers Property has raised a S$1.2 billion green loan, the first of its kind by a South-east Asian borrower under principles set by Asia Pacific Loan Market Association. The facility refinances existing loans tied to Frasers Tower, an energy-efficient office with its own park and podium roof gardens. This deal follows similar green and sustainability-linked loans in Hong Kong and Singapore, with lenders seeking to capitalize on strong financial performance in green buildings and renewable energy. The move aims to address pollution and congestion caused by rapid urbanization.

images.alt_text: Singapore-based Frasers Property raised a S$1.2 billion green loan, the first of its kind by a South-east Asian borrower under principles set by Asia Pacific Loan Market Association (APLMA) in March that aim to standardise disclosure. The facility refinances existing loans tied to Frasers Tower (seen here in an artist's impression).

site_title: Global advertising expenditure to grow 4.5 per cent in 2018: Zenith
summary: Global advertising expenditure is predicted to reach $581 billion by the end of 2018, growing 4.5% from 2017, according to Zenith. Most of the growth will come from sponsored content in search engines and social media ads, with paid search and social media ads driving 67% of the growth. The UK ad market is expected to grow 2.4% in 2018, with the country remaining the fourth-largest ad market by 2020, according to Zenith's revised forecast.

site_title: Danske executive bonuses at stake as bank explores all options
summary: Danske Bank A/S is exploring options to claw back bonuses for executives, including CEO Thomas Borgen, amid a money laundering scandal. Borgen left the bank with 12 months' pay despite failing to address signs of dirty money. The bank's head of human resources, Henriette Fenger Ellekrog, says they are looking into claw-back possibilities. Borgen's 2017 total pay was 15.4 million kroner ($2.4 million). The move comes as indignation mounts over the decision to let Borgen leave with a significant payout.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's Competition and Consumer Commission fined Uber and Grab over S$13 million for their merger. The fine consists of S$6.58 million for Uber and S$6.42 million for Grab. Meanwhile, Singapore's inflation remained steady at 0.7% in August, with core inflation rising 1.9%. Additionally, properties in the Upper East Coast and nine HDB shops in mature estates are up for sale. Keppel Corp is exploring a potential transaction involving its stake in Keppel T&T and M1 stake with SPH.

site_title: Yoma Strategic ties up with Myanmar partner in heavy equipment financing
summary: Yoma Strategic's subsidiary Yoma Fleet has partnered with Myan Shwe Pyi Tractors (MSP CAT) in Myanmar, providing financing for heavy equipment and supporting the retail and rental business of the authorized Caterpillar dealer. Yoma Fleet will initially finance $7 million worth of equipment and become the preferred financing partner. This partnership aims to capitalize on Myanmar's infrastructure development needs, with plans to allocate $21.4 billion to rail, road, port, and aviation projects by 2030. The partnership is expected to provide scalable financial returns for Yoma Financial Services.

site_title: Home modems, routers hit by US China tariffs as 'smart' tech goods escape
summary: US tariffs targeting $200 billion worth of Chinese goods have hit home modems, routers, and internet gateways, excluding high-profile consumer tech items like smart watches and speakers. The 10% tariffs are expected to impact billions of dollars in these products, including those designed for home use, creating a two-tiered tariff structure for consumer internet. Consumer tech industry officials and the US Customs and Border Protection agency say the move will make internet access more expensive for consumers, with costs passed on to mobile plans and connected devices.

site_title: Blackstone plans 7 per cent yield for India's first REIT IPO
summary: Blackstone Group LP and its Indian partner, Embassy Group, plan to offer India's first real estate investment trust (REIT) with an annual yield of around 6.5-7% and a total return of 14-16%. The REIT will hold over 300 billion rupees of assets, including 33 million square feet of real estate. The firms aim to raise approximately 52.5 billion rupees through the IPO, which will be marketed with a greenshoe option to boost the size of the offering.

site_title: Seeking America's quietest spots: the quest for silence in a loud world
summary: In a quest for silence, some wilderness lovers are traveling to remote areas in search of quiet spots, despite increasing noise pollution in national parks and other protected land. Researchers have found that noise pollution is doubling sound levels in these areas, posing a threat to animals that rely on hearing to survive. Efforts to regulate noise are underway, including measures at national parks and monuments, but opposition from industry groups and tourism interests has hindered progress. Individuals like Dennis Follensbee, a programmer who has mapped 23 quiet places in New Hampshire's White Mountains, are searching for areas without man-made noise, wind, or rushing water.

site_title: Dubai developer Nakheel plans sukuk sale, mall financing - sources
summary: Dubai developer Nakheel plans to raise a loan for a new mall and issue US dollar-denominated sukuk bonds, sources say. The company is working with a group of banks, led by Emirates NBD, to secure a 4 billion dirham loan for the mall project. Nakheel is also planning to issue sukuk bonds, which could be sold in the next few months. The company's previous debt restructuring was a result of Dubai's real estate crash at the turn of the decade. The mall project, worth 6.1 billion dirhams, is expected to be completed by 2021.

site_title: Stratech announcement on court orders of winding-up, appointment of liquidators done without approval: BDO
summary: BDO, the appointed liquidators of Stratech Group, stated that the company's winding-up announcement and liquidator appointment were carried out without their prior written approval and knowledge. Stratech's directors, Chew Khien Meow David and Leong Sook Ching, no longer have authority to act on behalf of the company without liquidators' consent. BDO is reviewing the company's books and records, and transactions entered without consent may not be recognized or binding. Trading in Stratech's shares remains suspended.

site_title: Seoul: Financial markets closed on Monday
summary: South Korean financial markets closed on Monday due to a public holiday, resuming trade on Thursday, Sept 27. Meanwhile, in other markets, Singapore stocks rallied for a 5th consecutive day ahead of GDP data, and Asia traders remained optimistic despite US President Trump's new threats. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged to fresh records in the US, despite tariff uncertainty, and eSIM platform Airalo raised $220 million in new funding, lifting its valuation to over $1 billion.

site_title: Volkswagen's Porsche drops diesel in electric car push
summary: Porsche, a unit of Volkswagen, has announced it will stop offering diesel versions of its cars, shifting its focus to hybrid and battery-powered vehicles. The decision comes after Volkswagen admitted to deliberately cheating diesel emissions tests, leading to a sector-wide crackdown on polluting diesel engines. Porsche, which is investing heavily in electric mobility, cited declining demand for diesel models and a desire to be diesel-free. The company will continue to serve existing diesel customers and will launch its first fully-electric sports car, the Taycan, next year.

site_title: World still waiting for wages boost despite stronger economy: Hays
summary: A global economy report by Hays and Oxford Economics found that wage growth remains elusive despite a robust economy, with weak productivity growth hindering wage increases. A skills shortage is prevalent across 33 countries, with Japan, the US, and major European economies showing significant disparities. The Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development predicts 1.1-1.4% growth in economic output per worker, short of its pre-financial crisis average. The report concludes that a meaningful wage boost is unlikely in the near future.

site_title: Worst liquidity crunch in two years spooks Indian financiers
summary: India is experiencing its worst liquidity crunch in over two years, sparking refinancing risks for shadow banks and non-bank lenders. A debt crisis at Infrastructure Leasing & Financial Services Ltd has increased borrowing costs, exacerbating a cash deficit of 1.4 trillion rupees. The crisis is also affecting corporate tax payments, which had already reduced liquidity in the financial system. The government has vowed support for financial markets, but worsening sentiment could hinder Prime Minister Narendra Modi's efforts to boost the country's economy. Non-bank lenders face significant refinancing risks.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Monday afternoon at 3,230.26, up 0.4%
summary: Singapore stocks resumed trading Monday at 3,230.26, up 0.4% on the Straits Times Index. The most actively traded counters included Nico Steel and Wheelock Properties. Losers outnumbered gainers 165 to 133, with 587 million shares changing hands. This follows a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data release.

site_title: In London, electric trucks are helping UPS make 'eco-friendly' deliveries
summary: UPS is testing electric trucks in London as part of a plan to electrify its central London fleet of 170 vehicles. The trucks, which have been spotted in the Kentish Town area, are part of a British government-backed initiative to reduce the company's carbon footprint. Drivers report that the electric vehicles draw comments from passers-by, with some questioning how a large vehicle can be electric. The move is seen as a step towards a more eco-friendly delivery service.

images.alt_text: A fleet of electric UPS trucks in London. The company plans to electrify its full central London fleet of about 170 vehicles.

site_title: Fastest-growing destinations in Europe
summary: The fastest-growing destinations in Europe, according to the UN World Tourism Organization, include Armenia (18.65% year-on-year growth), Bosnia and Herzegovina (18.66%), the Republic of Moldova (19.6%), Azerbaijan (20%), Macedonia (23.5%), Iceland (24.11%), Turkey (24.14%), Israel (24.6%), Georgia (27.9%), and San Marino (31.1%). These destinations offer a mix of cultural richness, natural beauty, and accessibility, making them attractive to travelers looking for off-the-beaten-path experiences.

site_title: Stable leadership transition critical to country's businesses and economy: Shanmugam
summary: Law and Home Affairs Minister K Shanmugam emphasized the importance of stable leadership transition for businesses and the economy in a small country like Singapore. He noted that reliable leadership can address social mobility and inequality while avoiding populism's negative impact. US Securities and Exchange Commission Commissioner Robert Jackson Jr also highlighted the need for exchanges to oversee dual-class shares.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Mind Your Business - Disrupting the video production industry
summary: The Money FM podcast "Mind Your Business" discusses the disruption in the video production industry. Key points include the rise of new technologies and platforms changing the way content is created and consumed. The podcast also touches on the impact of these changes on traditional video production companies. No further details are available in the provided article content.

site_title: With new blood test, Roche dives deeper into personal cancer care
summary: Swiss drugmaker Roche has launched a new blood test, FoundationOne Liquid, to identify common gene mutations in solid tumors from a patient's blood. The test can identify 70 of the most commonly mutated genes and may help identify patients most likely to benefit from cancer immunotherapy. Roche is investing in personalized cancer treatment and has spent $2.4 billion on US-based genetic profiling company Foundation Medicine. The test is expected to guide oncologists in treating tumors that vary by patient, regardless of which firm's drug they choose to use.

site_title: S&P Global Platts investing in Singapore innovation lab to drive digitalisation of commodity markets
summary: S&P Global Platts is establishing an innovation lab in Singapore to drive the digitalisation of commodity markets. The lab will collaborate with market participants to explore blockchain, alternative data sets, and computational methods to trade and risk-manage commodity portfolios. The goal is to provide robust and timely information, starting with digitally capturing oil inventory data.
