The lab will work with government agency Enterprise Singapore to develop and deploy innovative solutions, with the potential to benefit startups in the energy industry through grooming and mentorship.

site_title: Europe: Trade war dents European shares
summary: Europe's stock markets declined on Monday due to the US-China trade war, with the STOXX 600 falling 0.1% and Germany's DAX down 0.3%. Autos and mining sectors were hit hardest, with shares falling 0.8-0.9%. Meanwhile, Sky shares jumped 8.6% after Comcast's successful auction bid. The decline in European markets broke their longest winning streak since 1997, with dealmaking driving the greatest moves across sectors.

site_title: Retailer Casino says it rejected Carrefour approach, which Carrefour denies
summary: French supermarket retailer Casino rejected an approach from rival Carrefour due to regulatory hurdles, the company stated. Casino expressed confidence in its strategy despite the potential tie-up. However, Carrefour denied the rejection, suggesting it had made an approach. The decision comes amid concerns over Casino's debt, which has impacted its shares. Regulatory challenges and market dominance issues were cited as reasons for the rejection.

site_title: Hong Kong bans pro-independence party over 'national security' fears
summary: Hong Kong banned the pro-independence Hong Kong National Party (HKNP) on Monday, citing national security concerns. The ban, the first on a political party since Hong Kong's return to China in 1997, comes amid Beijing's increasing pressure on dissent. The party's leader, Andy Chan, had advocated for Hong Kong's independence, while the government claimed the party had spread "hatred and discrimination" against mainland Chinese people. Human Rights Watch described the ban as a "milestone in the assault on Hong Kong's freedoms."

site_title: Google looking to future after 20 years of search
summary: Google is celebrating its 20th anniversary, marking two decades since its founding by Larry Page and Sergey Brin as a better way to explore the internet. The company has grown into a search engine woven into daily life, with a range of offerings including Maps, Gmail, and Android. Despite efforts to diversify, Google still generates most of its revenue from online ads, raising concerns about data privacy and the spread of misinformation. The company has also faced regulatory scrutiny and criticism from US President Donald Trump, who claims conservative viewpoints are downplayed in search results.

images.alt_text: Google celebrated its 20th birthday Monday, marking two decades in which it has grown from simply a better way to explore the internet to a search engine so woven into daily life its name has become a verb.

site_title: Asia: Markets fall on new trade worries in thinned business
summary: Asian markets fell on Monday due to fresh trade worries, with Hong Kong leading the sell-off after China pulled out of planned talks with the US. The US prepared to impose 10% duties on $200 billion of Chinese goods, while China lined up $60 billion in imports in retaliation. Low trading volumes and uncertainty amid the trade standoff contributed to the decline, with Tokyo, Shanghai, and other markets closed for public holidays.

site_title: Nine HDB shops in mature estates go on sale for S$34m
summary: Nine HDB commercial units in mature estates are up for sale with a guide price of S$34 million. The ground-floor units range from 581 to 2,776 sq ft and are fully tenanted. They may appeal to family offices, private equity funds, real estate funds, and high net worth individuals, as well as end-users looking to operate small businesses. It is rare for an HDB commercial portfolio in mature estates to be available for sale, with only about 8,500 HDB shophouses that can be resold on the private market.

site_title: Australian shares end lower as materials, financials falter; a2 Milk drags NZ
summary: Australian shares ended lower on Monday, falling 0.1% or 7.70 points to 6,186.90, due to a decline in materials stocks and financials. Lower commodities prices hit mining stocks, with Rio Tinto and South32 Ltd falling 1.2% and 1.3% respectively. Banks and insurers also slid, hurt by damaging testimony from a quasi-judicial inquiry into wrongdoing in the financial sector. In New Zealand, the S&P/NZX 50 index fell 0.4% due to a slump in a2 Milk Company Ltd, which fell 5.4%.

site_title: Singapore's inflation steady in August at 0.7%, in line with expectations
summary: Singapore's inflation rate remained steady at 0.7% in August, in line with expectations. Accommodation costs declined 2.6% in August, contributing to the steady inflation, while private road transport costs fell 0.2%. Retail and food inflation rose, offsetting a moderation in services inflation. Core inflation rose 1.9% for the second consecutive month, the fastest rate since August 2014. The Monetary Authority of Singapore expects imported inflation to rise mildly, driven by global oil price increases and stronger demand for food commodities.

site_title: German banks hoarding more cash, says ECB
summary: German banks are hoarding increasing amounts of cash to avoid the European Central Bank's (ECB) punitive charge on excess liquidity. Between 2016 and 2017, cash holdings rose by 21 billion euros, primarily due to German lenders. The ECB charges banks for excess liquidity, but once the cost of storing cash is lower than the charge, banks tend to store more. This has created an effective floor for ECB rates and tested the limits of monetary policy. The ECB notes that logistical constraints limit the amount of cash banks can hold, and some stored notes may return if interest rates increase.

site_title: Yoma Strategic in partnership to enter Myanmar's heavy equipment sector
summary: Yoma Strategic, a MAINBOARD-listed company, partnered with Myan Shwe Pyi Tractors (MSP CAT) to enter Myanmar's heavy equipment sector. Yoma Fleet, its automotive and heavy equipment financing platform, will finance MSP CAT's existing rental portfolio and become the preferred financing partner. The partnership aims to support Myanmar's infrastructure development, with the government planning to allocate US$21.4 billion for rail, road, port, and aviation projects by 2030. The partnership is expected to provide scalable financial returns for Yoma Financial Services.

site_title: Spray-can satire creates headache for Thai junta
summary: Thai street artist "Headache Stencil" is creating satirical graffiti targeting the country's junta, using spray cans to caricature powerful figures and critique the government's lack of transparency and corruption. The artist's work has gained widespread attention and sparked a growing artistic movement in Bangkok, with other artists addressing social issues and challenging the status quo. The junta's response has been to try to monitor the artist and cover up subversive graffiti, but Headache's work continues to spread through social media, fueling a growing demand for free expression in Thailand.

site_title: Money FM podcast: The Hot Seat - Andruew Tang, founder of Singapore Pro Wrestling
summary: Andruew Tang, founder of Singapore Pro Wrestling, appeared on the Money FM podcast "The Hot Seat". Tang discussed the growth of the pro wrestling scene in Singapore, its increasing popularity, and the challenges faced by the industry. He also shared insights into the business side of pro wrestling, including revenue streams and partnerships. Tang highlighted the importance of creating a community around the sport and fostering a culture of inclusivity and diversity. The conversation provided a unique glimpse into the world of professional wrestling in Singapore.

images.alt_text: Andruew Tang aka 'The Statement', founder of Singapore Pro Wrestling

site_title: Trump's latest tariffs on China begin to bite
summary: US President Donald Trump's latest tariffs on China took effect, adding $200 billion in Chinese imports to the escalating trade war. The tariffs, which include 10% tariffs on goods such as voice data receivers and office equipment, bring the total value of goods hit by duties to over $250 billion. China has retaliated with duties on $60 billion in US goods, and Trump has threatened to impose further tariffs if China doesn't change its policies. The trade war has raised concerns about the potential for "significant economic costs" and has led to warnings from the International Monetary Fund and Fitch Ratings about the impact on global growth.

site_title: EU calls for probe into Danske Bank money laundering scandal
summary: The European Commission has called for an EU investigation into Danske Bank's money laundering scandal, citing regulatory failures that led to a multi-billion euro scandal. A probe is needed to establish any breach or non-application of EU law by Danish and Estonian supervisors. The scandal, which involved 200 billion euros in suspicious transactions, has triggered multiple inquiries, including in Denmark and Britain's National Crime Agency. The European Commission is urging the European Banking Authority to "fully utilise" its powers to probe the matter with urgency.

site_title: China developers' funding source at risk in sales crackdown
summary: China's housing authority is considering ending the practice of pre-sales, which allows developers to receive upfront payment for unfinished apartments. This move could significantly impact the sector, which is already facing a record $23 billion maturity wall in 2019. The decision aims to curb excessive property investment and reduce financial risks. If implemented, it could lead to a third of small developers disappearing, intensifying funding pressure and stretching their cash flow. The move aligns with President Xi Jinping's efforts to curb property speculation.

site_title: India says it will ensure liquidity for non-bank finance firms, mutual funds, smaller businesses
summary: India's Finance Minister Arun Jaitley has announced that the government will take measures to ensure liquidity for non-banking financial companies (NBFCs), mutual funds, and small and medium-enterprises. The statement comes after concerns over liquidity arose due to a series of defaults by India's Infrastructure Leasing & Financial Services. The Reserve Bank of India and Securities and Exchange Board of India have also reassured investors that they are monitoring developments and ready to take action if needed.

images.alt_text: The Reserve Bank of India and market regulator Securities and Exchange Board of India, sought on Sunday to reassure investors saying they were closely monitoring developments in financial markets and are ready to take appropriate steps if needed.

site_title: MAS explains its investigative powers covering financial sector in latest enforcement monograph
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has published a new enforcement monograph detailing its investigative powers and procedures for addressing misconduct in the financial sector. The MAS prioritizes cases based on public interest, number of victims, and sophistication of schemes, among other factors. It regulates over 1,500 financial institutions in Singapore and has the power to order companies to hand over documents, apply for injunctions, and impose civil penalties. The monograph supersedes an earlier one published in 2016, covering enforcement only within the capital markets.

site_title: US, China impose fresh tariffs with no trade talks in sight
summary: The US and China imposed fresh tariffs on each other's goods, with the US imposing 10% tariffs on $200 billion worth of Chinese products and China retaliating with 5-10% tariffs on $60 billion worth of US goods. The move escalates a bitter trade dispute that has rattled financial markets, with economists warning that a prolonged dispute could stunt global growth. Neither side has signaled a willingness to compromise, with China deciding not to send Vice Premier Liu He to Washington for talks. The US is set to increase tariffs to 25% by the end of 2018, while China may wait for US mid-term elections for any hints of policy changes.

site_title: Tuan Sing takes 75m yuan stake in Hainan mixed-use development project
summary: Tuan Sing Holdings has taken a 7.8% stake in Hainan-based Sanya Summer Real Estate for 75 million yuan (S$15 million), part of a 2.6 million square-foot mixed-use development project in Hainan, China. The project, valued at 1.6 billion yuan and 5 billion yuan, is slated for completion by end-2021. Tuan Sing plans to increase its stake through its SP Corp subsidiary if shareholders agree to repay a S$20 million loan. The deal aims to give Tuan Sing a foothold in China's growing market, particularly in Hainan's tourism boom.

site_title: 'Game-changing' global pact against illicit tobacco trade kicks in
summary: A global pact to combat the illicit tobacco trade, known as the Protocol to Eliminate Illicit Trade in Tobacco Products, has taken effect, with the World Health Organization (WHO) hailing it as "game-changing." The treaty aims to track and trace tobacco products, prevent smuggling and counterfeiting, and is expected to reduce the estimated $31 billion in lost tax revenues annually. The pact, which requires 40 ratifications, has been signed by over 40 countries, with the WHO chief stating that it is a "vital step towards a tobacco-free world."

site_title: E-commerce could widen Indonesia's trade-current deficit and hurt the rupiah, analysts warn
summary: Indonesia's trade and current account deficit may widen due to e-commerce growth, analysts warn. A surge in cross-border consumer sales could drive up imports, despite companies failing to raise exports. The rupiah may be under pressure, and online retail may destabilize the emerging economy. Analysts suggest that e-commerce needs to be encouraged to become a two-way street, allowing Indonesia to increase exports significantly. The recent hike in import taxes may worsen troubles if online retailers can circumvent the duties and taxes.

site_title: DBS sets its sights on China for debt capital markets push
summary: DBS Group Holdings, Southeast Asia's largest lender, is expanding its fixed-income business in China to bring more first-time bond issuers to the offshore market. The bank has set up a debt capital market product and advisory team in China, focusing on getting local clients, with the goal of capitalizing on China's growing debt financing needs. This move aims to enhance DBS' understanding of the local market and attract more business from China, which is the linchpin of Asia's dollar bond market.

site_title: Annica targets Q1 2019 for waste tyre acquisition, Q4 2018 for solar-hydrogen project
summary: Annica Holdings, a CATALIST-listed company, is targeting Q1 2019 to complete its 25.79% acquisition of a waste tyre pyrolysis business and Q4 2018 to launch a pilot solar-hydrogen project in Malaysia. The project's timeline has been delayed due to manufacturing issues, but is now in the final assembly stage. Annica is taking a cautious approach to finalize the Perak deal, which is still in financial and operational due diligence. The company has paid 60% of the production costs for the project to a Chinese manufacturer.

site_title: Upper East Coast landed property launched for sale with S$26m asking price
summary: A freehold landed residential site in Upper East Coast, Singapore, has been launched for sale with an asking price of S$26 million (S$914 per square foot) for the 28,449 sq ft plot. The site, which can be redeveloped into three-storey mixed landed housing, is zoned for semi-detached homes and is located near the upcoming Bedok South and Sungei Bedok MRT stations. The tender exercise closes on October 31. The sale is considered rare and palatable to developers, according to the marketing agent.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks fall at open on Monday
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell 0.72% in early trade on Monday, September 24, 2018, after China called off planned trade talks with the US, fueling fears of a tariff escalation. The Hang Seng Index dropped 200.87 points to 27,752.71. Mainland Chinese markets were closed for a public holiday.

site_title: Malaysia shares open lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index fell 1.41 points to 1,809.23 at 9am on Monday, with a total trading volume of 31.32 million lots worth RM12.08 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 97 to 33.

site_title: Australia: Shares fall as probe hits financials; a2 Milk pushes NZ lower
summary: Australian shares fell 0.2% on Monday, weighed down by a probe into the financial sector and lower commodities prices. The S&P/ASX 200 index dropped 11.1 points to 6,183.50. Financials stocks, including Commonwealth Bank of Australia and Suncorp Group, fell due to damaging testimony from a quasi-judicial inquiry into widespread wrongdoing. The inquiry found some insurers may have broken laws, including those with criminal penalties. The Sino-US trade war also hurt risk sentiment, with benchmark copper falling 1%.

site_title: Sabana Reit ends rent standoff with Changi South tenant; variation reached on lease, no impact to DPU expected
summary: Sabana Reit has ended a rent standoff with tenant Adviva Distribution at Changi South, reaching a variation on the lease agreement. The Reit trustee and tenant signed a deal on Sept 21, allowing the trustee to mitigate occupancy risks by bringing in direct sub-tenants. A $2.15 million payment has been made, covering outstanding rental arrears and late payment charges, and is expected to have no material impact on the Reit's distribution per unit (DPU) for the financial year. The agreement will also prevent a potential 0.05 Singapore cent hit to DPU.

site_title: Sydney breaks ground on new airport
summary: Sydney has broken ground on its new $3.6 billion airport, Western Sydney Airport, set to open in 2026. The project aims to handle growing air traffic numbers, with the number of global air passengers projected to nearly double to 7.8 billion by 2036. Sydney is expected to double its passenger numbers within two decades, with low-cost airlines driving growth. The new airport will initially handle 10 million passengers per year, addressing concerns that Sydney's current airport would be overwhelmed even without restrictions.

site_title: What's next for Comcast and Sky?
summary: Comcast has won the auction for British pay-TV broadcaster Sky plc with a US$39 billion bid, besting 21st Century Fox's offer of £15.67 per share. Comcast's final bid of £17.28 per share secured the deal, and the company plans to start buying Sky shares in the market, aiming to amass over 50% of the stock before an Oct 11 deadline. Fox, backed by Walt Disney Co, is considering selling its 39% stake in Sky to Comcast, potentially allowing the company to rapidly reach its acceptance target.

site_title: Hong Kong's surging dollar sends warning on housing market
summary: Hong Kong's currency surged 0.6% on Friday, its largest gain in 15 years, as traders worry about rising borrowing costs. The Hong Kong dollar's value against the US dollar rose due to concerns that local banks will raise interest rates, mirroring the US Federal Reserve's hikes. This could pressure the housing market, which has seen a decade-long liquidity party. Home prices rose 170% in the past decade, making Hong Kong one of the world's least affordable cities. Experts predict a reversal in expectations of rising mortgage servicing costs, which could hurt the property market.

site_title: Asian property developers delving deeper into green loans
summary: Asian property developers are increasingly using green loans to finance sustainable projects. Frasers Property Ltd, a Singapore-based developer, secured a S$1.2 billion green loan for its energy-efficient office tower, Frasers Tower. This is the first green loan by a South-east Asian borrower under the Asia Pacific Loan Market Association's guidelines, which aim to standardize disclosure. As green finance gains traction, it's playing catch-up to bond markets, with borrowers seeking more channels for sustainable financing amid rapid urbanization and pollution concerns.

site_title: India's Flipkart may name new group CEO in place of Binny Bansal: report
summary: Walmart's Flipkart unit is considering naming a new group CEO in place of Binny Bansal, the current CEO. Kalyan Krishnamurthy, Flipkart's current chief executive officer, is a leading candidate for the position. Walmart is considering both internal and external candidates for the role, as it seeks to strengthen its leadership. The move comes amid changes in the e-commerce landscape and the company's efforts to integrate Flipkart into its global operations.

site_title: Critical for straits of Malacca and Singapore to remain open, safe and clean: Khaw Boon Wan
summary: Coordinating Minister for Infrastructure and Transport Khaw Boon Wan emphasized the importance of the Straits of Malacca and Singapore remaining "open, safe and clean" for the global maritime community. Over 80,000 vessels pass through the straits annually, carrying a third of the world's traded goods, and one-sixth of the world's oil supply. Khaw stressed the need for collective commitment and cooperation to address current and future challenges, including technological advancements and making shipping clean and sustainable. The 11th Cooperation Forum aims to address these issues and ensure the straits remain a vital waterway.

site_title: Tokyo: Markets closed on Monday for public holiday
summary: Japanese markets closed on Monday, Sept 24 for a public holiday, resuming trading on Tuesday, Sept 25. Meanwhile, Singapore stocks notched a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, while Asia traders brushed off new Trump threats to extend stocks rally. In the US, the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty. The STI rose 0.4% on Thursday, and eSIM platform Airalo raised US$220 million in new funding, lifting its valuation past US$1 billion.

site_title: Singapore competition watchdog fines Uber, Grab more than S$13m for merger
summary: Singapore's competition watchdog fined Uber and Grab more than S$13 million for their merger, deeming it detrimental to local drivers and riders. Uber paid S$6.58 million and Grab S$6.42 million, citing the merger "removed Grab's closest rival" and the companies' cooperation in levying the penalties. The Competition and Consumer Commission of Singapore (CCCS) considered turnovers, infringement severity, and factors like cooperation in determining the fines.

site_title: Changi Airport Group unit inks MOU with Hunan partner for more consultancy projects in China
summary: Changi Airport Group's international arm, Changi Airports International, signed a memorandum of understanding with Hunan Airport Management Group to cooperate on airport consultancy projects in China. The agreement will facilitate collaboration in airport planning, design, and operation in Hunan province. This marks Changi Airports International's growth in China, where the Chinese partner owns and manages five airports, including Changsha Huanghua International Airport. The partnership aims to enhance airport consultancy services in the region.

site_title: EU palm oil ban sows bitter seeds for Southeast Asian farmers
summary: The European Parliament is set to ban the use of palm oil in biofuels, a move that could devastate Southeast Asian farmers who rely heavily on the commodity. Indonesian palm oil farmer Kawal Surbakti warns that losing the European market will significantly impact his livelihood and millions of others in Indonesia and Malaysia, the world's top two palm oil producers. The ban is expected to lead to a drop in prices, causing economic hardship for small farmers and potentially disrupting global supply chains.

site_title: Trump's China fight puts US tech in cross hairs
summary: US President Donald Trump's trade war with China is set to escalate, with a $200 billion tariff on Chinese goods taking effect. The tariffs will target consumer products and tech companies reliant on Chinese-made components, putting the US tech industry at risk. US tech and telecom companies warn that their reliance on Chinese-made products could lead to disruptions in the supply chain and potential casualties in the trade war. The move aims to protect America's dominance and disrupt China's plan for technological and economic supremacy.

images.alt_text: President Donald Trump says his trade war with China will protect America's dominance and derail Beijing's plan for technological and economic supremacy.

site_title: Germany, carmakers to continue diesel talks: transport minister
summary: Germany's transport minister said talks between carmakers and the government over hardware retrofits for older diesel vehicles will continue in the coming week. The talks failed to reach a compromise ahead of a September deadline to avoid vehicle bans due to high nitrogen oxide emissions. The conservative-led coalition is strained due to differing opinions between the conservatives and Social Democrats on how to address the issue. A solution is needed to stave off bans on older vehicles.

images.alt_text: Transport Minister Andreas Scheuer favours incentives for drivers of older diesel vehicles to trade them in for newer models to curb pollution.

site_title: Valuetronics, SunMoon Food and SATS commence buybacks
summary: Valuetronics, SunMoon Food and SATS have commenced buyback mandates. The buyback consideration totals S$13 million, down from S$49.6 million in the preceding five sessions. Meanwhile, 36 primary-listed stocks reported changes in director interests or substantial shareholdings, with Oxley Holdings and Centurion Corporation among those making significant transactions.

site_title: Keppel looking into possible transaction involving Keppel T&T interest; also considering M1 stake with SPH
summary: Keppel Corp is considering a potential transaction involving its 79.2% stake in Keppel T&T, which also holds interests in data centre trust Keppel DC Reit and telco M1. The conglomerate has asked Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) to participate in a possible deal involving their stakes in M1. No specific terms were announced, and no certainty exists that a transaction will occur. The stake in Keppel T&T is valued at around S$602 million, while the stakes in M1 are worth S$292 million for Keppel T&T and S$203 million for SPH.

site_title: Singapore shares decline at Monday's open; STI down 0.03% to 3,216.69
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) opened weaker on Monday, retreating 0.03% to 3,216.69. The decline came after China called off trade talks with the US over the weekend. Losers outnumbered gainers 73 to 49, with Wheelock Properties and Thai Beverage Public Co being among the most heavily traded stocks. Despite this, Keppel Corp and United Overseas Bank saw gains of 0.1% and 0.7%, respectively. The market reaction appears to be driven by the uncertainty surrounding the US-China trade talks.

site_title: Opec data leaves room for Saudis to boost output
summary: OPEC+ producers, led by Saudi Arabia and Russia, are pumping less than their target, leaving room for Saudi Arabia to boost output. Despite this, any increase would cut the cushion of spare capacity, testing their ability to react to future disruptions. OPEC+ officials gathered to review output data, but there has been no discussion of a new proposal to boost output, amid divisions over collective action to cool rising oil prices.

site_title: White House considers draft order to look into Google, Facebook
summary: The White House is considering a draft executive order instructing US antitrust authorities to investigate Google and Facebook for potential antitrust law violations. The order, in its early stages, would also look into other social media companies. A White House official described it as a response to growing concerns over the dominance of online platforms. The move aims to address issues of competition and fairness in the tech industry.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Keppel, Keppel T&T, SPH, M1, Wheelock, Creative, Keppel KBS-US Reit
summary: Keppel Corp is considering a possible transaction involving its interest in Keppel T&T and its indirect stake in telco M1. Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) has been approached by Keppel Corp to participate in the deal. M1 has halted trading after two indirect shareholders, SPH and Keppel Corp, disclosed a possible transaction. Meanwhile, Wheelock Properties will not revise its offer price for a privatisation attempt, and Creative Technology launched its new headphone amplifier, Super X-Fi. Keppel KBS-US Reit is acquiring a business campus portfolio in Seattle for US$169.4 million.

site_title: BIS warns global economy risks crisis 'relapse'
summary: The Bank of International Settlements warned that the global economy risks a "relapse" of the 2007-2008 crisis, citing a fragile recovery and mounting pressure on emerging economies. BIS chief economist Claudio Borio noted that central banks have administered "powerful medicine" through low interest rates, but this has led to side effects, including crises in Argentina and Turkey. The US Federal Reserve has begun hiking interest rates, while the European Central Bank has ended its stimulus program, leading to a divergence between US and emerging economies.

site_title: Keppel-KBS US Reit to buy business campus in Seattle for US$169.4m
summary: Keppel-KBS US Reit has agreed to acquire a business campus in Seattle for US$169.4 million, expanding its presence in the city. The portfolio comprises 21 buildings and will increase the Reit's aggregate valuation by 20.8% and net lettable area by 24.2%. The acquisition is expected to be yield accretive and benefit from steady rent growth of approximately 4% by 2020, aligning with the Reit's strategy to create long-term value for unitholders.

site_title: Microsoft, Amazon, Google join fight to prevent famine
summary: Tech giants Microsoft, Amazon, and Google are joining forces with the World Bank and UN to use data analysis and AI to prevent famines in developing nations. The Famine Action Mechanism (FAM) aims to trigger funding for action before a famine becomes a crisis. With over 124 million people living in crisis-level food insecurity, the initiative seeks to save lives by responding earlier and more effectively. The FAM will initially be rolled out in vulnerable countries and will use AI models called "Artemis" to estimate and forecast worsening food security crises.

site_title: Venezuela banks on petro, but it remains 'non-transferable'
summary: Venezuela's cryptocurrency, the petro, was launched six months ago but has been in limbo. Despite this, President Nicolas Maduro's government claims it will start working. However, a citizen's attempt to make a transaction using the petro failed, highlighting the currency's non-transferable nature.

site_title: Wheelock Properties buy-out price remains at S$2.10; offer to close on Oct 2
summary: Wheelock Properties' buy-out price remains at S$2.10, with the offer set to close on Oct 2, according to its Hong Kong-listed parent. The offeror has stated it will not revise the offer price, and shares have fallen back to S$2.10 after breaching the offer price. The final closing date has been pushed back from Sept 28 to Oct 2. The offeror warned shareholders that any share purchases after Sept 26 will settle only after three market days, and recommended accepting the offer to reinvest in other stocks or cash proceeds.

site_title: Britain's Labour party plans to make companies transfer shares to workers
summary: Britain's Labour party plans to require large companies to transfer up to 10% of their shares into a collective worker-owned fund, starting with companies having over 250 employees. The fund, known as the "Inclusive Ownership Fund", will be managed by workers and distribute dividend payments. The plan aims to give workers a share in economic prosperity, with the goal of eventually transferring 2.1 billion pounds into public services. This move is seen as a shift towards a more interventionist left-wing platform, with the aim of increasing productivity and long-term thinking.

site_title: Oil rises as markets tighten ahead of Iran sanctions
summary: Oil prices rose on Monday, with Brent crude futures increasing by 1.2% to $79.74 per barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude futures rising by 1.1% to $71.52 a barrel. The market tightened ahead of US sanctions on Iran's petroleum exports, expected to drop by over 1 million barrels per day in early November. US commercial inventories are at their lowest level since 2015, and recent subdued US drilling activity suggests a slowdown in output. The OPEC meeting is discussing a potential 500,000 barrels per day output increase to counter the supply loss from Iran.

site_title: Hackers target US real estate deals, with devastating impact
summary: Hackers targeted US real estate deals, resulting in devastating losses for victims. A lawsuit filed by the Butchers, who lost $272,000, revealed that hackers hacked into a real estate settlement company's e-mail account, altering wiring instructions to steal the funds. The FBI reported a 1,110% rise in e-mail fraud victims and nearly 2,200% increase in losses between 2015 and 2017, with nearly 10,000 victims reporting losses of over $56 million in 2017. Experts warn of lax security in the real estate chain, making it an attractive target for hackers.

site_title: Canada PM says informal Nafta talks likely in next few days at UN
summary: Canada's Prime Minister Justin Trudeau announced that informal Nafta talks between the US and Canada are likely to take place in the next few days at the UN General Assembly. The talks come as time runs out ahead of a US-imposed deadline, with US President Donald Trump threatening to exclude Canada if necessary and impose a 25% tariff on Canadian autos exports. Canadian Foreign Minister Chrystia Freeland and US Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer are set to meet in New York, and Trudeau stated that conversations are likely to occur in a constructive but less formal way.

site_title: Amid rupiah slump, Indonesia kicks off campaigning for presidential race
summary: Indonesia kicked off its presidential election campaign on September 23, 2018, with incumbent Joko Widodo facing a challenge from former military general Prabowo Subianto. Widodo, known as Jokowi, is leading in opinion polls, but his bid is facing headwinds due to the country's economic slump and fears of fake news campaigns. The election, set for April 17, will also determine members of national and local parliaments, with analysts predicting a focus on the economy, inequality, and rising intolerance.

site_title: HK bullet train signals high-speed integration with China
summary: Hong Kong's bullet train made its debut, integrating the former British colony with mainland China. The $11 billion project, which took less than 20 minutes to reach China, received praise from passengers despite concerns over Beijing's influence on the city's freedoms. The high-speed rail service marked a significant step in deepening the region's economic ties, with speeds reaching up to 200 km/h.

site_title: HK property developers cut prices
summary: Hong Kong property developers are cutting prices to attract buyers amid market uncertainty. Vanke Property Overseas launched a new project with prices as low as HK$9,878 (S$1,728) per square foot, the lowest in two years. This move aims to lure buyers in the world's least-affordable housing market.

site_title: Qingjian Realty sells 300 units at JadeScape
summary: Qingjian Realty (South Pacific) Group sold 300 units at the JadeScape condo, with an average price of S$1,700 per square foot. Interest was balanced across all unit types, and sales began on Saturday morning. The development, located on the former HUDC Shunfu Ville site, has a 99-year leasehold and features 1,206 residential units. Experts say the strong first weekend showing should translate to steady weekly sales for months ahead, driven by the project's strong product offering and accessible location.

site_title: Saudi says door open to future oil output hike
summary: Saudi Arabia's energy minister Khalid al-Falih left the door open for a future oil production hike, despite a meeting of oil-producing countries in Algiers deciding not to alter global supply. The meeting, attended by US President Donald Trump, aimed to reduce prices, but the committee expressed satisfaction with the current oil market balance. The decision comes as US sanctions on Iranian oil, set to take effect in November, tighten supplies and drive prices up. A potential production hike by Saudi Arabia could help alleviate the pressure on the global market.

site_title: OCBC seeks wider ranging, viable environmental solutions
summary: OCBC Bank is launching its #OCBCCares Fund for the Environment for a second year, offering S$100,000 in funding for ground-up environmental initiatives in Singapore. The fund aims to support projects addressing various environmental issues, such as waste reduction, clean waters, energy, and biodiversity efforts. Last year, six projects were funded, demonstrating that environmental initiatives don't have to be expensive. A workshop is scheduled for Oct 23, and applications close on Nov 30. The bank hopes to receive proposals covering a wider range of environmental issues beyond waste management.

site_title: New paths for New Silkroutes
summary: New Silkroutes Group, a Singapore-based conglomerate, is shifting its focus from energy to healthcare. CEO Goh Jin Hian says energy will be the "stable business" behind the healthcare business, which aims to contribute half of the group's profits. The group is seeking hospital management contracts and equity acquisitions, with plans to build a vertically-integrated regional healthcare player. It has already acquired six family medicine and aesthetics clinics in Singapore and is close to securing its first hospital contract in Malaysia. The healthcare business is expected to achieve margins of 10-15% and will be the primary focus going forward.

site_title: Danger in soaring foreign currency debt: BIS
summary: The Bank for International Settlements (BIS) warns that soaring foreign currency debt is endangering financial markets, with US dollar strength aggravating problems for borrowers in emerging markets. Global debt has surged to $11.4 trillion, with euro and yen debt also increasing. The BIS predicts further turbulence due to overstretched markets, low interest rates, and high global debt. The US dollar's strength has particularly hurt emerging market companies and governments that must find local currency to repay US dollar-denominated loans.

site_title: No clear winners
summary: The US-China trade spat has had a mixed impact on Asia's business and economy, with no clear winners. Yeoh Oon Jin, Executive Chairman of PwC Singapore, notes that a trade war increases costs for businesses and consumers. China has urged Southeast Asia to support openness amidst US tariffs, while also unveiling new steps to aid employment amid trade tensions. The situation remains uncertain, with no clear outcome for businesses in the region.

images.alt_text: Yeoh Oon Jin, Executive Chairman, PwC Singapore.

site_title: Nikkei 225 to rise after convincing bullish break
summary: The Nikkei 225 stock index is expected to rise after a convincing bullish break, with the index advancing 1.35% on September 18. The Bank of Japan maintained its dovish stance, keeping interest rates low and pumping liquidity into the market. The index has been stuck in an ascending triangle since April, but broke above the 23,010 resistance area, signaling a bullish narrative. Analysts predict the Nikkei 225 to stair-step higher, targeting the 2018 high of 24,170 points and potentially reaching the 26,000-point area, representing a 9% upside from current price.

site_title: CapitaLand group upholds governance standards
summary: The Securities Investors Association of Singapore is holding the 9th Singapore Corporate Governance Week 2018, focusing on whether corporate governance is a hindrance or a help to businesses. 91 companies, including CapitaLand Group, have signed a Statement of Support for good corporate governance standards. The companies emphasize the importance of transparency, effective internal controls, and stakeholder engagement in maintaining long-term success. They also highlight their commitment to upholding high standards of corporate governance to enhance shareholder value and ensure the stability of the financial markets and economy.

site_title: Comcast outbids Fox for control of UK broadcaster Sky
summary: Comcast emerged as the winner of a months-long auction for control of UK broadcaster Sky, outbidding 21st Century Fox with a final offer of £29.7 billion (S$53 billion). The US cable giant will gain control of Sky, a pay-television company with 23 million customers across five European countries, and its valuable sports broadcasting rights. Comcast's acquisition promises to reshape the media landscape, while leaving Fox and its soon-to-be owner, Disney, to consider selling their 39% stake in Sky to Comcast in exchange for its 30% stake in Hulu.

site_title: Last US nuclear project faces 'jeopardy' as owners mull exit
summary: The Vogtle nuclear power plant in Georgia, the only US nuclear project under construction, faces "jeopardy" as minority owners consider pulling out due to cost overruns and rising costs. The project, valued at $28 billion, has seen costs increase by $2.3 billion, prompting a Florida utility to sue to get out of a contract to buy electricity. The US Energy Department has warned Southern Co., the project's lead owner, that it will withhold loan guarantees if the owners decide to cancel the project, which could have significant implications for the US nuclear industry.

site_title: Trump holds on to diplomatic 'success' in North Korea
summary: US President Donald Trump claims diplomatic progress with North Korean leader Kim Jong Un, citing "tremendous progress" and "great responses" since their June summit in Singapore. Despite stalled momentum on denuclearization, US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo hopes for a second summit to press ahead with efforts. North Korea agreed to close a missile testing site and dismantle a nuclear facility, but experts caution much remains to be done, and denuclearization must come first.

site_title: China must get to grips with dodgy data
summary: China's economic data has become increasingly difficult to track, with market watchers searching for irregularities in numbers such as GDP growth, retail sales, and debt. Analysts are using creative methods to mirror GDP growth, comparing data points to identify discrepancies. This suggests underlying statistics may be misleading, raising concerns about the state of the economy. Policymakers face pressure to address the issue, which could impact China's economic growth and stability.

site_title: Europe's talks with US to soften trade impasse are a 'long shot': analyst
summary: The European Union's trade chief, Cecilia Malmstrom, is set to meet with US and Japanese officials in New York to discuss ending China's unfair commercial policies. The EU, US, and Japan aim to create an agreement to force China to end non-market-oriented policies, which lead to overcapacity and hinder technological development. The talks, considered a long shot, may provide an "off-ramp" from the current tariff escalation and address shortcomings in the World Trade Organization. The meeting comes as the US has imposed tariffs on China, and China has threatened retaliation, causing global tensions to rise.

site_title: Ether cryptocurrency, a victim of blockchain success
summary: Ether's price has collapsed by 20% due to the popularity of Ethereum's blockchain technology, which has led to congestion on the network and increased transaction fees. Co-founder Vitalik Buterin's comments about a "ceiling in sight" for the blockchain space have also contributed to the decline. The surge in initial coin offerings (ICOs) in 2017, which resulted in a 160-fold increase in ether's value, has caused congestion and discouraged investors, further exacerbating the price drop.

site_title: No market drop despite new bubble set to pop
summary: US stocks surged to records last week as trade war fears faded, with investors focusing on the Federal Reserve's midweek policy statement. The yield on the 10-year Treasury note reached 3.06%, near its highest level since May. Investors expect the Fed to raise rates, but some see a compromise between the US and China as a positive outcome, citing "two out of three ain't bad" sentiment. However, concerns about slowing home sales and speculative mania persist, with some warning of a potential market correction.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights report for the week ending September 23, 2018, reveals mixed market trends. Tanker rates were marginally firmer, with VLCC rates ranging from WS 56.5/57.5 for Middle East Gulf to China and Singapore, and WS 21.5 for US Gulf to US Gulf. Suezmax rates rose 2.5 points to WS 72.5 for West Africa/UK-Continent, while Black Sea rates nudged WS 90. Aframax rates rose five points to WS 100 for Mediterranean routes. Panamax rates remained steady, with Clean rates increasing for Middle East Gulf/Japan. DRY BULK markets also showed mixed trends, with Capesize rates failing to hold and dropping to $7.20 for West Australia/China route.

site_title: Technology as a means to access justice
summary: Singapore's WongPartnership LLP collaborated with Alt+Law to organize the first-ever LegalTech competition, Code for a Cause. 18 teams from various disciplines participated in the event, with the top three teams presenting their ideas on using technology to access justice. The competition aimed to raise awareness of technology as an enabler for pro bono organizations, showcasing its potential to drive positive change in the legal sector.

site_title: Forget robots, retailers need people power
summary: Retailers are increasing their focus on workforce talent due to a tight labor market, with companies like Walmart and J C Penney offering perks and raises to attract and retain employees. This shift is expected to continue even if the economy cools, as in-store shopping experiences become increasingly important for traditional retailers. Companies are recognizing the value of their store workers, who are often essential to their online businesses, and are investing in training and benefits to keep employees motivated and loyal.

site_title: Opec, like a dying star, is about to go supernova
summary: Opec, the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, is nearing the end of its existence due to a record-high membership but a record-low share of global oil output. The group's decline mirrors the life cycle of a star, where a core contraction and outer layer expansion lead to either insignificance or a supernova. As Opec implodes, its influence may be replaced by other oil-producing nations, potentially altering the global energy landscape. The US may rejoice at Opec's demise, but its own energy policies could have unintended consequences.

site_title: Shadow banker in India rushes to sell assets as defaults pile up
summary: IL&FS, a shadow banker in India, is rushing to sell assets amid defaults on several obligations. The firm, which has $12.6 billion in debt, has missed payments on 4.9 billion rupees and has additional dues of 2.2 billion rupees to be repaid by October. Investors are concerned about potential contagion spreading to other shadow banks, leading to a decline in the Indian stock market. The company's top executives are also resigning, and it has identified 25 projects to sell.

site_title: Ferragamo brings Tuscan countryside to Milan
summary: Italian fashion designer Salvatore Ferragamo showcased its spring-summer 2019 collection in Milan, inspired by the Tuscan countryside's colors and rolling hills. Creative directors Paul Andrew and Guillame Meilland introduced bold tones and rich leather, with designs for both men and women. The collection featured monochrome pieces with palm tree patterns and leather accessories, including shoes with sculpture-like heels. The show aimed to appeal to a younger clientele while maintaining the brand's traditional customer base, with a diverse cast of models and a focus on leather and new bag designs.

site_title: Easy money in China, Japan bodes well for real estate investments
summary: LaSalle Investment Management's Asia-Pacific head of research & strategy, Elysia Tse, argues that real estate is a more stable asset class compared to stocks and bonds due to its longer-dated nature and multi-year leases tied to income. Despite "easy money" inflating asset prices, Tse sees opportunities in China and Japan, particularly in logistics and Grade-B offices. The firms favor Tier-1 cities and satellite cities, and logistics yields in Shanghai generate an attractive spread over office yields. Tse expects transaction volumes to remain solid in the region, driven by intra-regional trade, and projects stable occupancies for the industrial sector and strongest rental growth in the office sector.

images.alt_text: LaSalle IM likes Grade-B offices in Tokyo and logistics real estate in China's Tier-1 cities, among other things, says its Asia-Pacific head of research & strategy, Elysia Tse.

site_title: Stamford Land lawsuit: Company supports engaging shareholders meaningfully
summary: Stamford Land Corporation has stated that it supports engaging shareholders meaningfully on company issues, contradicting media reports that the company filed a defamation suit against a minority shareholder. The lawsuit was filed after a shareholder, Mano Sabnani, made public accusations against the company. Stamford Land claims that the accusations damaged its reputation and integrity. The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has weighed in, encouraging companies to avoid overly legalistic approaches and promote free discussions between boards and shareholders.

site_title: Toyota agrees to add Android Auto in its cars
summary: Toyota Motor has agreed to add Android Auto to its vehicles, marking a significant shift after years of resistance due to safety and security concerns. This move comes after announcing compatibility with Apple's CarPlay in January and will allow Android Auto devices to connect directly to Toyota cars. The addition is expected to attract customers who had stayed away from Toyota vehicles due to lack of connectivity, with over 80% of smartphones using Android Auto. An announcement could come as early as October.

images.alt_text: Toyota Motor agreed to add Android Auto to its vehicles, according to a person familiar with the matter, ending years of resistance to the Google infotainment software due to safety and security concerns.

site_title: Tariffs, FOMC meeting in spotlight this week
summary: US tariffs on Chinese imports will take effect Monday, dominating headlines this week. The Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) decision is expected on September 26, with a 25 basis point rate hike anticipated, and Fed Chairman Jerome Powell's press conference to follow. US economic data, including the consumer confidence index and second-quarter GDP, will also be released this week. The Singapore market will also be influenced by local data releases and the mid-Autumn festivities, which will impact trading volumes.

site_title: 300 units sold at JadeScape condo
summary: Qingjian Realty (South Pacific) Group has sold 300 units at the JadeScape condo, with an average transacted price of S$1,700 per square foot. The 99-year leasehold project offers smart home and smart estate management systems. Sales began on Saturday morning, with interest balanced across all unit types. Experts expect steady sales for the months ahead, citing a strong product offering and easily-accessible location. The next phase of sales details will be announced later.

site_title: Dissected new iPhones reveal Intel, Micron, Toshiba parts
summary: Apple's latest iPhones, iPhone Xs and Xs Max, use components from Intel, Micron Technology, and Toshiba, among others, according to teardowns by iFixit and TechInsights. This marks a rare disclosure of the suppliers for Apple's iPhones, which typically keep the information secret. The study is considered a significant coup for chipmakers and other manufacturers, as it highlights their involvement in supplying parts for the popular smartphones.

site_title: Trade war spurs soy merry-go-round as China turns to Argentina
summary: China's 25% tariff on US soybeans is prompting traders to find alternative routes, with US soybeans being shipped to Argentina and then exported to China. Three vessels are set to load 167,740 metric tons of Argentine soybeans between September 23 and October 1. This is a result of a drought that reduced Argentina's soybean production by 31% and a trade war with China. US traders have sold 840,000 tons of soybeans to Argentina, taking advantage of a "nice margin" for crushing in the country.

site_title: Iran will defeat Trump just like it did Saddam, won't abandon missiles: Rouhani
summary: Iranian President Hassan Rouhani stated that US President Donald Trump will fail in his confrontation with Iran, just like Saddam Hussein, and vowed that Tehran will not abandon its missiles. Rouhani's comments came as Iran displayed its naval power in the Gulf during annual parades, vowing a "pounding reply" to its enemies. Iran has threatened to block other countries' oil exports in retaliation for US sanctions, and has maintained a fleet of vessels in the Gulf to protect its interests.

site_title: Trump administration curbs new green cards for those on public aid
summary: The Trump administration has introduced new rules that could deny green cards to immigrants who use public benefits such as food assistance and Section 8 housing vouchers. The move aims to keep out individuals deemed a drain on the country. Millions of poor immigrants relying on public assistance would be forced to choose between receiving financial help or seeking a green card to live and work legally in the US. The rules could significantly impact the lives of low-income immigrants.

site_title: Pound plunges after EU rejects May's Brexit plans
summary: The British pound plummeted 1.44% on Friday, its largest daily loss since June 2017, after the European Union rejected Prime Minister Theresa May's Brexit plans without explanation. The pound's fall strengthened the US dollar, which rebounded from early lows, and drove investors to buy riskier assets, fueling a surge in the US dollar and euro. The US dollar index rose 0.38% to 94.255, while the euro broke above the US$1.18 line for the first time in three months.

site_title: Hong Kong property developers sell low on rate hike, more supply
summary: Hong Kong property developers are cutting prices to lure buyers amid increasing downside risks in the market. Developers have released new projects with prices as low as HK$9,878 (S$1,724) per square foot, the lowest in about two years. The market has shown signs of "cooling off" with borrowing costs expected to rise this month. Rising new house supply in September adds further pressure on property prices, with nearly 6,000 units to be offered, up 20% from August. Bearish sentiment is mounting, with forecasts predicting declines in home prices.

site_title: Malaysia's Axiata in talks for more tower acquisitions over next 12 months
summary: Malaysia's Axiata Group Bhd's tower unit, edotco Group Sdn Bhd, is in talks to acquire more towers over the next 12 months, aiming to boost its infrastructure portfolio. CEO Suresh Sidhu said two to three deals are being considered, primarily in Malaysia, Myanmar, Bangladesh, and Sri Lanka, where the sector has developed. The company has $200 million in cash reserves and no urgency to raise funds, with any future growth plans to be discussed in mid-2019.

site_title: German carmakers join race against Tesla
summary: German luxury carmakers Mercedes-Benz, BMW, Audi, and Porsche have unveiled their first all-electric SUVs, marking a significant shift in the industry's response to Tesla's dominance. The German giants have committed to investing nearly $64 billion in battery-powered vehicles over the next three years, aiming to increase electric car sales to 30% of their market share by 2025. This move comes as cities worldwide ban diesel engines to reduce air pollution, and Tesla faces challenges in stabilizing its production and profitability under CEO Elon Musk's leadership.

site_title: GOP threatens Monday vote on Kavanaugh unless accuser testifies
summary: Senate Judiciary Committee Chairman Chuck Grassley threatened to vote on Brett Kavanaugh's Supreme Court nomination on Monday unless the woman accusing him of sexual assault agrees to testify by Friday night. The committee and accuser Christine Blasey Ford's lawyers are in negotiations over her appearance, with Republicans rejecting her request to call other witnesses. Grassley said he will postpone the vote if a resolution is reached, but Democrats demand a delay to allow an FBI investigation. President Trump cast doubt on Ford's allegations, and moderate Senator Susan Collins expressed her opposition to his tweet.

site_title: China cancels trade talks with US as tariff threats escalate: WSJ
summary: China has cancelled trade talks with the US and will not send Vice-Premier Liu He to Washington next week, citing escalating tariff threats. The move comes after China added $60 billion of US products to its import tariff list in retaliation against US duties on $200 billion of Chinese goods set to go into effect from September 24.

site_title: Comcast and Fox take US$34b battle for Britain's Sky to the wire
summary: Comcast and Twenty-First Century Fox are set to battle it out in an auction for Britain's Sky, with a deadline passed on Friday for either side to increase their all-cash offers of $34 billion. The auction, run by Britain's Takeover Panel, will last a maximum of three rounds, and Sky's independent directors are expected to decide which offer to back after meeting on Saturday. Comcast's £14.75 a share offer values the broadcaster at £25.9 billion, while Fox's bid is £14 a share. The winner will control Sky and potentially influence Disney's future plans.

site_title: Europe: European stock index scores best winning streak in two decades
summary: Europe's stock index achieved its best 10-session winning streak in two decades, with the STOXX 600 rising 0.4% and the Euro STOXX 50 increasing 0.8%. Despite fears of a US-China trade war, investors focused on lower-than-expected tariffs and hopes for a compromise. Inexpensive valuations also fueled demand for European shares, with miners and autos leading the advance.

site_title: May faces new Brexit resistance in Northern Ireland
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May faces resistance from Northern Ireland's unionist and nationalist parties over her Brexit plan, which includes a potential regulatory trade barrier between Northern Ireland and the rest of the UK. The Democratic Unionist Party, which supports May, vows to veto any deal that sets up a border, while Sinn Fein, favoring Irish unification, demands the EU's "backstop" proposal, which would keep Northern Ireland in the EU customs union. May's slender majority in parliament relies on DUP support, complicating her negotiations.

site_title: Trafigura's entire fleet of new vessels to be Singapore-flagged
summary: Trafigura Group, an independent commodity trading firm, has named its first 35 new vessels being built in South Korea and China as Singapore-flagged, with the first of these vessels being christened last week. Senior Minister of State for Transport and Health Lam Pin Min attended the ceremony, praising Singapore's role in the global shipping industry. The vessels, including Medium Range tankers and Suezmax tankers, will be leased to Trafigura and are set to be delivered in the first quarter of 2019.

images.alt_text: At the ceremony - at Hyundai Samho Heavy Industries' shipyard in South Korea - were: Lam Pin Min (fourth from left), Singapore's Senior Minister of State for Transport and Health; Jeanette Chen fifth from left), Dr Lam's wife; and Michelle Lee (sixth from left), wife of Tan Chin Hwee (seventh from left), Trafigura CEO (Asia Pacific).

site_title: Vietnamese president Tran Dai Quang dead at 61
summary: Vietnam's President Tran Dai Quang, 61, died Friday after a year-long treatment in Japan for a rare virus. A former police chief and hardline communist, Quang's death won't dramatically alter politics in Vietnam, where the powerful communist government oversees almost every aspect of society. His role was largely ceremonial, and his death is seen as a rare occurrence in a one-party state. Quang's legacy includes a crackdown on dissidents and a simmering conflict with Beijing over the South China Sea.

site_title: Can this US$18m penthouse beat New York's market slump?
summary: A US$18 million penthouse at 555 West End Avenue in New York's Upper West Side is set to hit the market, amidst a struggling high-end real estate market. Developer Cary Tamarkin is sticking to his original plan, despite acknowledging "excess supply" and questioning the economy. The building, which includes a former Catholic school, will offer luxury apartments with custom touches, including high ceilings and expensive finishes. The penthouse, with 3,420 square feet and 18.5-foot ceilings, has an asking price of US$18 million, comparable to prices in other luxury buildings in the city.

site_title: Champions League telecast impasse a bummer for fans
summary: The Champions League telecast has been delayed in Singapore due to an impasse between pay-TV operators Singtel and StarHub over broadcast rights. Despite initial announcements, fans are still unable to watch the matches on TV, with Singtel only broadcasting five of the eight matches scheduled for the first day. The situation remains uncertain, with negotiations ongoing, and fans are growing frustrated with the lack of clarity and potential for missed games.

site_title: United Airlines pilots resist contract changes over regional routes
summary: United Airlines pilots are resisting contract changes that would allow regional carriers to operate heavier planes on routes where mainline pilots are paid less. The pilots, represented by the Air Line Pilots Association, are holding firm on a "scope clause" that restricts planes over 39,000 kg with more than 76 seats from regional routes. The United Airlines president, Scott Kirby, wants to change the clause to make the carrier more competitive, but the pilots disagree, stating they won't disadvantage mainline employees. The negotiations are being watched by other airlines and commercial plane makers.

images.alt_text: United Airlines pilots said they refuse to budge on the wording of their contract governing the outsourcing of regional flights.

site_title: Troubled production of new Bond movie reflects how Hollywood really operates
summary: The 25th James Bond film, initially expected to feature a new lead actor, will instead see Daniel Craig reprise his role as Bond. Director Cary Fukunaga, known for his art-house style, was announced in September 2018, following a series of changes in the production. Craig was initially set to leave the role, but ultimately decided to return. The film's production process was highly publicized, with Fukunaga having previously considered Idris Elba for the role. This transparency is a departure from the past, when behind-the-scenes drama was often kept private, and now audiences are privy to the entire filmmaking process through news reports and social media.

site_title: Wells Fargo CEO says he's prepared to stay until he's 65
summary: Wells Fargo CEO Tim Sloan, 58, has expressed his willingness to remain in the company until 2029, citing his unanimous board support. Sloan credits analysts for his efforts to overhaul the firm, installing a new management team and bolstering internal controls. He plans to reduce the workforce by 5-10% within three years to focus on costs, with many cuts coming through attrition. Sloan admits to having regrets about the pace of changes, but believes the company has made the right decisions.

images.alt_text: Wells Fargo & Co chief executive officer (CEO) Tim Sloan, commenting two days after the bank's chairman batted back Wall Street whispers that the board is looking to replace him, said he's prepared to keep running the company for much of the next decade.

site_title: China's tech boom at risk over muddled tax hike proposals
summary: China's tech boom is at risk due to unclear tax hike proposals, causing venture capitalists to reconsider investments and residency in the country. The government's announcements could hike taxes on investors and high-skill employees, potentially putting China at a disadvantage compared to the US, where taxes are capped at 20%. Funding for Chinese startups has slowed, with capital raised by investment firms plunging 53% in the first half of the year, and some companies are shutting operations. The government is expected to provide clarity on the tax policies soon, which could alleviate concerns and support the tech industry.

site_title: NTUC Enterprise to buy Kopitiam, subsidiaries for undisclosed sum by year-end
summary: NTUC Enterprise Co-operative Limited is acquiring Kopitiam Investment and its subsidiaries for an undisclosed sum by the end of 2018. The acquisition aims to provide affordable, quality, and healthier meal options to the Singapore community, complementing NTUC Foodfare's current operations. The transaction is part of NTUC Enterprise's social mission to ensure cooked food remains accessible to the community.

images.alt_text: NTUC Enterprise Co-operative Limited is acquiring homegrown food centre operator Kopitiam Investment and its subsidiaries as part of its social mission to ensure that cooked food remains affordable and accessible to the Singapore community, it announced on Friday.

site_title: Trump sees gain in China tariffs despite consumer pain
summary: The Trump administration has implemented a 10% tariff on $200 billion of Chinese imports, which could rise to 25% next year, amid a growing trade fight between the US and China. Industry groups have expressed concerns about the impact on consumer prices, with analysts predicting a depression in spending and a hit to the retail sector. The US has not yet announced further tariffs, but China has threatened retaliation with levies on $60 billion of American goods. The move is seen as a necessary step to defend US long-term interests despite consumer pain.

site_title: Rupiah key issue at Indonesia polls, says VP contender
summary: Indonesia's upcoming presidential election will focus on the economy and jobs, with the country's struggling currency, the rupiah, being a key issue. Vice-presidential candidate Sandiaga Uno claims the government has been too slow to respond to the rupiah's decline, which has fallen almost 9% against the dollar this year. Uno, running mate to Prabowo Subianto, proposes reforms to boost domestic and foreign investment, including tax breaks and labor law changes, to address the current-account deficit and skills gap.

site_title: A decade late and without key features, Nintendo is finally online
summary: Nintendo has launched its first online subscription service for its Switch console, charging $20 a year for users to play games online. The service, known as Switch Online, was introduced 18 months after a free trial period and is being met with criticism for lacking key features such as in-game chat and dedicated servers. Analysts say Nintendo is at least five years behind its rivals, Sony and Microsoft, in terms of online gaming capabilities, and that the service is only the minimum expected from an online service. Despite the criticism, digital sales through the platform have jumped 68% in the latest quarter.

images.alt_text: Good things come to those who wait. Except, maybe, for Nintendo gamers.

site_title: ECB heads for peak liquidity as Euro-area stimulus tools top out
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is nearing the peak of excess liquidity in the euro zone, with outstanding loans set to be repaid and a bond-buying program to be cut. Excess liquidity is projected to peak at around 2 trillion euros by the end of 2018 and drop below 500 billion euros in 2022. The ECB expects to keep interest rates unchanged through the summer of 2019 and has acknowledged market expectations for a hike late next year. The central bank's stimulus measures have driven economic growth and boosted stocks, but may drag on an already slowing expansion.

site_title: A shoemaker turns billionaire with luxury goods IPO
summary: Jose Neves, 44, the founder of Farfetch, has become a billionaire after the company's initial public offering (IPO) raised $885 million, with shares closing at $28.45. Neves owns 14.8% of the company, valuing his stake at up to $1.2 billion. The IPO was above the company's marketed range of $17 to $19 per share.

site_title: Lehman Brothers workers share memories 10 years after the fall
summary: Ex-employees of Lehman Brothers gathered at Irish pubs in Manhattan to reminisce 10 years after the bank's collapse, marking the largest US bankruptcy of the 2008 financial crisis. Over 100 former traders, lawyers, and recruiters shared memories of the bank's scrappy underdog reputation and its eventual filing for bankruptcy on September 15, 2008.

site_title: Safe as houses? The property investment story so far
summary: Singapore's residential property market has experienced significant growth over the past five decades, with prices increasing by 100 times their 1975 value. Land scarcity, the city-state's transformation into a global hub, and pro-home ownership policies have driven this growth. However, experts warn that high rates of capital appreciation may not be sustainable due to supply-demand dynamics and potential policy risks. The government's recent cooling measures, including higher additional buyer's stamp duty rates and lower loan-to-value limits, aim to keep price increases in line with economic fundamentals. Meanwhile, investing in equities, such as stocks and REITs, has outperformed physical property, with returns averaging 129% over the past 15 years.

images.alt_text: SAFE AS HOUSES? The investment story so far, and the outlook for Singapore residential property as an asset.

"If policy management of private home prices becomes a norm, the future rate of capital appreciation of private homes may be expected to decline." - Ong Teck Hui, JLL Singapore's national director of research & consultancy.

(Above) One of the earliest Housing Board flats built in Queenstown. For the majority of Singaporeans, owning an HDB flat was one way to have a stake in the nation, to have a sense of belonging and also to sink roots.

site_title: A commitment to clear and transparent governance practices
summary: The Securities Investors Association (Singapore) is hosting the 9th Singapore Corporate Governance Week 2018, from September 24 to 28, with 82 companies having joined the Statement of Support initiative for excellence in corporate governance. The initiative aims to uphold and advance good corporate governance standards to enhance shareholder value and stability of the financial markets and economy. Companies participating include City Developments, Sabana Real Estate Investment Management, and Wing Tai Holdings, who emphasize the importance of effective corporate governance and strong business ethics in achieving sustainable growth and maximizing shareholder returns.

site_title: Can this US$18m penthouse beat New York's slump?
summary: A US$18 million penthouse at 555 West End Avenue in New York City is set to hit the market, despite the city's luxury real estate market slump. Developer Cary Tamarkin, who purchased the building in 2014 for US$50 million, plans to sell the penthouse with a 3,420 square foot terrace for US$18 million. Tamarkin believes the building's unique history and custom touches will set it apart from other luxury developments, but experts say the high-end market is oversaturated with inventory.

site_title: Open electricity market goes island-wide in stages from Nov 1
summary: The Energy Market Authority (EMA) of Singapore will extend the open electricity market to all consumers, starting from November 1, with 1.3 million households and 67,000 businesses having the option to choose from 12 retailers. This follows a successful soft launch in Jurong, where households paid an average of 20% lower electricity rate. The rollout will occur in four zones, with retailers offering standard price plans and non-standard plans. Consumers can switch or remain with SP Group without a deadline, and retailers that exit the market will transfer customers to SP Group.

images.alt_text: The open electricity market will be extended to all consumers in Singapore, zone by zone, starting from Nov 1, the Energy Market Authority (EMA) announced on Friday.

site_title: Sakae Holdings files police report over 'highly questionable' sugar trade by its representative
summary: Sakae Holdings has filed a police report against a customer who failed to pay US$4.3 million for 9,343 metric tonnes of sugar delivered in December 2017. An internal audit found the transaction to be "highly questionable" and determined no criminal misconduct by Sakae or its officers. The customer's shareholders and directors have remained uncontactable, and the representative appointed by Sakae to carry out the trade has also been unreachable. Sakae had previously authorized the representative to conduct commodity trading and had made a full provision for doubtful debts.

site_title: Drug developer Cennerv lodges prospectus for Catalist IPO
summary: Singapore-based biotech company Cennerv Pharmaceuticals lodged a preliminary prospectus for a planned initial public offering (IPO) on the Singapore Exchange's Catalist board. The company specializes in treatments for CNS disorders, including depression, insomnia, and autism. Cennerv has not generated revenue and reported annual losses from FY2015 to FY2017, but expects to initiate clinical development of its lead drug products and acquire a 60% stake in a US-based developer of non-CNS drugs with the IPO proceeds. The IPO's details, including pricing and timing, have not been announced.

site_title: Slowing home sales hitting China's home-appliance stocks
summary: Chinese home-appliance stocks, such as Qingdao Haier and Gree Electric Appliances, have seen their shares decline in 2018 due to the slowing property market. The sector's fortunes are closely tied to property sales, and the government's tightening controls have weighed on the outlook. Analysts predict that pessimistic expectations over home sales may persist, impacting appliance stocks for the next two to three years. Other consumer discretionary stocks have also suffered, with the CSI 300 Index dropping 16% in three months.

site_title: French handbag maker Longchamp to invest in China to revive sales
summary: Longchamp, a French handbag maker, plans to invest in China and the US to boost sales, driven by celebrity tie-ups and online platforms. Founded in 1948, the company aims to outperform global luxury industry growth of 6-8% by 2019. Longchamp, which saw sluggish growth in 2016 and 2017, plans to launch its own e-commerce platform in China in 2019 and expand its US presence. The company's CEO, Jean Cassegrain, believes that improving its current network is key to growth.

site_title: Asia's fundamentals strong despite sharp market swings
summary: Asia's equity markets have experienced a sharp decline in recent months, with a 9.2% drop in SGD terms as of September 17, 2018. Despite this, the region's economic fundamentals remain positive, with most major economies expected to see strong growth and resilient corporate earnings. The decline in share prices has led to a discount in the forward price-to-earnings ratio, making Asian equities an attractive proposition for investors. Experts expect an attractive annualized total return of 23% by end-2019, with various investment options available to access the region's potential returns.

images.alt_text: The disruption to global trade growth has sent Asian equities tumbling, with China the main target of the US.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Ascott Residence Trust (ART) has acquired a prime greenfield site in Singapore for S$62.4 million, planning to develop the first co-living property, lyf one-north Singapore. The project is expected to achieve a Temporary Occupation Permit by 2020 and open in 2021, targeting millennials with smaller units and larger communal facilities. ART's gearing post-transaction will be 37.2%, and the estimated cost of S$117 million will be funded by debt, resulting in an expected net yield of 6% on a stabilized basis. The trust's FY18-FY20F DPU forecasts are reduced by 3-6%.

site_title: Reits
summary: Realty news highlights the ongoing market trends. US mortgage rates rose after a five-week decline, affecting the global real estate market. In Singapore, a Q3 wave of condo launches will test demand for prime projects above S$3,000 psf. Manhattan rents hit a record, with more increases predicted. Goldman Sachs acquired a hotel and retail portfolio in Seoul, while UK homebuyer demand rebounded to a six-month high. New World is selling China property assets after a loan deal. WeWork secured new tenants at its Singapore location.

site_title: SGX proposes new 'trade at close' session for securities market
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has proposed a new "trade at close" (TAC) session, allowing participants to execute orders at the closing auction price after the closing routine ends. The 5-minute session will apply to ready and unit share markets, with three key features: no trading if no closing auction price, matching orders at the closing auction price, and amended orders must be priced at the closing auction price. The proposal aims to preserve price discovery while allowing fixed-price trading. The TAC session will be implemented in July 2019 if feedback is positive.

site_title: China can offset the negative impact of the new round of US tariffs
summary: China can mitigate the negative impact of US tariffs by implementing looser fiscal policies and supporting investment in certain sectors. The country's GDP growth is expected to shed 0.3-0.5 percentage points due to the tariffs, but analysts believe Beijing has tools to offset this impact. The government will pursue targeted investment in sectors such as infrastructure and manufacturing, and the depreciation of the yuan will also make Chinese exports more competitive globally.

site_title: Greenbacks and green travel
summary: Hotels are cutting luxury perks to reduce costs and go green, but do eco-travelers really exist? Many hotels are adopting ISO 14001 standards, which have helped Hilton save over $550 million since 2009. However, guests are willing to make some eco-friendly adjustments, such as accepting energy-saving bulbs and reducing towel and linen changes. Despite this, some studies suggest that price and convenience remain top priorities for travelers.
