As a result, the industry is struggling to determine whether eco-friendly practices boost earnings or not.

site_title: SGX proposes new 'trade at close' session for securities market
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) proposes a new 'trade at close' session, allowing investors to trade at the closing auction price after the closing auction routine ends. The five-minute long session will apply to the ready and unit share markets, preserving the integrity of the price discovery process. This move aims to provide investors with more flexibility and liquidity, particularly during times of market volatility.

site_title: STI regains 3,200 level as calm returns to Wall St
summary: Asian stocks rose on Friday, driven by Wall Street's gains and expectations of less economic damage from US-China tariffs. The Hang Seng Index, Shanghai Composite Index, and Japan's Topix all increased, with the Straits Times Index regaining the 3,200-point mark for the first time this week. Local banks led gains, including DBS Group Holdings, OCBC Bank, and United Overseas Bank, while Keppel Corp and Sembcorp Marine also saw significant increases. The surge was attributed to a "return in risk appetite" and positive economic data from the US.

site_title: Hot tech sector prompts shake-up in S&P 500 stock indexes
summary: The S&P 500 stock index has reshuffled its components in response to the rapidly changing tech sector, creating a new "communication services" group that replaces the "telecommunication services" sector. The change affects three sectors and allows investors to have more exposure to companies like Google, Netflix, and Facebook, which were previously in the "information technology" group. The shift also results in a shift of billions of dollars in shares, with analysts expecting further investment in technology due to the increased sector weight.

site_title: Almost 300 CBRE agents to move over to ERA Realty
summary: CBRE Realty Associates agents, nearly 300 in number, are moving to ERA Realty Network under a "strategic collaboration" aimed at pooling their residential market strengths. The transfer will see ERA acquire the agents, while CBRE will maintain a small core residential team. The partnership aims to enhance ERA's presence in the Singapore residential market.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed higher on Friday, rising 6.94 points to 1,810.64. The index saw 2.07 billion lots worth RM3.61 billion traded, with 477 gainers outnumbering 389 losers. The gains followed a global stock rally, despite US President Trump's new threats.

site_title: Anti-theft bags for anti-stress travel
summary: Travelers can enhance their holiday experience with anti-theft bags from eBags.com, which feature slash-proof "eXomesh" and "Carrysafe" wire-mesh structures, and "Turn & Lock" and "Snap & Lock" security hooks. The Anti-Theft Hobo and Anti-Theft Crossbody bags, priced at US$89.99 and US$84.99 respectively, offer comfort, organization, and peace of mind with features such as RFID-safe pockets, foam-lined pockets, and light-colored interiors. These bags are designed to reduce the risk of pickpocketing and provide greater security for travelers.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Lafe Corporation Ltd and its former subsidiary Lafe Technology (Hong Kong) Ltd have settled a lawsuit in Hong Kong for US$300,000. The company had faced a writ of summons in 2012 for US$5.7 million.

site_title: Valuetronics resumes production at flooded Guangdong plant
summary: Valuetronics Holdings has resumed production at its flooded Guangdong plant in China, with power supply restored after Super Typhoon Mangkhut caused temporary work stoppages. The company will gradually ramp up operations at the facility. All employees were safe, and the majority of production facilities were unaffected. Valuetronics shares initially fell 5.3% but recovered, ending the day unchanged at 68 Singapore cents. The company is assessing the effects of the flooding and working on its insurance claim.

site_title: Sakae Holdings files police report against customer who failed to pay for sugar trade
summary: Sakae Holdings has filed a police report against a customer who failed to pay US$4.3 million for 9,343 metric tonnes of sugar delivered in December 2017. An internal audit found the sales transaction to be "highly questionable", but no criminal misconduct was determined by the firm. The customer's shareholders and directors remain uncontactable, and a representative appointed by Sakae to carry out the sugar trade has also failed to respond. The incident occurred during a period of high sugar trading activity for Sakae's subsidiary, Sakae Capital Pte Ltd.

site_title: Mystery 0.6% rise in HK dollar jolts city's sleepy FX market
summary: The Hong Kong dollar experienced a 0.6% rise, its largest gain in 15 years, on Friday, propelling the local currency to its strongest level since November. The surprise move caught traders off guard, with theories including rising borrowing costs, position adjustments, and a buying stampede by short sellers. The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) said it will maintain the dollar's link to the US greenback, and market participants view elevated interbank rates as a contributing factor to the strengthening. The risk of higher borrowing costs triggering a downturn in the city's property market remains, with home prices soaring 16% over the past 12 months.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Friday afternoon trading higher at 3,213.52, up 1% on day
summary: Singapore stocks resumed trading on Friday afternoon, advancing 33.09 points, or 1%, to 3,213.52. Gainers outnumbered losers 186 to 134, with total shares traded worth S$559.4 million. Notable movers included YZJ Shipbuilding and Thai Beverage, which rose 0.9% and 2.2%, respectively.

site_title: Low cost portfolios get you a headstart, says endowus
summary: Endowus, a fee-only financial advisory firm, aims to shake up Singapore's unit trust landscape with low-cost portfolios. The firm will invest in institutional share classes of funds, where management fees are significantly lower than retail fees. By avoiding product commissions, endowus believes it can reduce conflicts of interest. With its FA licence obtained early this year, endowus is poised to disrupt the industry, potentially making low-cost investing more accessible to Singaporean investors.

site_title: Lack of awareness, tardy response contributed to SingHealth cyber-attack: Solicitor-General
summary: A Singaporean cyber attack on SingHealth compromised the private data of 1.5 million patients, with the attacker gaining entry into the healthcare group's network as early as August 2017. A lack of situational awareness and a tardy response by SingHealth and its technology vendor, Integrated Health Information Systems (iHiS), contributed to the breach. The attacker exploited weak passwords and inactive administrator accounts to steal sensitive data, which was exfiltrated between June 27 and July 4, 2018. The incident was only reported on July 20, two weeks after the breach was detected.

site_title: Samsung plans to slow chip growth to keep supplies tight, maintain prices
summary: Samsung Electronics plans to slow chip growth in 2019 to maintain tight supplies and prices, aiming for less than 20% growth in dynamic random-access memory (DRAM) and 30% growth in Nand flash. This move is expected to prop up prices for Samsung and its peers, but may cut back on investment, affecting suppliers. Analysts believe the decision shows Samsung prefers maintaining a tight oligopoly market structure, keeping prices high rather than taking market share, which may lead to sustained DRAM prices.

images.alt_text: Investors are increasingly concerned that Samsung and its peers are headed for a downturn as chip demand softens after years of record profit.

site_title: Going to pot: Maine eatery uses weed to sedate lobsters
summary: A Maine restaurant owner, Charlotte Gill, claims to be using marijuana smoke to sedate lobsters before cooking them, aiming for a more humane death. The method involves blowing marijuana smoke into a tank with lobsters, which Gill believes reduces aggression. However, animal rights group PETA opposes the practice, stating it does not alleviate the suffering of being boiled or steamed alive. Experts disagree on whether lobsters feel pain and whether cannabis has a similar effect on them. Gill plans to offer this method as an option for customers who want baked lobsters.

site_title: Tech-crazy Asians - and the firms that woo them
summary: Apple's new iPhone XS and XS Max release saw telcos and retailers going above and beyond to impress customers, offering unique experiences such as same-day delivery and exclusive bundles. Companies like Lazada, Courts, and Singtel invested in creating smooth launches, with some retailers even offering free gifts like power banks from Huawei. The release of the new iPhones saw a surge in traffic and sales, with some items selling out within the first hour. The effort paid off, with customers expressing appreciation for the hassle-free experience.

images.alt_text: StarHub CEO Peter Kaliaropoulos (right) delivering an iPhone XS Max to Mr Edwin Sim, a loyal StarHub customer since 2000.
Singtel staff welcoming iPhone customers. It offered subscribers an exclusive Apple bundle at a big discount, as well as S$100 off their new iPhone.

site_title: RHB banks on small-, mid-caps going abroad
summary: RHB Bank plans to expand its SME network in Singapore, focusing on small- and mid-cap businesses, and take them beyond the city-state into Asean. The bank will add cash management services and engage with fintech firms to better analyze SMEs' operations. It aims to tap into the region's growing trade and manufacturing sectors, where Singapore companies can export technology to countries with lower manufacturing costs. RHB also plans to offer private wealth services to business owners, leveraging its expertise in the Malaysian-Singapore corridor.

site_title: MAS senior official joins Accounting Standards Council
summary: A senior official from the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS), Lim Cheng Khai, has been appointed a member of the Accounting Standards Council (ASC) by the Minister for Finance. Lim, executive director of MAS' Capital Markets Intermediaries Department II, joined the ASC on August 30, replacing retiring member Ng Yao Loong.

site_title: The future is in Africa, and China knows it
summary: China is investing heavily in sub-Saharan Africa, with a focus on business services, construction, and infrastructure, rather than extractive industries. This investment is seen as a key part of an effective growth strategy, creating jobs and income for local entrepreneurs and workers. Africa's large and growing population, combined with improving governance and literacy rates, make it an attractive destination for foreign investment. As the continent becomes more populous, companies with a presence in Africa will be better positioned to sell into emerging markets, and the sector is expected to grow in importance, driven by services and infrastructure development.

site_title: Vietnam President dies, aged 61, after 'serious illness'
summary: Vietnam's President Tran Dai Quang, 61, died on Friday after a "serious illness" despite international medical efforts. The presidency is largely ceremonial, with Quang holding mostly ceremonial duties. He was appointed in 2016, previously serving as Minister of Public Security. Quang's health had been a subject of concern, with rumors circulating on social media prior to his death. His passing marks a significant development in Vietnam, which has no paramount ruler and is officially led by the president, prime minister, and Communist Party chief.

site_title: Bank of America sees high-level exits over strategy differences
summary: Bank of America's investment bank is experiencing high-level exits due to disagreements over risk-taking and a struggle to retain market share in US merger advisory. CEO Brian Moynihan questioned the bank's risky moves at a June meeting, prompting departures including Christian Meissner, head of the corporate and investment-banking division. The bank's appetite for risk has been reined in after a large margin loan loss, and it lags behind competitors in the US merger advisory market. More executives may follow Meissner's lead, potentially leading to further changes within the bank.

site_title: Sustainability reporting and investors: what to look out for
summary: Investors are increasingly driving companies to disclose more detailed sustainability information, following SGX rule changes requiring sustainability reporting from 2017. Investors look for a company's framework for addressing sustainability issues, key risks and opportunities, and materiality of risks. Key areas of focus include climate change, energy intensity, employee relations, and management quality. Sustainability reports can provide insights into a company's long-term performance and business model, with efforts to reduce water and energy intensity offering near-term benefits and a low-carbon economy presenting long-term opportunities. Effective sustainability management can lead to competitive advantages and better investment decisions.

site_title: Don't get used to being used at work
summary: Employees should establish and maintain healthy boundaries at work to avoid being taken advantage of. Signs of being exploited include lack of respect for time, zero appreciation for exceptional work, colleagues taking on more work while others coast, doing the work of a manager without a promotion, and lack of concern for career progression. To protect oneself, prioritize tasks, delegate work when possible, and communicate with superiors about compensation and career growth. Standing up for oneself is essential for a healthy work-life balance and career advancement.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks climb as trade worries ease, won gains
summary: South Korea's KOSPI stock index rose 0.68% to 2,339.17 on Friday, driven by easing trade worries and a stronger won. Investors took a cautious approach ahead of US-China tariffs set to take effect on September 24, but optimism over the resumption of the Kaesong Industrial Complex in North Korea boosted shares of companies with ties to the zone. The won gained 0.46% against the US dollar, its second straight weekly gain.

site_title: Innovation 'is key for business success and needs right mindset'
summary: Singapore's Senior Minister of State for Trade and Industry Koh Poh Koon emphasized the importance of innovation in business success, particularly in the face of disruptive forces such as new technologies and changing consumer demand patterns. He stressed the need for the right mindset towards innovation, stating that it is not limited to large or 'deep tech' firms. The Emerging Enterprise Awards highlighted the presence of innovation among smaller firms, underscoring the potential for these companies to drive business success.

site_title: China stocks soar on policy support hopes
summary: China's stock markets surged on Friday, with the blue-chip CSI300 index rising 3.0% to its biggest one-day gain since May 2016, driven by hopes that government efforts to boost domestic demand could offset trade war effects. Analysts attributed gains to low valuations in banking and real estate stocks, as well as new State Council guidelines on improving domestic consumption. The yuan also strengthened, and several stocks rose by the 10% daily limit, despite the Shanghai index still being down 15.4% for the year.

site_title: Tech to snooze to
summary: Bose's Sleepbuds, a pair of noise-masking earbuds, aim to improve sleep quality by replicating soothing sounds, such as a babbling brook or aircraft cabin, to help users fall asleep and wake up refreshed. The earbuds, which double the battery life of the original earbuds, attach magnetically to a charging case and come with a variety of sounds to choose from. Reviewers found the Sleepbuds to be effective in promoting better sleep, but noted some drawbacks, including a tendency for the earbuds to rasp on the pillow and the inability to stream music from the phone. The device's focus on sleep and limited sound options may be a drawback for some, but overall, the Sleepbuds have been praised for their potential to change "millions of people's lives."

site_title: US existing home sales flat in August: survey
summary: US existing home sales remained steady in August at an annual rate of 5.34 million units, after four months of declines. Prices continued to rise, increasing 4.6% to $264,000, marking the 78th straight month of increases. The inventory of available homes remained unchanged at 1.92 million, representing a 4.3-month supply. Economists attribute the steady sales to stabilizing inventory and rising prices, but note that the housing sector is unlikely to contribute to GDP growth this year due to rising material costs and labor shortages.

site_title: Uber-Deliveroo deal: Singapore deja vu for ridehailing giant?
summary: Uber is in talks to acquire Deliveroo for over $2 billion, aiming to dominate the food delivery market in Europe. The deal would merge Uber's expertise in logistics and business insights with Deliveroo's network of over 500 cities. In Singapore, where Deliveroo is the market leader, Uber would face a dilemma: competing with GrabFood, its own rival, or pulling out and ceding market share to foodpanda or GrabFood. Deliveroo's profitability and valuation of over $2 billion make it a tempting target, but the outcome could lead to a costly fight with Grab or a retreat from the Singapore market.

images.alt_text: The Uber-Deliveroo deal unveiled on Friday could present Uber with a dilemma in South-east Asia, where Uber owns a nearly 30 per cent stake in Grab (which runs GrabFood, a Deliveroo rival), and where Deliveroo is said to be the market leader in food delivery in Singapore.

site_title: Australian shares rise as materials rally; NZ at record
summary: Australian shares rose 0.4% on Friday, following a strong US market finish, with materials stocks leading gains. The S&P/ASX 200 index reached 6,193.60, its highest since August 14. BHP and Rio Tinto surged, while consumer staples and industrials also contributed to gains. Across the Tasman Sea, New Zealand's benchmark index hit a record high of 9,375.97, up 1.1% on the week.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's open electricity market will be extended islandwide in phases starting from November 1. NTUC Enterprise acquired Kopitiam to keep cooked food prices affordable. An attack on SingHealth's network in August 2017 has been linked to cyber attacker entry. Valuetronics resumed production at a flooded Guangdong plant and Vibrant Group is in talks for a sale-and-leaseback deal. Singapore shares rose 1.2% on Friday, while the Asian garment industry braces for higher US tariffs and China's GDP growth is expected to slow.

site_title: Owner of Soilbuild Reit's manager takes S$30m of its S$65m perps offering
summary: The manager of Soilbuild Business Space Reit's owner, Lim Chap Huat, has agreed to take nearly half of the Reit's S$65 million subordinated perpetual securities offering, subscribing for S$30 million. The perpetuals will bear a 6% annual distribution rate for the first three years, resetting to 379 basis points over the three-year Singapore-dollar Swap Offer Rate thereafter. The net proceeds will be used for financing the Reit's general corporate purposes, including acquisitions and investments. Units of Soilbuild Reit rose 0.5 cents to 59.5 Singapore cents following the announcement.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close higher as yen edges lower
summary: Tokyo stocks closed higher on Friday, with the Nikkei 225 index rising 0.82% and the Topix index up 0.92%, driven by receding trade war worries and a weaker yen against the dollar. The gains follow a strong week, with the Nikkei 225 up 3.36% and the Topix up 4.36%. The news comes as US shares also rose, despite ongoing tariff uncertainty and split views on the Fed's future moves.

site_title: South Korea exports rise most in a year despite trade war
summary: South Korea's exports rose 22% in the first 20 days of September, the largest increase in a year, despite the escalating US-China trade war. Semiconductor, petroleum goods, and cars led the growth, with exports to China and the US increasing 29% and 18.6% respectively. Economists attribute the surge to exporters rushing shipments ahead of the Chuseok holidays, rather than the trade war itself. This marks the first time exports have seen a year-over-year increase since September last year.

site_title: NTUC Enterprise to buy Kopitiam in move to keep cooked food prices affordable
summary: NTUC Enterprise Co-operative Limited has acquired Kopitiam Investment, a homegrown food centre operator, to ensure affordable and accessible cooked food options in Singapore. The transaction complements NTUC Foodfare's operations and retains management teams and employees. The deal aims to leverage mutual capabilities and create better experiences for customers and employees. Kopitiam operates 56 food courts, 21 coffeeshops, and employs over 1,000 staff, serving 350,000 meals daily. The acquisition is part of NTUC Enterprise's social mission to make quality cooked food affordable to the Singapore community.

images.alt_text: Kopitiam operates 56 food courts, 21 coffeeshops, three hawker centres and two central kitchens, serving about 350,000 meals a day.

site_title: Singapore shares close 1.2% higher on Friday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 1.2% to 3,217.68 on Friday, driven by a 261-156 gainers-to-losers ratio, with 1.63 billion shares worth S$1.71 billion changing hands. Notable gainers included Genting Singapore (3.9%) and YZJ Shipbuilding SG (flat). The 5-day rally comes ahead of GDP data, with investors brushing off new Trump threats.

site_title: Hong Kong dollar gone wild: 0.6% surge shocks sleepy market
summary: Hong Kong's dollar surged 0.6% on Friday, its largest gain in 15 years, shocking the city's sleepy foreign-exchange market. The unexpected move came as a surprise to traders, with one describing it as "huge." The strengthening of the local currency is a rare occurrence, with swings greater than 0.4% only happening three times since a trading band was widened in 2005.

site_title: Jet Airways set for four-year low as tax officials check books
summary: Jet Airways shares plummeted 7.6% as tax officials conducted a survey at its offices, marking a four-year low. The airline, struggling to pare losses, is seeking to raise funds and reduce debt. It reported its biggest quarterly loss since 2015 and has lost market share to budget carriers like IndiGo and SpiceJet. The incident of pilots forgetting to maintain cabin pressure during ascent also raised concerns. An initial inquiry by India's Registrar of Companies into potential wrongdoings at the airline has been initiated.

images.alt_text: Shares of Jet Airways India Ltd headed for their lowest level in almost four years after income-tax authorities conducted a "survey" at its offices, the latest trouble for an airline that's been struggling to pare losses.

site_title: Malaysia shares open higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 8.06 points to 1,811.76 on Friday, with a trading volume of 42.48 million lots worth RM22.38 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 163 to 42, indicating a positive market trend.

site_title: Valuetronics resumes production at flooded Guangdong plant
summary: Valuetronics Holdings has resumed production at its Guangdong plant, which was suspended due to flash flooding from Super Typhoon Mangkhut. The company had halted operations on September 17, but power supply has been restored. Valuetronics is assessing the effects of the flooding and working on its insurance claim. The company's main plant in Huizhou remains unaffected. Shares were trading up 1.5% before the announcement.

site_title: Asia: Markets build on gains after Wall St record
summary: Asian markets continued their upward trend on Friday, driven by record closes on Wall Street and positive US economic data. The Dow and S&P 500 reached new highs, easing concerns about the US-China trade row. Emerging market currencies also recovered, with some currencies rising over 1%. Shanghai dipped 0.2%, but overall, the region's markets ended the week on a strong note, with Tokyo, Hong Kong, and Singapore leading the gains.

site_title: Vibrant Group in talks over proposed sale-and-leaseback for its facility
summary: Vibrant Group's subsidiary LTH Logistics (Singapore) is in exclusive discussions with an international real estate fund about the possible sale and leaseback of its chemical logistics and warehousing facility for over S$220 million. The facility, located at 121 Banyan Drive, comprises two plots of land with warehouse facilities and ancillary offices. The sale and leaseback deal would allow Vibrant Group to free up capital and reduce its property costs. No further details have been disclosed, but the deal is expected to be finalized in the coming months.

site_title: Japan PM Abe, US President Trump to hold summit on Sept 26
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe and US President Donald Trump will hold a summit meeting on September 26 in New York during the United Nations General Assembly. The meeting will also include a dinner on September 23. This marks the first time the two leaders will meet since Trump took office. The summit is seen as an opportunity to discuss key issues, including trade and security.

images.alt_text: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe (right) and US President Donald Trump will hold a summit meeting on Sept 26, Japan's top government spokesman said on Friday.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open sharply higher on Friday
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened sharply higher on Friday, tracking a record performance on Wall Street and extending this week's rally on hopes of resolving the US-China trade dispute. The Hang Seng Index rose 0.85% to 27,712.35, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also edged up. This week's rally is attributed to investors' optimism over a potential resolution between the US and China, despite ongoing trade tensions.

site_title: Vietnam President Tran Dai Quang dies, aged 61, after 'serious illness'
summary: Vietnam President Tran Dai Quang, 61, died after a 'serious illness' in a military hospital in Hanoi. Despite efforts by international doctors, Quang, who held mostly ceremonial duties, passed away. Rumors of his illness had been circulating on social media for months. Quang, a former police general and member of the Politburo, was appointed president in 2016 and had no paramount ruler role. His death comes after a series of public appearances showing his declining health, including during a visit by Indonesian President Joko Widodo.

site_title: iPhone XS buyers undeterred by eye-watering prices, few upgrades
summary: Hundreds of iPhone XS buyers, despite the phone's eye-watering price, lined up at Apple stores worldwide to purchase the latest iPhone model. The iPhone XS is up to $200 more expensive than last year's iPhone X, featuring dual sim-cards for the first time, but few upgrades. Sales were largely restricted to those who had already ordered, and online orders are not arriving until October. The global smartphone industry has stalled, but Apple's business model focuses on steadily raising average prices and expanding the total number of active devices to support sales of accessories and digital services.

site_title: Samsung is planning to lower chip growth to maintain prices
summary: Samsung Electronics plans to curb chip growth next year to maintain tight supplies and drive up prices amid slowing demand. The move is expected to impact semiconductor prices, with Samsung now forecasting less than 20% growth for dynamic random-access memory and 30% for Nand flash. Limiting chip supply may boost prices, but would also mean reduced investment, potentially affecting suppliers such as Applied Materials and Lam Research Corp. This strategy is seen as a sign of Samsung's preference for maintaining oligopoly market structure and keeping supply tight to support higher prices.

site_title: Opportunities for Singapore startups in Russia's consumer, tech sectors
summary: Singapore businesses can tap into Russia's thriving consumer market, with the average Russian spending 80% of their disposable monthly income. Russia's e-commerce market is expected to be worth US$21 billion by 2020, offering opportunities for Singapore startups to collaborate with Russian partners. Two memoranda of understanding (MOUs) were signed, providing access to business networks, markets, and resources in both countries, aiming to diversify Singapore's economy and capitalize on Russia's growing consumer and tech sectors.

site_title: Singapore shares rise at Friday's open; STI up 0.94% to 3,210.44
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.94% at Friday's open, with the Straits Times Index reaching 3,210.44. Gainers outnumbered losers 85 to 28, driven by 41 million securities worth S$85 million. Key stocks included Mapletree Logistics Trust and Yangzijiang Shipbuilding, both advancing. This marks the 5th consecutive day of gains ahead of GDP data release.

site_title: Attack on SingHealth network traced back to Aug 2017: COI hearing
summary: A cyber attack on SingHealth's network, which compromised 1.5 million patients' data, began in August 2017 when an attacker infected workstations, allowing them to move laterally through the network. The attacker exploited weak passwords and inactive administrator accounts to gain access to the electronic medical records (EMR) system, stealing data between June 27 and July 4. Inadequate situational awareness and response to red flags contributed to the breach, with staff not reporting incidents until July 9, allowing the breach to go unreported for several days.

site_title: Amazon aims to make Alexa assistant bigger part of users' lives
summary: Amazon is expanding its Alexa digital assistant and online services with new products and partnerships. The company is integrating Alexa into various devices, such as microwaves, and enabling it to anticipate users' needs. Alexa can now set microwave cooking times and voice instructions. Amazon is also partnering with various companies to further develop its AI capabilities, aiming to make Alexa a bigger part of users' lives.

site_title: Moon's nuclear diplomacy a 'dangerous gamble': analysts
summary: South Korean President Moon Jae In's recent nuclear diplomacy with North Korea has been criticized as a "dangerous gamble" by analysts. Despite securing only minimal concessions from Kim Jong Un, Moon prioritized trust-building with Pyongyang over denuclearization, sparking concerns that Seoul's approach may facilitate North Korea's efforts to maintain its nuclear arsenal. Analysts argue that the agreements reached in Pyongyang fall far short of US demands for a "final, fully verified denuclearization" of North Korea.

site_title: California to limit use of plastic straws in restaurants
summary: California will ban single-use plastic straws in restaurants unless customers explicitly ask for them, starting next year. The law, signed by Governor Jerry Brown, aims to reduce plastic waste and encourage alternatives. Non-compliant restaurants will receive two warnings and face a maximum fine of $300 per year. The move follows global efforts to address the plastic waste crisis, including a proposed EU ban on single-use plastics and France's penalty system for consumer goods made of plastic.

site_title: Portable Scent
summary: Muji's portable aroma diffuser, priced at S$59, is a cordless, palm-sized device that disperses scent for up to four hours without water. It can be used in various settings, such as hotel rooms, planes, and crowded public transportation, and turns off automatically after two hours of continuous use. The device requires only three to five drops of essential oil and comes with a storage pouch, holder, and USB cable.

site_title: No new progress reported in US-Canada trade talks
summary: US-Canada trade talks ended with no progress, two days after high-level negotiations. Canadian Foreign Minister Chrystia Freeland described the talks as "constructive" but did not mention any breakthroughs. Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau has resisted the US push for a deal, saying it will take more work to reach an agreement. US President Donald Trump has demanded a revised NAFTA deal, while Canada will not accept any deal that compromises its managed dairy sector. The talks are expected to resume in the future, but no date has been set.

site_title: Singapore's open electricity market to be extended islandwide in phases from Nov 1
summary: Singapore's open electricity market will be expanded islandwide in phases, starting from November 1, with 1.3 million households and 67,000 businesses able to choose from 12 authorized retailers. The rollout will occur in four zones, with the first phase covering postal codes 58-78. Retailers must offer at least one of two standard price plans: a fixed price plan and a plan with a fixed discount off the regulated tariff. Consumers can compare prices using a tool on the Energy Market Authority's website, and those who switch may see a 20% lower electricity rate on average.

site_title: Transcelestial raises S$2.5m in seed funding to deliver Internet with satellites, lasers
summary: Transcelestial Technologies, a Singapore-based space startup, raised S$2.5 million in seed funding to develop a space laser network for high-speed Internet access. The funding round was led by Wavemaker Partners and Enterprise SG's SEEDS Capital, with additional investors including Airtree Ventures and angel investors. The company aims to deliver Internet to the 4 billion people globally without access, using a space-based network.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Mapletree Logistics Trust, Soilbuild Reit, Olam, OUE Lippo Healthcare
summary: Mapletree Logistics Trust completed a private placement raising S$375 million, Soilbuild Business Space Reit issued S$65 million in subordinated securities, and Olam International secured a S$365 million Japanese loan facility. OUE Lippo Healthcare received a listing and quotation notice for 2.2 billion new rights shares.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher, extending Wall St rallies
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Friday, extending rallies in New York as investors focused on positive economic data. The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.62% and the Topix index rose 0.58%, driven by a lack of concern over trade war worries. This follows a similar trend on Wall Street, where the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Uber is in early talks to buy Europe's Deliveroo
summary: Uber Technologies Inc. is in early talks to acquire London-based food-delivery company Deliveroo for several billion dollars, marking a major attempt to dominate the European food-delivery market. The talks come as Uber prioritizes its food-delivery business ahead of a planned initial public offering. Deliveroo, valued at over $2 billion, has been reluctant to relinquish independence, and the acquisition price is unknown. Uber is weighing other acquisitions, including Middle Eastern ride-sharing rival Careem, as it seeks to expand its presence in Europe and Asia.

site_title: Wells Fargo to cut up to 26,500 jobs within three years
summary: Wells Fargo announced plans to cut 5-10% of its workforce, affecting up to 26,500 jobs, to become more efficient and meet customer needs through digital platforms. The move is part of the bank's transformation efforts to regain footing after scandals. The job cuts and attrition will help the company streamline its business model and deliver what customers want.

site_title: US takes off the gloves in global cyber wars: top officials
summary: The US has taken a more aggressive stance in the global cyber war, with National Security Advisor John Bolton announcing a new cyber strategy that allows for offensive cyber operations without prior approval. The strategy targets China, Russia, and other rivals, with Bolton stating that the US will respond to cyber attacks "offensively, as well as defensively." The US will also increase efforts to build up internet security in allied countries and impose cyber sanctions on adversaries. This shift marks a departure from the Obama administration's approach, which required high-level authority for military cyber operations.

site_title: Hong Kong dollar up about 0.2%, hits highest level since late Feb
summary: The Hong Kong dollar rose about 0.2% against the US dollar, reaching its highest level since late February, at 7.8244. The currency has been stuck near 7.85 since March, within its trading band set by the Hong Kong Monetary Authority.

site_title: China races to get goods to US before tariffs hit
summary: US President Donald Trump's 10% tariffs on $200 billion of Chinese imports, set to take effect Monday, have sparked a freight frenzy as Chinese manufacturers rush to deliver goods to the US before the tariffs kick in. Cargo rates across the Pacific have reached a four-year high, with shipments from China to the US surging and ports like Los Angeles and Oakland experiencing record volumes. The tariffs may benefit US consumers by delaying anticipated price hikes on household goods, but could lead to higher prices and product shortages if the 25% tariff is imposed later.

site_title: Japan inflation edges up but way below target in August
summary: Japan's inflation rate rose to 0.9% in August, still below the Bank of Japan's 2% target, and 0.4% when excluding food and energy costs. The central bank's ultra-loose monetary policy appears to be having limited impact, and the economy continues its battle with deflation. Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's re-election is expected to lead to active fiscal measures to boost the economy, while the Bank of Japan will maintain its interest rate policy for an extended period.

site_title: Trump's ex-lawyer Cohen cooperating in Mueller probe: report
summary: Michael Cohen, former personal lawyer to President Donald Trump, has been cooperating with Special Counsel Robert Mueller's investigation for over a month, according to a report. Cohen, who pleaded guilty to bank fraud and campaign finance violations, has participated in multiple interview sessions with Mueller's team. His cooperation could help him receive a lighter sentence. This development is seen as bad news for Trump, as Mueller's investigation increasingly closes in on the White House, probing potential collusion with Russia and obstruction of the investigation.

site_title: China anti-graft agency probes head of energy administration
summary: China's anti-graft agency has placed Nur Bekri, the head of the country's energy administration, under investigation for "serious violations of Party disciplinary rules and laws", indicating corruption. Bekri, an ethnic Uighur, held several high-ranking positions, including deputy party secretary and government chairman in Xinjiang. This is the latest top official to be ensnared in the Communist Party's anti-graft campaign, targeting the energy industry. Bekri's investigation follows a broader crackdown led by President Xi Jinping since 2012, which has resulted in several top officials being investigated.

images.alt_text: Nur Bekri, an ethnic Uighur, had worked his way up in his native Xinjiang, eventually rising to deputy party secretary and government chairman in the far western region, before receiving the post at the energy administration in 2014.

site_title: Singapore needs foreign tech talent: Ong Ye Kung
summary: Singapore's economy is facing a shortage of high-tech workers, particularly in areas like software programming and artificial intelligence. To address this, the country plans to bring in foreign talent while rebalancing its education system to meet future demands. Education Minister Ong Ye Kung emphasized the need for a critical mass of workers in these sectors to drive innovation and productivity. The government will maintain restrictions on foreign labor for high-end jobs, while keeping a quota system for lower-skilled industries.

site_title: Singapore and China sign seven deals on bilateral cooperation
summary: Singapore and China signed seven bilateral cooperation deals on Thursday, including a project to replicate the government-to-government project, Tianjin Eco-city. The deals cover areas such as arts, entrepreneurship, research, and emerging industries. This is the first time Chinese Vice-Premier Han Zheng co-chaired the annual bilateral meeting with Deputy Prime Minister Teo Chee Hean. The agreements aim to enhance cooperation between the two countries, with a focus on promoting economic growth and innovation.

site_title: Federal Reserve likely to push aside recession worry in unveiling 2021 view
summary: The Federal Reserve is expected to project a continued US expansion through 2021, despite recession worries. According to Deutsche Bank economists, the Fed will likely slow growth but avoid a downturn. Officials have expressed concerns about an inverted yield curve, but the longest US expansion in 10 years may last a few more years. The Fed's 2021 forecasts are expected to focus on slowing growth and potentially lower interest rates, with a "soft landing" possible. Former Fed Chairman Ben Bernanke and Ray Dalio also predict a potential decline in 2020.

site_title: SGX assures it will act in clear cases of minority oppression
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has assured that it will act in clear cases of minority oppression, following a long AGM discussion on the matter. The exchange called for an exchange to mediate disputes between companies and shareholders, addressing concerns raised by a minority shareholder suing the board of a listed company. This move aims to improve corporate governance and protect minority interests.

site_title: Europe: Britain's FTSE lags peers as upbeat retail data boost pound
summary: Britain's FTSE 100 index closed up 0.5% despite lagging European peers, as upbeat UK retail data boosted the pound and countered the impact of Brexit concerns. The data showed British shoppers continued to spend despite the World Cup ending, preventing the FTSE from fully participating in the global equity rally. Basic materials and financials were the main sectors contributing to the FTSE's rise, while shares in GVC Holdings and Diageo also rose.

site_title: Singapore and China sign seven bilateral agreements
summary: Singapore and China signed seven bilateral agreements, including a deal to replicate the government-to-government project, Tianjin Eco-city. The agreements cover arts, entrepreneurship, intellectual property, and research. The Memorandums of Understanding and Strategic Framework Agreement were signed at the 14th Joint Council for Bilateral Cooperation meeting, co-chaired by Deputy Prime Minister Teo Chee Hean and Chinese Vice-Premier Han Zheng. The agreements aim to strengthen bilateral cooperation between the two nations.

site_title: Owner of Soilbuild Reit's manager takes S$30m of its S$65m perps offering
summary: The controlling shareholder of Soilbuild Business Space Reit's manager, Lim Chap Huat, is taking nearly half of the S$65 million subordinated perpetual securities offering. He will subscribe for S$30 million at an annual distribution rate of 6% for the first three years. The remaining proceeds will be used for financing the Reit's general corporate purposes. The securities are expected to be issued on September 27, and come under Soilbuild Group Holdings' S$500 million multi-currency debt issuance program.

site_title: ECB must discuss rate path beyond first hike: Praet
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) will need to discuss its interest rate path beyond its initial hike to maintain consistent market prices with a slow rise in inflation. ECB chief economist Peter Praet stated that more extensive guidance is necessary to ensure investors price only a very slow policy normalization. Praet's comments follow a similar argument from fellow board member Benoit Coeure, suggesting the ECB may need more extensive rate guidance to lay down conditions for future moves.

site_title: China's unicorns race to public markets as Silicon Valley waits
summary: China's tech unicorns are rushing to public markets, cashing in on their valuation. At least 16 tech bigwigs have raised a combined $48 billion in net worth through IPOs, with Xiaomi co-founders holding half of the value. Pinduoduo's CEO Colin Huang became a billionaire two weeks after the e-commerce platform's US IPO. This contrasts with US tech titans, who are holding onto their private wealth, estimated to be over $60 billion.

site_title: Court orders winding-up of Stratech, appoints liquidators from BDO
summary: A Singapore court has ordered the winding-up of Stratech, a mainboard-listed company, after it failed to garner enough support from creditors on a proposed scheme of arrangement. The company's controlling shareholders are working to overturn the decision and may appeal. Stratech's shares remain suspended, and the company will continue to execute ongoing contracts and support customers while awaiting further developments.

site_title: US: Dow, S&P 500 end at records as market shrugs off trade fights
summary: US stocks ended at records on Thursday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average up 1.0% at 26,656.98 and the S&P 500 gaining 0.8% to 2,930.75, despite ongoing trade tensions with Canada and China. Investors seemed to shrug off concerns, with tech stocks and bank stocks driving gains. The market's optimism was tempered by caution from analysts, who noted that any further trade developments could dent the rally.

images.alt_text: Residents wait in line for their Covid-19 vaccine inside the Discovery Ltd. mass vaccination site at the Cape Town International Convention Centre in Cape Town, South Africa, on Tuesday, Sept. 7, 2021. Talks are underway with Johnson & Johnson about running a booster trial in South Africa after the company’s Covid-19 vaccine was used in a mass trial of almost half a million health workers in the country. Photographer: Dwayne Senior/Bloomberg##########mlvaxx18d##########

site_title: Abe wins third term as LDP leader - a step closer to becoming Japan's longest-serving PM
summary: Shinzo Abe won a commanding victory in the Japanese governing party's leadership vote, securing a third term as party leader and prime minister. The win moves him closer to becoming Japan's longest-serving prime minister, surpassing the previous record set in the early 20th century. Abe faces challenges including a towering national debt, climate change-related disasters, and the 2020 Olympics in Tokyo, and analysts say he must navigate US President Donald Trump's trade demands and domestic scandals to achieve his goals.

site_title: US sanctions Chinese military unit for buying Russian jets, missiles
summary: The US has imposed sanctions on China's Equipment Development Department of the Chinese Ministry of Defence and its top administrator, Li Shangfu, for purchasing Russian Sukhoi Su-35 fighter jets and S-400 surface-to-air missiles. This marks the first time a third country has been punished under the CAATSA sanctions legislation for dealing with Russia. The US aims to impose costs on Russia for its "malign activities", including aggression in Ukraine and cyber intrusions, and will consider similar action against other countries taking delivery of Russian fighter jets and missiles.

images.alt_text: Stepping up pressure on Moscow over its "malign activities," the US State Department said it was placing financial sanctions on the Equipment Development Department of the Chinese Ministry of Defence, and its top administrator, for its recent purchase of Russian Sukhoi Su-35 fighter jets and S-400 surface-to-air missiles.

site_title: Panel on online falsehoods unveils 22 recommendations to fight fake news
summary: Singapore's Select Committee on Deliberate Online Falsehoods has released 22 recommendations to combat fake news, including enacting legislation and creating a national framework for public education. The committee also urges technology companies to take proactive steps against fake content. However, there are divergent views on whether the government should be part of a fact-checking coalition. The recommendations aim to swiftly disrupt the spread of online falsehoods and promote fact-checking.

site_title: Man charged with trying to steal passenger jet at Orlando airport
summary: A 22-year-old student, Nishal Sankat, was charged with attempting to steal a passenger jet at Orlando Melbourne International Airport. Sankat, who holds a commercial pilot's license, jumped a fence and boarded an Airbus 321 but was quickly detained by security personnel. Authorities found no evidence of a connection to terrorism and no weapons or explosives. The motive behind the incident is unknown, and Sankat is being held on charges of attempted theft of an aircraft, burglary, and criminal trespassing.

site_title: Coca-Cola, Walmart to cut plastic pollution in oceans
summary: Coca-Cola and Walmart have pledged to help reduce plastic pollution in oceans as part of a campaign by G-7 nations. The goal is to develop alternatives to plastic packaging, increase recyclability, and achieve 100% recyclable plastics by 2030 and 100% recyclable and reused plastics by 2040. Major companies such as Loblaws, Nestle Canada, and IKEA are also backing the initiative, with Volvo aiming to make 25% of its car plastics recyclable by 2025. The move follows the signing of the Ocean Plastics Charter by G-7 nations in June.

site_title: Indiana Jones hat fetches £393,600 at auction
summary: Indiana Jones's fedora sold for £393,600 at a London auction, exceeding expectations. The iconic hat, worn by Harrison Ford in the 1981 film "Raiders of the Lost Ark," was signed by Ford and underwent a worn look treatment before filming. The jacket worn by Han Solo in "The Empire Strikes Back" failed to meet its £500,000 reserve, but has generated interest from potential buyers. The auction, held by Prop Store, featured over 600 costumes and props from popular films and TV series, with total sales expected to reach a record £3.5 million.

site_title: A worrying future for the next generation?
summary: A new survey by the Pew Research Center found that confidence in the future is weak, especially in the richest societies, with only 33% of US respondents believing children will be financially better off than their parents. In contrast, confidence in the current economic situation is higher, with 65% of US respondents believing it is good. Experts suggest that people may compartmentalize their economic views, using the Great Recession as a reference point for the future, or that they have broadened their definition of well-being to include harsher recessions.

site_title: Myanmar 2.0 in the making?
summary: Myanmar's economy is expected to grow 6.9% in 2018, but sectors like property and construction are slumping due to foreign investment decline and rising inflation. The country is also facing significant political controversies, particularly over the Rakhine state and Muslim minority, the "Rohingya". However, the government has taken steps to address these issues, including simplifying business registration processes and implementing the Myanmar Sustainable Development Plan. The government also acknowledges the need for increased transparency and engagement with the international community. Despite these challenges, investors should consider the potential for growth and development in Myanmar, but must also be aware of the risks and responsibilities involved.

site_title: Disney admits Dark Side for 'Star Wars', plans slowdown of releases
summary: Disney has admitted to releasing too many "Star Wars" films too quickly, planning to slow down the release schedule after the underwhelming performance of "Solo: A Star Wars Story". CEO Bob Iger acknowledged that the franchise's initial plan to release a new film every year was a mistake, citing anticipation as a key factor. The company now plans to take a more cautious approach, with no specific timeline for future releases, and is exploring new content, including a "Star Wars" series created by "Game of Thrones" producers.

images.alt_text: In contrast, "Star Wars: The Last Jedi," which was released just six months before in late 2017, earned more than US$1.3 billion worldwide.

site_title: Ping An's Lu Global stakes claim on wealth outside China
summary: Ping An Group's Lu International has launched its online wealth management platform Lu Global in Singapore, targeting 10,000 customers within the next 12 months. The platform aims to grow assets under management (AUM) by 20-30% next year, offering premium wealth-management products with a minimum investment of under $1,000. Lu Global uses Ping An's technology for risk management and has strict know-your-customer and anti-money laundering compliance procedures. The platform's growth is seen as a move to differentiate itself in the competitive Singaporean online wealth management market.

site_title: Malaysia's Felda to sell assets, reduce debts by end of 2018
summary: Malaysia's Felda, a state palm oil plantation agency, plans to sell assets, including properties in London, to reduce its debts of nearly $2 billion by the end of 2018. Chairman Megat Zaharuddin aims to trim debts by 20% and boost cash flow, with a focus on restructuring loans and improving palm oil productivity. The agency has diversified into property, including hotels, but has faced issues of poor management and corruption. A loan restructuring and asset sales are expected to take at least two years to complete.

site_title: OECD trims economic outlook over trade and EM woes
summary: The Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) has trimmed its economic outlook, citing rising trade frictions and emerging market turbulence. Global growth is expected to peak at 3.7% this year and next year, down from earlier forecasts of 3.8% and 3.9%. Trade growth has slowed to 3% due to US-China tensions, while emerging markets like Argentina, Brazil, and Turkey face challenges from rising US interest rates and a stronger dollar, leading to forecast cuts for these countries.

site_title: Oil prices pull back as Trump tweet shifts focus to Opec
summary: US President Donald Trump's tweet to Opec to increase production at its meeting in Algeria led to a pullback in oil prices. Brent crude oil settled at $78.70 a barrel, down 78 cents, and US light crude at $70.80 a barrel, down 32 cents. The easing was a result of Trump shifting the focus away from the market's bullish momentum, which had driven prices toward four-year highs. Global benchmark Brent had been trading near $80 a barrel due to expectations of reduced supply from US sanctions on Iran.

site_title: Najib slapped with another 25 charges over 1MDB funds
summary: Former Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak has been charged with 21 counts of money laundering and four counts of abuse of power over hundreds of millions of dollars received in his personal bank account from scandal-plagued 1Malaysia Development Bhd (1MDB). The charges bring the total to 32, as investigators ramp up a probe into the disappearance of billions from the state fund. Najib has denied all charges, claiming they will allow him to clear his name. He was released on bail of RM3.5 million after the judge set the amount to be paid by September 28.

site_title: Mid-Autumn Night's Dream
summary: The Sun Yat Sen Nanyang Memorial Hall in Singapore is set to celebrate the Mid-Autumn Festival with a line-up of activities, including a giant 180cm mooncake, lantern installations, workshops, and an evening concert featuring traditional performances. The festival, Wan Qing Mid-Autumn Festival 2018, will take place on September 22 and 23 from 10am to 9:30pm. Visitors can enjoy a variety of activities, including making snowskin mooncakes and lanterns, tea appreciation, and watching dragon and lantern dances.

site_title: The Real Marco Pierre White
summary: Marco Pierre White, a renowned British restaurateur, has poured four years of labor and dedication into restoring two derelict shophouses in Singapore into "The English House," a unique eatery that celebrates the country's old-world heritage. White personally oversaw the restoration process, selecting furniture and artifacts from his personal collection, and even participated in construction, revealing hidden stone carvings. The result is a visually stunning, eclectic space that blends kitsch and history, showcasing White's meticulous attention to detail and passion for preserving Singapore's architectural heritage.

site_title: The Big Picture
summary: The Singapore International Photography Festival is back for its sixth edition, showcasing 11 exhibitions and numerous workshops and masterclasses. Notable exhibitions include solo shows by cult photographers Nguan and Nobuyoshi Araki, featuring soft and intimate photographs of everyday life and erotic poses. Other notable photographers include Laura Letinsky, known for her still-life images with accidents and ambiguity, and Mark Neville, who documents contrasting stories of individuals from various communities. The festival runs from September 20 to December 9.

site_title: Lendlease joins growing trend of developers running co-working spaces
summary: Lendlease is set to launch its own co-working brand within its Paya Lebar Quarter mixed-use development in Singapore, joining a growing trend of developers running their own co-working spaces. The move aims to cater to the demand for high-quality flexible workspace from corporate occupiers. Several other developers, including Keppel Land, Mapletree Investments, and Ascendas-Singbridge, have already launched their own co-working brands in the country. This trend is gaining traction in the Asia-Pacific region, with benefits including capturing all revenue and having more control over the workspace.

images.alt_text: Keppel Land's KLOUD centre, at Keppel Bay Tower in Singapore, offers almost 18,000 square feet of smart office space. The company plans to operate a KLOUD centre in each of the markets where it operates.

site_title: Return Of The Celebrity Chef
summary: Celebrity chefs are set to return to Singapore's dining scene, with several high-profile names, including Alain Ducasse, Anne-Sophie Pic, and Jereme Leung, opening restaurants at Raffles Hotel. The influx of big-name chefs is seen as a response to the city's evolving dining scene, with locals and visitors alike seeking unique experiences. Ivan Brehm, chef-owner of Restaurant Nouri, notes that the market is saturated, making it harder for celebrity chefs to make an impact. However, Raffles Hotel aims to redefine the celebrity chef dining experience with an approachable and honest positioning. The return of Jereme Leung to helm Raffles Hotel's Chinese restaurant, Yi, is seen as a homecoming story, and his restaurant will offer guests a modern take on Chinese cuisine.

site_title: Design For All
summary: Archifest 2018, an annual festival celebrating architecture and the built environment, is being held from Sept 28 to Oct 10. The event features a pavilion at Marina Bay Sands Event Plaza, designed by Kite Studio Architecture, where visitors can recreate the colourful flats at Rochor Centre by painting bricks. The festival explores three sub-themes: Design for People, Design for Time, and Design for Environment, with activities including symposia, talks, and exhibitions on topics such as well-being, sustainability, and community engagement.

site_title: Ascott Reit acquires one-north site to build co-living property
summary: Ascott Residence Trust acquired a 60-year leasehold site in Singapore's one-north hub for S$62.4 million, planning to develop the site into the area's first co-living property, lyf, under The Ascott's co-living brand. The bid was the highest among four, exceeding the second-highest bid by nearly S$13m.

site_title: US dollar slides to 7-week low as trade war fears ebb
summary: The US dollar fell to a 7-week low against major currencies due to easing trade war concerns between China and the US. Currency markets have stabilized after reacting to new tariffs announced by Washington and Beijing on Tuesday. Traders expect minimal global shock from the dispute, with potential fallout taking time to affect corporate earnings.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: OUE Hospitality Trust's unit price declined 7.3% after a related party's acquisition of office components through a dilutive rights issue. The decline was attributed to concerns of an equity fundraising to fund the acquisition of Oakwood Premier, a serviced residence component.

site_title: Sushi Chiharu delivers value-for-money omakase
summary: Sushi Chiharu, a Singaporean offshoot of a renowned Osaka restaurant, offers value-for-money omakase at a capped price of S$140 for 18 courses. Despite a few missteps, including a mediocre opening course and some inconsistent flavors, young chefs Issei Taba and Nakahara Saya showcase strong core skills and impeccable manners. The restaurant's unpretentious ambience and promise of a varied meal make it a welcome respite from the cacophony of Cuppage Terrace. Overall, Sushi Chiharu earns a promising 6.5 rating for its potential and potential for growth.

images.alt_text: Anago (saltwater eel) sushi, which was unconventionally served at the start of the meal instead of at the end.
Nigiri sushi and sashimi from Sushi Chiharu by Tayama Dining.
The interior of the restaurant, which is located on one end of Cuppage Terrace.

site_title: Fidelity's venture arm Eight Roads opens Singapore office
summary: Eight Roads, the venture capital arm of Fidelity International, has opened an office in Singapore to invest in startups in the region. The office will focus on writing Series B to D cheques, investing up to S$25 million, and participate in occasional Series A funding rounds. Eight Roads will target sectors like fintech, healthcare IT, and AI, and has a unique single LP structure allowing it to hold onto its positions longer. The move aims to bridge the gap in funding for startups in South-east Asia, where each market is regulated differently and requires different managerial talent.

site_title: Asian markets close mixed, STI inches up
summary: Asian markets closed mixed on Thursday, with Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) inching up 0.1% to 3,180.43. Keppel Corp led gains, rising 2.6% on news of a 40% stake in a Nanjing residential project. Banking counters UOB and DBS also rose, while OCBC slipped 0.2%. The STI's gains were largely due to tech stocks rebounding after being oversold, with Venture and Hi-P gaining 3.3% and 4.4% respectively. Elsewhere, Japanese stocks ended flat, while Hong Kong and Korean stocks rose.

site_title: This new Audi is a "technological rock star"
summary: Audi unveiled its first fully electric vehicle, the e-tron SUV, with a 95kWh lithium-ion battery pack, offering a range of over 400km on a single charge and a top speed of 200km/h. The car boasts all-wheel drive and can complete the 0-100km/h dash in 5.7 seconds. Audi plans to launch 12 EVs by 2025, with a focus on differentiating itself through premium digital services and a "charge-on-demand" service in Singapore. The e-tron is part of Audi's efforts to overcome the difficulties of EV ownership in Singapore, where most car owners lack private parking for charging.

site_title: Mapletree Logistics Trust prices S$375m placement offer at S$1.21 apiece
summary: Mapletree Logistics Trust has completed a S$375 million private placement, issuing 309.9 million new units at S$1.21 apiece. The deal was about 2.4 times covered and saw shares close at S$1.24, down S$0.02. The proceeds will be used to fund warehouse acquisitions and pay fees. The trust plans to list the new units on or around September 28 and declare an advanced distribution to existing unit holders.

site_title: The evolving role of the Singapore CIO/CISO
summary: The evolving role of the Singapore CIO/CISO is highlighted in the wake of rising data breaches and cyber threats. Industry leaders agree that CIOs and CISOs must go beyond technical expertise to provide strategic leadership and business knowledge. With the increasing importance of cybersecurity, CIOs/CISOs are expected to advise boards on security threats, updates, and risk mitigation. To combat the growing threat, boards must take note of security and update themselves on prevailing risks, and companies must adopt a security-first approach with stronger privacy laws in mind.

site_title: Keppel unit buys 40% stake in project on prime Nanjing site
summary: Keppel Land China, a subsidiary of Keppel Corp, is acquiring a 40% stake in a prime Nanjing residential site for approximately S$283 million. The 8.8-hectare site will feature 1,728 units and 50 street-front shops, with the first phase expected to launch in Q4 2018. The project is expected to be completed in Q2 2022, marking Keppel Land China's first foray into Nanjing and expansion in the Yangtze River Delta region.

site_title: BOE governor's dire UK housing scenario deemed 'highly unlikely'
summary: Bank of England Governor Mark Carney's warning of a 35% UK housing crash in a no-deal Brexit scenario has been deemed "highly unlikely" by economists. A survey of 10 economists found that home prices would decline 10% or less, with seven predicting a 5-10% rise in London in the event of a soft Brexit. Experts, including Savills and the Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors, have expressed skepticism about the severity of a housing market downturn, citing encouraging signs of a rebound in home prices.

site_title: Four electric luxury cars headed for Singapore
summary: Four luxury electric cars, including the BMW iX3, Jaguar i-Pace, Mercedes-Benz EQC, and Porsche Taycan, are set to arrive in Singapore. The vehicles, which offer varying power and battery capacities, are part of the growing competition in the electric vehicle market. The BMW iX3 and Jaguar i-Pace are expected to enter production in 2020, while the Mercedes-Benz EQC's availability is yet to be confirmed. Porsche's Taycan, with its sporty design and high-performance capabilities, is also expected to debut in Singapore in 2020, rivaling Audi's e-tron.

site_title: SIA launches new service for transporting pharma cargo
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) launched Thrucool, a new service for transporting pharmaceutical cargo, on September 20, 2018. The service offers dedicated cold chain services with priority uplift and handling, cold room facilities, and temperature control. SIA has partnered with terminal operators to launch a quality corridor along the Zurich-Singapore-Sydney route. The airline is the first in the Asia-Pacific region to be awarded the IATA CEIV Pharma certification, ensuring the integrity of pharmaceutical shipments.

site_title: On A Cultural High In Tokyo
summary:
Tokyo offers a unique blend of cultures, with nine million people creating their own utopian societies. Visitors can experience this diversity through various attractions. Mount Takao, a 600-meter mountain, features ancient Shinto and Buddhist temples, verdant flora, and fauna, as well as a flight of 108 stairs that symbolize purification. The nearby Takaosan Yakuoin Temple offers a daily fire ceremony and life-size sculptures of mythical Tengu. 

Sanrio Puroland, an amusement park dedicated to kawaii culture, attracts fans of Hello Kitty, with merchandise worth over $50 billion. Visitors can also stay at the Keio Plaza Hotel Tama, which features Hello Kitty rooms.

The Mori Art Museum showcases contemporary art, with an exhibition on Japanese architecture that explores the evolution of buildings since the Meiji Restoration. The museum also features other shows, including "Invisible Cities," which highlights utopian habitats.

site_title: Ghost properties: cruel legacy of Venezuela's migration crisis
summary: Venezuela's economic crisis has led to a mass exodus, with 1.6 million people fleeing since 2015, and a total of 2.3 million living abroad. Deserted homes and apartment blocks, known as "ghost properties," have become common, with many owners choosing not to sell or rent due to the country's hyperinflation, insecurity, and lack of access to basic necessities. The situation has sparked a new business - management of deserted homes - but homeowners remain concerned about squatters and the potential loss of their properties.

site_title: EQ Power: Mercedes switches on its electric drive
summary: Mercedes-Benz has launched its first plug-in hybrid electric vehicle (PHEV) in Singapore, the E 350 e. The car combines an electric motor with a 2.0-litre turbo petrol engine, offering 33km of emissions-free electric propulsion. With a price tag of S$305,888, the E 350 e is considered a premium offering, and its price may hinder widespread adoption. The introduction of PHEVs in Singapore follows a global trend, with over 297 PHEVs on the road in the country as of August, and the car industry expected to sell 1.9 million plug-ins worldwide in 2018.

site_title: Singapore market still singing trade war blues
summary: Singapore-listed companies with supply chain links in China, such as electronics manufacturers and banks, are expected to be impacted by the latest round of Sino-US tariffs. The new 10% tariffs on $200 billion worth of Chinese goods take effect Monday, with the potential to rise to 25% in 2019. Companies like Hi-P, Valuetronics, and Memtech International may face challenges due to their reliance on Chinese suppliers. Analysts predict a difficult investment proposition for Singapore stocks, with a 12-month investment horizon recommended. The trade war's impact may also affect airlines and port operators, such as Singapore Airlines and Hutchison Port Holdings Trust.

site_title: The Right Fit
summary: Customization options for homes are expanding, with made-to-measure furniture, exotic homeware, and online platforms like Custo and Blafink offering tailored solutions. LivingDNA's new store in Singapore offers a wide range of rugs and homeware, while customers can also design and order custom furniture online. These services cater to the growing demand for space-efficient and functional living spaces, particularly in Singapore where living areas have shrunk over the past 30 years. By providing customization options, these businesses aim to make furniture shopping a more enjoyable experience.

site_title: Still safe as houses?
summary: A recent article discusses property investing in Singapore, comparing returns from physical residential property to other assets. Despite market fluctuations, property remains a tried-and-tested strategy for building and preserving wealth. The article notes opportunities in Asian equities and sustainability-focused investments, but cautions investors to establish clear boundaries in the workplace to avoid exploitation.

site_title: Lexus UX review: "On a mission to conquer"
summary: The Lexus UX, a compact luxury crossover, is designed to attract new customers and challenge traditional perceptions of the Lexus brand. With a smaller price tag, it offers a more accessible luxury experience, competing with popular models like the Audi Q2, BMW X1, and Mercedes-Benz GLA. The UX boasts a refined interior, sharp design, and a smooth powertrain, making it a strong contender in the competitive small SUV market. With a starting price expected to be under $150,000, the Lexus UX aims to win over new customers and redefine the Lexus image.

site_title: Australia raises jail terms for food tampering to 15 years
summary: Australia has raised the maximum jail term for food tampering to 15 years, in response to a scare over needles found in strawberries and other fruits. The move aims to repair public trust in the industry, worth A$160 million. The new legislation also criminalizes hoax claims, punishable by up to 10 years in prison. The government has welcomed the action from strawberry farmers, who face financial ruin if demand does not recover quickly, and retailers have withdrawn sewing needles from store shelves to prioritize customer safety.

site_title: Trump plans to nominate financial stability expert Nellie Liang to Fed
summary: US President Donald Trump plans to nominate Nellie Liang, a financial stability expert and former Federal Reserve economist, to the Fed's Board of Governors. If confirmed, Liang would join the central bank at a time it faces financial dangers, including a build-up of risks due to low interest rates and investors seeking higher returns. Liang, who has expertise in financial stability policy and research, would be a forceful voice in advocating for higher bank capital standards to mitigate risks.

site_title: World powers jockey for position in Europe
summary: US President Donald Trump and Russian President Vladimir Putin met with Eastern European populists, Polish President Andrzej Duda and Hungarian Prime Minister Victor Orban, respectively, amid growing international interest in the region. The meetings, along with Chinese Premier Li Keqiang's "16+1" summit, underscore the competition for economic and political influence in Europe. Brussels is concerned about Hungary and Poland's leadership of the Visegrad group, which is pushing back against EU integration proposals. The region's rise of right-wing populism poses challenges to EU standards on democracy and the rule of law, prompting Brussels to trigger the EU's most serious disciplinary procedure against Hungary.

site_title: Dutch cities see beauty in trash recycled for parks and crafts
summary: Dutch cities are turning trash into valuable resources, aiming to become circular economies by 2030 and 2050. The Zero Waste Lab in Amsterdam and Rotterdam's "Recycled Park" are examples of initiatives that collect waste, upcycle it into useful items, and reward participants. Since 2016, the lab has collected 1,100 household items and partnered with local businesses to create cushions, bags, and children's arts and crafts projects. The goal is to improve recycling rates and social cohesion, while showcasing the beauty in waste.

site_title: Anderson Valley is among California's best for pinot noir
summary: Anderson Valley in California's Mendocino County has emerged as one of the state's top regions for producing high-quality, balanced pinot noir wines. A recent blind tasting of 20 Anderson Valley pinot noirs by The New York Times found that the region's wines are nuanced and expressive, with flavors of flowers, red fruits, and earthy minerality. The top-rated wines came from producers such as Ceritas, Donkey & Goat, and Peay, who have found success in making subtle, restrained wines that showcase the region's unique terroir.

site_title: Foreign and Korean investors duke it out over Samsung Electronics
summary: Foreign and Korean investors are engaged in a battle for control of Samsung Electronics Co. South Korean individual investors are defending the company against bearish institutional Korean firms and foreign sellers, who are concerned about Samsung's uncertain outlook. The company's shares are being contested in a tug-of-war, with foreign investors seeking to capitalize on potential weaknesses, while individual Korean investors are fighting to maintain control and protect the company's interests.

images.alt_text: Samsung is the Korean company that is most sold by foreigners and institutions, and also the biggest buy for domestic retail investors, going by flow data complied by Bloomberg from Korea Exchange.

site_title: French rail giant SNCF gearing up for German threat to iconic TGV
summary: French rail operator SNCF must repair relations with staff and prepare for competition from German Deutsche Bahn and Italian Trenitalia when the high-speed sector is liberalized in 2020. CEO Guillaume Pepy aims to transform the state-owned company into a "normal" operator with improved customer service and punctuality. Following a restructuring agreement, SNCF will introduce new services, including InOui and Ouigo, and may consider a tie-up with Alstom and Siemens to bolster European train manufacturing. The company's bid to run trains on the UK's High Speed 2 line shows confidence in growth.

site_title: Buoyant gas industry may be blindsided by renewables
summary: The global gas industry is experiencing a surge, with LNG trade expected to double to 600 million tonnes annually by 2025 and reach 700 million tonnes by 2030, according to analysts. However, this growth may be threatened by the rise of renewable energy. Commodity merchant Vitol expects the industry to be blindsided by this shift, which could alter the market dynamics and impact the gas industry's future growth.

site_title: Aston Martin aims to overtake Ferrari with IPO of up to £5.07b
summary: Aston Martin is set to go public with an IPO valuing the company at up to £5.07 billion, surpassing Ferrari's valuation. The luxury sports car maker will sell a 25% stake at £17.50-£22.50 per share, with trading beginning around October 8. The valuation is a "big vote of confidence" for the company, which is halfway through a turnaround and has a headstart in the SUV market. Analysts are skeptical, citing the company's loss-making history and fragile balance sheet.

images.alt_text: CEO Andy Palmer, seen here with a Vantage, said the company's first SUV is coming out in 2020, giving it access to the Chinese market and a headstart over Ferrari, which has postponed its SUV to 2022.

site_title: The house of Aston Martin could design you a house
summary: Aston Martin is collaborating with Aston Martin Consulting to design and build a range of properties, including houses and underwater structures, inspired by their sports cars. The company aims to create unique and luxurious living spaces that combine Aston Martin's design expertise with innovative materials and technologies. This project represents a departure from the company's traditional focus on high-performance vehicles and marks a new frontier in luxury design and engineering.

images.alt_text: From submarines (above), to powerboats, to condos, no project is off the table for Aston Martin Consulting, says design director Miles Nurnberger.
From submarines, to powerboats, to condos, no project is off the table for Aston Martin Consulting, says design director Miles Nurnberger (above).

site_title: Classic Opera
summary: A classic 1918 Peking opera, "Farewell My Concubine," is being re-adapted by the West Kowloon Cultural District Xiqu Centre. The opera tells the story of warlord Xiang Yu's last hours with his concubine, drawing inspiration from Lilian Lee's 1985 novel. The new adaptation combines traditional Cantonese opera techniques with innovative stage techniques, performed in Mandarin and Cantonese. The production will be held at the China Cultural Theatre Centre on September 21 and 22.

site_title: China's doctor shortage prompts rush for AI healthcare
summary: China is addressing its severe doctor shortage by leveraging AI technology.
