The company aims to boost margins to over 38% without sacrificing exclusivity, and plans to invest 3.6 billion euros in new vehicles and hybrid technology. Ferrari's shares rose 3.9% after the announcement, as investors welcomed the revised forecast and the company's plans to expand into new markets and technologies.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: CapitaLand acquired 16 US freehold multi-family properties for US$835 million, with 3,787 apartment units. The company aims to achieve a 10% total return through strategic asset enhancement initiatives and plans to scale up its exposure to the sector through partnerships. Sembcorp Industries reported a strong core profit of S$28 million in Q2 2018, driven by high electricity spot prices in India.

site_title: Looking for cheap real estate in Dubai? Check the stock market
summary: Dubai's real estate market is becoming more affordable, as the stock market offers cheaper shares of major property owners and developers. Emaar Properties PJSC, the developer of the world's tallest building, has seen its shares at their lowest valuation since 2010, while Damac Properties Dubai Co PJSC traded at its cheapest price-to-earnings ratio in 17 months. This trend may make owning real estate in Dubai more accessible to those looking for affordable options, despite the city's reputation for luxury living.

site_title: Cooling measures make it harder to clear new housing stock: Redas
summary: Singapore's nearly 46,000 new private residential units, set to be released in 2019 and 2020, may take five years to be absorbed by the market due to cooling measures. Redas president Augustine Tan said developers must differentiate their projects, price them sensitively, and work harder to sell units. The measures, imposed in July, have weakened market sentiment and demand, with sustained downward pressure on the retail and industrial markets. Second Minister Desmond Lee reiterated the government's rationale for the measures, aiming to maintain a stable and sustainable property market.

site_title: More scope for Asia's PE firms to expand: report
summary: Asia-Pacific private equity firms see increased scope for expansion, with 75% of executives believing geographic expansion is more important, and 70% favoring vertical integration deals. However, they prioritize industry specialization less than their global counterparts. The majority of executives (70%) expect increased consolidation among firms due to competition for deals, with respondents planning to make acquisitions based on industry or market differentials, create vertically integrated portfolio companies, or build from scratch with a hand-picked management team.

site_title: Yuen Sing Mansion up for en bloc sale
summary: Yuen Sing Mansion, a four-storey freehold development in Geylang, Singapore, has been launched for collective sale by tender. The 7,868 sq ft site, zoned residential/institution, can accommodate up to 29 apartments. Owners are expecting bids exceeding S$17 million, with a potential gross floor area of 24,235 sq ft. The tender closes on Oct 23, with the site accessible to nearby entertainment and dining options and within a 10-minute drive to major attractions.

site_title: Singapore to spend S$30m to fund new cybersecurity centre
summary: Singapore plans to spend S$30 million to fund the Asean-Singapore Cybersecurity Centre of Excellence, set to launch in Q2 2019. The centre will enhance the region's cyber capabilities and response to emerging global threats. The five-year initiative aims to deepen regional cyber capabilities.

site_title: BT's video series looks at growth of e-payments
summary: Singapore is heading towards a digital economy with electronic payments (e-payments) on the rise. A video series by The Business Times explores this trend, featuring initiatives like DBS PayLah! and GrabPay, which have seen over 50,000 daily transactions. The Singapore Quick Response Code (SGQR) has also been launched, adopting 27 payment schemes. Efforts to encourage seniors to adopt digital payments are underway, and the "Smart City" series will cover various initiatives to make Singapore a Smart Nation.

site_title: Wall Street fears the end of an era
summary: Wall Street is concerned that the exclusive club of wholesale trading venues, operated by interdealer brokers, is being breached by hedge funds and brokers. These platforms, traditionally used by big banks, are now being accessed by non-bank entities, threatening the banks' control over the corporate bond market. The tension is fueled by post-crisis regulations that reduced the banks' role, allowing smaller firms to step in. The interdealer brokers are fighting to maintain their share of the market, while the banks are trying to defend their turf, but it's a losing battle, according to analysts.

site_title: Facebook accused of allowing bias against women in job ads
summary: Facebook has been accused of allowing employers to discriminate against women in job ads, with a group of job seekers filing charges with the federal Equal Employment Opportunity Commission. The allegations claim that Facebook's targeting technology was used to exclude women from job ads, with some employers using the platform to reach only men. Facebook has denied the allegations, stating that it does not take down job ads that exclude a gender, but the group of job seekers and lawyers involved in the case say the technology makes it akin to an employment agency, facilitating discrimination.

site_title: Straits Trading expands into logistics sector in Australia
summary: Straits Trading Company (STC) is expanding into the logistics sector in Australia through a joint venture with Commercial & General. The partnership aims to develop, own, and manage logistics properties and ancillary business space. Commercial & General has over A$2 billion in projects delivered or under development. This move marks STC's entry into the Australian logistics market, further diversifying its business operations.

site_title: A sigh of relief for Asian markets
summary: Asian markets experienced a sigh of relief on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) hitting a two-week high after two straight days of declines. The STI rose 1.2% to close at 3,176.57, driven by buoyant Asian equities and investor sentiment lifted by cheaper yen and Wall Street gains. Despite the latest US-China tariffs, nearly all Asian indices ended trading in the green, with Tokyo's Nikkei surging to an eight-month high and Hong Kong's Hang Seng rising 1.2% to a two-week high.

site_title: Danske CEO to step down amid laundering scandal
summary: Danske Bank A/S CEO Thomas Borgen is stepping down amid allegations of a major European money laundering scandal, with up to $234 billion in illicit funds potentially flowing through a unit in Estonia between 2007 and 2015. The scandal has shocked Denmark, a country known for low corruption and transparency, and has raised questions about the bank's controls. Borgen will remain in his job until a replacement is appointed, and shares in Danske have plummeted 32% this year. The bank is facing potential fines of up to $800 million and may impact Denmark's AAA credit rating.

images.alt_text: "Even though the investigation conducted by the external law firm concludes that I have lived up to my legal obligations, I believe that it is best for all parties that I resign," says Mr Borgen.

site_title: Seeing stars this Weekend
summary: Celebrity chefs Alain Ducasse, Anne-Sophie Pic, and Bjorn Frantzen are set to open outposts in Singapore, reviving the city's dining scene. This influx of big-name chefs follows the success of homegrown Michelin-starred chefs and a vibrant street food scene. Marco Pierre White discusses his restored English House, while Jeong Ae Ree shares her mission to expose audiences to opera experiences. The article also explores Tokyo's hidden cultural gems, including spirituality in Mount Takao, kawaii culture in Puroland, and high-brow art at the Mori Art Museum.

site_title: HNA exploring sale of CWT: sources
summary: HNA Group, a Chinese conglomerate, is exploring the sale of its logistics firm CWT to non-Chinese buyers in a move to reduce debt. The sale comes nine months after HNA acquired CWT in a US$1 billion deal. This is part of HNA's efforts to restructure its operations, following a series of high-profile acquisitions and investments that have sparked intense scrutiny. A part of CWT is expected to be sold, with talks with investment banks currently underway.

site_title: 'Hope springs eternal' for Team Emerio
summary: Team Emerio, an IT-services company, has participated in the Business Times Corporate Golf League for eight years, with their best finish being runners-up in 2016. Despite not being in the running for top honors, Team Emerio's captain, Harish Nim, remains optimistic, saying "hope springs eternal." The tournament is set to enter its final leg, with newcomers Proelect and Team Boss leading the competition. The two teams are expected to field their best players, with Proelect's Tan Lee Hong and Team Boss's John Lim leading the charge.

site_title: SGX-listed Geo Energy eyes dual primary listing in Hong Kong
summary: Geo Energy Resources, a Singapore-listed Indonesian coal miner, plans to pursue a dual primary listing on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange (HKEX) by next May or June. The move aims to improve liquidity and valuation, with the company citing its undervalued stock price and greater depth in the sector. Geo Energy's CEO, Tung Kum Hon, sees the listing as an exciting development, which will provide the company with options to fund acquisitions and attract new equity capital. The company has hired Guosen Securities as the sole sponsor for the potential listing.

site_title: DBS ramps up project finance deals on Asia infrastructure
summary: DBS Bank is expanding its project finance team to capitalize on Asia's growing infrastructure development needs. The bank aims to advise on projects across sectors, leveraging its local knowledge and strong regional connections. With $26 trillion in infrastructure investment needs from 2016 to 2030, DBS is focusing on sectors such as solar, wind, and hydroelectric power, as well as transportation and telecommunications projects. The bank has secured notable deals in Indonesia, China, and Australia, and currently has six advisory mandates related to the Belt and Road Initiative.

site_title: China will not resort to massive stimulus, yuan devaluation: PM Li
summary: China's Prime Minister Li Keqiang stated the country will not resort to a massive stimulus to boost its economy, unlike in 2008. China aims to maintain steady growth, despite facing challenges at home and abroad, including US trade policies and aggressive imports. Li emphasized the need for a balanced approach, focusing on investment, fiscal policy, and monetary policy to offset downward pressures. China will not devalue its currency and instead work on reforming its economy, positioning itself as a leader of multilateralism.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Singapore Post's subsidiary QSI to sell 10.77% of 4PX shares, reducing stake to 19.75%, after issuing additional shares to existing shareholder Zhejiang Cainiao Supply Chain Management Co. 4PX ceases to be an associated company of SingPost. Meanwhile, MM2 Asia appoints Haitong International Securities as financial adviser to review its businesses and explore foreign listing. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer receives 9.8 times oversubscription.

site_title: Facing the test of history in the Taiwan Strait
summary: The Chinese government is intensifying its efforts to isolate Taiwan diplomatically, with recent actions including China luring away El Salvador, the Dominican Republic, and Panama, and pressuring companies to declare Taiwan as part of China. The US has responded by issuing a statement warning El Salvador's decision to end relations with Taiwan, citing concerns over China's interference in the country's domestic politics. The US has a history of recognizing China and severing ties with Taiwan, but now appears to be favoring maintaining diplomatic relations with Taiwan. China has threatened to use force to protect its sovereignty and territorial integrity, and the US may consider notifying Congress of a threat to Taiwan, potentially leading to a re-evaluation of its relationship with El Salvador.

site_title: Is technology disrupting governance?
summary: Technology is disrupting governance by creating new business models and increasing innovation, leading to a "just do it and ask for forgiveness later" approach. This has brought significant changes in corporate governance, with companies focusing on operational efficiencies and value creation. The rapid development of technology has also led to new opportunities for growth, but raises concerns about the need for honesty and ethical values in governance. A balance between digital transformation and promoting high standards of ethics is essential.

images.alt_text: Mr Low says good governance practices help organisations move quickly in a volatile and digital world, with the support of their clients and stakeholders.

site_title: US consumers may bear brunt of Trump's tariffs
summary: US consumers may bear the economic costs of President Trump's tariffs on Chinese-made goods, despite the tariffs unlikely to affect the US GDP. Starting Monday, half of everything Americans buy from China will be subject to 10% levies, rising to 25% in three months. The tariffs will affect a wide range of products, including shampoo, furniture, vacuum cleaners, handbags, and mobile phones. Barclays predicts the costs will be borne by American households, rather than the US economy.

site_title: Cielo to sell mobile payment device in deal with telecoms
summary: Cielo SA, Brazil's largest payment processor, will partner with telecoms Claro and TIM Participacoes SA to sell a mobile phone, dubbed Lio+, that also functions as a credit and debit card reader. The device will be sold under the Quantum brand and use an Android operating system, allowing users to make payments using any mobile carrier's network. Cielo aims to boost margins by selling additional products and services through the smartphone, charging higher-than-average transaction fees after one year of use.

site_title: UK watchdog wants in-depth review of Sainsbury's-Asda merger
summary: The UK's Competition and Markets Authority (CMA) has referred Sainsbury's £7.3 billion takeover of Asda for an in-depth review due to overlapping stores in hundreds of local areas. This could lead to higher prices or a worse quality of service for shoppers in these areas. The CMA's decision aims to ensure that the merger does not harm competition and consumers.

site_title: Food options for Paris Opera fans
summary: The Paris Opera's 350th anniversary season is underway, with food options available in and around Opéra Bastille and Palais Garnier. This season is a celebration of the city's rich opera history, similar to other major European cities like Vienna and Berlin, where opera houses serve as central hubs of city life.

site_title: Kim offers to permanently dismantle nuclear test site - but only after US makes concessions
summary: North Korea's leader Kim Jong Un offered to permanently dismantle a missile engine test site and launchpad at Tongchang-ri, but only if the US makes concessions. The move comes after two days of talks with South Korean President Moon Jae-in, which aimed to advance dialogue with the US. Kim pledged to visit Seoul, allow external inspectors, and continue dismantling facilities, but experts say the concessions are unclear and may not limit North Korea's nuclear program. The US wants Pyongyang to take a meaningful step toward dismantling its nuclear weapons program, but North Korea is pushing for the US to declare the 1950-1953 Korean War formally over.

site_title: Rule out 'no deal' Brexit, UK car industry warns in Brussels
summary: The UK's automotive industry body, Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders (SMMT), has warned in Brussels that a "no deal" Brexit could add at least 5.7 billion euros in car tariffs and disrupt production. A delegation from the SMMT emphasized the need for securing a deal to avoid damage to the sector, citing the high level of integration between the UK and EU automotive industries. A "no deal" Brexit would result in 10% tariffs on British-built cars sold in the EU, adding 3,000 euros to costs, and would also lead to delays and increased costs due to border issues.

site_title: WeWork tops JPMorgan as top New York tenant
summary: WeWork has surpassed JPMorgan as the largest tenant of Manhattan office space, with over 5.3 million square feet of leased space. The company signed a 258,344 square foot lease at 21 Penn Plaza, highlighting growing demand for flexible leases. WeWork's flexible space accounted for 12% of Manhattan leasing activity in the first six months of the year, with co-working providers signing long-term leases and renting to clients on a short-term basis. This milestone marks the appeal of co-working as a mainstream trend in the US.

site_title: Qatar names Mansoor Al Mahmoud as US$320b fund chief
summary: Qatar appointed Mansoor bin Ebrahim Al Mahmoud as the new CEO of its $320 billion sovereign wealth fund, replacing Sheikh Abdullah Bin Mohammed Al Thani. Al Mahmoud, a dealmaker, is expected to pursue an aggressive investment strategy. Under Sheikh Abdullah's leadership, the QIA shifted focus to diversifying its portfolio in the US and Asia, and investing more domestically.

site_title: Alliance Mineral puts dual listing plans on hold
summary: Alliance Mineral Assets has put its plans to seek a dual listing on the Australian Securities Exchange (ASX) on hold. The company, which is listed on the Singapore Exchange (SGX), had proposed a merger with Tawana Resources to create a mid-tier lithium producer. The ASX declined to give assurance on the merger's listing, citing uncertainty over the company's ability to remain a going concern. Alliance will remain listed on the SGX and will hold an extraordinary general meeting on September 21 to vote on the proposed merger.

site_title: 4Fingers acquires 50% stake in Aussie brand Mad Mex
summary: 4Fingers, a Singaporean fried chicken chain, acquired a 50% stake in Australian brand Mad Mex Fresh Mexican Grill for an undisclosed sum. The partnership aims to expand Mad Mex's presence in Southeast Asia, with plans to open outlets in Singapore and Malaysia within the next 12 months. Mad Mex, a leading quick-service restaurant in Australia, will retain its CEO and a 50% stake in the business. The acquisition is part of 4Fingers' strategy to aggregate complementary food concepts with global scalability.

site_title: Are there risks to having too many Jardine units in the STI?
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) may raise concerns about the risk of having too many Jardine units, as five Jardine companies are included in the index, with Dairy Farm's inclusion sparking debate. However, experts argue that the diversified businesses of the companies mitigate systemic risk and share-price contagion. The majority of day-to-day trading volume for Jardine units is transacted on the Singapore Exchange (SGX), reducing the risk of share-price contagion. The STI's inclusion of foreign companies, such as DBS Group Holdings and Singtel, also reduces concerns about the index representing the Singapore stock market.

site_title: Tripping of power-generating units caused blackout
summary: A blackout affecting nearly 147,000 customers in Singapore occurred on Tuesday due to the tripping of power-generating units at Sembcorp Cogen and Senoko Energy. The Energy Market Authority (EMA) is investigating the cause, citing preliminary findings that one unit at Sembcorp tripped first. The tripping resulted in insufficient electricity supply, prompting EMA to instruct other units to provide additional electricity. The restoration of electricity was done in a controlled manner over 38 minutes, with 19 areas in Singapore affected. Experts suggest possible causes include overloading, faulty equipment, or supply problems, but the situation was handled well due to safeguards in place.

site_title: MAS warns of second site soliciting Bitcoin investments
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has warned of a second fraudulent website soliciting Bitcoin investments, using fabricated comments from MAS chairman Tharman Shanmugaratnam. MAS advises the public to exercise extreme caution and avoid providing financial or personal information on linked forms.

images.alt_text: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has warned of a second fraudulent website that has been soliciting investments in Bitcoins, using fabricated comments attributed to MAS chairman and Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam.

site_title: Synthetic identity fraud: Exposing the modern-day Frankenstein monster
summary: Synthetic identity fraud is on the rise, with fraudsters using stolen real data to create fake identities and steal from organizations such as banks and governments. These "Frankenstein monsters" are made up of a combination of real and false personal data, allowing them to pose as legitimate users online. As data breaches continue, synthetic identities are being used to defraud various sectors, including telecommunications services providers. Law enforcement and organizations must take action to combat this modern form of identity theft and protect against these increasingly sophisticated fraudsters.

site_title: Far East Group unit to sell HK property
summary: Far East Group's subsidiary, Far East Refrigeration, has entered into a sale and purchase agreement to sell a Kowloon, Hong Kong property to China Glory Creation for HK$5.36 million (S$937,082). The property, with an estimated 876 square feet, is currently vacant and has a tenure of 75 years. The proposed disposal is expected to result in a gain of approximately S$825,644. The sale is non-core to Far East Group and will be used as general working capital, with no specific use for the property. The disposal is expected to be completed by November 30.

site_title: SembMarine to build a dozen LNG-hybrid tugs to replace existing diesel-powered ones
summary: Sembcorp Marine plans to build 12 liquefied natural gas (LNG)-hybrid powered tugs to replace existing diesel-powered ones by 2025, meeting emission targets set by the International Maritime Organization. The yard group will start constructing the first pair of hybrid tugs in 2019 and have them operational by 2021. The project is part of SembMarine's Tuas Boulevard Yard development, aiming to create a future-proof, smart, and sustainable facility. The company is collaborating with American Bureau of Shipping and A*Star's Institute of High Performance Computing to develop new technologies and applications for LNG adoption.

site_title: Danske Bank CEO quits over 200 billion euros money laundering scandal
summary: Danske Bank CEO Thomas Borgen resigned amid a 200 billion euros money laundering scandal, with payments totaling the amount through the bank's Estonian branch, many of which were suspicious. The investigation revealed compliance and control failings, and investors are concerned about US authorities' potential punishment. The bank's shares fell nearly 8% as it acknowledged failings and took action against staff and overhauled systems. The scandal is the largest money laundering case in European history and has raised concerns about the bank's global financial network.

site_title: China's subway expansion could help its steel sector get back on track
summary: China's expansion of its subway networks and infrastructure investment plans are expected to boost the country's steel sector, helping it recover from a slowing construction sector and weakening auto sales. The projects, worth billions of dollars, will require large amounts of steel, with 80 million tonnes needed for the subway expansion, 10% of China's annual demand. This is expected to lead to a price rally in steel, benefiting steelmakers such as Magang Group and Ansteel Group. The move is part of Beijing's efforts to spur economic growth amid a trade war with the US.

site_title: Kuroda stays the course, helping Abe towards record-beating run
summary: Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda maintained monetary stimulus, reaffirming its commitment to 2% inflation. This decision supports Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's re-election, which will extend his premiership and endorse his economic policies. Economists predict "stealth tapering" and eventual policy normalization, but the BOJ remains behind global peers in terms of monetary policy. Kuroda stated that bond market functioning had improved, but it's too soon to assess the impact of recent changes.

site_title: India banks to plan resolving 1.4 trillion rupees power sector debt
summary: India's lenders will meet to discuss resolving 1.4 trillion rupees ($25.5 billion) of power sector debt. The meeting follows a court order to halt bankruptcy proceedings against delinquent power producers, allowing lenders to continue with resolution plans for at least seven assets. Thirty-four stressed assets in the coal-fired power sector have been identified, with 14 already referred to insolvency court and eight having resolved difficulties. The meeting aims to clean up soured debt and boost lending and investment in India's power sector.

site_title: Ousted ex-PM Sharif, daughter set to be freed during appeal
summary: A Pakistani court suspended the 10-year jail term of ousted Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif and his daughter Maryam, freeing them from prison. The ruling comes after a lower court handed down the sentences in July over the purchase of London apartments. The court found that the prosecution failed to prove the properties belonged to Sharif. The convictions are still under appeal, but the judge ordered their immediate release while the case continues. Sharif's release comes as he is set to meet with Saudi officials seeking financial help.

site_title: GOP rejects Kavanaugh accuser's bid for FBI probe before hearing
summary: President Trump expressed willingness to hear from Christine Blasey Ford, the woman accusing Supreme Court nominee Brett Kavanaugh of sexual assault, saying it would be "unfortunate" if she doesn't testify. Ford's lawyers requested an FBI investigation, but Senate Judiciary Chairman Chuck Grassley rejected this, stating the hearing invitation still stands. The nomination is at risk of alienating moderate Republican senators, and some GOP senators want to proceed with the vote despite Ford's testimony. Kavanaugh denies the allegation, calling it "completely false."

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks push further ahead by close
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose, with the Hang Seng Index increasing 1.19% to 27,407.37, as investors remain optimistic about a potential US-China trade agreement. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also rose, with gains of 1.14% and 1.36%, respectively. The rally comes despite ongoing US tariff threats, with traders brushing off the uncertainty to push stocks higher.

site_title: 'I don't have an attorney general,' Trump says in a new attack on Sessions
summary: President Donald Trump stated in an interview that he does not have an attorney general, Jeff Sessions, escalating their public feud. Trump has repeatedly criticized Sessions for recusing himself from the Russia investigation and has expressed disappointment in his handling of immigration issues. Trump recently stated he would not fire Sessions before the midterm elections in November.

site_title: mm2 Asia appoints financial adviser to undertake strategic review
summary: mm2 Asia appoints Haitong International Securities as its financial adviser to undertake a strategic review of its businesses. The review aims to enhance corporate profile, branding, and market awareness in North Asia, and explore possibilities of foreign listings to increase shareholder value. However, the outcome is uncertain, and no corporate action is guaranteed.

site_title: CAAS awards contract to Rohde & Schwarz to improve air traffic control radio communications
summary: The Civil Aviation Authority of Singapore (CAAS) has awarded a 15-year contract to Rohde & Schwarz to upgrade and enhance air traffic control radio communications at Changi Airport. The project includes installing over 240 high-frequency radios, featuring the detection of simultaneous transmissions (DSiT) technology, allowing air traffic controllers to communicate with two counterparts at once. This technology will enhance safety and operational efficiency, supporting the growth of air traffic in the Asia-Pacific region.

site_title: Mastercard inks global sponsorship deal with world's largest e-sport
summary: Mastercard has signed a multi-year global sponsorship deal with Riot Games to become the first global sponsor for League of Legends, the world's largest e-sport. The deal will see Mastercard as the exclusive global payment services partner for three annual global tournaments, including the Mid-Season Invitational and the World Championship. The partnership aims to engage fans and bring them closer to the action, leveraging Mastercard's "Priceless" experiences. The deal underscores Mastercard's support of the e-sports community and further diversifies its sports and entertainment portfolio.

images.alt_text: Mr Rajamannar sees e-sports growing bigger globally, eventually becoming more mainstream in future with large brands jumping aboard the sponsorship bandwagon.

site_title: Najib arrested, to be charged on Thursday over 1MDB allegations
summary: Malaysian former leader Najib Razak was arrested on Wednesday and will be charged on Thursday over allegations that US$628 million linked to state investment fund 1MDB ended up in his personal bank accounts. Najib faces charges related to allegedly abusing his position and abusing his power. The arrest is part of reopened probes into 1MDB, which were shut down by the former government. Najib has already been arrested and hit with seven charges related to claims he pocketed US$10 million from a former unit of 1MDB.

images.alt_text: Mr Najib's arrest relates directly to the allegation that huge sums from the fund flowed into his bank accounts ahead of a hotly contested election in 2013.

site_title: MAS warns about second fraudulent website soliciting Bitcoin investments
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has warned about a second fraudulent website soliciting Bitcoin investments, using fabricated comments from MAS chairman Tharman Shanmugaratnam. The website is highly deceptive and misleading, asking users to provide financial and personal information. MAS advises the public to exercise extreme caution and avoid providing sensitive information. Cases of fraudulent investments should be reported to the Police. This warning follows a similar warning issued by MAS on Tuesday regarding another fraudulent website.

site_title: Sustainability in a garden city - it's all about clever space utilisation
summary: Singapore aims to transform 80% of its buildings into green buildings by 2030, but its limited land area poses a challenge. To address this, the city-state has turned to high-density developments, such as Marina One, a mixed-use building that incorporates a "Green Heart" - a 65,000 sq. ft biodiversity garden. Designed by Ingenhoven Architects, Marina One features energy-saving ventilation systems, glazing, and rainwater harvesting irrigation to reduce its carbon footprint. The building's design aims to promote well-being and health, while also showcasing Singapore's commitment to becoming the world's best "Garden City."

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher as investors shrug off trade war
summary: US stocks opened higher on Wednesday, brushing off the latest trade tensions between the US and China. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.16%, the S&P 500 gained 0.08%, and the Nasdaq Composite rose 0.08%. Investors appeared to shrug off new threats from US President Trump to extend the trade war, instead focusing on economic data and corporate earnings. The market rally continues, with stocks reaching fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: US housing starts rise on jump in multi-family construction
summary: US housing starts rose 9.2% to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.282 million units in August, exceeding expectations. Multi-family construction jumped 29.3% to 406,000 units, while single-family homebuilding rose 1.9% to 876,000 units. Building permits fell 5.7% to 1.229 million units. The US housing market has underperformed the broader economy, with economists attributing the slowdown to low inventories and rising mortgage rates.

images.alt_text: US homebuilding increased more than expected in August, a positive sign for the housing market which has underperformed the broader economy amid rising interest rates for home loans.

site_title: US current account deficit decreases to 2% of GDP
summary: The US current account deficit decreased to 2% of GDP in the second quarter, narrowing by $20.3 billion to $101.5 billion, the Commerce Department reported. This marks the smallest share of national output since 2014. The decline is attributed to a tax overhaul that led to companies repatriating foreign earnings, resulting in $169.5 billion in dividend payments. Analysts had expected a narrower deficit, but the actual figure fell short of expectations.

site_title: French court upholds magazine fines over topless Kate photos
summary: A French court upheld fines of 45,000 euros on the editors of gossip magazine Closer for publishing topless photos of Kate Middleton in 2012, confirming they must also pay 100,000 euros in damages to the royal couple. The court found Closer guilty of invading Kate's privacy, which sparked outrage among the British public and royal family. The magazine's editors and photographers were also fined, with the photographers facing additional 5,000-euro fines if they reoffend. The royal couple had initially sought 1.5 million euros in damages.

site_title: No-deal Brexit is seen bringing 5.7b euros in car tariffs
summary: A report by the British industry group Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders estimates that a no-deal Brexit could result in 5.7 billion euros in car tariffs, affecting exports and imports. The industry could also suffer production halts due to the political split. The head of the lobby, Mike Hawes, warned that a no-deal Brexit would be the "worst option" for the industry, emphasizing the need for a withdrawal agreement by November.

site_title: Singapore among best Asian cities for technology companies: report
summary: Singapore ranks second among Asian cities for technology companies, with a score of 63%, due to its strong talent pool, personal tax rate, and living quality. The city is expected to continue benefiting from its position as a financial and communications hub for South-east Asia and Asia-Pacific operations. Bangalore tops the list with a score of 68%, followed by Shenzhen with 61%. The report highlights Singapore's low staff costs, ample office stock, and flexible workspace as key factors contributing to its ranking.

images.alt_text: Singapore is the second-best city for technology companies looking to establish or expand operations in Asia, according to a report published on Wednesday by real estate services and investment management company Colliers International.

site_title: Asiatravel.com Holdings, subsidiary granted moratorium by High Court until Nov 30
summary: The High Court has granted Asiatravel.com Holdings and its subsidiary a moratorium until November 30, restraining actions such as winding-up resolutions. The moratorium was sought after the company missed a funding payment and received a notice of intent to suspend operations from the Singapore Tourism Board. Trading in shares has been suspended since July 6, and an independent auditor has flagged going concern issues in the company's 2017 financial statements. The moratorium will allow the company to propose a scheme of arrangement.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's share prices closed higher on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 7.77 points to 1,800.71. The index saw 502 gainers and 368 losers, with a total trading volume of 2.007 billion lots worth RM1.896 billion.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's property market faces numerous challenges, with nearly 46,000 private residential units expected to be available for sale between 2019 and 2020. The country ranks second in top Asian locations for tech companies, according to Colliers. Meanwhile, the Asian garment industry prepares for higher US tariffs, while China's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers. In other news, a Malaysian agency plans to seize assets worth RM3 billion from Daim Zainuddin, and Citigroup sets a target of 1,150 for MSCI's global equity index by mid-2026.

site_title: COEs end mostly lower
summary: Singapore's latest Certificate of Entitlement (COE) tender ended with mostly lower prices, with smaller cars seeing a premium of $28,000, down from $30,209. Larger vehicles and commercial vehicles saw slight increases. Industry experts expect lower COE prices to boost buying interest, but some quarters predict they may encourage car owners to revalidate their COE for longer periods.

site_title: Global goal to end poverty by 2030 unlikely to be met, World Bank says
summary: The World Bank forecasts that the global goal to end extreme poverty by 2030 is unlikely to be met, with approximately 480 million people, or 6% of the world's population, remaining in extreme poverty. Despite a record low of 655 million people living on less than $1.90 a day, significant shifts in policy are needed to meet the target, particularly in African countries. World Bank President Jim Yong Kim noted that the global poverty rate is at its lowest in recorded history.

site_title: Singapore's new single QR code for payment
summary: Singapore has launched a single, standardized QR code for electronic payments, potentially setting a global model for other jurisdictions. The move is part of the country's efforts to transform its electronic payment system. The government has also opened interbank payment services, such as the FAST service, to fintech firms. This development aims to facilitate faster and more secure payments in the country.

site_title: US companies repatriated US$169.5b in Q2
summary: US corporations repatriated $169.5 billion in offshore profits in Q2, up from $34.9 billion in the same period last year. This follows a downwardly revised $294.9 billion returned in the first quarter. Despite this, the total repatriated funds are still significantly lower than the estimated $3 trillion accumulated overseas. President Trump expects more than $4 trillion to return, citing incentives from the tax overhaul signed into law in December, which lowered the repatriation tax rate to 15.5% for cash and 8% for non-cash assets.

site_title: Europe: Shares hit two-week high on trade talk hopes
summary: European shares rose 0.3% to a two-week high on Wednesday, driven by hopes of US-China trade talks resuming. Materials stocks led the gain, while staffing firm Adecco and home improvement retailer Kingfisher disappointed. Credit Suisse expects a settlement in the next 6-9 months, supporting the positive sentiment.

site_title: Britain refers Sainsbury's-Asda merger to in-depth review
summary: Britain's competition regulator referred Sainsbury's 7.3 billion-pound takeover of Asda to an in-depth review due to overlapping stores in hundreds of local areas, potentially affecting prices and services. The regulator will investigate whether the deal would increase buying power over suppliers and impact millions of shoppers. The merged companies would become market leader, but competition lawyers suggest store disposals could render the deal unviable. The Phase 2 inquiry typically lasts 24 weeks with the possibility of an eight-week extension.

site_title: Coke eyes overseas market for Australian Kombucha it just bought
summary: Coca-Cola has acquired Australian kombucha maker Organic & Raw Trading Co. for undisclosed terms, with plans to expand distribution of the MOJO kombucha line in Australia and eventually globally. The company aims to capitalize on the growing health beverage market, following its recent acquisition of Costa Coffee and investments in kombucha startups. This move marks Coca-Cola's first direct addition of kombucha to its portfolio, as the company diversifies beyond its core soft-drinks business.

site_title: Prominent British Conservative distances himself from Steve Bannon
summary: Jacob Rees-Mogg, a prominent British Conservative, has distanced himself from Steve Bannon's planned "Movement" to elect right-wing nationalist and populist members in European Parliament elections. Rees-Mogg stated he has no interest in joining the campaign and had only met Bannon once in 2017. Despite Bannon's praise, Rees-Mogg's views are not aligned with Bannon's, and he is a leading figure in the anti-EU wing of Theresa May's party. The Movement, which aims to elect right-wing leaders in Europe, will not involve Britain, according to Bannon.

site_title: Thai August auto sales jump 27.7% y-o-y: federation
summary: Thai domestic car sales in August jumped 27.7% year-over-year to 86,780 units, driven by stronger economic growth and higher investment. This follows a 25.7% increase in July. Auto exports fell 0.38% from a year earlier. Thailand remains a key vehicle production and export base for top automobile manufacturers.

site_title: Tokyo's Nikkei index jumps to near eight-month high
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei 225 index rose 1.08% to a near-eight-month high of 23,672.52, driven by gains on Wall Street and a cheaper yen. The broader Topix index also gained 1.46%. This marks the fourth consecutive day of gains for the Nikkei. The rally comes as investors remain optimistic despite ongoing trade uncertainty.

site_title: Singapore property market facing 'many challenges': Redas president
summary: Singapore's property market is facing several challenges, including the recent cooling measures, which have weakened market sentiments and demand. Nearly 46,000 private residential units are expected to be available for sale over the next five years, but demand is expected to drop 15-20% in 2018. Trade tensions and rising interest rates are also affecting the market. Despite this, demand for developments in good locations and close to MRT stations remains resilient, attracting first-time homebuyers and owners of en bloc developments.

site_title: Knights of the tripe: French food cults defend local fare
summary: In the Normandy countryside, a group of individuals gather for an ancient French initiation ceremony, donning colorful robes and oversized medallions. The event is centered around a glazed pot filled with tripe, a traditional French dish. The participants defend local cuisine and cultural heritage, evoking comparisons to medieval guilds and druids. The gathering aims to preserve and promote French gastronomy, highlighting the importance of preserving local traditions in the face of modernization and globalization.

site_title: Tesco undercuts Lidl and Aldi
summary: Tesco has launched a new line of stores called "Jack's" to undercut German discounters Lidl and Aldi, with the intention of being the cheapest option in town. The stores will offer private label products, including items such as olive oil, milk, and potato chips, with prices starting from 2.89 pounds. Tesco aims to woo budget-conscious shoppers with a patriotic pitch, emphasizing local provenance and contrasting its UK roots with the German ownership of Lidl and Aldi. The move comes as Tesco posts its 10th consecutive quarter of growth, despite struggling to compete with the discounters in recent years.

images.alt_text: Dave Lewis, Chief Executive Officer of Tesco walks inside one of Tesco's new discount supermarkets called Jack's, in Chatteris, Britain.

site_title: Singapore shares close 1.2% up on Wednesday
summary: Singapore stocks rose 1.2% on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index reaching 3,176.57 points, driven by gains from all three major banks (DBS, UOB, and OCBC). Gainers outnumbered losers 245 to 155, and 1.30 billion shares changed hands.

site_title: Sembcorp, Senoko power generating units tripped, causing Tuesday's blackout: EMA
summary: A blackout on Tuesday affecting 147,000 customers in Singapore was caused by the power generating units of Sembcorp Cogen and Senoko Energy tripping. The Energy Market Authority (EMA) is investigating the incident with the companies and their suppliers. Preliminary findings indicate one power generating unit at Sembcorp tripped, leading to the blackout. The EMA is working to establish the cause of the incident.

site_title: Nikkei nears 8-month highs; insurers rally after US yields rise
summary: Japan's Nikkei index reached near eight-month highs on Wednesday, jumping 1.6% to 23,804.65, driven by a strong performance on Wall Street despite lingering trade war concerns. US yields rose, lifting insurers and banks, while exporters also gained ground. The Nikkei is now just shy of its highest point since November 1991.

site_title: Najib arrested, to face charges in 1MDB case
summary: Former Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak, 65, was arrested on September 19, 2018, and will face charges over hundreds of millions of dollars transferred to his personal account from the state investment fund 1MDB. Najib was previously charged with corruption and money laundering, and his latest arrest involves US$681 million deposited into his account in 2013. He will appear in court on Thursday and faces several charges, including money laundering. Najib's ouster in May's election led to the rise of Mahathir Mohamad as prime minister once again.

images.alt_text: Former Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak will face charges of abusing his position and graft related to money allegedly siphoned off from state fund 1Malaysia Development Berhad, the country's anti-corruption agency said on Wednesday.

site_title: Waterloo Apartments in Civic District up for collective sale at S$115m, with provisional nod for hotel use
summary: The 999-year leasehold site at 64 Waterloo Street in Singapore's Civic District is up for collective sale at S$115 million. The site has outline planning permission for hotel use, allowing for approximately 180 rooms, and is zoned for "residential with first storey commercial" use. The site's proximity to public transport links major locations, including Marina Bay Sands and Raffles Place. The tender for the site closes on October 23, 2018, with the potential developer expected to capitalize on Singapore's strong MICE industry demand for hotel rooms.

site_title: SembMarine to invest in LNG tugs, teams up to advance LNG value chain
summary: SembCorp Marine is investing in a fleet of liquefied natural gas (LNG)-hybrid powered tugs to meet International Maritime Organization (IMO) emission targets. The yard group plans to design and build up to 12 tugs by 2025, starting construction in 2019. A memorandum of understanding (MoU) has been signed with ABS and A*Star's Institute of High Performance Computing to develop new technologies and capabilities for LNG adoption. The partners aim to advance the LNG value chain and reduce environmental impact through joint research, training, and technical workshops.

site_title: Alliance, Tawana postpone plans to list as merged group on ASX
summary: Alliance Mineral Assets and Tawana Resources have postponed plans to list as a merged group on the Australian Securities Exchange (ASX) due to uncertainty over the merged group's ability to remain a going concern. The ASX declined to provide assurance on the listing, and the boards have determined it is not feasible to meet the condition within the current timetable. Alliance will instead remain listed on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) and plans to list on the ASX after the merger is completed, expected to occur by the end of October.

site_title: China goes for broke in Indonesian e-commerce
summary: China's e-commerce giants, including Alibaba and Tencent, are investing heavily in Indonesia, seeking to expand their market share and surpass India's e-commerce sales by 2020. However, the path to profitability seems uncertain due to low transaction fees and high competition. To break even, e-commerce platforms need to generate at least $4.50 in revenue per $100 transaction. Industry consolidation may be the only viable way for Chinese companies to make money in Indonesia, where venture-capital culture prioritizes growth over profitability.

site_title: Microsoft steps up Salesforce rivalry with new AI, HoloLens features
summary: Microsoft has introduced new AI-powered features for its sales and customer-service software, Dynamics 365, in response to competition from Salesforce.com. The new features include Remote Assist, which uses augmented reality goggles to guide field service workers, and AI-powered tools for customer-service agents, sales staff, and marketing teams. These tools aim to improve customer experience and sales efficiency. Microsoft's Dynamics products are growing, but still lag behind Salesforce in the market. The company's move is part of its efforts to step up its rivalry with Salesforce.

site_title: Changi is again Asia's most connected international airport; slips to 8th globally
summary: Changi Airport has been named Asia's most connected international airport for the second year in a row, but dropped to eighth globally in the rankings by OAG. London's Heathrow Airport took the top spot, with the consultancy calculating the total number of possible connections between inbound and outbound flights within a six-hour window on the busiest day for global aviation.

site_title: Wilmington Port is shut down due to floods, delaying shipments
summary: The Port of Wilmington in North Carolina has been shut down due to Hurricane Florence, delaying shipments of goods including fertilizer, textiles, and gasoline. The port plans to resume operations by the end of the week and truck operations on September 24. The closure has impacted companies such as Enviva Partners, LP, which ships wooden pellets to Europe, and has affected the local economy, which contributes around $12.9 billion annually to North Carolina's economy and supports 73,000 jobs.

site_title: Singapore fried chicken chain 4Fingers buys 50% stake in Australia-based eatery Mad Mex
summary: Singapore's 4Fingers acquired a 50% stake in Australian eatery Mad Mex Fresh Mexican Grill for an undisclosed sum. The partnership aims to expand Mad Mex's presence in South-east Asia, with plans to open outlets in Singapore and Malaysia within the next 12 months. 4Fingers seeks to aggregate complementary food concepts with global scalability, while Mad Mex's founder will remain CEO and retain a 50% stake. The move is part of 4Fingers' strategy to aggressively scale up management bandwidth and capitalise on supply chain and menu innovation.

site_title: North Korea to allow international inspections for nuclear dismantlement, if US takes reciprocal measures
summary: North Korea agreed to allow international inspectors to monitor the dismantlement of its key missile facilities, with US reciprocal measures required. The move follows a summit between North Korean leader Kim Jong Un and South Korean President Moon Jae In, who aim for a "land of peace without nuclear weapons and nuclear threats." Kim also plans to visit Seoul "in the near future." The agreement marks a significant step towards denuclearization, with North Korea taking steps to close its main Yongbyon nuclear complex if the US takes reciprocal measures.

site_title: HNA explores sale of newly acquired CWT logistics unit
summary: China's HNA Group is exploring the sale of its CWT logistics unit, nine months after acquiring it in a US$1 billion deal. The sale, if completed, would be part of HNA's efforts to slash debt, which currently stands at US$96 billion. A non-Chinese buyer is being targeted, with only a part of CWT expected to be sold. This is the latest in a series of divestments by HNA, which has attracted scrutiny for its recent large deals, including hotels in the US and a stake in Deutsche Bank.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Wednesday afternoon trading higher at 3,159.67, up 0.6% on day
summary: Singapore stocks resumed trading on Wednesday, advancing 0.6% to 3,159.67, with the Straits Times Index gaining 20.33 points. Gainers outnumbered losers 181 to 116, with 670.4 million shares traded. Notable movers included Rex International Holding (down 2.6%) and YZJ Shipbuilding (up 3.6%). Other active stocks like Singtel and DBS also gained 1% and 0.6%, respectively.

site_title: China's Alibaba doubles down on chips amid cloud computing push
summary: Alibaba Group Holding Ltd announced plans to establish a dedicated chip subsidiary, aiming to launch its first self-developed AI inference chip in the second half of 2019. The move is part of the company's push into cloud and Internet of Things (IoT) businesses, as China's government seeks to increase the quality of domestically made chips. Alibaba's aggressive chip development comes amid growing trade tensions with the US, with co-founder Jack Ma stating the need to control core technology like chips to avoid over-reliance on foreign imports.

site_title: Fincantieri extends exit offer for Vard to Oct 15
summary: Fincantieri has extended its buyout offer for shipbuilder Vard Holdings to October 15, giving shareholders until then to accept the S$0.25 per share offer. The Italian shipbuilder currently holds 94.73% control over Vard and does not intend to extend the deadline. Vard's shareholders approved delisting in July, and the counter traded at S$0.25 before the offer extension was announced.

site_title: China's Premier Li says unilateral trade actions will not resolve problems
summary: China's Premier Li Keqiang stated that unilateral trade actions won't resolve problems, emphasizing the importance of multi-lateralism and maintaining the basic principle of free trade. This comes as China retaliated against US tariffs by adding $60 billion of US products to its import tariff list. China's process of opening up will only quicken, according to Li, amid a deepening trade war between the two nations.

site_title: Strawberry sabotage akin to 'terrorism': Australia PM
summary: Australia's Prime Minister Scott Morrison described the tainting of supermarket strawberries with sewing needles as "terrorism" and urged tougher sentencing, calling for a 15-year maximum sentence for deliberate food contamination. At least 20 pieces of fruit were found contaminated, prompting supermarket recalls and a nationwide scare. Morrison also urged Australians to make a strawberry pavlova to help struggling farmers. The authorities are still investigating the motive behind the attacks and are asking for public help.

site_title: WeWork tops JPMorgan as No. 1 New York tenant as coworking booms
summary: WeWork has surpassed JPMorgan as the largest tenant of Manhattan office space, with a total of 5.3 million square feet. WeWork signed a lease for 258,344 square feet at 21 Penn Plaza, making it the largest private occupier of office space in the island. Flexible space accounted for 12% of Manhattan leasing activity in the first six months of the year, with WeWork responsible for about half of that. The trend highlights growing demand for flexible leases as companies seek extra space.

site_title: Gas leak at Ascendas H-Trust's Sydney hotel; about 30 guests, employees receive medical attention
summary: A gas leak at the Pullman Sydney Hyde Park hotel, managed by Accor, caused 30 guests and employees to receive medical attention due to a pool chemical mix-up. The leak, which produced toxic hydrogen chloride gas, occurred at 9am Australian time. The hotel has since resumed operations, and Accor is investigating the matter. At least eight people were hospitalized, and the incident is under review.

site_title: SIA plane hits aerobridge at Changi Airport; all 272 passengers and 12 crew on board unhurt
summary: A Singapore Airlines Airbus 330-300 suffered damage when it hit an aerobridge at Changi Airport on Tuesday. The incident occurred when the plane was being pushed back by a tow tug after just leaving the gate. All 272 passengers and 12 crew members disembarked normally via another aerobridge. The flight departed two hours later with a replacement aircraft. Damage to the aircraft and the aerobridge is being assessed, with investigations to determine the cause of the incident underway. This is not the first time an SIA plane has been damaged at Changi Airport.

site_title: Ho Bee names new deputy CEO, COO with succession in mind
summary: Ho Bee Land has promoted Nicholas Chua, 43, to deputy CEO and appointed Ong Chong Hua as COO, part of the company's leadership development and succession planning. Chua, the son of chairman and CEO Chua Thian Poh, will assist in implementing strategies and managing business operations. Ong, who has been with the company since 1995, will oversee operational aspects. The move aims to position the group for further growth and success, according to Chua Thian Poh.

site_title: 7 in 10 retrenched workers in Singapore helped by taskforce found jobs within 6 months
summary: In Singapore, 7 out of 10 retrenched workers helped by a taskforce found jobs within 6 months, according to the Taskforce for Responsible Retrenchment and Employment Facilitation. 90% of companies that cut workers paid retrenchment benefits, and the taskforce resolved 74 retrenchment-related disputes through mediation and adjudication. The taskforce's chairman, Tan Choon Shian, attributed the success to the mandatory retrenchment notifications and the use of job matching services.

images.alt_text: Seven in 10 retrenched workers who were helped by a dedicated government taskforce last year were able to find jobs within six months.

site_title: New regional cybersecurity centre set up to counter threat of cyberattacks
summary: A new Asean-Singapore Cybersecurity Centre of Excellence has been established to counter the growing threat of cyberattacks in the region. The centre will enhance collaboration among Asean countries, train Computer Emergency Response Teams, and promote information sharing. The centre will also support the development of cyber strategies, legislation, and research capabilities. A Government Bug Bounty Programme will be launched to invite experts to test the government's systems and identify vulnerabilities. The centre aims to strengthen Asean members' cyber defences and achieve Smart Nation goals.

site_title: Asia-Pacific private equity firms more keen on geographic expansion, vertical integration deals: poll
summary: Asia-Pacific private equity firms are prioritizing geographic expansion and vertical integration deals, with 70% and 60% of respondents respectively expressing a more favorable view. In contrast, 80% of respondents in the APAC region emphasize less on specialization in domain expertise compared to other regions. The majority of executives believe competition for deals will lead to consolidation among firms, and they are likely to make acquisitions based on industry or market differentials to combat competition and higher multiples.

site_title: Five key points from the Pyongyang summit
summary:
North Korean leader Kim Jong Un and South Korean President Moon Jae-in agreed on several key proposals during their summit in Pyongyang, including:

* Kim's visit to Seoul, expected to happen in the near future.
* The permanent closure of the Tongchang-ri engine test site and missile launch pad under foreign inspectors.
* The dismantlement of the Yongbyon nuclear facility in exchange for US reciprocal steps.
* The removal of 11 guard posts and halt of military drills along the DMZ.
* The establishment of a buffer zone in the West Sea and implementation of a no-fly zone to prevent accidental clashes.
* Joint projects, including the connection of cross-border railways and roads, and the normalization of a joint factory zone in Kaesong.
* The resumption of Southern tours to the North's Mount Kumgang under the right conditions.
* A joint bid to host the 2032 Summer Olympics.
* The opening of a facility at Mount Kumgang to host family reunions and the holding of Red Cross talks on allowing exchanges of letters and live video broadcasts.

site_title: Soy planting speeds up in Brazil after favorable weather
summary: Brazilian farmers accelerated soy and corn planting this week due to favorable weather conditions and a positive market outlook. Soybean planting in Paraná reached 9% of expected final area, up 8 percentage points from last week, while corn planting reached 37% of projected area, ahead of the same time last year. The swift planting is attributed to ample soil moisture and strong demand from China, which is seeking alternative sources of soybeans due to raised tariffs on US beans.

site_title: Indonesia woos domestic investors with 7.32 trillion rupiah of online retail savings bonds
summary: Indonesia's finance ministry sold 7.32 trillion rupiah ($672.8 million) worth of online retail savings bonds to local investors, the largest in the series. The bonds, maturing in 2020, were nearly four times oversubscribed and mostly bought by millennials, with 80% of 21,672 investors being new. The government aims to reduce foreign ownership and increase domestic investment. The bonds have a floating rate of 8.05% and are the second retail savings bond sold online, following a predecessor that raised 1.93 trillion rupiah.

site_title: Trade deal with South Korea ready to be signed, says Trump
summary: US President Donald Trump announced that a revamped trade agreement with South Korea is ready to be signed, following a revised 2012 trade pact. The agreement includes provisions for increased US auto exports, extended tariffs on South Korean-made pickups, and a cap on imports of South Korean steel. Trump initially denounced the agreement as unfair and a job destroyer, but now calls it a "fair deal". The signing is expected to occur at the UN General Assembly this month.

site_title: India plans to more than double sugar export aid
summary: India plans to provide 45 billion rupees in aid to sugar mills to boost exports and cut domestic surplus, with a proposed subsidy of 13.88 rupees per 100 kilograms of cane and reimbursement of transport and handling charges. The assistance aims to support domestic prices and help cut reserves amid bumper harvests. The government is considering allocating a total of 5 million tons of sugar export quota, which could help mills clear 135.67 billion rupees of cane arrears.

site_title: US consumers may bear brunt of Trump's tariffs
summary: US consumers will likely bear the brunt of President Trump's tariffs on Chinese-made goods, with 11,400 products worth $250 billion subject to 10% levies, rising to 25% in about three months. This could lead to higher prices and reduced sales, particularly during the holiday shopping season. Economists warn that the tariffs will ultimately be passed on to consumers, who are already sensitive to price increases. The National Retail Federation estimates that the tariffs could cost American consumers up to $6 billion a year.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks build on gains at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.32% at the open on Wednesday, following a healthy lead from Wall Street. The Hang Seng Index reached 27,170.02, while the Shanghai Composite Index eased 0.19% and the Shenzhen Composite Index lost 0.25%. The gains came as investors considered tit-for-tat tariffs from China and the US as lenient, despite ongoing trade uncertainty.

site_title: Maintaining China's steady growth increasingly difficult: Premier Li
summary: China's steady growth is becoming increasingly difficult due to external changes, but Premier Li Keqiang assures the country will not resort to massive stimulus. China will maintain macro-economic policies steady, focusing on reducing taxes and fees, and easing funding difficulties for firms. The country will also widen market access for foreign companies and ensure fair competition. China will not engage in currency devaluation to boost exports, instead choosing prudent monetary policy.

site_title: Malaysia shares open higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 2.30 points to 1,795.24 at 9:01am on Wednesday, with gains outnumbering losses 129 to 49. Volume was 47.39 million lots worth RM19.3 million.

site_title: Banks give China's Web lenders a second life
summary: China's online lenders, which were once seen as disruptors to traditional banking, are teaming up with banks to stay afloat amid a funding squeeze caused by regulatory crackdowns. The sector, valued at $200 billion, has been hit by strict rules and caps on loan balances, forcing companies to seek funds from commercial banks or traditional consumer finance firms. Many startups are now diversifying their funding sources, with some seeing benefits from sharing costs and risks with web partners.

site_title: Singapore ranks second in top Asian locations for tech companies: Colliers
summary: Singapore ranks second in Asia for tech companies, behind Bangalore, due to its strong talent pool, personal tax rate, safety, and living quality. The city scored 63% on Colliers' socio-economic, property, and human factors scoring scale. Singapore's position as a well-connected financial and communications hub is expected to continue benefiting its tech industry. The city's office space and infrastructure scored lower, but its low staff costs and office rents offset these drawbacks. Colliers predicts supply of business park and high-specification industrial space will double by 2030.

site_title: Bank of Japan keeps policy steady, sticks to rosy economic view
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) maintained its monetary policy steady, keeping interest rates at minus 0.1% and a pledge to guide 10-year government bond yields around zero percent. The decision was made with a 7-2 vote, with Governor Haruhiko Kuroda holding a news conference to explain the policy. The BOJ maintained its optimistic view on the economy, citing moderate expansion, despite escalating global trade frictions and soft inflation.

site_title: Cambodia is open for business
summary: Cambodia's ruling party declared victory in the country's general election, paving the way for the implementation of pro-business policies. The country's robust GDP growth, burgeoning middle-class consumer market, and large working-age population make it an attractive investment destination. The government has implemented policies aimed at attracting foreign direct investments, including cheap labor, corporate tax holidays, and special economic zones. The Agreement for the Avoidance of Double Taxation between Singapore and Cambodia also reduces the cost of investing in the country. With continued political stability and minimal setup costs, Cambodia is poised to emerge as a hub of opportunity for investors, particularly those from Singapore.

site_title: Indian tycoon Birla seeks more purchases based on rationale, value
summary: Indian tycoon Kumar Mangalam Birla stated that his Aditya Birla Group is focused on acquiring companies based on business rationale and value. The conglomerate has completed a merger to create India's top wireless carrier and acquired a US aluminium producer this year. Mergers and acquisitions in India are expected to pick up pace as banks tackle bad loans. The Indian economy is showing signs of growth, with a 8.2% GDP increase in the three months ended June. Birla also expects the price war in the telecom sector to ease as Idea and Vodafone work out a strategy.

site_title: Japan trade surplus with US shrinks for second month
summary: Japan's trade surplus with the US decreased for the second consecutive month, reaching 455.8 billion yen in August, due to a rise in US imports of aerospace, natural gas, and coal. Japan's global trade deficit widened to 444.6 billion yen, driven by increasing energy imports. Exports rose 6.6% led by semiconductor, automobile, and shipbuilding, but foreign imports climbed 15.4% due to rising energy costs. The US-China trade war continues, with US President Trump targeting Japan as his next trade partner.

site_title: South Korea's Moon seeks nuclear agreement with Kim at summit
summary: South Korean President Moon Jae In met with North Korean leader Kim Jong Un in Pyongyang, seeking a nuclear agreement. The two leaders had "frank and sincere" discussions, but it's unclear if any deal was reached. The US is pressing for North Korea's "final, fully verified denuclearisation", while Pyongyang wants a formal declaration of the end of the Korean War. The summit comes after Kim declared his backing for denuclearisation in Singapore, but no details were agreed upon. Moon's visit aims to reboot stalled denuclearisation talks with the US.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher as yen drops
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Wednesday, driven by gains on Wall Street and a cheaper yen. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index rose 1.45% to 23,759.54, while the Topix index climbed 1.32% to 1,783.06.

site_title: US-China trade tussle is creating winners in South-east Asia
summary: South-east Asian countries are capitalizing on the US-China trade war, with many businesses shifting production sites to the region to avoid tariffs. Vietnam, Thailand, and Malaysia are expected to benefit from the shift, with companies like Phu Tai Corp and Kangaroo Group receiving new orders from American clients. The region's low production costs, well-established manufacturing plants, and improving ease of doing business make it an attractive alternative to China. Economists expect the trade war to continue, with South-east Asia emerging as a winner as companies seek to diversify their supply chains.

site_title: China will use trade war with US to replace imports: state media
summary: China will use the ongoing trade war with the US to promote localisation and develop high-tech products, replacing imports, according to state media. The country added $60 billion of US products to its import tariff list in retaliation for US tariffs on $200 billion worth of Chinese goods. Analysts and Chinese state-owned newspapers say the US tactics will prove ineffective, and China will emerge stronger, with some speculating the trade war could lead to China's financial markets gaining global recognition.

site_title: Singapore shares rise at Wednesday's open; STI up 0.18% to 3,145
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.18% to 3,145 at open on Wednesday, driven by gains in Yangzijiang Shipbuilding and AusGroup Limited. Gainers outnumbered losers 55 to 45, with 44.6 million securities worth S$66.8 million changing hands. The rally follows a 5-day streak ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Freehold Yuen Sing Mansion in Geylang up for collective sale
summary: Yuen Sing Mansion, a four-storey freehold collective sale site in Singapore, has been launched for sale by tender. The site, comprising nine apartments, is expected to receive bids exceeding S$17 million, reflecting S$779 per square foot per plot ratio. The site is zoned for residential and institutional use, with a gross plot ratio of 2.8 and a maximum allowable height of eight storeys. The tender closes on October 23, 2018, with easy access to entertainment and dining options in the Geylang area.

images.alt_text: The four-storey development comprises nine apartments built on a regular shaped plot. All the owners have consented to the collective sale and no Strata Titles Board approval would be required.

site_title: Tencent investment exec quits amid Chinese gaming industry turmoil
summary: Tencent Holdings Ltd executive Jonathan Lai, who led investments in Western digital entertainment firms, has left to join a New York-based investment manager amid Chinese gaming industry turmoil. Tencent faces a crackdown on online gaming, limiting new game releases and restricting youth gaming time, resulting in a 20% market value loss this year. Lai's departure comes as Tencent navigates a high-stakes rivalry with Alibaba Group Holding.

images.alt_text: His exit comes at a time when Tencent is reeling from a Chinese crackdown on online gaming that seeks to limit the number of new online video games and restrict the time young people spend playing games.

site_title: Level of Myanmar army brutality 'hard to fathom': UN probe
summary: The UN has released a report detailing widespread brutality by Myanmar's army against the Rohingya minority, with investigators calling for the military to be removed from politics and top generals to be prosecuted for genocide. The report, which estimates 10,000 people were killed and women were gang-raped, has led to a preliminary probe by the International Criminal Court. The UN also criticized Myanmar's civilian government for enabling rights violations and holding a quarter of seats in parliament, which maintains the military's grip on power.

site_title: Microplastics may enter foodchain through mosquitoes
summary: Researchers have found that mosquito larvae ingest microplastics, which can enter the food chain and potentially harm the environment. Microplastics, tiny plastic shards from man-made products, litter the world's oceans and can contaminate water supplies. The discovery highlights a new pathway for microplastics to damage the environment. This finding could have significant implications for human health as microplastics move through the food chain.

site_title: Tencent deemed the world's most disappointing stock
summary: Tencent Holdings Ltd. is the world's most disappointing stock in 2018, according to Bloomberg data. The company's Hong Kong stock tumbled 22% and wiped out $108 billion in value, despite being a top-rated buy by analysts. Tencent's failure to maintain earnings momentum and a government crackdown on the games industry contributed to the decline. Analysts still predict a 42% rebound over the next 12 months, but the company's disappointing performance in 2018 sets it apart from other top-rated stocks.

site_title: SingPost unit's share of associated company to fall to 19.75% on new share issue
summary: SingPost's subsidiary Quantium Solutions International (QSI) will see its equity shareholding in Shenzhen 4PX Information and Technology Co (4PX) fall to 19.75% after 4PX issues additional shares to existing shareholder Zhejiang Cainiao Supply Chain Management Co. This comes as 4PX ceases to be an associated company of SingPost, with QSI's equity shareholding percentage diluted. The new share issue does not affect QSI's current 30.52% stake in 4PX, but may impact future shareholdings if subsequent cash contributions do not occur.

site_title: Two Koreas aim for agreement to unlock nuclear talks
summary: North Korean leader Kim Jong Un and South Korean President Moon Jae-in are set to announce steps aimed at rekindling stalled nuclear talks and deepening bilateral ties after their second day of summit talks in Pyongyang. The joint statement expected from the two leaders will provide clues on whether negotiations between North Korea and the US can regain momentum. The talks aim to implement the Panmunjom Declaration, a military accord, and address the US demand for concrete action towards denuclearisation.

site_title: Indonesia anti-graft agency summons BlackGold unit's senior exec for another interview
summary: Indonesia's anti-graft agency, the Corruption Eradication Commission, has summoned the senior executive of BlackGold's subsidiary PT Samantaka Batubara for another interview. This follows a previous call for interviews by three senior BlackGold executives, including President Director Rudy Herlambang, as witnesses to an investigation. The interviews are related to an ongoing graft case involving a 285 trillion rupiah (approximately $20 billion USD) scandal. The company has not provided further details on the investigation or its findings.

site_title: National Australia Bank slashes executive pay amid misconduct scandal
summary: National Australia Bank slashed executive pay by 11% for its CEO and 15% for its executive leadership team in fiscal 2018 following a public inquiry revealing misconduct in the financial sector. The move aims to restore trust and demonstrate accountability. The bank's total rewards for its executive team will be reduced from 2017 levels. This action follows a similar trend seen in other financial institutions.

site_title: McDonald's workers in 10 US cities strike over sexual harassment
summary: McDonald's workers in 10 US cities staged a one-day strike over alleged inadequate response to sexual harassment, inspired by the #MeToo movement. The strike, the first of its kind, aimed to end the company's failure to curb incidents such as groping and propositions for sex. Protests were held in cities including Chicago, Kansas City, and Saint Louis, with workers demanding a committee to address workplace sexual violence. The strike followed a previous wave of sexual harassment claims filed with the US Equal Employment Opportunity Commission four months prior.

site_title: Bert and Ernie a 'loving couple' claims writer, 'Sesame Street' disagrees
summary: A former "Sesame Street" writer, Mark Saltzman, claims that Bert and Ernie are a "loving couple." However, the show's creators disagree, stating that the pair are simply best friends. Saltzman based their dynamic on his own long-term relationship with film editor Arnold Glassman. The writers' differing opinions on the characters' relationship have sparked debate among fans, with some interpreting the pair's closeness as romantic.

site_title: Silkroad Nickel inks heads of agreement for joint venture to build smelter facilities in Sulawesi
summary: Indonesian nickel mining group Silkroad Nickel has signed a heads of agreement with PT Anugrah Tambang Smelter to build and operate smelter facilities on its mine site in Sulawesi, Indonesia. The joint venture aims to produce nickel pig iron. Silkroad Nickel's subsidiary will acquire 30% of PT Anugrah Tambang Smelter, while another subsidiary will acquire 70%. The agreement includes a $1 million shareholder loan and provision of smelter equipment and technical knowledge. The project is part of Silkroad Nickel's strategy to become an integrated nickel mining company.

site_title: Pompeo to lead UN meeting on North Korea
summary: US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo will chair a UN Security Council meeting on North Korea on September 27, urging the international community to maintain pressure on Pyongyang. Pompeo aims to update the council on US efforts towards North Korea's full denuclearization and enforce existing sanctions. The meeting comes after a June summit between US President Donald Trump and North Korean leader Kim Jong Un, where a vague commitment to denuclearization was made. Pompeo's tough stance on Pyongyang follows criticism of Russia's sanctions evasion and concerns over China's attitude, with the US pledging to keep up pressure until denuclearization is on track.
