summary: Australia's chief commodity forecaster trimmed its forecast for wool production by 6% due to drought affecting the country's east coast, where 90% of the world's exported fine wool is produced. Wool production is expected to total 404,000 tonnes, down from 430,000 tonnes. Drought conditions also damage the country's cattle industry, with 8.345 million head of cattle expected to be slaughtered, and beef production expected to fall. Dairy production is also expected to decline, with milk output totaling 9.327 billion litres.

site_title: Amazon dominates early Emmy Awards in sign TV bet is paying off
summary: Amazon dominated the early Emmy Awards, claiming four of the first five awards announced. The Marvelous Mrs Maisel, an Amazon original series, won awards for best supporting actress, best lead actress, best writing, and best directing. This victory marks a significant win for Amazon's push into prestige television, following similar successes by Netflix and Hulu. The show's success highlights the growing influence of streaming services in the television industry.

site_title: North Korea's Kim Jong Un welcomes South's Moon at airport
summary: North Korean leader Kim Jong Un welcomed South Korean President Moon Jae In at Pyongyang airport on Tuesday, marking their third summit this year. The two leaders, accompanied by their wives, exchanged brief greetings before a welcome ceremony and field gun salute. The summit is the latest in a series of diplomatic efforts between the two nations, with a focus on improving relations and reducing tensions.

site_title: US ranks low on commitment to development, France drops: report
summary: The US ranks 23rd in commitment to global development, according to a report by the Centre for Global Development. Sweden takes the top spot, overtaking Denmark. The US scores low on foreign aid, finance, and environmental policies, but excels in security and trade. France drops three places to seventh, while Japan, Poland, Greece, and South Korea fall below the US. European countries dominate the top 12 spots, with Sweden scoring near the top in six categories. The report emphasizes the importance of considering multiple factors beyond foreign aid in development policy.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower after Trump announces China tariffs
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on September 18, 2018, after US President Donald Trump announced tariffs on $200 billion in Chinese goods. The Nikkei 225 index dropped 0.18% and the Topix index fell 0.15%. The move followed Trump's earlier announcement of tariffs on $50 billion in Chinese goods. The announcement led to a decline in Japanese stocks, with the benchmark index falling to 23,052.72.

site_title: Emmys fashion: white-hot, glamorous and political
summary: The 2018 Emmy Awards red carpet saw A-listers showcasing glamorous and politically-charged fashion choices. Stars wore white-hot frocks, sexy pantsuits, and sartorial statements, including a few pairs of sneakers. The event highlighted the intersection of fashion and politics, with many outfits making bold statements.

site_title: Ex-NY mayor Bloomberg once again mulling White House bid
summary: Billionaire ex-New York mayor Michael Bloomberg is considering a presidential bid as a Democrat in 2020, according to an interview with The New York Times. Bloomberg, 76, has been a vocal critic of the Republican Party since the rise of Donald Trump and has financially backed Democrats in recent midterm elections. However, his potential candidacy may face opposition from the activist left within the party, who have pushed for more women and minority candidates. Bloomberg has previously explored presidential bids in 2008, 2012, and 2016 without success.

site_title: EMA investigating blackout that hit large parts of Singapore on Tuesday morning
summary: A blackout affected nearly 150,000 residential and commercial customers in Singapore, with power restored within 38 minutes. The blackout, which occurred at 1:18am, was caused by a partial loss of electricity supply from two power generation companies. Investigations are ongoing, and the Energy Market Authority (EMA) has assured that its electricity network is in order. The disruption was reported in 19 areas, including Bedok, Jurong, and Ang Mo Kio.

images.alt_text: Several parts of Singapore, such as Yishun, were hit by a blackout in the wee hours of Sept 18, 2018.

site_title: Singapore shares decline at Tuesday's open; STI down 0.66% to 3,120.80
summary: Singapore stocks fell 0.66% to 3,120.80 at Tuesday's open, following US President Donald Trump's announcement of tariffs on $200 billion of Chinese imports. Losers outnumbered gainers 71 to 35, with Genting Singapore and Rex International Holding being among the most traded stocks. The decline came despite a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Canada trade minister pushes quick ratification of trade deal with Asia Pacific
summary: Canada's trade minister, Jim Carr, has signaled the government will push for quick ratification of the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) to maintain access to the US market amid stalled North American free trade talks. The TPP, signed in March without the US, requires ratification by at least six of its 11 signatories. Ottawa aims to be among the first six signatories, but faces opposition from Unifor, which wants stricter labor standards. Implementation of the TPP is crucial for Canada to counter US protectionism under President Donald Trump.

site_title: Days of fear, years of obstruction
summary: The US economy's 2008 financial crisis, triggered by Lehman Brothers' collapse, lasted for seven years due to politics, particularly Republican opposition. The financial crisis itself was brief, but the broader economic crisis persisted, with unemployment rising to 10% and taking seven years to recover. The Obama administration's stimulus efforts were insufficient and faded quickly. Republican opposition to fiscal policies, including raising the debt limit, was a major factor, driven by a "scorched-earth" approach to limit job creation and support for the economy. This obstructionism hindered a full recovery, with the economy still struggling when the Republican Party took control in 2011.

site_title: Dozens buried in Philippine landslide as China counts cost of Typhoon Mangkhut
summary: Typhoon Mangkhut, the world's most powerful storm this year, has left a trail of destruction in the Philippines and Hong Kong. At least 65 people are confirmed dead in the Philippines, with dozens feared buried under a landslide in the northern mountain town of Itogon. In China, four people were killed, and over 3 million were evacuated as the storm made landfall. Hong Kong suffered severe damage, with over 300 people injured and thousands of residents stranded. The storm's massive clean-up efforts are underway, with millions affected by the disaster.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Sembcorp, CapitaLand, Plastoform, Valuetronics, YZJ, Debao
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Several Singaporean companies reported significant developments on Tuesday, September 18, 2018. Sembcorp Industries secured a 20-year solar energy deal with Facebook, while CapitaLand acquired 16 US multifamily properties. Plastoform Holdings shut down its Shenzhen production facility, and Valuetronics temporarily halted production due to power outages. Yangzijiang Shipbuilding formed a joint venture in Panama, and Debao Property Development requested a third extension for its annual general meeting. Meanwhile, Sapphire Corporation secured a new contract in China, and BBR Holdings won several construction contracts. These developments may impact trading of their shares.

site_title: Najib's wife Rosmah Mansor expected to be charged with money laundering soon, says report
summary: Malaysian authorities are expected to formally charge Datin Seri Rosmah Mansor, the wife of former Prime Minister Najib Razak, with up to 20 counts of money laundering in a case linked to 1MDB. Investigators have "tied up all the loose ends" in their probe into Rosmah, who was questioned in June. The charges may include allegations of purchasing hormone-based anti-ageing products worth over RM1 million. Rosmah and her husband, Najib, have been barred from leaving Malaysia amid ongoing investigations into the 1MDB scandal.

site_title: Tariffs on US$200b of China goods to be announced 'soon': White House
summary: US President Donald Trump is expected to announce punitive import tariffs on another $200 billion in Chinese goods "soon," according to a White House official. Economic advisor Larry Kudlow confirmed news stories indicating 10% duties on these imports are "more or less correct." This move comes amid ongoing trade tensions with China, the world's second-largest economy.

site_title: Valuetronics stops work at Guangdong plant due to Super Typhoon Mangkhut-related flooding
summary: Valuetronics has temporarily halted work at a Guangdong plant due to power outages caused by Super Typhoon Mangkhut's flash floods. All employees are safe, and most production facilities remain unaffected. The company plans to resume production as soon as power and local traffic normalize. The typhoon, the world's strongest storm this year, has caused four casualties in Guangdong and 65 in the Philippines. Valuetronics will assess the full impact and notify its insurer before resuming production.

site_title: South Africa fintech firm JUMO raises US$52m to drive expansion in Asia and Africa
summary: South African fintech firm JUMO has raised US$52 million in funding led by Goldman Sachs to expand into new markets in Asia and Africa. The funds will be used to drive growth in these regions, with CEO Andrew Watkins-Ball relocating to Singapore to oversee the expansion. This latest round brings JUMO's total fundraising to US$90 million, as the company continues to drive expansion in the fintech sector.

images.alt_text: Andrew Watkins-Ball, chief executive officer of South African fintech firm JUMO, has relocated to Singapore to drive the company's expansion in Asia.

site_title: Trump slaps tariffs on US$200b in Chinese goods, spares some consumer tech
summary: US President Donald Trump imposed 10% tariffs on approximately $200 billion worth of Chinese imports, sparing consumer tech products such as smart watches and bicycles. The tariffs, set to start on September 24, are the latest escalation of the US-China trade war. China has vowed to retaliate further, with its yuan currency weakening against the US dollar. The move has sparked concerns about the impact on US farmers, industries, and consumers, with some groups warning of "lasting harm" and "a tax on American families."

site_title: Ex-president Kirchner charged in Argentina corruption scandal
summary: Argentina's ex-president Cristina Kirchner was charged with corruption on Monday, accused of accepting tens of millions of dollars in bribes in the "corruption notebooks" scandal. She faces charges of heading an "illicit association" and collusion with businessmen to secure public works contracts. Kirchner's immunity as a senator is unlikely to be lifted, making it difficult for her to be jailed if found guilty. She has already been called in for questioning twice and is due to appear again on Tuesday, maintaining her "categorical denial" of any wrongdoing.

site_title: Debao Property Development applies for third extension to hold FY2017 AGM
summary: Debao Property Development has applied for a third extension to hold its FY2017 annual general meeting (AGM), now scheduled for November 30 instead of September 30. The company has appointed Ernst & Young (China) Advisory Limited to review its consolidated financial statements for FY2017, following an audit request. Debao's auditors received the final report on September 5 and will require an additional 4-6 weeks to complete their review before issuing the financial statements. The company will provide further updates on the outcome of the application.

site_title: CAAS launches official probe into SIA pilot who failed alcohol test, says 1st such case in 10 years
summary: Singapore's aviation regulator, CAAS, has launched an investigation into a Singapore Airlines pilot who failed an alcohol test before a flight in Australia, the first such case in 10 years. The pilot was suspended and the airline has started its own investigation. CAAS Director Alan Foo stressed that substance abuse by pilots is taken seriously, with penalties including fines of up to $100,000 and five years in jail. SIA has implemented stricter rules for its flight crew, requiring them to abstain from alcoholic drinks for at least 10 hours before flying.

images.alt_text: Singapore's aviation regulator has launched its own investigations against a Singapore Airlines (SIA) pilot who was caught in Australia on Saturday for failing an alcohol test before a flight.

site_title: US to spare Apple watch, many gadgets from new China tariffs
summary: The US will spare Apple's Watch and other consumer gadgets from the latest round of tariffs on Chinese goods, which will take effect on September 24 at 10% and rise to 25% by the end of the year. Smart watches, Bluetooth devices, and products that work with smartphones, such as Apple's AirPods, will be excluded. However, some products that help computer networks, like routers, will remain on the list. This reprieve affects around 300 product categories, including some non-tech consumer devices, amidst an intensifying trade dispute between the US and China.

site_title: CapitaLand buys 16 multifamily properties in US for US$835m
summary: CapitaLand acquired 16 multifamily properties in the US for US$835 million, expanding its global investment portfolio. The portfolio comprises 3,787 apartment units in suburban areas of Seattle, Portland, Los Angeles, and Denver, with an average occupancy rate of 90% and average length of stay of two years. This marks CapitaLand's entry into the US multifamily asset class, with the transaction expected to be completed in the fourth quarter of 2018. The acquisition increases CapitaLand's investment in the US to over US$1.5 billion and its presence in the market to over 6,500 units.

site_title: US: Stocks tumble as Trump hints China tariffs imminent
summary: US stocks plummeted on Monday as President Donald Trump hinted at imminent tariffs on China, sparking concerns of an all-out trade war. The Dow Jones fell 0.4%, the S&P 500 dropped 0.6%, and the Nasdaq Composite slid 1.4%. Technology shares were hit hard, with Apple, Alphabet, and Microsoft experiencing significant declines. China has vowed retaliation against new tariffs, raising worries about the impact on global markets.

site_title: Ipco gets more time to hold AGM, warns some financials may need to be restated
summary: Ipco International has been granted more time to hold its annual general meeting (AGM) by the Singapore Exchange (SGX), with the deadline set at October 30. The company is also required to submit its annual report by October 16, or its shares will be suspended until its financial state is clear.

site_title: Plastoform to close Shenzhen production plant; plans to liquidate unit
summary: Plastoform Holdings, a manufacturing service provider, announced the closure of its production facility in Shenzhen, China, as part of its restructuring efforts. The group faces challenges in debt collections and insufficient sales orders, leading to a decision to liquidate its Shenzhen subsidiary. The closure is expected to result in cost savings and a reduction in monthly losses, with the group planning to transform its business to a project-oriented model. The liquidation process will involve realising assets and repaying staff, suppliers, and government expenses.

site_title: Europe: Stocks keep steady amid tariffs fears; H&M surges
summary: European stocks closed in positive territory, reversing early losses, amid US President Trump's plans for new 10% tariffs on $200 billion of Chinese imports. The pan-European Stoxx 600 rose 0.1% and Germany's DAX fell 0.2%. Wall Street opened lower but remained steady.

site_title: Sembcorp inks 20-year deal to supply solar power to Facebook's Singapore operations
summary: Sembcorp Industries signed a 20-year deal with Facebook to supply 100% renewable energy from 50 MWp of solar panels on 900 rooftops in Singapore. The contract, valued at an undisclosed amount, will support Facebook's data centre and operations, marking Sembcorp's first renewable energy partnership in Asia. The deal aligns with Sembcorp's target to double its renewables portfolio and reduce carbon intensity by 25% by 2022, and does not significantly impact its financial performance.

images.alt_text: Solar panels will be installed on close to 900 rooftops in Singapore to supply renewable power to Facebook's recently announced 170,000 square metre Singapore data centre, as well as its other Singapore operations.

site_title: Startup SG Network launched to help startups find partners
summary: Singapore's Enterprise Singapore launched the Startup SG Network, an online portal connecting startups, incubators, accelerators, and investors across 30 technology sectors. The platform allows users to profile themselves and find suitable partners using filters and search terms. The site will feature AI-powered interactive features, such as a chatbot and recommendation engine, in later stages. Interested parties can register with the Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority and access the platform at www.startupsg.net.

site_title: Victor Li gets his timing right for a UK IPO
summary: Victor Li, the CEO of CK Infrastructure Holdings Ltd, is considering a UK IPO to raise cash, amid a decline in returns on assets and increasing debt levels. Li has acquired several assets in the UK, including a power network and Northumbrian Water Group Ltd, and may list these assets through a new vehicle. The IPO timing is seen as strategic, given the current market conditions and Brexit uncertainty. The move could provide relief for Li's empire, which has seen its debt levels rise due to aggressive acquisitions.

site_title: Oil near flat as market weighs US-China trade tensions, Iran sanctions
summary: Oil prices remained little changed on Monday, influenced by US-China trade tensions and potential supply tightening due to Iran sanctions. Brent crude futures fell to $78.05 a barrel and US WTI crude futures to $68.91 a barrel. Top White House adviser Larry Kudlow stated that the US would soon announce tariffs on an additional $200 billion worth of Chinese goods.

images.alt_text: Oil prices were little changed on Monday as the market weighed deepening trade tension between the US and China that is expected to dent global crude demand and potential supply tightening due to Iran sanctions.

site_title: Govt seeks to set record straight on ministerial pay
summary: Singapore's government has denied reports that Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong earns up to S$4.5 million annually, citing "falsehoods" online. The government website Factually explained that ministerial salaries are calculated based on a fixed component, 13th month bonus, and variable pay components including a performance bonus and national bonus. The Prime Minister's annual salary is S$2.2 million, excluding bonuses, and he receives the national bonus. The government also clarified that ministerial salaries will remain unchanged until they are reviewed after five years.

site_title: Price gains in Hainan property market moderating after curbs
summary: Hainan, China's tropical island, saw a 21% year-over-year increase in property prices in August, the largest annual gain among 70 monitored cities. However, transactions since January have plummeted, and price gains have been moderating after curbs were implemented to prevent a speculative bubble. The government's restrictions, including lengthy residency requirements and high down payments, have distorted the property market, making it "on hold" according to CLSA Ltd's Nicole Wong. This moderation is seen as a positive step to avoid another boom-bust cycle in the island.

site_title: Asians can build new patterns for business
summary: Asian family-owned businesses can play a key role in shaping a more sustainable globalisation, enabling the delivery of the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). With new technologies and digital transparency, companies can take responsibility for social and environmental issues throughout their supply chains. Smaller businesses and smallholder farmers also have a crucial role to play in driving sustainable development, and value networks can help harness their influence. A new generation of Asian leaders is stepping up to address long-term sustainability, with the opportunity to drive sustainable development through innovative business models and investments.

site_title: China to speed up efforts to cut solar, wind subsidies: draft guidelines
summary: China plans to accelerate efforts to eliminate subsidies for its wind and solar power sectors, aiming for "grid price parity" with traditional energy sources. The National Energy Administration has issued draft guidelines, urging regions to provide technological and policy support to ensure the sectors can operate subsidy-free. As costs for solar power generation have fallen 90% since 2007, industry experts expect grid price parity to be achieved within a year, with some regions already achieving price parity with clean coal-fired power. The move aims to ease China's dependence on polluting fossil fuels.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Brokerage firms ESR-Reit and DBS maintain their "buy" target prices for the companies, citing potential benefits from the merger and growth prospects. ESR-Reit's target price is set at S$0.59, while DBS' target price is S$30.30, driven by the bank's rising net interest margin and strengthening capital adequacy ratio. Analysts believe the companies' assets hold untapped potential for conversion and growth, despite some short-term challenges.

site_title: Don't let lease angst overshadow HDB's great job in public housing
summary: The Housing and Development Board (HDB) has been addressing concerns over the resale value of HDB flats, particularly those nearing the end of their 99-year leases. Despite public debate, HDB flat buyers are owners, not lessees. The government is exploring flexibility in purchasing flats with shorter leases and plans to upgrade every HDB flat twice during its lifetime to preserve value. These initiatives aim to reassure homeowners that their flats still have value as they approach the end of their lease, amidst concerns over public housing's long-term value.

site_title: 9 new precincts to join pilot Business Improvement District programme
summary: Nine new precincts in Singapore will join a pilot Business Improvement District (BID) programme to drive efforts in enlivening the city. The precincts, including China Place and Marina Bay, will host activities and programmes with public participation. The government will support stakeholders in transforming their precincts and public spaces, with dollar-for-dollar matching for membership fees collected by pilot BIDs. The pilot programme, launched in 2017, has seen increased stakeholder participation and footfall in areas like Singapore River One.

site_title: World's richest economies enjoy biggest pay raise in a decade
summary: The world's richest economies are experiencing their largest pay raise in a decade, with 2.5% wage growth in the second quarter, according to JPMorgan Chase & Co. This trend is driven by falling unemployment rates, forcing companies to retain and attract staff. The bank predicts wages will accelerate to near 3% next year, as central bankers seek to address labor market puzzles.

site_title: How safe is your personal data collected by your smart devices?
summary: A growing concern surrounds the collection and use of personal data by smart devices and IoT systems, with multiple stakeholders in multiple jurisdictions involved. The Personal Data Protection Act (PDPA) requires consent and notification for data collection, but its application in IoT ecosystems is complex due to the involvement of various stakeholders, including telecoms companies, device manufacturers, and data centers across multiple countries. To comply with PDPA, organizations must identify stakeholders, consider data flow and purposes, and obtain consent from individuals, often a challenging task, especially for those not tech-savvy.

site_title: Investigators home in on Deutsche Bank exec's 1MDB role
summary: Singapore authorities are investigating the role of Deutsche Bank executive Tan Boon Kee in the 1MDB scandal, a multi-billion dollar Malaysian state fund embezzlement case. Tan, who stepped down from her Asia-Pacific head role at Deutsche Bank, has been interviewed by the Commercial Affairs Department and the Monetary Authority of Singapore. Investigators are looking into her dealings with Malaysian financier Low Taek Jho and former Goldman Sachs banker Roger Ng, who introduced Tan to Low. The probe is part of a global investigation into 1MDB, where $4.5 billion was allegedly siphoned off.

site_title: Vividthree to raise S$12.95m in IPO
summary: Vividthree Holdings (VVH) plans to raise S$12.95 million through a proposed spin-off and Catalist listing on September 25, with 51.8 million shares at S$0.25 each. The virtual reality studio's net profit for FY2018 was S$2.7 million, with a pre-placement earnings per share of S$0.96. The company will use the funds for general working capital, intellectual property, and acquisitions. Following the placement, mm2 Asia will be the controlling shareholder with about 41.53% ownership.

site_title: No systemic failure by Datapulse in M&A due process: review
summary: A review by law firm Lee & Lee found no systemic failure in Datapulse Technology's due process for mergers and acquisitions (M&A) between 2000 and 2018, but noted the company can improve internal controls. The review criticized a hasty process in the acquisition of hair care business Wayco, including a lack of due diligence and unclear terms in a buyback agreement. Lee & Lee recommended Datapulse strengthen its corporate governance and compliance, and establish a board risk committee. Datapulse has adopted most recommendations, but is proposing to have its audit committee assume this role instead.

site_title: Saudi sovereign fund secures US$11b loan to boost diversification blitz
summary: Saudi Arabia's Public Investment Fund secured a $11 billion international loan to boost its diversification efforts, following the stalled Aramco IPO. This loan marks the fund's first ever international debt funding and is part of its medium-term debt-funding programme. The move aims to reduce the kingdom's dependence on oil and diversify its economy.

site_title: Trump's Scottish golf homes attract interest even before approval
summary: US President Donald Trump's golf resort in Scotland is attracting interest from property buyers even before approval. Large properties have been reserved and many others are in high demand, with up to 500 homes potentially being built. The project, valued at £150 million, is expected to create 2,000 construction jobs. However, Trump's Scottish golf investments have not been profitable, with losses at Trump Turnberry reaching £17.6 million in 2016 and a shortfall at the Aberdeenshire course of £1.4 million.

site_title: Is Ascott trust mulling sale of Ascott Raffles Place?
summary: Ascott Residence Trust (ART), a Singapore-based real estate investment trust, is reportedly considering the sale of its 20-storey serviced apartment building, Ascott Raffles Place, after receiving several unsolicited offers. The property, valued at S$215 million, could be sold for over S$350 million, according to market talk. ART may divest the asset to recycle capital, as it is set to be replaced by a new Citadines serviced residence at CapitaSpring, and to focus on other projects. A potential buyer could also consider reconfiguring the existing apartments or converting the building into co-working or co-living facilities.

site_title: Credit Suisse urged to improve money laundering controls
summary: Credit Suisse has been ordered by Switzerland's financial regulator, Finma, to strengthen its internal processes to combat money laundering by the end of next year. The regulator has also identified deficiencies in the bank's anti-money laundering controls and shortcomings in its oversight of a banker. Credit Suisse has made "some substantial" improvements and avoided a fine in the probes. The probe focused on the bank's relationships with officials of FIFA and Petrobras. The regulator's review covered the period from 2006 to 2016 and is part of a broader effort to increase compliance costs for wealth managers.

site_title: Macau casinos fall with typhoon shutdown estimated to cost US$186m
summary: Macau casinos were forced to shut down for 33 hours due to Typhoon Mangkhut, resulting in estimated losses of US$186 million in revenue. The shutdown, which occurred on Saturday and Sunday, affected nearly all casinos in the enclave, with nearly all reopening on Monday. Industry analysts expect the storm's impact to dampen casino revenue in Macau, with September's revenue growth rate potentially affected by up to 7 percentage points. The shutdown is the first time Macau has shut down casinos since licenses were granted in 2002, and is the latest blow to the industry, which has been experiencing a rebound after a two-year slowdown.

site_title: Super ways to handle waste
summary: 800 Super Holdings, a Singapore-based waste management company, has expanded its operations by making the most of its own waste. The firm's approach includes recycling, energy production, and innovative technologies such as biomass plants and laundry facilities. Its integrated development at Tuas includes a depot, biomass energy plant, sludge incinerator, and industrial laundry. 800 Super's innovation and productivity initiatives have also improved its public cleaning services, including real-time monitoring and automated collection systems. The company's transformation has attracted younger talent and improved its bottom line.

site_title: STI tracks Asian markets to end lower
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) fell 20.02 points to 3,141.40, its first decline since Tuesday, amid concerns over a new round of US-China tariff war. US President Donald Trump is set to announce $200 billion in tariffs on Chinese imports, sparking investor fears. The decline follows three days of gains, and investors are bracing themselves for the potential economic impact.

site_title: Machines to handle half of work tasks by 2025: WEF study
summary: The World Economic Forum (WEF) predicts that by 2025, machines and automated software will handle half of all workplace tasks, displacing 75 million workers globally. However, the report also forecasts that new technologies could create 133 million jobs. Companies are urged to invest in retraining and continuing education for employees to mitigate job losses, as the effects of automation vary across industries.

site_title: DBS appoints receiver for Triyards unit Strategic Marine to protect its claims
summary: DBS Bank has appointed a receiver for Strategic Marine, a unit of Singapore-listed Triyards Holdings, amid claims of about US$43.9 million from DBS. The move comes after Triyards disclosed receiving letters of demand from DBS and raises doubts over the company's restructuring process. The receiver, Justin Lim Loo Khoon, will oversee the protection of DBS's claims, including a hull and a construction contract, and earnings accruing to the vessel Lewek Hercules. The appointment has sparked concerns over Triyards' disclosure lapses and the company's ability to recover from its protracted restructuring exercise.

site_title: BlackGold executives called as witnesses in bribery probe
summary: BlackGold Natural Resources, a coal mining company, has three employees called as witnesses in an ongoing bribery probe by Indonesia's Corruption Eradication Commission. The employees, including executive chairman and CEO Philip Cecil Rickard, chief investment officer James Rijanto, and president director Rudy Herlambang, are believed to know of a criminal act but are not suspected of committing a crime. BlackGold shares fell 3.8% after the announcement, but the company stated it will continue to cooperate with the investigation and maintain normal business operations.

site_title: Centurion to buy 133-bed UK student housing asset for £10.2m
summary: Centurion Corp has agreed to buy a 133-bed student housing asset in Nottingham, UK for £10.2m. The asset, Castle Gate Haus, will be managed under Centurion's dwell brand and is expected to increase its total student accommodation portfolio to 29 assets globally. The acquisition will also boost its beds under management to approximately 55,615, with the UK portfolio to reach 2,676 beds across 10 assets. Centurion CEO Kong Chee Min expressed optimism about the UK's purpose-built student accommodation sector, citing a 2.1-to-1 student-to-bed ratio in the Nottingham market.

site_title: Growth in Chinese home prices hits two-year high in August
summary: China's home prices surged 1.4% in August, the fastest pace in nearly two years, driven by Beijing's efforts to boost the slowing economy. The 40th straight month of price increases, despite tougher curbs, has raised fears of a bubble. Average new home prices rose 7% year-over-year, with 67 out of 70 cities reporting a monthly price increase. Analysts attribute the growth to looser credit and government stimulus, but warn that additional funds may flow into the market, stoking concerns of a bubble.

site_title: UK economy will shrink without Brexit deal, IMF warns
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) warned that the UK economy will shrink if it leaves the European Union without a Brexit deal, predicting a 1.5% annual growth rate in 2018 and 2019. IMF Managing Director Christine Lagarde stated that all Brexit scenarios will have economic costs, with a "no-deal" exit expected to make Britain significantly poorer. The UK is due to leave the EU on March 29, with Prime Minister Theresa May struggling to secure a deal, and the IMF's warning adds to pressure on her government to reach a deal before the deadline.

site_title: Will Korean denuclearisation post-S'pore be a mirage?
summary: South Korean President Moon Jae-in and North Korean leader Kim Jong-un are meeting to revive stalled peace talks and denuclearization efforts, following the cancellation of US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo's trip to Pyongyang. Despite Trump's positive response to Kim's letter, White House frustration with Pyongyang's lack of concrete actions grows, with National Security Adviser John Bolton calling for significant action. The talks aim to address the vagueness of commitments made in the Singapore summit and build confidence, with Kim seeking reciprocation of goodwill measures and Trump's team struggling to develop a comprehensive strategy for denuclearization.

site_title: An ace at crunching numbers
summary: Jace Koh, founder of UVentures, a company offering accounting and bookkeeping services, has successfully navigated the challenges of running multiple businesses. Starting with a mortgage broking firm, she transitioned to an accounting firm after her initial plans fell through. With no initial customers, she had to build everything from scratch. Today, UVentures focuses on a technology-friendly approach and has acquired insights from various industries, enabling it to help SMEs and startups. Despite her success, Koh faces challenges in managing her own business and often finds herself busy helping other companies, which she attributes to her ability to see the big picture and problems quickly.

site_title: New Noble's board to have up to 5 IDs
summary: Noble Group's board for its newly formed company, New Noble, is expected to consist of 8-9 directors, mostly from the Asia-Pacific region. The board will include 2 company executives, 1 representative from Abu-Dhabi based investment fund Goldilocks, and 1 from senior creditors, with up to 5 independent non-executive directors. The composition will be announced before the restructuring is completed, expected in November, and will oversee rebuilding the business and making key strategic decisions over the next 2 years.

site_title: Grange Heights, Cairnhill Astoria have another go at en bloc sale
summary: Two prime freehold residential sites in District 9 near Orchard Road are up for collective sale. Grange Heights in St Thomas Walk will be offered for S$820 million, with each owner potentially receiving between S$5.235 million and S$10.762 million. Cairnhill Astoria in Cairnhill Rise relaunches with a S$196 million asking price, with owners potentially receiving between S$2.275 million and S$14.261 million. The sites are zoned residential and have a gross plot ratio of 2.8, with both developments expected to be completed with a building height control of up to 36 storeys.

images.alt_text: Each owner at Cairnhill Astoria (above) might receive between S$2.275 million and S$14.261 million upon successful completion of the transaction, and it'll be between S$5.235 million and S$10.762 million for each owner at Grange Heights.

Each owner at Cairnhill Astoria might receive between S$2.275 million and S$14.261 million upon successful completion of the transaction, and it'll be between S$5.235 million and S$10.762 million for each owner at Grange Heights (above).

site_title: SGX leads US$44.4m funding round for online freight platform
summary: SGX has closed a US$44.4 million Series C funding round for Freightos, the world's largest online marketplace for freight rates. The funding, led by General Electric Ventures, brings Freightos' total funding to US$94.4 million. Freightos aims to transform the international shipping industry into a more transparent and agile market, leveraging data and a network of logistics providers. The company's platform has expanded from price comparison to instant booking, tracking, and communication, and its global rate database drives the Freightos Baltic Index.

site_title: Paris show brings together rare views of young Picasso
summary: A Paris exhibition featuring over 300 works from Pablo Picasso's early years (1900-1906) has opened at the Musee d'Orsay. The show brings together rare pieces from the Blue and Rose periods, showcasing Picasso's formative days as a young artist. The exhibition includes 80 paintings, 150 drawings, and sculptures, as well as portraits by other artists, offering a new perspective on Picasso's early work and his influences from artists like Manet and Van Gogh. The show highlights Picasso's emotional journey, from his somber Blue period to the lighter, warmer tones of the Rose period.

site_title: Singapore's payments transformation pushes ahead with single QR code
summary: Singapore has launched a single, standardised QR code for e-payments, a key step in the country's electronic payments transformation. The move aims to simplify transactions and could serve as a global model. The government is also opening interbank payment services, such as the FAST service, to fintech firms. This development is expected to enhance the country's financial infrastructure and promote a more efficient payment system.

images.alt_text: Mr Ong touring 100 AM Mall and paying for purchases using SGQR; the code will be adopted by 27 payment schemes and will be rolled out progressively over the next six months.

site_title: US dollar backtracks on trade concerns
summary: US dollar loses ground as investors await potential new tariffs on Chinese imports. The US dollar briefly rose last Friday but fell nearly a quarter of a percent on Monday. Emerging market currencies slipped nearly half a percent. The US has already imposed duties on $50 billion worth of Chinese goods, and China is unlikely to play defense in an escalating trade war. Speculators are unwinding short bets against the euro and sterling, and net long positions in the dollar have fallen to $19.2 billion.

site_title: Victoria Beckham debuts in London
summary: Victoria Beckham made her London Fashion Week debut, marking a decade in the fashion industry with a triumphant homecoming. The show, held in a contemporary art gallery, showcased her spring-summer 2019 collection, featuring classic chic with modern twists. Beckham, who launched her VB label in 2008, has built a global empire with four clothing lines, over 400 retail outlets, and offices in London and New York. Her collection explored contrasts and codes, with a focus on choice and dressing women, not just one woman. The event marked a milestone for the 44-year-old designer, who has earned widespread recognition for her hard work and determination.

site_title: New interactive forum to showcase global thought leaders
summary: Singapore's Straits Times and The Business Times will launch "Cutting Edge," a new public interactive forum, featuring renowned thought leaders from around the world. The first forum, with Howard Yu, will take place on October 5, where Yu will share insights on innovation and corporate disruption. The forums will be live-interviewed and videocast, with limited tickets available for S$68-S$85. The series is sponsored by GuocoLand and aims to bring interesting ideas and perspectives to engage audiences.

site_title: Betting against Tesla: sceptics make their case
summary: Tesla is facing skepticism from investors who base their views on cold financial calculations, rather than antipathy for the company or its CEO, Elon Musk. Detractors point to the company's heavy debt load, voracious cash burn, and out-of-whack stock price with demand for its product. Despite Musk's claims of a sharp increase in sales driving up revenues, short-sellers argue that Tesla's financials are precarious, with a shortage of cash and high liabilities. The company's valuation of $50 billion makes it the most shorted stock on Wall Street, with many experts questioning whether Musk is mentally fit to lead the company through its challenges.

site_title: CapitaLand invests US$25.9m in Indonesian hotel operator
summary: CapitaLand has invested US$25.9 million in Indonesian hotel operator Green Oak Hotel Management (GOHM) for a 70% share. This investment is part of CapitaLand's strategy to grow its hospitality business through The Ascott, a serviced residence business unit. The deal will see the Ascott portfolio increase by nearly 20,000 units in 122 hotels across Indonesia, Malaysia, and Vietnam, bringing the global total to over 94,000 units.

site_title: China pig fever outbreak gives poultry farmers a boost
summary: China is experiencing a surge in chicken prices due to the African swine fever outbreak, with broiler prices reaching two-and-a-half year highs. The shortage of pork, combined with concerns about swine fever safety, has driven up demand for chicken, particularly in the infected regions. As a result, chicken prices have increased by 13.2% year-over-year, with some cuts reaching record highs. The outbreak has provided a windfall for chicken farmers, with some companies seeing a boost in share prices.

site_title: Uber said in talks to acquire Dubai ride hailing firm
summary: Uber is in talks to acquire Dubai-based ride-hailing firm Careem Networks for $2 billion to $2.5 billion, according to people familiar with the matter. The deal could head off a potential initial public offering (IPO) for Careem, which had previously raised $500 million in funding. Careem, backed by Japanese e-commerce giant Rakuten and German automaker Daimler, operates in over 100 cities across the Middle East and has more than a million drivers. Negotiations are ongoing, with no final decisions made.

site_title: Equity Residential seeks buyers for two NYC buildings
summary: Equity Residential is marketing two Manhattan apartment buildings, 800 Sixth Ave in Chelsea and 505 W 54th St in Hell's Kitchen, as the company seeks to reduce its holdings in a softening rental market. The Chicago-based real estate investment trust has already sold a third building. The sales come amid rising mortgage rates and a record-breaking Manhattan rent market, which is expected to see further increases. Equity Residential's decision to sell its buildings may be part of a broader strategy to adapt to the changing rental market.

site_title: Saudi Aramco to spend over US$133b on drilling over next decade
summary: Saudi Aramco plans to spend over $133 billion on oil and gas drilling over the next decade, according to senior executive Mohammed al-Qahtani. This investment aligns with the Saudi Vision 2030 goals, aiming to diversify the economy. The spending will support drilling activities and contribute to the country's energy sector growth.

site_title: 2018 new home sales forecast to wilt by a quarter
summary: Singapore's new home sales are forecast to decline by 25% in 2018, with 6,287 units sold in the first eight months of the year, 25.1% lower than the same period last year. The drop is attributed to the government's cooling measures and the Hungry Ghost Festival, which saw lower launch activity and buyers becoming more selective. Analysts predict full-year sales to be between 8,000 and 10,000 units, with a possible rebound in the latter half of the year.

images.alt_text: This year's new home sales could be as much as 25 per cent lower than last year's levels, market watchers said, after government data revealed subdued home-buying activity in August as a result of the cooling measures and also the Hungry Ghost Festival.

site_title: Bangladeshi garment workers reject wage hike; want global fashion brands to pay more
summary: Bangladeshi garment workers have rejected the country's minimum wage increase of over 50% to 8,000 taka (S$131) per month, citing it as insufficient to live on. The wage hike, the first in seven years, was introduced last week amidst concerns over poor working conditions. The workers are now urging global fashion brands to pay more for the clothes they buy, rather than relying on the government to provide a higher wage. The rejection highlights the ongoing struggles of garment workers in Bangladesh and the need for higher pay from international buyers.

site_title: Flights resume as Mangkhut moves on after battering Hong Kong
summary: Cathay Pacific and other airlines resumed flights to Hong Kong, a city battered by Typhoon Mangkhut, after the storm moved on. Almost 900 flights were cancelled, with Cathay scrapping over 400 flights. The Hong Kong International Airport advised passengers to check their seats and flight times before proceeding. Despite some damage, Hong Kong is returning to normalcy, with the Hong Kong Observatory lowering its warning signal. Flights at Guangzhou airport also resumed on Monday, as the city limped back to normalcy after the typhoon's storm surges and strong winds caused destruction.

site_title: The Predator slaughters at the box office with US$24m haul
summary: The Predator, a sci-fi action film, debuted at the top of the North American box office with a US$24 million haul, despite costing US$88 million to make. The film's performance was seen as underwhelming, but it is expected to generate revenue in international markets. The movie's opening weekend was a significant victory for the franchise, which has been around for decades.

site_title: Changing hands
summary: Singapore's NTT DC Reit's public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed. The US stock market opened lower after President Trump's fresh tariff salvo on Canada. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and operating loss in the second half of the year. London's Heathrow is considering higher fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a graft case involving 285 trillion rupiah. OCBC announced Tan Teck Long as its incoming CEO, replacing a DBS veteran. Singapore stocks rallied for the fifth day ahead of GDP data release.

site_title: Saudi wealth fund to invest US$1b in Tesla's rival Lucid
summary: Saudi Arabia's Public Investment Fund (PIF) has agreed to invest $1 billion in Lucid Motors Inc., a US electric-car maker, to support the commercial launch of its first electric vehicle, the Lucid Air, in 2020. This deal comes as Tesla faces uncertainty after CEO Elon Musk tweeted about securing funding to take the company private. The investment gives Lucid the necessary funding to move forward with its commercial launch, while PIF gains exposure to the growing electric vehicle market and long-term growth opportunities.

site_title: Nine chosen to be Nominated MPs in Parliament
summary: Nine individuals have been selected to represent various segments of Singapore society in Parliament as Nominated Members of Parliament (NMPs). The selected NMPs include a pharmacist, a para-athlete, a leader of the traditional arts sector, and an activist for inter-religious harmony. President Halimah Yacob will present the instruments of appointment on Sept 26, and the NMPs will take their oath at the next sitting of Parliament. The NMP scheme provides non-partisan views in Parliament and can have up to nine NMPs in each term, which lasts 2 1/2 years.

images.alt_text: Douglas Foo, chairman of Sakae Holdings, is among the nine individuals who will become Nominated Members of Parliament.

site_title: High-tech truck makes one-man show possible
summary: A 61-year-old Singaporean truck driver, Balbant Singh, is part of a year-long trial using a high-tech recycling collection truck that allows him to collect recyclables with minimal human intervention. The truck's advanced system features cameras, sensors, and a computerized control system to guide the claw and ensure proper bin handling. This technology reduces the need for additional workers and enhances safety, as Singh can complete his rounds without leaving his seat. The trial is part of the National Environment Agency's industry transformation map for the environmental services sector.

site_title: Qatar Fund is near investment in China's top online lender
summary: Qatar's sovereign wealth fund, the Qatar Investment Authority, is in advanced talks to invest in Lufax, China's largest online lender, with a potential purchase of a minority stake worth $500 million to $1 billion. Lufax, an arm of Ping An Insurance, became profitable for the first time in 2016 and was valued at $18.5 billion in a 2016 fundraising. A deal could be announced as early as the next few weeks.

site_title: Laguna Park up for sale with S$1.48b reserve price
summary: Laguna Park, a 99-year leasehold estate in Singapore's East Coast area, has been put up for collective sale with a reserve price of nearly S$1.5 billion. The site, comprising 7 residential blocks and 12 commercial units, can yield approximately 1.87 million sq ft of gross floor area upon redevelopment. The reserve price includes a land rate of S$1,253 psf ppr, and the tender closes on Nov 1. This is the second en bloc offering in Singapore this year, following Horizon Towers and Faber Garden, which also failed to sell.

site_title: Time acquired by Salesforce billionaire Marc Benioff
summary: Marc Benioff, billionaire co-CEO of Salesforce, and his wife Lynne have agreed to acquire Time magazine from Meredith Corp for $190 million in cash. The deal is the latest in a trend of tech billionaires buying print publications, following Amazon's acquisition of the Washington Post. The Benioffs plan to keep Time's current leadership team in charge and will not be involved in day-to-day operations or journalistic decisions. The acquisition marks a new role for Benioff as a media baron, with Time reaching over 100 million readers in print and online.

images.alt_text: The Benioffs say they won't be involved in day-to-day operations or journalistic decisions. They also plan to keep Time's current leadership team in charge.

site_title: A limping WTO affects small countries like Singapore
summary: The World Trade Organization (WTO) is in crisis due to the US blocking the reappointment of several judges, including Mauritius' Shree Baboo Chekitan Servansing, to its Appellate Body. This will leave the body with only three or two members, rendering it unable to function. The consequences will be dire, particularly for small countries like Singapore, which heavily relies on free and open trade. The WTO's paralysis will disrupt global trade, posing a significant threat to the entire global economy, and leaving countries with little recourse in case of trade disputes.

site_title: Non-oil exports grow at slower but forecast-beating 5% in August
summary: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports (NODX) grew 5% in August, beating forecasts of 3.9%, according to Enterprise Singapore data. Non-electronic NODX led the growth, driven by the pharmaceutical sector. This marks a reversal from July's 11% expansion. The data suggests a slowdown in NODX growth, but still indicates a resilient Singaporean economy.

site_title: Brexit: countdown to March 2019
summary: The UK is set to leave the European Union at the end of March 2019, marking a significant event in European history. Despite being a tiny blip, Brexit has been debated for 18 months with no solution in sight. The UK's position has been characterized as intransigent, while the EU has suggested a "Canada Plus" deal that seems to be the desired outcome. The Irish Problem, a historic issue stemming from the UK's partition of Ireland, remains a major obstacle to a deal, with both sides rejecting a "soft" border solution and instead favoring customs regulations.

site_title: US aims to start LNG deliveries to Germany in four years: Bild
summary: US energy secretary Dan Brouillette has stated that US companies expect to start delivering liquefied natural gas (LNG) to Germany in four years, potentially challenging Russia's dominance in the market. This move aims to diversify Germany's energy sources and set a price ceiling for Gazprom, the Russian state energy company leading the Nord Stream 2 pipeline. US President Donald Trump previously urged Germany to halt the pipeline project, but Germany remains open to diversifying its energy sources on economic grounds. Qatar is also interested in selling LNG to Germany.

site_title: Singapore-listed equity offerings strongest since 2014
summary: Singapore-listed equity offerings reached a 6.1% increase in proceeds compared to the first nine months of 2017, driven by follow-on offerings that raised US$3.3 billion, the strongest first nine-month period since 2014. Real estate accounted for 67% of the amount raised, followed by media and entertainment. The number of equity capital market issuances increased by 33.3% from a year ago, but declined in the third quarter of 2018.

site_title: Opec committed to supply deal as demand faces headwinds
summary: Opec secretary-general Mohammad Barkindo stated that the historic supply deal between Saudi Arabia, Russia, and other producers needs to become permanent to manage global supplies amid "headwinds" in demand. Crude prices are averaging around $72 a barrel, and the IEA warned that prices could rise above $80 a barrel unless producers make up for lost supply. A committee of Opec members and allied producers will meet next week to review compliance with production targets. The deal aims to maintain stability in markets, which are threatened by low crude prices and investment.

site_title: Hilton splashes into the Caribbean with all-inclusive resort deal
summary: Hilton Worldwide Holdings Inc has announced an alliance with Playa Hotels & Resorts NV to convert two Caribbean hotels into Hiltons and team up on eight additional resorts by 2025. The deal aims to expand Hilton's all-inclusive resort portfolio, currently consisting of 11 properties. The move follows the growing popularity of all-inclusive resorts, which generated $3.8 billion in revenue in the Caribbean region in 2017. The partnership seeks to reduce commissions and gain access to millions of loyalty members, with Playa spending up to $54 million upgrading the two converted properties.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Keppel O&M and Gaztransport & Technigaz (GTT) have partnered to jointly market liquefied natural gas (LNG) solutions, offering LNG systems for designing and building LNG carriers, vessels, and storage units. Meanwhile, NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed, and Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall. London's Heathrow is considering higher fees for a £10 billion upgrade, while Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a graft case. Singapore's stock market saw a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, with OCBC's incoming CEO Tan Teck Long set to take office.

site_title: New academy to send Singapore students overseas for internship at startups
summary: Singapore has launched the Global Innovation Alliance Innovators Academy to send over 1,300 students abroad for internships at startups or companies in 17 cities. The academy aims to groom future innovators with a global view. Additionally, the National Research Foundation has developed the National Quantum Engineering Programme to translate quantum science into industry-ready solutions, with a S$25 million budget. This move is part of Singapore's efforts to cultivate strong international networks and act as a springboard for regional enterprises.

site_title: Omni United: Treading in the right direction
summary: Gajendra Singh Sareen, founder and CEO of Omni United, emphasizes the importance of a customer-centric approach and solving real-world problems in business. Unlike many entrepreneurs who start businesses for fame and fortune, Sareen believes that success comes from doing the right things for the right reasons. His company, which designs, manufactures, and distributes high-quality and affordable tyres, aims to provide a reliable supply chain to global partner retailers. Sareen hopes to educate aspiring entrepreneurs that there are no shortcuts in business and that success will follow naturally.

site_title: US: S&P, Dow open flat, Nasdaq drops
summary: The S&P 500 and Dow Jones Industrial Average opened flat on Monday, while the Nasdaq dropped as shares of Apple and chipmakers fell due to fears of new US tariffs on Chinese goods. The Dow Jones fell 3.01 points, the S&P 500 opened 1.15 points lower, and the Nasdaq dropped 17.83 points.

site_title: Maersk says customers to pay for $2 billion-a-year fuel hike
summary: AP Moller-Maersk, the world's largest container shipping line, will start charging customers for fuel from 2020, with prices expected to surge due to tougher environmental standards. The company expects a $2 billion annual fuel hike, with an estimated extra fuel bill of $15 billion for container shipping lines. The move is seen as a game-changer for the shipping industry, with potential implications for global trade.

images.alt_text: AP Moller-Maersk A/S, the world's largest container shipping line, said Monday that customers using its giant box ships will have to pay separately for fuel from 2020, when prices are expected to surge because of tougher environmental standards.

site_title: Singapore shares close 0.6% down on Monday
summary: Singapore stocks closed 0.6% lower on Monday, with the Straits Times Index falling 20.02 points to 3,141.40. The decline was led by financials, with DBS, OCBC Bank, and UOB falling 0.24%, 1.07%, and 1.33% respectively. Losers outnumbered gainers 243 to 145, with Rex International being the top gainer, up 10.1% to 10.9 Singapore cents.

site_title: Och-Ziff to seek US$2 billion for its biggest real estate fund
summary: Och-Ziff Capital Management Group is seeking US$2 billion for its fourth real estate fund, targeting opportunistic property investments. The firm, led by billionaire Dan Och, has also raised US$750 million for a real estate debt strategy and US$150 million for an affordable-housing investment pool. This move comes after a period of change for the firm, including new leadership. Och-Ziff plans to raise the funds by the end of the year.

site_title: Trump's top court nominee agrees to talk to Senate Judiciary Committee about sex accusations
summary: Judge Brett Kavanaugh, President Trump's Supreme Court nominee, has agreed to discuss allegations of sexual assault by his high school classmate Christine Blasey Ford. Ford, Kavanaugh's accuser, is also willing to testify before Congress. Kavanaugh has denied the allegations, stating they "never happened" and he had "no idea" who made the accusation. The Senate Judiciary Committee will now schedule a hearing to discuss the allegations.

site_title: Coca-Cola is eyeing the cannabis market
summary: Coca-Cola is exploring the cannabis market, particularly CBD-infused drinks, as traditional sales slow. The Atlanta-based company is in talks with Canadian marijuana producer Aurora Cannabis to develop beverages, with no decisions made at this time. This move comes as other beverage makers, such as Corona beer brewer Constellation Brands and Heineken's Lagunitas, also enter the market. Aurora's shares surged 23% on the news, while other cannabis stocks also saw gains.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore launched the world's first unified payment QR code, the Singapore Quick Response Code (SGQR), to simplify mobile payments. Non-oil exports grew 5% in August, beating forecasts, while private home sales fell 64% in August due to cooling measures and the Hungry Ghost Festival. Fintech firms will gain access to Singapore's real-time payment system. Singapore-listed equity offerings rose 6.1% year-to-date, and shares closed 0.6% lower on Monday.

site_title: SGX leads latest US$44.4m, Series C funding round for online freight platform Freightos
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has completed a US$44.4 million, Series C funding round for Freightos, the world's largest online marketplace for sea freight rates. Existing investors, including General Electric Ventures and ICV, joined SGX in the funding round. Freightos aims to transform the international shipping industry into one with transparent rates and capacity, leveraging data points and logistics providers. The company plans to develop financial instruments and risk management tools with SGX, building on Singapore's unique position in the trade ecosystem.

site_title: Denmark to tighten money-laundering laws amid Danske Bank scandal
summary: Denmark plans to tighten its anti-money laundering laws amid the Danske Bank scandal, with increased financial penalties of up to 700% to be introduced. The move comes as a response to past failings in controlling money laundering in Estonia. A new anti-money laundering strategy is being negotiated, and the rules are expected to be presented on Wednesday. The new regulations will likely not apply to Danske Bank's past alleged breaches but will serve as a deterrent for future cases, aiming to signal the country's seriousness in tackling money laundering.

site_title: Asian currencies fall on fear of wider US-China trade war
summary: Asian currencies, including the Indian rupee and Indonesian rupiah, plummeted on concerns of a widening US-China trade war, potentially escalating a global trade war. The US is expected to announce tariffs on Chinese imports, prompting China to retaliate, and investors are seeking refuge in the dollar. The Indian rupee fell 1.1% and the Indonesian rupiah dropped 0.5% as domestic factors and rising interest rates also contributed to the decline.

site_title: Jho Low proclaims his innocence on new website
summary: Jho Low, accused of looting billions from 1MDB, has proclaimed his innocence on a new website. The 36-year-old, wanted in Malaysia and Singapore, claims he is innocent despite being described by US prosecutors as orchestrating the theft of $4.5 billion. Low, whose whereabouts are unknown, describes himself as a "global philanthropist, investor and entrepreneur" and calls on courts and prosecutors to keep an open mind until all evidence comes to light. He has been charged in absentia in Malaysia with money laundering and has faced public backlash.

site_title: DBS appoints receiver for Triyards unit
summary: DBS Bank has appointed a receiver, Justin Lim Loo Khoon of Deloitte & Touche, for Strategic Marine (S) Pte Ltd, a subsidiary of Ezra Holdings' yard operating arm Triyards. The appointment comes after DBS received letters of demand for claims of about US$43.9 million from Triyards. DBS has 10 charges against Strategic Marine, which has been suspended from trading since September 2017.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed higher on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 11.16 points to 1,803.76. The market saw 589 gainers and 302 losers, with a total volume of 2.683 billion lots worth RM2.483 billion.

site_title: Germany plans tax incentives to encourage housing construction
summary: Germany plans to introduce tax incentives to encourage private developers to build new rental flats, aiming to tackle the country's housing shortage. The plan, set to be approved by the cabinet, will let investors reduce their tax bills by deducting nearly a third of construction costs over four years. The measure is expected to cost the state around 235 million euros annually, with a focus on affordable flats with construction costs below 3,000 euros per square meter. The plan aims to support the construction of 10-year-rental flats, benefiting companies such as Vonovia and Deutsche Wohnen.

site_title: Singapore-listed equity offerings up 6.1% year-to-date, strongest since 2014
summary: Singapore-listed equity offerings have increased by 6.1% year-to-date, the strongest since 2014, with total proceeds reaching US$3.8 billion. This is driven by a 130.3% increase in follow-on offerings to US$3.3 billion, while initial public offerings (IPOs) raised US$518.1 million, down 75.9% from the previous year. Real estate accounted for 67% of the market share, followed by media and entertainment.

site_title: Abu Dhabi to sell over 25% of Spain's Cepsa
summary: Abu Dhabi's sovereign wealth fund, IPIC, is planning to sell over 25% of Spain's Cepsa energy company to the public through a listing on the Madrid stock exchange by the end of 2018. The deal is valued at around 10 billion euros, making it the largest listing on the Madrid stock exchange in a decade. Cepsa has been wholly owned by IPIC since 2011, and the sale is expected to provide wider access to capital markets for the company. The move is seen as a strategic partnership between Abu Dhabi and Spain.

site_title: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding sets up JV company with Mitsui & Co
summary: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding has established a joint venture company with Mitsui & Co in the Republic of Panama, with an initial registered share capital of US$13.2 million. Both companies hold a 50-50 stake in the venture. The move aims to leverage Mitsui's access to ship-owners and Yangzijiang's experience in ship-owning and vessel sales. The joint venture will deliver high-quality and performance vessels to global customers.

site_title: Sapphire Corporation secures 436m renminbi contract
summary: Sapphire Corporation secured a 436 million renminbi (S$87.2 million) contract to build a subway station and intervals in Hangzhou, China. The 22-month project will be completed in phases, with revenue recognized based on progressive completion. The contract brings Sapphire's order book to 2.9 billion renminbi, expected to positively impact the group's financial performance. The company's CEO, Wang Heng, attributed the win to Sapphire's experience in designing and constructing large-scale infrastructure assets in China.

site_title: Hongkongers battle debris to get to work after devastating typhoon
summary: Hong Kong struggled to recover from a devastating typhoon, with commuters battling debris to reach work. The city's rail system was severely impacted, and all buses were cancelled due to blocked roads. Residents resorted to climbing over broken branches and train tracks to reach their jobs. Despite the challenges, many residents were frustrated that city leader Carrie Lam did not announce an official day off for workers. Over 300 people were injured, but no fatalities were reported. Cleanup efforts continued, with residents and workers working to clear paths and repair damaged buildings.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks, won end lower on new round of US tariff threat
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index and currency closed weaker on Monday amid US President Donald Trump's threat of new tariffs on Chinese imports, despite a similar market reaction to the previous June imposition of tariffs. The KOSPI ended down 0.66% and the won lost 0.89% to 1,126.6 per dollar, its biggest percentage loss since August 10.

site_title: After disastrous 2017, French winemakers cheer 'incredible' 2018 vintage
summary: French winemakers are celebrating an "incredible" 2018 vintage, following a disastrous 2017 season marred by frosts, hailstorms, and scorching heat. The year's dry and sunny summer conditions resulted in high-quality grapes, with many regions producing above-average vintages. Alsace, Bordeaux, Burgundy, Champagne, Loire Valley, Rhône Valley, and Provence are all reporting excellent harvests, with quantities rebounding 25% over 2017. Prices are expected to remain high due to the region's prestige. Overall, the 2018 vintage is seen as a welcome rebound for the French wine industry.

site_title: China won't just play defence in trade war, 'Global Times' warns
summary: China has warned it will not only retaliate with tariffs in a trade war with the US, but also consider other measures such as restricting exports of key goods, in a response to President Trump's expected announcement of new tariffs on $200 billion in Chinese goods. China may decline to participate in proposed trade talks if the US proceeds with the additional tariffs, citing a "gun pointed to its head" negotiating position. China's Vice-Premier Liu He is invited for talks, but skepticism remains.

site_title: OPEC sees need to keep oil supply deal as demand faces headwinds
summary: OPEC's secretary-general, Mohammad Barkindo, emphasized the need to maintain a historic supply deal between OPEC and non-OPEC producers to manage global oil supplies. Demand for crude is "robust," but faces "headwinds," and Barkindo believes institutionalizing the cooperation is the only viable alternative to maintaining market stability. The deal, which was reached in 2016, needs to become permanent to ensure continued investment in the oil industry.

site_title: UK economy will shrink without Brexit deal, IMF warns
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has warned that the UK economy will shrink if it leaves the European Union without a Brexit deal. The Fund predicts Britain's economy will grow by 1.5% a year in 2018 and 2019, lagging behind Germany and France, if a broad Brexit agreement is struck. IMF Managing Director Christine Lagarde expressed hope for a deal between the EU and UK, calling herself a "desperate optimist." The warning challenges Brexit supporters' promises and highlights the potential economic risks of a no-deal Brexit.

images.alt_text: "I'm a desperate optimist, and I very much hope and pray that there will be a deal between the European Union and the UK," IMF Managing Director Christine Lagarde said.

site_title: Pay more for your clothes, Bangladesh workers tell global fashion brands
summary: Garment workers in Bangladesh rejected the country's 50% minimum wage increase to 8,000 taka ($130.3) per month, citing it is still insufficient to live on. They are demanding 16,000 takas and threatening an indefinite strike. The workers, who are among the world's worst-paid, work long hours and face poor health conditions. Global fashion brands are urged to pay more for their clothes, following a string of fatal factory accidents in 2013. The Bangladesh garment industry employs an estimated 4 million people, 80% of whom are women.

images.alt_text: Garment workers in Bangladesh have rejected an increase in the minimum wage, saying it is still not enough to live on and urging global brands to pay more for the clothes they buy, unions said on Monday.

site_title: Europe: Prospect of new wave of tariffs dents stocks
summary: European stocks fell 0.2% as reports suggested US President Trump may announce new tariffs on $200 billion of Chinese imports, sparking concerns over a fresh trade war. Trade-sensitive autos and mining stocks were particularly hard hit, with autos tumbling 0.9% and miners falling 0.6%. This latest development added to the uncertainty, sapping risk appetite and denting the pan-European STOXX 600 index.

site_title: Ipco Int'l gets more time to hold AGM
summary: Ipco International, a Singapore-based company, has been granted more time to hold its annual general meeting (AGM) by the Singapore Exchange (SGX), with the deadline now set for October 30. The company requires additional time to complete a review of its financial and operational positions, including addressing questions raised by new independent directors. Ipco's shares closed 33.3% lower on Monday due to concerns over financial figures and a S$266,000 loan allegedly advanced by the company's former CEO. The audited accounts for the full year have not been completed, and some figures may need to be restated.

site_title: China's pig fever outbreak a boon for chicken farmers
summary: China's African swine fever outbreak is driving up prices of chicken to two-and-a-half year highs due to pork shortages and safety concerns. The surge in demand is a boon for chicken farmers, who have experienced tepid demand growth in recent years. The increased chicken prices are expected to benefit the world's top poultry producer.

site_title: Saudi Arabia's sovereign wealth fund raises US$11 billion loan
summary: Saudi Arabia's sovereign wealth fund, the Public Investment Fund (PIF), has raised a $11 billion loan, its first-ever borrowing. The loan is larger than initially planned, establishing a core banking group to work on future deals. Managing director Yasir Al-Rumayyan stated that this marks the first step in incorporating loans and debt instruments into the PIF's long-term funding strategy.

site_title: China to speed up efforts to cut solar, wind subsidies - draft guidelines
summary: China has released draft guidelines to speed up efforts to phase out subsidies for wind and solar power sectors, aiming to achieve "grid price parity" with traditional energy sources. The guidelines encourage regions to provide technological and policy support to ensure subsidy-free operations. Solar power generation costs have fallen 90% since 2007, and experts predict grid price parity could be achieved within a year. The move aims to ease dependence on polluting fossil fuels and reduce the state's subsidy burden.

site_title: South Africa's AfriAg seeks UK medical cannabis producer license
summary: AfriAg Global Plc, a South African haulier, is seeking a UK medical cannabis producer license. The company has hired a law firm to assist with the application process, which is considered "highly regulated." This move follows the UK's decision to allow doctors to prescribe medicinal cannabis, starting this year, and comes as evidence grows of the treatment's effectiveness in conditions such as epilepsy and chronic pain. AfriAg sees an opportunity to increase its global market presence in the fast-growing sector.

images.alt_text: AfriAg Global Plc has hired a law firm to help with the application process to become a licensed medical cannabis cultivator and producer in the UK, the South African haulier said on Monday.

site_title: Australia bank shares' gains offset slump in aged-care providers; NZ flat
summary: Australian shares rose 0.3% on Monday, driven by gains in financials, offsetting a decline in healthcare stocks. The S&P/ASX 200 index rose to 6,185.00, with banks leading the gains. The news of a public inquiry into the aged-care system weighed on healthcare stocks. In contrast, New Zealand shares remained flat.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks sink more than one per cent
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell more than one percent on Monday, with the Hang Seng Index retreating 1.30% to 26,932.85, following reports that US President Donald Trump is planning to impose tariffs on another $200 billion of Chinese imports. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also declined, falling 1.11% and 1.54% respectively. The decline was attributed to Trump's latest trade threats, which have sparked concerns about the impact on global markets.

site_title: UK PM May cautions: The alternative to my Brexit deal is no deal
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May has warned that the alternative to her potential Brexit deal with the EU is a no-deal scenario. The UK is set to leave the EU on March 29, with little clarity on a full exit agreement. The main sticking point is ensuring a hard border between Northern Ireland and the Irish Republic. The EU is working on a new protocol text to minimize checks using technology, such as barcodes on shipping containers. May's comments come as the Conservative Party conference is set to begin on September 30.

site_title: One of China's wildest housing markets Is broken
summary: China's housing market in Hainan Island has cooled after a rapid price surge. New home prices rose 21% in August from the same period last year, but transactions have plummeted and month-on-month gains have moderated. The government's restrictions, including lengthy residency requirements and high down payments, have effectively ring-fenced the island from speculative money. Experts say the market is "on hold" and prices may be distorted due to government caps on developers' prices. The government's controls have also diminished market forces in pricing and sales, a concern for the housing sector.

site_title: Philippine paddy rice losses from typhoon exceed forecasts
summary: The Philippines has lost 250,730 tonnes of paddy rice due to Typhoon Mangkhut, exceeding initial forecasts by 60%. The typhoon has caused 11-12 billion pesos ($243-291 million) in agricultural damage. The country, a major rice importer, had planned to import additional rice this year and may import corn to fill a possible shortfall. Despite the losses, the country's rice crop losses are not expected to significantly impact prices, as there are still enough stocks in affected regions and the harvest season in other areas has begun.

site_title: Singapore launches unified payment QR code, said to be world's first
summary: Singapore has launched the world's first unified payment QR code, known as the Singapore Quick Response Code (SGQR). The code combines multiple payment QR codes into a single label, simplifying mobile payments for consumers and merchants. Adopted by 27 payment schemes, SGQR will be deployed over the next six months, replacing existing QR codes with a single label, reducing clutter on storefronts and streamlining payment processing.

site_title: Keeping up with Indonesia: Opportunities, misconceptions and challenges
summary: Indonesia's economy is one of the fastest-growing in Asia, averaging 5% annual GDP growth since 2000.
