site_title: IMF officials in Argentina for crisis loan talks
summary: IMF officials are in Argentina for crisis loan talks to strengthen and accelerate a $50 billion rescue lending programme. Argentina has received $15 billion so far, but seeks faster disbursement. Any changes will require IMF board approval. The talks come as Argentina faces economic crisis, while other global news includes UK economy shrinking for second month, and South Korea's trade chief seeking a 'landing zone' in US trade talks.

images.alt_text: Officials from the International Monetary Fund are in Argentina as part of talks to strengthen and accelerate a crisis loan package, the global lender said Wednesday.

site_title: After months of tensions, US and Germany talk trade
summary: US President Donald Trump's economic advisor Larry Kudlow met with German Chancellor Angela Merkel's counterpart Lars-Hendrik Roller at the White House, aiming to deepen bilateral economic and trade relations. The talks followed strained relations between the US and Germany over trade, with the threat of tariffs on European cars a key issue. The meeting was seen as a follow-up to a July meeting between Trump and European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker, which was hailed as a breakthrough. Few details were released about the agenda, but both sides agreed to enhance economic growth and market access.

site_title: Aspial invites noteholders to sell or exchange 2018, 2019 notes
summary: ASPIAL Corporation is inviting holders of its 2018 and 2019 notes to either sell or exchange them for new notes. The company plans to use cash from its real estate business to buy existing notes before their maturity dates, improving its debt position and reducing negative carry. Noteholders can sell notes for an early exit fee of 0.1% of the principal or exchange them for new notes with a 6.25% interest rate, payable semi-annually, with a one-time fee of 0.5% for those who exchange by the deadline.

site_title: Centennial falling granite: Owner wins suit against designer, sub-con
summary: Millenia Pte Ltd, owner of Centennial Tower, has won a lawsuit against Dragages Singapore and Builders Shop over the building's granite cladding. A court ruled that the cladding was structurally unsafe due to improper installation, defective materials, and deviation from agreed-upon rectification methods. The company is entitled to damages and recladding costs, which will be determined in the next proceeding. The high court judge found that corners were cut and workmanship was poor, leading to a series of defects and incidents, including a 2011 granite panel falling from the 35-storey skyscraper.

site_title: Trump authorises sanctions for foreign election meddling
summary: President Donald Trump signed an executive order authorizing punitive sanctions on foreigners who interfere in US elections, following Russia's alleged meddling in his 2016 campaign. The order sets up a formal process to impose financial penalties and blocks on actors seen trying to hack into voting systems and spread disinformation. Director of National Intelligence Dan Coats said signs of foreign interference have been seen in the 2016 election and promised round-the-clock monitoring. The move comes as the US intelligence chiefs have long warned of a concerted effort by Russia, China, and potentially Iran and North Korea to interfere in US elections.

site_title: Getting bullish on central kitchens and offices
summary: Singapore's central kitchens and offices are expected to see increased investment activity, driven by demand from the food and beverage sector. Central kitchens, which prepare and cook food for various establishments, are already an established market with 68% of surveyed companies operating standalone facilities. The growing number of F&B businesses and increasing space allocation in malls will fuel demand for central kitchens, with rental rates ranging from $2.70 to $3.50 per square foot. Meanwhile, office space is also expected to drive investment sales, with nearly 800,000 square feet of Grade A CBD office space set to be completed this year, leading to higher rents and steady momentum for office investments.

site_title: Malaysia's market recovery augurs well for investors
summary: Malaysia's residential property market has experienced a slowdown since 2012, with five consecutive years of declining sales volume. However, property prices have continued to rise, with Johor showing a 9.8% compounded annual growth rate from 2006 to Q1 2018. The market is expected to remain subdued, but opportunities for homebuyers and investors remain, particularly in the secondary market where value-buy properties are available. Developers are offering incentives, such as cash rebates and freebies, to attract buyers.

site_title: Europe: Stocks shrug off trade worries as oil stocks rally
summary: European shares rose 0.5% on Wednesday as oil and mining stocks rallied, shrugging off trade tensions between the US and China. Oil stocks rose 1.6% after Brent prices reached $80 a barrel, while mining shares climbed 1.3%. Key gains included Dutch biotech firm Galapagos, Inditex, Salvatore Ferragamo, and Hermes. However, British energy provider SSE fell 8.3% after warning of a halved profit margin. Analysts predict a slowdown or reversal of the sell-off, citing risk priced in at this stage.

site_title: Communal appeal of co-living
summary: Singapore's co-living market has seen significant growth, with millions of dollars in funding pouring in over the past year. The concept, which originated in the West as shared living spaces, has gained popularity among young expatriates as a convenient and affordable accommodation option. Co-living operators offer private spaces in shared apartments with common areas for community activity, and many have adopted a business model similar to hotels and serviced apartments. Despite this, the market remains untapped for locals, who prefer to buy homes or rent conventional rooms due to high costs and cultural factors.

site_title: Boeing's 737 production rebounds as it extends lead over Airbus
summary: Boeing's 737 production has rebounded, delivering 48 single-aisle aircraft in August, extending its lead over Airbus for new orders. Boeing's 2018 net orders total 581 aircraft through August, up from 487 in July. Airbus posted 219 net orders for January to August, including five in August, but some orders remain unconfirmed. The gap raises questions over a landmark order for 34 extra A330neo wide-body aircraft from AirAsia, which was seen as key to shoring up the slow-selling model.

site_title: Late Saudi king's widow allowed to keep London mansion
summary: A London judge has rejected a lawsuit filed by the Asturion Foundation, which manages the global assets of the Fahd bin Abdulaziz family, over ownership of a mansion in the affluent Highgate neighborhood. The foundation claimed the ownership of Kenstead Hall was unlawfully transferred to King Fahd's widow, Al Jawharah bint Ibrahim Abdulaziz Al Ibrahim, in 2011. The judge struck out the claim, citing the foundation's failure to deal constructively with requests for information about its assets. The widow is allowed to keep the mansion.

site_title: The Internet of Things and its possibilities
summary: The Internet of Things (IoT) is connecting the physical and digital worlds, transforming businesses with valuable data insights. IoT solutions are being strategically deployed in various sectors, including manufacturing, logistics, and healthcare, to drive business transformation and growth. However, the risks of data breaches and security threats must be carefully considered, with effective risk management being integral to IoT deployments. Organizations must assess their IoT strategy, identifying areas of value creation and potential risks, to maximize the benefits of IoT technologies.

site_title: Trade war with US may cost China at least 700,000 jobs: JPMorgan
summary: A JPMorgan study predicts a trade war with the US may cost China at least 700,000 jobs, with 3 million potential job losses if no retaliation occurs. The study also warns that a 25% US tariff on Chinese exports and China's retaliatory measures could cut China's GDP growth by 1.3 percentage points, resulting in 5.5 million lost jobs. A cheaper yuan could mitigate the effects, but would also lead to significant capital outflows.

site_title: ECB to stay on course to curb stimulus even with wobbly growth
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is expected to keep its policy unchanged, despite a slowdown in economic growth and weak data, to curb stimulus. The bank is likely to halve bond purchases to 15 billion euros a month and keep interest rates at record lows until next summer. ECB President Mario Draghi is expected to emphasize that solid growth can absorb spare capacity and generate inflation, aiming to convey confidence amidst uncertainty. The ECB will end quantitative easing at the end of the year, and its quarterly economic projections will be unveiled during Draghi's news conference.

site_title: Brent reaches US$80 a barrel after fall in US crude stocks
summary: Oil prices surged on Wednesday, with Brent reaching a 6-month high of $80 a barrel, amid a larger-than-expected drop in US crude inventories and growing concerns over global oil supply due to US sanctions on Iran. US crude inventories fell by 5.3 million barrels, while global benchmark Brent crude futures rose 68 cents to settle at $79.74 a barrel. The US Energy Information Administration's surprise drop in inventories and supply concerns over Iran sanctions pushed prices higher, with US West Texas Intermediate crude futures rising to a one-week high of $70.37 a barrel.

site_title: STI rises 0.47%, ends losing streak
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.47% to 3,124.65, ending a five-session losing streak, with financials and oil and gas companies leading the gains. OCBC Bank and DBS Group Holdings rose, while Sembcorp Marine and Sembcorp Industries also gained. Meanwhile, Asian markets closed lower, marking the longest sell-off in 16 years, amid concerns over a US-China trade war and a strengthening US dollar.

site_title: Zero-gravity bottle lets tourists sip champagne in space
summary: Designers from Mumm champagne house have created a high-tech bottle for drinking champagne in zero gravity. The bottle, designed by Octave de Gaulle, has two chambers and a valve that uses carbon dioxide to eject foam, which can be scooped out of the air using a specialized glass. Journalists will test the champagne on a zero-gravity flight from Reims, France, with the goal of catering to sub-orbital and orbital space tourism. The experience is expected to be unique, with the champagne landing on the palate and cheeks, amplifying gastronomic sensations.

site_title: Dollar rally plateaus as trade war anxieties continue
summary: The US dollar remained largely unchanged on Wednesday, plateauing after a recent rally, as trade war anxieties between the US and China continued to weigh on markets. The euro slipped 0.1% against the dollar, while the Canadian dollar gained after Ottawa offered limited access to the Canadian dairy market as a concession in trade negotiations. Emerging market currencies, including the Australian dollar and Indian rupee, fell, giving the dollar a boost and exacerbating financial conditions in emerging markets.

site_title: Big dreams for tiny houses
summary: Singaporean entrepreneur Adrian Chia founded Big Tiny, the first company in Singapore to integrate tiny houses with eco-tourism, in March 2017. The company offers handcrafted, compact homes on wheels in scenic rural settings, available for rent in Australian cities for around S$250 a night. Big Tiny aims to simplify living by pairing efficient homes with nature, and has expanded its operations to include a factory in Malaysia and plans to take the company public in the next five years.

site_title: Online firms may face EU fine if extremist posts stay up for over an hour
summary: The European Union's chief executive, Jean-Claude Juncker, proposed fining Google, Facebook, Twitter, and other online platforms up to 4% of their annual global turnover if they fail to remove extremist content within one hour. The proposal, which requires EU countries and the European Parliament's backing, also demands internet platforms develop tools to weed out abuse and human oversight of content. Internet firms have three months to show they are acting faster to take down radical posts, and service providers will need to provide annual transparency reports.

site_title: Gay sex ruling to free India's 'pink economy'
summary: India's Supreme Court ruling legalizing homosexuality is expected to boost the country's economy, known as the "pink economy," by billions of dollars. With over 55 million LGBT adults, representing a nominal income of $113 billion annually, businesses are lining up to cater to the community. The ruling is predicted to increase employment and sales in industries such as food and alcohol, as well as provide new opportunities for holidays and services. The move is expected to unlock a significant market, with estimates suggesting a boost of up to 1.7% to India's economic growth annually.

site_title: Singapore condo rents fall 0.1% in August from July; HDB rents rise 0.1%: SRX
summary: Singapore condo rents fell 0.1% in August from July, according to SRX Property, while HDB rents rose 0.1% from July. This marks the first time condo rents have decreased since May. HDB rents have continued their upward trajectory since July. The overall price index for non-landed private residential rentals decreased 0.1% month-on-month, while private rents year-over-year remained unchanged from August 2017.

site_title: Hard Brexit may cost thousands of jobs, warns Jaguar boss
summary: Jaguar Land Rover CEO Ralf Speth warns a bad Brexit deal could put tens of thousands of UK jobs at risk, costing the company over £1.2 billion a year. The company, which employs over 40,000 people, faces uncertainty due to the UK's departure from the EU's single market. Delays could cost £60 million a day, with Speth stating that decisions are being made now that won't be reversed.

images.alt_text: Mr Speth has flagged the uncertainty faced by carmakers as the clock ticks down to Brexit, scheduled for March 29.

site_title: Buyer cuts purchase of SingHaiyi's San Jose condo units from 141 to 34
summary: A buyer has cut its purchase of SingHaiyi's San Jose condo units from 141 to 34 after failing to close the escrow on time. The buyer had initially signed a deal for US$95.3 million, but the parties agreed to a new deal worth US$23.1 million. SingHaiyi will retain US$1.5 million of the original deposit as a credit. The sale's completion is expected by November 12, 2018.

site_title: Plan B: Hitting the sweet spot in response to curbs
summary: The Singapore government introduced fresh cooling measures in July 2018 to curb the private residential sector's euphoria, with a focus on the Outside Central Region (OCR). New homes in OCR have shrunk to around S$1m. Developers must build and sell all units within five years of site purchase, with a clawback of the 15-percentage points increase in the additional buyer's stamp duty (ABSD). Despite this, the potential supply of 40,000 units could take five years to clear, with 15,000 units expected to be launched over the next six to 12 months.

site_title: How China can respond to a changing US
summary: China should engage in dialogue with the US, despite US criticisms of China's economic and political systems. The US has pursued its goal of promoting democracy and human rights worldwide, but its efforts have not thrown China into chaos. China's economic growth has contributed to global prosperity, and its workers have paid a cost, including job losses and regulatory changes. China will not "decouple" from the US or global economy, and instead, will maintain a constructive cooperation stance. China's reforms, including increased market access and intellectual property protections, can be facilitated by US pressure, and the country will stand firm against US bullying over trade.

site_title: Guardians of our galaxy
summary: Heritage specialists and architects praise iconic Singaporean buildings such as Golden Mile Complex, People's Park Complex, and Pearl Bank Apartments for their visionary architecture and contributions to the urban landscape. A group of passionate conservationists is working to protect these structures from disappearing too soon. These buildings were designed by Singaporean architects, showcasing the country's unique architectural style. Efforts to preserve these heritage sites are crucial for maintaining Singapore's visual character and cultural identity.

site_title: Asean set to seize opportunities from 4th Industrial Revolution: PM Lee
summary: ASEAN is well-positioned to seize opportunities from the Fourth Industrial Revolution, Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong said at the World Economic Forum. The region has taken initiatives such as the Asean Agreement on E-Commerce and the Asean Single Window to benefit businesses and people. Asean has also launched smart city projects, established industrial parks, and is working to strengthen the open multilateral trading system. The completion of the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP) would create the world's largest trading bloc, covering one-third of global GDP.

site_title: ACRA moves service counters to Revenue House
summary: ACRA, Singapore's accounting regulator, has relocated its service counters to Revenue House at 55 Newton Road to serve citizens and businesses better. The move is part of the "One Public Service" initiative, which aims to provide a more integrated service experience. The new service centre offers a range of services, including CorpPass, SME Centre, and IRAS, with self-help kiosks available for customers who wish to access e-services. Businesses are encouraged to book appointments beforehand, and the centre is open from 8am to 5pm, Monday to Friday.

site_title: Gambling on Ronaldo and Madonna made this man a billionaire
summary: A Japanese entrepreneur, Toshiyoshi Matsushita, built his US$2.3 billion company by convincing Cristiano Ronaldo and Madonna to endorse his products, despite initial skepticism from others. Matsushita's unconventional approach paid off, making him a billionaire. The story highlights the power of unconventional marketing strategies in achieving significant success.

site_title: In Tesla's shadow, China's NIO raises US$1b from IPO: sources
summary: NIO, a Chinese electric vehicle startup, priced its shares at US$6.26 per share in its US initial public offering (IPO), valuing the firm at US$6.41 billion. The IPO was below the target price range of US$6.25-US$8.25 due to investor concerns about Tesla's struggles. NIO plans to use the IPO proceeds for research and development, marketing, and manufacturing facilities, and has delivered about 1,600 ES8 electric vehicles. The company aims to expand its production to curb vehicle emissions and promote high-tech industries in China.

site_title: Regulators need to tighten reins on fintechs
summary: Global regulators are under pressure to tighten oversight of fintech firms, which are increasingly staking a claim on financial services in Southeast Asia. Despite the Basel Committee's assessment that fintech firms pose little threat to stability, experts warn of three risks: SME lending by fintech firms could lead to financial instability, cybersecurity risks are present due to the "plug and play" approach to collaboration, and regulatory arbitrage could lead to financial exclusion of vulnerable groups. Regulators must act before it's too late, as fintech firms continue to gain momentum and disrupt traditional banking services.

site_title: Theme raises issue of whether CG is in step with business
summary: The Securities Investors Association (Singapore) is hosting the 9th Singapore Corporate Governance Week 2018, themed "Is Corporate Governance In Step With Business - Help Or Hindrance?", from September 24 to 28. 70 companies have joined the Statement of Support initiative for excellence in corporate governance, pledging to uphold high standards of corporate governance to enhance shareholder value. Companies such as Frasers Property, Koufu Group, NetLink NBN, ST Engineering, and SingPost have expressed their commitment to good corporate governance, citing transparency, accountability, and sustainability as key tenets.

images.alt_text: Voicing their support are (from left) Frasers Property's group CEO Panote Sirivadhanabhakdi, Koufu's executive chairman and CEO Pang Lim and NetLink's CEO Tong Yew Heng.
Voicing their support are (from left) ST Engineering's president & CEO Vincent Chong and SingPost's group CEO Paul Coutts.

site_title: Giving old technology new life
summary: Whizpace, a Singaporean startup, has developed technology that taps unused TV broadcasting airwaves, known as TV white space, to transport data, providing a robust and asset-light wireless network ideal for Smart Nation and IoT applications. The company's devices can reach long distances and penetrate obstacles, making it suitable for applications such as IoT, factories, and agricultural plantations. Whizpace provides low-cost internet access to rural communities and has seen steady revenue growth, with plans to triple revenue and break even by mid-2019.

site_title: Retailers bank on tech for footfalls
summary: Singapore's retail sector continues to face challenges, with subdued footfalls since Q4 2011. Consumers have migrated online, seeking better value and lower prices, leading to increased competition and higher operating costs. To remain competitive, retailers and landlords are repurposing mall spaces, improving the customer experience, and leveraging technology, such as big data analytics, AI, and AR. Hybrid concepts and personalized shopping experiences are gaining traction, with e-commerce platforms like Alibaba and Amazon expanding their physical retail footprints. The retail sector is expected to evolve further, with technology at its core, to provide transformative and curated experiences for consumers.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Nico Steel Holdings terminates up to S$50 million redeemable convertible bonds. CapitaLand Commercial Trust signs one-year lease extension with HSBC, totaling S$27.7 million. Keppel Corporation appoints Jean-François Manzoni as an independent director. ESR-Reit's CFO Shane Hagan resigns. Beauty treatment firm Mary Chia faces "material uncertainty" due to significant losses and cash outflows.

site_title: Househunt September 2018
summary: Key property market developments include a Q3 wave of condo launches in Singapore, testing demand for prime projects above S$3,000 psf, and a rebound in UK homebuyer demand to a six-month high. Manhattan rents reached another record, with more increases anticipated. In the US, mortgage rates rose after five weeks of declines. Meanwhile, Goldman Sachs acquired a hotel and retail portfolio in Seoul and WeWork secured new tenants at its post-bankruptcy office space. New World Group is selling its China property assets after securing a loan deal.

site_title: Low Keng Huat's Q2 earnings soar to S$4.2m
summary: Low Keng Huat's Q2 earnings surged to S$4.2 million, driven by higher profits from development, which more than offset weaker investment revenue. Revenue jumped 472% to S$77.9 million, primarily due to sales from the newly completed Kismis Residences. However, hotel revenue fell due to lower room rates and occupancy. The developer remains cautious, citing subdued residential property market conditions, and plans to be selective in land bidding and investment projects.

site_title: Companies should calculate the costs of data breaches
summary: The global cost of cybercrime has reached $600 billion, or 0.8% of global GDP, with data breaches accounting for the majority of costs. The average cost of a data breach is $3.86 million, with organizations containing breaches within 30 days saving $1 million in total costs. Companies with incident response plans and clear security strategies tend to recover better in the short-term, with a 5% drop in share price post-breach. Organizations should spend 9.8-13.7% of their IT budget on cybersecurity to reduce risks, with some industries and long-term planning requiring higher expenditures.

site_title: The slippery slope of regulating social media
summary: The rise of social media has led to a loss of individual control over online content, with users feeling bombarded by a flood of ideas and opinions. As a result, social media companies are increasingly viewed as a public square, where speech is perceived as a collective good rather than an individual right. This has led to calls for restrictions on speech, both online and off, and has blurred the lines between personal and public space. To combat this, it's essential to return to the original promise of social media, where users have control over what they see and interact with, and social media should work for individuals, not against them.

site_title: The rise and rise of exec condos
summary: Singapore's executive condominium (EC) market continues to face a supply crunch, driving prices to historical highs. Despite recent property curbs, ECs remain attractive among Singaporeans, with 57% year-on-year sales growth in 2016 and 21,248 units of demand outpacing launches from 2012 to H1 2018. The dwindling supply and increasing demand have led to average prices rising 21% year-on-year, with many units selling above S$1 million. Authorities may need to consider releasing more land to moderate prices to a more sustainable level to prevent over-leveraging among buyers.

site_title: Sapura to sell 50% stake in upstream business
summary: Malaysia's Sapura Energy Bhd plans to sell a 50% stake in its upstream business to Austria's OMV for US$1.6 billion. The deal aims to boost Sapura's financial position and pare down debt. Sapura shares rose 4.5% after the announcement, while OMV has a valuation of US$16.9 billion. The partnership is expected to complement Sapura's strategy to grow its portfolio and expand acreage position. The deal is exclusive and based on an enterprise value of US$1.6 billion.

site_title: CSR: core values and business strategies
summary: Businesses can create maximum value in their contribution through strategic Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR) by aligning their CSR strategy with core values and business strategy. Examples of companies achieving this include Intel Vietnam, which created an eco-system in Ho Chi Minh City and improved the city's Customs system, and Swire Pacific Offshore, which supports local talent development and community initiatives. Companies can also measure the value of their CSR programs by evaluating staff engagement and retention rates. By instilling a sense of purpose in employees and creating opportunities for them to create value for the community, businesses can unlock their talent and potential, ultimately creating value for both the company and society.

site_title: Navigating choppy waters
summary: Singapore's property market is experiencing a cooldown following recent cooling measures, with a decrease in private housing transactions and sellers adjusting their price expectations. This shift may lead to more opportunities for buyers, particularly those looking for homes for personal use, as investors become more discerning. However, property investors will need to be more cautious, considering higher additional buyer's stamp duty and loan-to-value limits. The HDB resale market is expected to receive a boost from government announcements, and buyers should be prepared for rising interest rates.

site_title: Asia may need to brace itself for a prolonged trade war threat
summary: Asia faces a prolonged threat from a US-China trade war, driven by US President Donald Trump's tariff threats on Chinese goods. The escalating trade friction could hurt global growth, with experts warning of a 1930s-like full-scale trade war that could lead to cumulative trade losses and a 2-3% reduction in world GDP. Emerging markets, including India, Indonesia, and the Philippines, are particularly vulnerable due to portfolio outflows and currency pressure, while the US dollar has rallied amid the US Federal Reserve's monetary policy tightening.

site_title: Horizon Towers' S$1.1 billion tender sale ends with no takers
summary: The S$1.1 billion tender sale for Horizon Towers, a 211-unit 99-year leasehold development in Singapore, ended without a single bid. The tender was launched in July, coinciding with the government's introduction of property cooling measures, which may have deterred developers. Owners now have 10 weeks to negotiate a private treaty sale, with the collective sale committee considering a potential public tender if no sale is secured.

site_title: Fitch downgrades 4 Turkish banks
summary: Fitch Ratings downgraded four Turkish banks - AnadoluBank, Fibabanka, Sekerbank, and Odeabank - to B+ from BB- due to increased risks after the lira's slump and a higher chance of a "hard landing" for the Turkish economy. The downgrade follows Moody's downgrade of 20 Turkish financial institutions last month. The move reflects increased risks to banks' performance, asset quality, capitalization, liquidity, and funding profiles, and concerns over the Turkish government's monetary policy under President Erdogan.

site_title: 245 public eating places to take 20 e-payment modes in one unified system
summary: Nets, a Singaporean electronic payment network, has been appointed as the master acquirer for a unified e-payment system for coffee shops, hawker centres, and industrial canteens operated by government agencies. The system, launched by Enterprise Singapore, will allow customers to use up to 20 payment schemes, including EZ-Link and mobile payment applications, to purchase meals at participating establishments. This initiative aims to simplify payments and enhance customer convenience in these public eating places.

site_title: New normal for buyers, investors of residences
summary: The Singapore government raised additional buyer's stamp duty rates and lowered loan-to-value limits in July 2018 to cool the property market and keep price increases in line with economic fundamentals. The Urban Redevelopment Authority's private residential property price index rose 9.1% from mid-2017 to mid-2018, but subsequent measures may slow future growth. Investors face a trade-off between lower long-term capital appreciation and easier access to private homes. The market is expected to be controlled and managed, potentially benefiting owner-occupier purchasers, especially first-time buyers, with slower price increases keeping private homes within their affordability limits.

site_title: Airline fuel efficiency improves but lags industry goals - study
summary: Airline fuel efficiency on transatlantic flights has improved by 1% per year since 2014, reaching 34 passenger kilometers per liter of fuel, but still lags industry goals. The industry aims to cap emissions from international flights at 2020 levels, despite rising passenger traffic. A study found that airlines will need to become more efficient to meet industry goals, with Norwegian Air Shuttle ASA ranking first for fuel efficiency and British Airways last. The industry's average fuel efficiency improvement is lower than expected, with the International Air Transport Association (IATA) aiming for 1.5% per year.

site_title: ARA in advanced talks for Manulife Centre
summary: ARA Asset Management is in advanced negotiations to purchase Manulife Centre in Singapore for approximately S$550 million, or around S$2,300 per square foot on net lettable area. The 11-storey commercial building, owned by a 60:40 partnership between Alpha Asia Macro Trends Fund II and City Developments Ltd, has a remaining lease of about 96 years and offers potential for asset enhancement works, including raising NLA and expanding retail space. The sale comes after the exclusive due diligence period with British property group Chelsfield lapsed without a deal.

site_title: London adjusts to higher taxes
summary: London's prime residential property market has adjusted to higher taxes, with prices stabilizing despite ongoing Brexit uncertainty. By June, prime central London prices had fallen 9% from their 2015 peak, but a 9% decline has more than compensated for the increased transaction costs. Demand is picking up, with 31% more new prospective buyers in June compared to the same month last year. Asian buyers are also strengthening demand, accounting for 40% of overseas transactions in prime central London. A general election or EU referendum could potentially end the Brexit deadlock, but the outcome is uncertain.

site_title: Woodlands: Industry's magnetic north
summary: Woodlands, a northern Singapore area, is emerging as a key industrial hub due to government plans, large demographics, and modern industrial space. The North Coast Innovation Corridor and Woodlands North Coast are two significant development proposals that will impact the area's industrial property market. With the North-South Corridor set to be completed by 2026, Woodlands is expected to attract industrialists and enterprises, particularly those with business connections to Malaysia. Transacted industrial property prices and rentals have begun recovering, with median prices increasing by 3.4% to S$397 per square foot and rentals improving by 2.9% to S$1.43 per square foot.

site_title: What powers Australia's residential market
summary: Australia's residential market is experiencing a correction phase, driven by the tightening of credit availability for investors. Detached dwelling markets in cities like Brisbane are expected to outperform apartment markets, which may face a 10-15% price correction. The apartment development cycle has peaked, and high supply levels will be impacted. Population growth and demand from owner-occupiers will support moderate price growth in the house market, while the broader economy is in the early stages of recovery. Interest rates are expected to rise when the Reserve Bank of Australia lifts its official cash rate.

site_title: Asean needs to put pedal to metal on digital integration
summary: Southeast Asia must accelerate digital integration efforts to achieve the Asean Economic Community (AEC) 2025 blueprint. Asean economic ministers have endorsed the Asean Digital Integration Framework, which aims to bring all digital integration initiatives under a single body. Experts recommend harmonizing data privacy, mobile payment, cyber security, and SME banking frameworks. Bain & Co analysts suggest a single body to oversee priorities and ensure progress. Leaders have taken steps on trade, including the Asean Single Window and Self-Certification scheme, but challenges remain, including data localisation and interoperability issues.

site_title: Right time to buy landed property
summary: In Singapore's landed property market, prices are expected to remain resilient despite recent cooling measures. Key districts, such as 19 and 15, remain popular, with District 19 topping the charts for transactions. Landed homes in prime districts tend to hold their value better than non-landed homes, with some freehold detached properties in District 11 posting high compounded annual growth rates. The rental market for landed homes remains active, with owners cashing out, and buyers can act quickly to find suitable properties at value propositions, particularly in outlying areas.

site_title: Do your homework when venturing overseas
summary: Investors considering overseas property purchases should conduct thorough research to avoid pitfalls. A recent Bloomberg article highlighted the decline in major city house prices due to increasing taxes, tighter borrowing rules, and affordability issues. Key markets to consider for affordable housing investments include South-east Asia, particularly Malaysia, Indonesia, Cambodia, Thailand, and Vietnam. Investors should focus on mass affordable housing priced at 3-5 years of a factory worker's household income, avoiding luxury segments unless employment laws favor expatriate families. Researching local regulations, taxes, and post-investment activities is crucial to securing higher returns and managing risks.

site_title: Condos embrace accents on lifestyle
summary: Singapore's condo market has seen a 9.3% price increase from Q2 2017 to Q2 2018, with suburban areas performing the best. Developers are focusing on lifestyle, sustainability, and connectivity, offering amenities like smart features, lush greenery, and nature trails. The emphasis on green buildings has led to a rise in demand, with 54% of homeowners willing to pay a premium for a Green Mark building. The definition of a good location is shifting to include proximity to park connectors and nature, with demand for well-conceived suburban condominiums remaining resilient despite cooling measures.

site_title: US FDA considering ban on flavored e-cigarettes
summary: The US FDA is considering a ban on flavored e-cigarettes due to an "epidemic" of young people using e-cigarettes, according to Commissioner Scott Gottlieb. The agency plans to revisit its compliance policy and issue more warning letters to companies with deceptive marketing labels. Gottlieb stated that youth nicotine addiction is a major concern, and the FDA aims to prevent a whole new generation from becoming addicted to nicotine.

site_title: Carney joins UK government's back-up plans for Brexit
summary: Mark Carney, the Bank of England's governor, has been extended for a seven-month term as part of the UK's preparations for a potential no-deal Brexit. Chancellor Philip Hammond, who wanted Carney to stay, cited the need for continuity of leadership during a "quite turbulent period" in summer 2019. Carney's tasks could include helping banks and providing monetary support, and his extension aims to calm nerves amidst Brexit chaos. The move has been met with criticism from some lawmakers and economists, who argue it sets a bad precedent.

images.alt_text: Extending Mr Carney's (above) term means the chancellor has one less thing to worry about if the UK crashes out of the EU next March.

site_title: Taking a home loan amid rising interest rates
summary: Homebuyers in Singapore should carefully consider borrowing amounts and mortgage packages before purchasing a property amid rising interest rates. Online tools and credit bureau reports can help assess affordability, and banks have internal credit criteria that impact loan amounts. Home loan pricing packages are based on interest rates referencing a benchmark, and borrowers may need to re-price their loan if rates rise. Reviewing existing mortgages and seeking mortgage specialists can help manage financial commitments, especially when interest rates adjust.

site_title: Multilateralism, though effective, needs constant reform
summary: US President Donald Trump's attacks on multilateralism have sparked a debate about the future of global institutions. The World Trade Organization (WTO) is under threat, with some calling for its destruction, while others propose reforms or a new system of bilateral deals. The need for constant reform is acknowledged, given changes in the world economy and the rise of emerging markets, particularly China. Alternative systems, including a "law of the jungle" approach, a continued multilateral system, or a fragmented multilateralism, are being discussed, but a strongly fragmented system is seen as unable to deliver global public goods and benefits.

site_title: 13 fresh chicken distributors hit with S$26.9m fine
summary: Thirteen fresh chicken distributors in Singapore have been fined a total of S$26.9 million for price-fixing and agreeing not to compete for customers. The distributors, who collectively supply over 90% of fresh chicken products in Singapore, were fined between S$705,939 and S$11.4 million. The Competition and Consumer Commission of Singapore (CCCS) found that the distributors restricted competition in the market, leading to price increases for certain products. The CCCS imposed the high total penalty due to the large industry size, high market shares, and seriousness of the cartel conduct.

site_title: Building a zest for entrepreneurship
summary: The Young Founders School (YFS) hosted its 4th entrepreneurship Bootcamp in Singapore from September 8-9, featuring about 30 students aged 11-17 from public and private secondary schools. Participants developed startup ideas into business pitches, with the winning team, "Action", an app connecting donors and charities, receiving US$1,000. The bootcamp was part of YFS' 15th entrepreneurship bootcamp globally and offered participants the chance to join the Global Mentorship Programme and internship opportunities.

site_title: Dalai Lama says 'Europe belongs to Europeans'
summary: The Dalai Lama stated that "Europe belongs to the Europeans" and emphasized that refugees should return to their native countries to rebuild them. He emphasized the moral responsibility of Europe in helping refugees, but ultimately, they should develop their own country. This statement comes after the far-right populist party Sweden Democrats made gains in the country's general election, which highlighted the growing anti-immigration sentiment in the region. The Dalai Lama's comments were made in Sweden, a country that has taken in a high number of asylum seekers per capita in Europe.

site_title: Del Monte Pacific Q1 bottom line bolstered by one-off gain
summary: Del Monte Pacific reported a net profit of US$3.02 million in Q1 FY19, boosted by a one-off gain of US$6.8 million from purchasing DMFI's loans at a discount. Revenue declined 7.7% year-on-year due to lower sales in the US and exports of processed pineapple products. Without one-off items, the company would have posted a loss. Del Monte expects to post profits in FY19, barring unforeseen circumstances.

site_title: Britain's Lloyds banking group to close 15 branches - spokeswoman
summary: Lloyds Banking Group plans to close 15 branches between January and March 2019, following the recent closure of 380 jobs. The closures aim to adapt to declining branch footfall and growing digital banking usage. Customers will still have access to their banking services through nearby Post Offices. The move has sparked criticism from lawmakers and campaigners, but the bank believes it can minimize job losses through voluntary redundancies.

site_title: ESR-Reit CFO resigns
summary: ESR-Reit's CFO Shane Hagan has resigned to pursue his own interests, stepping down from both CFO and COO roles. Amy Low, financial controller, has been appointed as acting CFO, while Nancy Tan, head of real estate, will oversee all operational and investment matters. Hagan will remain until the end of October to support the transition. The company's units closed at S$0.50, up 1.01% on the day.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Kimly Ltd, a coffee shop chain, has launched a productive coffee shop using automation and digital solutions to improve efficiency. The company is expected to benefit from its acquisition of Asian Story Corp, which will be included in its financials from Q4 FY18, boosting profitability. Analysts maintain a "buy" recommendation for Kimly, citing its cash reserves and potential for larger acquisitions. In contrast, Avi-Tech Electronics' burn-in services business is expected to grow, but its engineering segment may continue to be a drag on profitability in FY19.

site_title: HSBC extends lease with CapitaLand Commercial Trust
summary: HSBC has signed a one-year lease extension with CapitaLand Commercial Trust (CCT) for its 21-storey office tower at 21 Collyer Quay, commencing April 30, 2019. The total rent payable will be S$27.7 million, contributing 4% to CCT's monthly gross rental income. CCT is evaluating options for the property after April 2020, including refurbishment and re-letting, redevelopment, and divestment.

site_title: Ryanair pilots, cabin crew in Germany stage strike
summary: Ryanair pilots and cabin crew in Germany staged a full-day walkout, canceling 150 flights, amid labor talks over pay and terms. The German pilots union, Vereinigung Cockpit, has called for mediation, but disagreements remain over the mediator and pay increases. The airline has offered a deal to address the union's demands, but the union threatens further strikes if management doesn't improve its offer. This strike follows a similar threat from cabin crew unions in other European markets, seeking improved working conditions and local contracts.

site_title: Shophouses: Investing in Singapore's heritage
summary: Singapore's shophouses, a cultural icon reflecting the city-state's multicultural influences, have seen a lucrative market due to their scarcity and heritage value. Total transaction value hit a historical high in Q1 2018, with buyers drawn to their prime locations, unique charm, and potential for F&B, hospitality, or retail use. Ultra-high net worth individuals, family offices, and small businesses invest in shophouses for their future capital appreciation and yield play, with prices remaining stable despite higher additional buyer's stamp duty rates. The market is expected to remain consistent in the next two to three years.

site_title: US: Wall St opens flat as energy gains offset tech losses
summary: The US stock market opened flat on Wednesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 rising slightly, while the Nasdaq Composite fell due to losses in technology stocks. Energy companies' gains helped offset the losses, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average increasing 18.01 points to 25,989.07.

site_title: Indonesia still a draw for startups despite depreciating rupiah
summary: Despite Indonesia's depreciating rupiah, the country remains attractive for startups, with key fundamentals intact. A young population, growing demand for products and services, and cash-flushed firms seeking to deploy capital into startups create a favorable environment. Singapore startups are actively exploring opportunities in Indonesia, with about 30 seeking help from Enterprise Singapore to enter the market. Key areas of interest include e-commerce services, fintech, and logistics. Analysts note that the currency challenge can be mitigated through financial products, and startups can ride out economic cycles by forging strong local partnerships and customizing products to fit the market.

site_title: Fintech venture builder targets Asean consumer finance
summary: Singapore-based venture builder Forum is targeting the trillion-dollar potential in consumer finance in emerging Asia. The firm has built a portfolio of five fintech companies, with three run by co-founders who worked with Forum's CEO, Gregory Krasnov, in building a successful consumer bank in Ukraine. The portfolio companies have shown significant expansion, with two crossing into Ebitda-positive territory, allowing them to go straight to Series B funding. Forum expects the portfolio companies to generate over $10 million in revenue by the end of the year and sees potential for a unicorn startup in three to four years.

site_title: US producer prices post first drop in 1-1/2 years
summary: US producer prices fell 0.1% in August, marking the first drop in 1-1/2 years, as declines in food and trade services offset an increase in energy costs. Despite the surprise weakness, overall inflation remains steady due to a tightening labor market and robust economy. The core PPI, excluding food, energy, and trade services, edged up 0.1% in August, while the personal consumption expenditures price index, excluding food and energy, rose 2.0% in July, hitting the Fed's 2% target for the third time this year.

site_title: HDB resale flats to receive much-needed boost
summary: The Housing and Development Board (HDB) has announced a new Voluntary Early Redevelopment Scheme (VERS), allowing flat owners to vote on the government's offer to buy back flats that are 70 years and older. The scheme aims to provide an alternative for HDB flat owners to monetize their flats before their value reaches zero at the end of 99 years. The expansion of the Lease Buyback Scheme to cover all flat types will also benefit ageing owners, allowing them to raise funds without having to sell their flats. The government's move is expected to provide a much-needed boost to the HDB resale market, which has been lukewarm due to uncertainties over the future of HDB flats.

site_title: Why we don't prepare for the future
summary: The US society is increasingly reliant on crises to drive change, rather than consensus or collective action. This trend is evident in the country's inability to address pressing issues such as poverty, global warming, and federal budget deficits. Politicians often prioritize short-term gains over long-term solutions, creating agendas that exacerbate polarization and stalemate. The author argues that the US political system makes it vulnerable to distant crises, as it fails to anticipate and defuse them, ultimately leading to a loss of control over the future.

site_title: Middle-class income hit an all-time high last year, U.S. Census says
summary: US Census reports that middle-class income reached an all-time high of $61,400 in 2017, with half of households earning more and half less. This marks the first time middle-class incomes exceeded $60,000. Economists have expressed concerns over sluggish wage growth, but Americans are compensating by working longer hours or having another family member find employment, with job openings hitting a record high in July.

site_title: Keppel Corp appoints new ID
summary: Keppel Corp appoints Jean-François Manzoni as an independent director, effective October 1, 2018. Manzoni is President and Nestlé Professor at the International Institute for Management Development in Switzerland, with expertise in leadership, corporate governance, and high-performance organizations. His appointment is seen as valuable to the board as Keppel navigates growth across multiple businesses and jurisdictions.

site_title: UK's top Archbishop rips Into Amazon and 'evil' gig economy
summary: Archbishop of Canterbury Justin Welby criticized Amazon and the gig economy, calling it "evil" and accusing the tech giant of "leeching off" the UK by avoiding taxes. Welby urged businesses to prioritize a just society and encouraged workers to join labor unions. Amazon responded, stating it pays all required taxes and offers comprehensive benefits to its UK employees. Welby's speech was seen as unusually political for a church leader, highlighting the contentious issue of tax avoidance by large US tech companies operating in the UK.

site_title: Brexit rebels pledge loyalty to May after talk of a plot to topple her
summary: British Brexit-supporting lawmakers from Prime Minister Theresa May's party pledged loyalty to her after media reports of a plot to oust her. About 50 lawmakers from the European Research Group met and discussed Mrs May's future, with some expressing dissatisfaction with her proposals for exiting the EU. However, the meeting ended with a show of support for May, with participants rejecting talk of a leadership challenge. The meeting follows May's struggles since losing her party's majority in parliament in 2017, as she attempts to clinch a Brexit deal with the EU.

site_title: London loses top spot to New York in financial survey due to Brexit
summary: New York has surpassed London as the world's most attractive financial centre, according to a survey, due to Brexit uncertainty. London's score fell by eight points, the biggest decline among top contenders, as banks shift jobs to maintain access to Europe's single market. The survey found that around 5,000 roles are expected to be shifted from London or created in the EU by March. Asian competitors, such as Hong Kong, are closing in on London, and the rankings highlight the uncertainty around Brexit's impact on the City of London's finance industry.

site_title: EU lawmakers call for global ban on "killer robots"
summary: The European Union's European Parliament passed a resolution calling for a global ban on "killer robots," or autonomous weapons that select and attack targets without human control. The move aims to preempt their development and use, with 26 governments already demanding a ban at the UN. The resolution, which passed on September 12, 2018, is an effort to address concerns over the potential security risks and humanitarian law violations posed by these weapons. EU lawmakers argue that the power to decide over life and death should remain in human hands, not machines.

site_title: Pope calls meeting of key bishops on sexual abuse - Vatican
summary: Pope Francis has summoned senior bishops from around the world to the Vatican in February to discuss the protection of minors from sexual abuse. This move comes after recent scandals in the US, Chile, and Australia, including a damning Grand Jury report in Pennsylvania that found 301 priests had abused minors over 70 years. The meeting aims to address the fallout from these scandals and other issues, including a scandal involving former American cardinal Theodore McCarrick.

site_title: Sasseur inks partnership with cornerstone investor to boost sales network
summary: Sasseur Reit, a Chinese retail investment trust, has partnered with Secoo Holdings to boost sales channels. The partnership will expand the channels to sell luxury goods in China via an omni-channel network, combining physical and online store presence. The move aims to enhance the shopping experience and solidify revenue growth for Sasseur Reit, with CEO Anthony Ang stating the partnership adds a new dimension to their offline channel and sharpened competitive advantage.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close lower
summary: Tokyo stocks closed lower on Wednesday, with the benchmark Nikkei 225 index losing 0.27% to 22,604.61, and the Topix index falling 0.45% to 1,691.32. This follows a 1.30% gain on Tuesday. The decline is attributed to investors locking in profits after the previous day's rally.

site_title: Fowl play: 13 chicken suppliers fined record S$26.9m for price-fixing, non-compete pacts
summary: Thirteen chicken suppliers in Singapore have been fined a record S$26.9 million for price-fixing and agreeing not to compete for customers, the largest total financial penalty in a single case to date. The distributors, which collectively supply over 90% of fresh chicken products in Singapore, were found to have coordinated price increases and restricted competition for seven years. The Competition and Consumer Commission of Singapore (CCCS) imposed the penalties after a seven-year investigation.

site_title: Auditors flag material uncertainty at beauty treatment firm Mary Chia
summary: Beauty treatment firm Mary Chia faces "material uncertainty" due to a post-tax loss of S$5.56 million and net operating cash outflows of S$1.64 million for fiscal year 2018. Its external auditor, Foo Kon Tan, stated that these factors may cast significant doubt on the company's ability to continue as a going concern. The firm also reported material differences between its unaudited and audited results, primarily due to interest-free loans from the founder.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed 13.92 points lower at 1,785.25 on Wednesday, with 896 losers outpacing 166 gainers. Volume reached 2.2 billion lots worth RM2.8 billion.

site_title: Low Keng Huat Q2 earnings jumps more than eightfold to S$4.2m
summary: Low Keng Huat's Q2 earnings surged 8.5-fold to S$4.2 million, driven by higher profits from its development segment. Revenue jumped 472% to S$77.9 million, mainly due to sales from its Kismis Residences development. However, the hotel segment saw lower revenue due to lower room rates and occupancy. The company plans to be selective in land bidding and investment projects amid a subdued residential property market, aiming to maintain rental rates for renewals.

site_title: Asean in good position to seize opportunities Fourth Industrial Revolution will bring: PM Lee
summary: Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong stated that Asean is well-positioned to seize opportunities from the Fourth Industrial Revolution, citing initiatives such as the Asean Agreement on e-Commerce and the Asean Single Window. He also highlighted the Asean Smart Cities Network and bilateral industrial parks with Vietnam. Lee emphasized the importance of economic integration within Asean to stay connected and create new synergies, particularly in the context of the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP) trade deal.

site_title: Decentralisation to dominate office market in next decade
summary: Singapore's office market is expected to shift towards decentralization over the next decade, driven by a tightening of CBD office supply and rising rents. The CBD Grade A office market will experience a stronger-than-expected recovery post 2022, while decentralised locations such as Punggol Digital District and Labrador Park are seeing increased supply. As land leases for transitional office buildings expire, companies may relocate to new decentralised office projects, boosting demand for these areas. By 2030, it's predicted that prime CBD Grade A office rents will reach S$16 per square foot per month, while decentralised areas will account for nearly 30% of total office stock.

site_title: The biggest name in cannabis is taking a tech venture public
summary: Bruce Linton, co-founder of Canopy Growth Corp, is taking Martello Technologies Group Inc. public through a reverse takeover, beginning trading on the TSX Venture Exchange under the symbol MTLO. Linton, who co-chairs the company, is also co-chairman with Terry Matthews, a tech entrepreneur with a history of founding or funding companies. This move follows Canopy Growth's own successful reverse takeover, making it the world's largest publicly traded cannabis company with a market value of C$14.8 billion.

site_title: 'Pink Dollar' to boost India's economy after gay sex legalized
summary: India's Supreme Court has decriminalized homosexuality, overturning a 158-year-old colonial law that criminalized same-sex relationships. The ruling is expected to boost the country's $2.6 trillion economy by encouraging businesses to be more inclusive of the LGBTQ community. Multinational companies in India and elsewhere have already taken steps to end discrimination in staff benefits, and the ruling is likely to attract more tourists and international investment to the country. The move is also expected to improve the reputation of India's financial capital, Mumbai.

site_title: Saudi King's widow keeps mansion on London's billionaire's row
summary: A UK judge rejected a lawsuit by the Asturion Foundation, which claimed ownership of a £28 million mansion on London's "Billionaires Row" was unlawfully transferred to King Fahd's widow, Al Jawharah bint Ibrahim Al Ibrahim. The lawsuit, filed in 2015, alleged the transfer was made without the foundation's knowledge. The judge found the foundation had failed to deal constructively with requests for information about its assets, leading to the lawsuit being struck out in its entirety. The ruling provides a rare glimpse into an inheritance dispute within the Saudi royal family.

site_title: Singapore retail sales fall 2.6% in July as car sales slump
summary: Singapore's retail sales fell 2.6% in July, the first decline since March, due to a slump in motor vehicle sales. Motor vehicle sales dropped 15.2% year-over-year, while other segments like furniture and household equipment saw a 2.8% increase. Petrol stations saw a 10.1% surge in revenue, but after adjusting for higher pump prices, the increase was just 0.5%. The decline is attributed to market concerns about trade tensions and regional stock market fluctuations.

site_title: Will CCR see clearer skies?
summary: Singapore's new cooling measures, introduced on July 6, 2018, aim to curb the rapid rise in private home prices. The measures include a 5% increase in additional buyer's stamp duty (ABSD) and lower loan-to-value (LTV) limits, primarily affecting luxury and prime residential properties in the Core Central Region (CCR). Despite these measures, the CCR still offers opportunities for buyers, with median prices ranging between S$1.5 million and S$2.4 million for new homes and resale market. Buyers can now be more selective, and property prices are expected to hold up until year-end due to higher land costs and sound economic fundamentals.

images.alt_text: Residential buildings in the Tanglin area as seen from ION Orchard shopping mall in Orchard Road. Buyers can now be more selective as they recalibrate their budgets and study their options in the wake of the 5 percentage point increase on ABSD.

site_title: Singapore remains the top choice for US investments in Asia
summary: US investments in Singapore remained strong, reaching $15 billion in 2017, surpassing China and Japan's combined investments of $107.6 billion and $129.1 billion respectively. Despite uncertainty over US tax policy, foreign investments in the US grew 6.9% to $4,025.5 billion, with Singapore's investments in the US increasing from $82.8 billion to $88.6 billion. The US also saw increases in investments from Japan, South Korea, and other Asia-Pacific countries.

site_title: Singapore shares end higher on Wednesday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 14.74 points, or 0.47%, to 3,124.65 on Wednesday, driven by gains in Rex International and Yangzijiang Shipbuilding. The key stock changed hands 105.7 million shares, while 1.9 billion securities worth S$1 billion were traded. This marks the 5th consecutive day of gains for the index ahead of GDP data release.

site_title: One-off gain lifts Del Monte Pacific Q1 income
summary: Del Monte Pacific earned a net income of US$3.02 million in Q1 FY2019, boosted by a one-off gain of US$6.8 million from purchasing Del Monte Foods Inc's loans at a discount. Excluding one-off items, the company would have reported a loss of US$3.73 million. Turnover declined 7.7% year-on-year to S$437.23 million, mainly due to lower sales in the US and exports of processed pineapple products. The company plans to sell 20% of its stake in Del Monte Philippines through an IPO, which was previously shelved due to market volatility.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: ASEAN is poised to capitalize on opportunities from the Fourth Industrial Revolution, according to Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong. Meanwhile, Singapore's retail sales fell 2.6% in July, ending three months of growth, due to a slump in car sales. The country's condo rents also declined 0.1% in August, while HDB rents rose 0.1%. Other news includes Malaysia seizing assets worth RM3 billion, China's GDP growth expected to slow, and the UK economy shrinking for the second month.

site_title: Australian shares end lower on banks and miners; NZ down
summary: Australian shares fell 0.1% to 6,175.90, with banks and miners taking a hit due to falling commodities prices and revelations of misconduct in the financial industry. Index heavyweight Australia and New Zealand Banking Group Ltd dropped 0.7%, while Westpac Banking Corp fell 0.6%. Mining stocks, including BHP and Fortescue Metals Group Ltd, also declined, while local energy stocks like Woodside Petroleum Ltd rose. New Zealand's benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index fell 0.3%.

site_title: Abu Dhabi set to cash in Cepsa Investment with US$11.6b IPO
summary: Abu Dhabi's Mubadala Investment Co is set to cash in on its investment in Spanish oil firm Cepsa through a potential initial public offering (IPO). The state-owned investor, which acquired Cepsa in 2011 for about 7.5 billion euros, could raise up to 3 billion euros (S$4.79 billion) from selling a portion of its shares. This would value the company at up to 10 billion euros, making it the largest oil IPO in about a decade. Abu Dhabi would see significant paper gains if the valuation is achieved.

site_title: 10 e-payment modes to be available at selected eating places by end-2018
summary: Singapore's Enterprise Singapore, Housing and Development Board, National Environment Agency, and JTC Corporation have launched an e-payment solution for coffee shops, hawker centres, and industrial canteens. Nets will be the master acquirer for the unified e-payment solution, allowing customers to use up to 20 payment schemes to purchase meals. The initiative aims to adopt the solution across 200 coffee shops, 25 hawker centres, and 20 industrial canteens within two years. The first phase will include 10 payment schemes, with customers able to choose from 20 schemes by August 2019.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks see further trade-linked losses
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell 0.29% on Wednesday, marking the sixth consecutive day of losses, due to fears over the China-US trade row and emerging markets crisis. The Hang Seng Index dropped to 26,345.04, while the Shanghai Composite Index fell 0.33% to 2,656.11. The decline was attributed to investor uncertainty and trade tensions.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks steady amid US-China trade concerns; won slips
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index closed steady on Wednesday amid investor concerns about emerging markets and the US-China trade conflict. The Korean won and bond yields slipped, while shares of Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix dropped 1.1% and 2% respectively due to disappointing chip industry outlooks. The country's unemployment rate rose to an eight-year high in August, and President Moon Jae-in's approval rating is at its lowest since inauguration. The inflation rate is expected to reach the target level before a potential rate hike, dampening expectations for monetary tightening.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Wednesday afternoon at 3,109.16, down 0.02% on day
summary: Singapore stocks resumed trading on Wednesday afternoon at 3,109.16, down 0.02% from the previous day's close. The Straits Times Index fell 0.75 points, with 144 securities gaining and 155 losing, as 995.3 million securities worth S$448.9 million changed hands. Notable movers included Rex International Holding and KrisEnergy, with Rex advancing 5.6% and Kris rising 7.3%. The index remains in a 5-day rally ahead of upcoming GDP data.

site_title: TV ratings provider Nielsen to explore sale of entire company
summary: Nielsen Holdings Plc, a TV ratings company, is exploring strategic alternatives, including a sale, after facing pressure from hedge fund Elliott Management Corp. The company is working with investment banks and law firms to assess options, including continuing as a public company, separating segments, or selling the entire business. Nielsen has been struggling to adapt to the shift to digital advertising and video consumption. A sale is not certain, and the company's review will consider a range of possibilities.

site_title: PM Lee unsure if China-backed RCEP trade pact will be finalised this year
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong expressed uncertainty about finalizing the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP) trade agreement by the end of this year, despite hopes of a substantial conclusion. The agreement, backed by China and involving ASEAN member countries, Australia, India, Japan, South Korea, and New Zealand, aims to establish a major regional trade pact. A final decision on the RCEP's terms remains pending, with Lee attributing the uncertainty to ongoing negotiations.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower on Wednesday; STI down 0.1% to 3,106.42
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.1% to 3,106.42 on Wednesday, with about 63 million shares changing hands. Gainers outnumbered losers 74 to 56, led by Rex International's 4.4% rise. Regional markets also declined, with Tokyo's Nikkei and Australian stocks falling 0.25% and 0.3% respectively.

site_title: Asia stocks caught in longest sell-off in 16 years
summary: Asia's stock markets have entered their longest sell-off in 16 years, with the MSCI Asia Pacific Index falling for a 10th consecutive day, extending its decline to about 5% and a loss of nearly $700 billion this year. The decline is attributed to trade tensions, a rising US dollar, emerging-market turmoil, and the bear market in Chinese stocks. Many strategists believe the sell-off is not over yet, with some predicting further downgrades to earnings estimates and a potential risk-off sentiment globally.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A Vietnam Airlines Airbus A321-200 aircraft lands at Noi Bai International airport in Hanoi January 17, 2017. REUTERS/Kham/File Photo##########vietnam##########

site_title: Acra relocates service counter to Revenue House
summary: The Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority (Acra) has relocated its service counters to Revenue House at 55 Newton Road in Singapore. The move aims to provide citizens and businesses with a better service experience through the co-location of service counters with the Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore (IRAS), SME Centre, and CorpPass. Businesses can now access various services, including business registration, tax matters, and CorpPass applications, at the new Taxpayer and Business Service Centre on Level 1 of Revenue House.

site_title: Juncker ready for one more push for EU unity
summary: European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker plans to unveil an ambitious reform program for his final 12 months in charge, aiming to address EU unity and strengthen institutions. He will focus on building a robust border force, combating cyber-crime, and reforming migrant reception. Despite facing challenges from rising populism and euroscepticism, Juncker remains committed to the European project, citing its potential for greatness. His term is expected to be marked by Brexit negotiations and a possible EU parliamentary vote that will impact his own future.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks post small gains at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks made small gains in the first few minutes of trading on Wednesday, edging up 0.15% to 26,462.82, following a five-day retreat. However, the Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indexes fell 0.19% and 0.06% respectively. Investors remain cautious due to ongoing China-US trade tensions, which continue to impact markets.

site_title: Singapore condo rents fall 0.1% in August from July; HDB rents rise 0.1%: SRX
summary: Singapore condo rents fell 0.1% in August from July, returning to year-ago levels, while HDB rents rose 0.1% for the second consecutive month. Private rents are down 19.1% from their peak in January 2013, and HDB rents are down 1.7% from August 2017. Leasing volumes for condos and HDB flats also declined, with condo leases down 4.7% and HDB leases down 8.6%.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Serial System, Nico Steel, Sabana Reit, SIIC Environment, Straits Trading
summary: Serial System sold its 27.34% stake in SPL Holdings for US$31.2 million, recognizing a US$20 million gain. Nico Steel terminated an agreement for S$50 million redeemable convertible bonds, converting outstanding bonds into shares. No other significant developments were mentioned for the other listed companies, Nico Steel Holdings, Sabana Reit, SIIC Environment, and Straits Trading.

site_title: Anwar Ibrahim launches bid to return to Malaysia's parliament
summary: Malaysia's Anwar Ibrahim has announced his bid to return to parliament, contesting the Port Dickson seat in Negri Sembilan. His People's Justice Party (PKR) has pledged to ensure his return, with PKR secretary-general Saifuddin Nasution stating it will strengthen Pakatan Harapan's position. Anwar, who was imprisoned for sodomy charges, was released in 2004 and later jailed again in 2015. He was recently named prime minister-in-waiting by the ruling coalition, with Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad promising to step aside for him. Anwar's return to politics marks a significant development in Malaysian politics.

site_title: US to take longer to mull Sprint merger with T-Mobile
summary: The US Federal Communications Commission (FCC) has extended its review of Sprint and T-Mobile's proposed merger, pausing the 180-day transaction clock. The extra time is needed to assess updated engineering and economic modeling information. The merger, announced in April, aims to form a new company and develop a super-fast 5G network. The review will continue until the companies complete their record and a reasonable period of staff and third-party review has passed.

site_title: Broker's take: UOB Kay Hian initiates coverage on PropNex with 'buy'
summary: UOB Kay Hian has initiated coverage on PropNex with a "buy" call and target price of S$0.65, citing the company as a low-risk proxy to Singapore's property market. PropNex, a real estate agency, employs 7,512 agents and holds a dominant share of the residential primary private market. Analysts attribute the company's resilience to higher commissions, a strong pipeline of mandates, and resilience in the resale market. The company's asset-light approach and strong brand equity are also seen as advantages.

site_title: Asia: Markets stumble again as trade fears persist
summary: Asian markets fell, with Hong Kong plummeting into a bear market, as investors feared a China-US trade war would batter the global economy. China plans to impose $7 billion in anti-dumping sanctions on the US, amid escalating tensions over trade practices. The Hang Seng Index dropped 0.8% and Shanghai fell 0.6%, while Tokyo, Sydney, and Seoul also declined. Experts warn that trade tensions add to downside risks to growth, with volatility and risk aversion in financial markets expected to continue.

site_title: Oil up over 2% on concerns over Iran, slower US output growth
summary: Oil prices rose over 2% on Tuesday due to US sanctions on Iran and slower-than-expected US crude output growth. Brent crude futures increased to $79.06 a barrel and WTI crude to $69.25 a barrel. The US Energy Secretary met with Saudi and Russian energy ministers to encourage high oil production. A potential new long-term cooperation deal among major oil producers may also impact the market. US crude production is forecast to rise 840,000 barrels per day, lower than initially expected.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on Wednesday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Wednesday, extending rallies on Wall Street as traders shrugged off lingering trade worries. The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.12% or 28.31 points to 22,693.00, while the Topix index rose 0.10% or 1.65 points to 1,700.56. This follows the S&P 500 and Nasdaq's fresh records in the US, despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Poland wants its planned airport to be a European gateway to Asia
summary: Poland plans to build a 45-million passenger airport with a train hub, aiming to become a European gateway to Asia. The $12.9 billion project, set to be completed by 2027, will be the largest transportation hub in central and eastern Europe. The government is open to partnering with Asian countries to finance the project, which will also include highways and railroads. Despite criticism from Ryanair and opposition parties, the deputy infrastructure minister believes the project will be profitable with just two runways and necessary links, and has seen "great interest" from financial institutions.

site_title: Cancer in Europe: more cases but fewer deaths
summary: The number of cancer cases in Europe has risen by 50% since 2000, with 2.4% of the population affected in 2014, according to the World Health Organization's European Health Report. Mortality rates from the disease have decreased, with 20 deaths per 100,000 women in 2015, down from 26.8 in 2000. Breast cancer cases increased by 30% between 2000 and 2014, while cervical cancer death rates have halved in the EU since the 1970s.

site_title: Operation Tsukiji: Tokyo battles rats as iconic market shuts
summary: Tokyo is preparing for a massive rat invasion as the world-famous Tsukiji fish market closes next month. The 23-hectare market, home to tens of thousands of rats, will relocate to a new facility in Toyosu. To prevent a mass exodus, officials are blocking pipe and sewer exits, plugging holes in fences, and erecting a steel wall around the site. They will also use 40,000 sticky sheets, traps, and rat poison to catch the rodents. Despite the efforts, local businesses are on high alert, fearing a possible influx of unwelcome rodent visitors.

site_title: Malaysia shares open higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened higher on Wednesday, rising 15.15 points to 1,814.32. The index saw a volume of 66.34 million lots worth RM93.22 million. Losers outnumbered gainers 104 to 95.

site_title: District 10's Gisborne Light to seek S$37m in en bloc tender
summary: District 10's freehold condominium Gisborne Light is up for collective sale with an asking price of S$37 million (S$1,671 psf ppr) in a public tender starting Sept 13. The site, zoned for residential, has a gross plot ratio of 1.6 and could be redeveloped into a luxury boutique project with 27 units. The land rate is attractive following the introduction of new cooling measures, with comparable transactions in the area ranging from S$1,734 to S$1,847 psf ppr.

site_title: Spanish health minister resigns over 'mastergate' scandal
summary: Spanish Health Minister Carmen Monton resigned due to allegations of irregularities in her educational qualifications, specifically a master's degree from University Rey Juan Carlos. The scandal, dubbed "mastergate," has also affected opposition leader Pablo Casado, who admitted to obtaining a master's degree without attending classes or passing exams. The incident has raised concerns about an "old-boys network" at the university, potentially harming the government's image.

site_title: Most big exporters failing to check foreign bribery: report
summary: A report by Transparency International found that 22 countries, accounting for 39.6% of global exports, fail to enforce the OECD's 1997 Anti-Bribery Convention, which requires criminalizing bribery of foreign public officials. Countries such as China and India, as well as OECD members like Mexico and Japan, are among those that "turn a blind eye" to foreign bribery. The report highlights the disparity between countries that strictly enforce the convention and those that do not.

site_title: Buyer in SingHaiyi's US commercial project cuts commitment by three-quarters
summary: A buyer of SingHaiyi's US commercial project, Vietnam Town in San Jose, California, has reduced its commitment by three-quarters, cutting from 141 units to 34 units. The new deal, valued at US$23.1 million, replaces a previous agreement to buy the entire Phase II units for US$95.3 million, which was terminated under a mutual agreement. Completion of the new deal is expected by November 12, 2018.

site_title: Russia launches biggest ever war games
summary: Russia has launched its largest ever military drills, dubbed "Vostok-2018," involving 300,000 soldiers, 36,000 military vehicles, 80 ships, and 1,000 aircraft, in a show of force that NATO has condemned as a rehearsal for "large-scale conflict."
