site_title: Four new providers join MOH telemedicine sandbox
summary: Four new medical services providers, including two with on-demand house call services, have joined Singapore's Ministry of Health (MOH) regulatory sandbox for telemedicine. The new providers, MyDoc, Doctor Anywhere, Speedoc, and MaNaDr, will offer services within specified patient safety and welfare parameters. The MOH's Licensing Experimentation and Adaptation Programme (Leap) will allow these services to operate until telemedicine is officially licensed under the Healthcare Services Act. The move aims to provide patients with more options for telemedicine services while ensuring patient safety and welfare.

site_title: Australia business conditions strengthen in August: survey
summary: An index of Australian business conditions rebounded in August, reaching +15, up 2 points from the previous month, with improved sales and profits reported by firms. The employment index held firm at +10, suggesting around 23,000 jobs per month over the next six months. However, business confidence softened to +4, possibly due to political uncertainty. Despite this, firms reported strength in their businesses, with forward orders rising and investment plans picking up outside the mining sector. The Reserve Bank of Australia forecasts economic growth to top 3% this year and next.

site_title: Russia to launch biggest war games in its history
summary: Russia is set to launch the largest war games in its history, dubbed "Vostok-2018," featuring hundreds of thousands of troops, Chinese soldiers, and Mongolian armies. The week-long deployment, starting in eastern Siberia, has been condemned by NATO as a rehearsal for "large-scale conflict." The event is expected to be attended by Russian President Vladimir Putin, who will also host Chinese President Xi Jinping at an economic forum in Vladivostok.

site_title: Asia: Markets cautious as trade tensions weigh, pound holds gains
summary: Asian markets remained cautious due to ongoing trade tensions, with investors wary of a possible full-blown trade war between the US and China. The pound held gains after the EU's chief Brexit negotiator made optimistic remarks. Despite some investors returning to pick up bargain stocks, concerns about US tariffs on China and emerging markets kept prices in check. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged to fresh records, but the uncertainty weighed on markets.

site_title: US teens prefer remote chats to face-to-face meeting: study
summary: US teenagers now prefer remote chats to face-to-face meetings, with 35% preferring texting over in-person meetings, compared to 32% in 2018. This shift is attributed to the increasing prevalence of smartphones among teens, from 41% in 2012 to 89% in 2018. Social media platforms, such as Snapchat, Instagram, and Facebook, are also popular among teens, with 81% of respondents saying online exchange is part of their lives. However, some teens report that social media steals attention away from in-person interactions and prevents them from spending more time with friends.

site_title: US House Republicans propose more tax cuts as elections near
summary: US House Republicans have proposed a package of bills to make permanent the federal individual income tax cuts approved in December, eliminating the maximum age for some retirement account contributions, and allowing new businesses to write off more start-up costs. The measures aim to draw a contrast with Democrats ahead of the elections. However, the passage of the bills remains uncertain.

images.alt_text: Federal individual income tax cuts approved in December on a temporary basis would become permanent under a package of bills unveiled on Monday by Republicans in the US House of Representatives, although the outlook for passage was uncertain.

site_title: Japan semiconductor company Renesas to buy US firm IDT for US$6.7b
summary: Japan's Renesas to acquire US-based semiconductor firm IDT for $6.7 billion in a cash deal. The deal, expected to be completed by mid-2019, aims to strengthen Renesas' presence in industrial and automotive segments. Renesas, the world's largest automotive microcontroller chip supplier, will finance the deal using cash reserves and bank loans. The acquisition is expected to boost Renesas' market share and competitiveness.

site_title: Aquatech startup Umitron raises S$3.7m in latest round; brings total funding to S$15.2m
summary: Umitron, a Singapore-based aquatech startup, has raised S$3.7 million in funding from the Mirai Creation Fund, bringing its total funding to S$15.2 million. The startup, which released its product Umigarden in June 2017, is now demonstrating a service providing reliable data for aquaculture insurance using Internet of Things technology and satellite remote sensing. Umitron aims to expand its business to other markets through partnerships with enterprise aquafarms and insurance providers, operating in Singapore and Japan.

site_title: GIC, GLP tie up to establish US$2b fund to acquire logistics facilities in China
summary: Singapore's sovereign wealth fund GIC and logistics provider GLP have partnered to establish a US$2 billion fund to acquire income-generating logistics facilities in China. GLP China will contribute seed assets, and the partnership aims to capitalize on China's structural growth of the logistics sector, driven by e-commerce demand. This venture will enable GIC to invest long-term in the sector, while GLP seeks to strengthen its network in China.

site_title: Many conservatives fret over Trump's war on tech giants
summary: President Donald Trump's attacks on tech giants have raised concerns among conservatives about a potential crackdown on Silicon Valley that could damage free speech protections. Industry leaders are worried about a legal crackdown, but conservative activists fear punishing the tech industry for political reasons. Experts warn that the administration's claims of "censorship" misapply the First Amendment, and a government effort to regulate algorithms could lead to abuse of power. The prospect of a politicized antitrust process has sparked warnings from conservative groups and industry leaders.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher as yen remains cheaper
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Tuesday, despite trade worries, as the yen lost ground against the dollar. The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.45% to 22,474.28, while the Topix index gained 0.19%. The yen's decline boosted stocks, with investors brushing off new Trump threats to extend the rally.

site_title: Singapore condo resale prices see first monthly decline in a year after cooling measures: SRX data
summary: Resale condo prices in Singapore declined 0.2% in August, marking the first monthly drop in a year, according to SRX Property data. The decline was attributed to the latest property cooling measures, which included higher additional buyer's stamp duty and tighter loan-to-value limits. Resale volumes also dropped 35.3% to an estimated 694 units, with prices rising 8.8% year-to-date, compared to 11.2% in August 2017. Prices in prime districts fell more significantly, while those in outlying areas continued to rise.

site_title: Oil steadies as US inventory concerns curb gains
summary: US oil prices steadied on Monday after early gains were curbed by data suggesting rising US crude inventories. Weekly data from Bloomberg contradicted a report from Genscape, which forecast declining inventories. Oil prices settled with US crude futures down 21 cents to $67.54 a barrel and Brent crude up 54 cents to $77.37 a barrel. The US drilling industry's slowdown and potential impact from Iran sanctions on supply weighed on prices.

site_title: 'Anonymous' can't derail Trump plans
summary: US President Donald Trump has secured a key political win and a buoyant economy, despite a recent 'Anonymous' attack on him. The attack, which included a barrage of text messages and social media activity, was largely ignored by the public. Trump has reasons to be optimistic, with a growing economy and a strong political position. The 'Anonymous' attack is seen as a minor setback, with Trump moving forward with his plans.

site_title: Simple blood test may reveal your body's inner clock
summary: Researchers at Northwestern University have developed a blood test that can measure a person's inner body clock within 1.5 hours. This advance may help personalize medical treatments in the future. The study, published in the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, could lead to more effective treatments for conditions such as sleep disorders and circadian rhythm-related illnesses. The test measures the body's natural circadian rhythm, allowing for targeted medical interventions tailored to an individual's unique internal clock.

images.alt_text: Ever feel like it's 7am, even though the clock says 9am?

site_title: Stocks to watch: OUE, OUE C-Reit, Centurion, MS Holdings, Datapulse, ICP
summary:
Here's a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Several Singaporean companies saw developments that may impact their shares: OUE C-Reit agreed to buy office components from OUE for S$908 million, while Centurion Corporation acquired a South Korean hotel for S$16.6 million. MS Holdings plans a strategic cooperation with LongRunn International Group to develop a casino amenity and complex in South Korea. Datapulse Technology's CEO resigned, and ST Engineering appointed Tom Vecchiolla to head its US headquarters. Other notable moves include the appointment of a new non-executive chairman at Mary Chia Holdings and a trading halt at Serial System.

site_title: US approves possible sale of early-warning planes to Japan
summary: The US State Department has announced its approval of a potential sale of up to nine early-warning military planes, the E-2D Advanced Hawkeye aircraft, to Japan for over $3 billion. The deal includes associated technology and spare engines, and is seen as vital to US national interests to support Japan's self-defense capability. Congress has 30 days to raise objections, but it is unlikely given Japan's close relationship with the US.

site_title: Trump received Kim Jong Un letter seeking second meet: White House
summary: US President Donald Trump has received a "very positive" letter from North Korean leader Kim Jong Un seeking a follow-up meeting after their historic summit in Singapore. The letter, written by Kim, shows Pyongyang's continued commitment to denuclearization and expresses a desire to schedule another meeting with Trump. The White House is open to coordinating a meeting, with National Security Advisor John Bolton stating it's "entirely possible" for the two leaders to meet by year's end.

images.alt_text: US President Donald Trump has received a "very positive" letter from North Korean leader Kim Jong Un seeking a follow-up meeting after their historic summit in Singapore, the White House said on Monday.

site_title: US: Stocks end mostly higher ahead of data
summary: US stocks ended mostly higher on Monday, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index advancing 0.2% and 0.3% respectively, despite lingering trade tensions. The Dow Jones Industrial Average declined 0.2%. Investors engaged in bargain hunting after last week's losses.

images.alt_text: Rubble (voiced by Keegan Hedley), Chase (voiced by Iain Armitage), Rocky (voiced by Callum Shoniker), Skye (voiced by Lilly Bartlam), Ryder (voiced by Will Brisbin), Marshall (voiced by Kingsley Marshall), Liberty (voiced by Marsai Martin), and Zuma (voiced by Shayle Simons) in PAW PATROL: THE MOVIE from Paramount Pictures. Spin Master/Handout via REUTERS##########movie24##########

site_title: Europe: Stocks rise on Swedish vote relief
summary: European stocks rose on Monday as a far-right party failed to gain significant ground in Swedish elections, reducing concerns of a potential "Swexit" and bolstering the Swedish krona. The OMX 30 index of major companies gained 0.4% and the Frankfurt and Paris indices followed suit. Analysts warn that the inconclusive vote has exposed simmering tensions over immigration in the EU, potentially influencing other countries' decisions. Meanwhile, investors await the European Central Bank and Bank of England's monetary policy decisions and the UK's Brexit negotiations.

site_title: Abe aims for constitution change in bid for another term
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe has reaffirmed his intention to revise the country's post-war constitution, aiming for a historic extended term. He hopes his party will submit a proposal to Parliament later this year. Abe, who returned to office in 2012, is expected to defeat his rival Shigeru Ishiba in the Sept 20 election for leader of the Liberal Democratic Party. This move is seen as a key step towards bolstering Japan's defenses and rebooting the economy.

site_title: As mid-terms approach, Trump insists the economy is not Obama's
summary: US President Donald Trump has continued to claim ownership of the country's strong economy, despite Obama's legacy, amid the approaching midterm elections. Following a strong August jobs report, Trump tweeted that the economy is "sooo good, perhaps the best in our country's history," and predicted it will do better. Trump's comments come as the US economy faces various challenges, including the impact of higher US tariffs on the Asian garment industry.

images.alt_text: In his fiery speeches and Twitter blitzes, President Donald Trump has forcefully claimed ownership of the American economy's vigorous health while denigrating the legacy of Barack Obama, the president in office during most of the last decade's expansion.

site_title: VW faces first big German court date over 'dieselgate' scandal
summary: A German court began hearing a major case against Volkswagen over the "dieselgate" scandal, in which the company installed defeat devices in 11 million cars to cheat emissions tests. Investors are seeking billions in compensation for a 40% stock plunge in 2015. The case centers on whether executives should have informed investors sooner about the cheating, and whether they complied with disclosure obligations. The hearing is expected to last at least until next year, with judges examining timelines and priority issues in the massive case.

site_title: Trump dismisses Woodward book as 'joke'
summary: US President Donald Trump dismissed journalist Bob Woodward's book "Fear: Trump in the White House" as a "joke" on Monday, a day before its release. The book portrays Trump as "dangerously erratic and uninformed" and quotes him making derogatory remarks about his cabinet members. Trump has denied the quotes, calling them "fiction" and saying they were made up by Woodward. The book's release comes after a series of anonymous leaks and excerpts that criticize Trump's leadership style.

site_title: Apple to unveil new iPhones to gain fresh momentum
summary: Apple is set to unveil new iPhones on Wednesday, aiming to regain momentum in the premium smartphone market. Speculation includes three new models, including a lower-priced iPhone with X features, and an improved iPhone X. Analysts predict modest improvements in new iPhones, as the company has a loyal customer base and steady sales. The event comes ahead of the 5G rollout in 2019, expected to boost smartphone sales. Despite the global market being saturated, Apple is expected to maintain its niche in the premium segment.

site_title: Singapore's small builders seen facing debt troubles amid curbs
summary: Singapore's small construction firms face debt troubles due to a slowdown in demand for homes, largely caused by increased stamp duties and tighter borrowing limits. The construction sector, which accounted for 12.3% of employment in 2017, is vulnerable to thin margins and a decrease in construction activity. The economy's slower growth pace in the second quarter also exacerbates the issue. As a result, small domestic construction firms are expected to struggle repaying debt.

site_title: Billion-dollar sites not giving up on en bloc dreams
summary: Billion-dollar en bloc sites in Singapore are pressing on with their collective sale plans despite new cooling measures. The 669,486 sq ft Laguna Park is launching its tender sale on September 18 at a reserve price of S$1.48 billion, while owners of the 623-unit Pandan Valley condo agreed on a record asking price of S$2.6 billion. Analysts note that the size of these projects increases the risks for buyers, but the attractive locations and potential for high breakeven prices make them attractive to developers.

site_title: Australia's housing downturn unlikely to hit banks: RBA
summary: Australia's housing market slowdown is unlikely to impact the country's banks, according to Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) assistant governor Michele Bullock. Despite high household debt levels of 190% of income, Bullock believes Australian banks are well-capitalized and have tightened lending standards. While an adverse economic shock could lead to households struggling with repayments, Bullock notes that average households have the ability to absorb some increase in required repayments, citing the growing economy and low unemployment.

site_title: STI down 0.43% as trade tensions persist
summary: Asian markets closed mixed on Monday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) falling 13.47 points to 3,120.92, amid ongoing trade tensions. Hong Kong and Singapore markets declined, while South Korea and Tokyo snapped losing streaks. Key stocks like Singtel, OCBC Bank, and United Overseas Bank fell, while DBS rose. Analysts expect Asian markets to remain cautious and bearish this week due to persistent trade tensions.

site_title: A decade on, Great Recession's ghost still haunting markets
summary: A decade after the Great Recession, financial markets are still vulnerable to the threat of a global crisis. Inflated asset prices, excessive borrowing, and the potential for a global economic downturn are among the concerns shared by analysts and fund managers. The removal of easy money from central banks' policies is expected to deflate asset bubbles, potentially in an orderly but still disorderly fashion. Higher interest rates and risk spreads could lead to a drop in bond prices, hurting emerging markets and currencies. Regulators have patched up fault lines from the previous crisis, but experts warn that the next crisis may be entirely different and more devastating.

site_title: Handicap the next financial crisis before it starts
summary: The world economy appears to be repairing itself 10 years after the 2008-2009 global financial crisis. Emerging-market countries, such as Argentina, Brazil, and China, may trigger a new crisis if they default on loans, but a new report by McKinsey Global Institute suggests that pluses outweigh minuses. Key improvements include reduced consumer debt, decreased cross-border capital flows, and diminished global trade imbalances. However, debt-heavy economies remain a concern, and the report warns of the importance of being vigilant in the face of uncertainty.

site_title: 1MDB probe: Singapore court orders S$15m returned to Malaysia
summary: A Singapore court ordered the return of approximately S$15.3 million to Malaysia, the first time assets have been repatriated following a global probe into 1MDB. The funds were recovered from 1Malaysia Development Berhad and its subsidiary SRC International. This move comes after Singapore and Malaysia agreed to cooperate on returning funds in 2016. The repatriation is part of efforts to recover unlawfully misappropriated assets linked to the scandal-hit state fund, with a total of US$4.5 billion suspected to have been siphoned off.

site_title: New Aussie PM under pressure in maiden Parliament address
summary: Australia's new Prime Minister Scott Morrison faced pressure in his maiden address to Parliament, with a poll indicating his government may soon be out of a job. The ruling Liberal Party trails behind the opposition, and Morrison's approval ratings are threatened by public unease over party infighting. Morrison sought to focus on economic growth, but opposition leader Bill Shorten questioned the reasons behind the removal of former Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull. The country is no stranger to leadership upheaval, but Morrison's arrival comes at a precarious time, with warning signs of an economic slowdown.

site_title: Crypto wipeout deepens to US$640m as Ether leads decline
summary: Cryptocurrency prices plummeted to a 10-month low as Bitcoin and Ether fell 2.1% and 8.9% respectively, with the market capitalization shrinking to US$197 billion from its January peak of US$640 billion. The decline is attributed to concerns that a broader adoption of digital assets will take longer than expected, and regulatory crackdowns, including the suspension of trading in two exchange-traded notes linked to cryptocurrencies. Experts warn that the days of explosive growth in the blockchain industry may be over, and a temporary suspension of trading has led to an initial knee-jerk reaction.

site_title: Vibrant Group units face lawsuit in China
summary: Eight subsidiaries of Singapore-based logistics firm Vibrant Group are being sued in China for allegedly failing to meet payment and guarantee obligations under a 500 million yuan loan facility. The lawsuit, filed by China Minsheng Banking Corporation, targets 12 parties, including eight Vibrant Group subsidiaries. This is the first reported lawsuit against Vibrant Group. The outcome of the lawsuit is uncertain and has yet to be resolved.

site_title: Trio lift Team Boss' hopes
summary: Team Boss is in contention for the prestigious Business Times Corporate Golf League title, trailing leaders Proelect by just two points as the annual event nears its end. The team's quartet of players, led by William Tay's 37 points, have managed to score heavily despite playing on challenging courses without drivers. The mandatory Tanah Merah leg, where all four players' scores will count, has narrowed the gap between Proelect and Team Boss, with Team Boss now just two points behind the leaders.

site_title: SPH buying UK student housing portfolio for £180.5m
summary: SPH has acquired a UK student housing portfolio of 14 purpose-built buildings for £180.5m (S$321m), with a total capacity of 3,436 beds. The portfolio, acquired from Unite Group, includes 10 freehold and 4 leasehold assets in established university towns. The acquisition is expected to generate recurring cash flow and diversify SPH's business. The deal is part of SPH's strategy to enter the UK's growing student accommodation sector, driven by increasing demand for international and postgraduate students.

site_title: Solar farms not backed by government subsidies sprouting across Europe
summary: Solar farms in Europe are proliferating without government subsidies, as the cost of generating solar power has decreased to a level where they can profit from selling power at market price. Anesco Ltd is building a hybrid solar-and-battery facility in Milton Keynes using its own capital, and this is part of about 15 photovoltaic projects underway across the UK and Italy. This trend is expected to continue as more developers invest in solar energy without relying on subsidies.

site_title: Look beyond pedigree names that burnish young firms
summary: Prominent business figures are being associated with startups and cryptocurrencies to boost credibility, despite the lack of actual investment. This practice, known as "window-dressing," can be misleading and may not accurately reflect the founders' or investors' level of commitment. Industry experts warn that investors should focus on a company's fundamentals rather than its celebrity backers, and that the emphasis on pedigree can be unproductive.

site_title: Private developers not ruled out for Vers: Lawrence Wong
summary: Singapore's National Development Minister Lawrence Wong has left the door open for private developers to participate in redeveloping ageing HDB flats under a new Voluntary Early Redevelopment Scheme (Vers). Wong stated he "won't rule out" private developers, emphasizing the government's goal of preserving the character of HDB towns while ensuring affordable and quality homes. The scheme aims to pace out redevelopment over 20-30 years, with the first flats set to be 70 years old. Authorities need more time to work out details, including coverage and compensation.

site_title: It's about time: eBay now authenticates luxury watches
summary: eBay has expanded its Authenticate program to include luxury watch brands such as Rolex, Omega, and Breitling, offering buyers an authenticated selection of over 30 brands with nearly 7,000 items. The program, launched in 2017 for luxury handbags, verifies the authenticity of watches priced from $500 and up, with top-rated sellers selected for participation. eBay projects the program will grow to showcase over 10,000 luxury timepieces in weeks, with 80% of sale prices going to the seller.

site_title: Insiders at 800 Super bought almost S$1m worth of shares as stock slumped
summary: The controlling shareholders of 800 Super Holdings acquired almost S$1 million worth of shares in September amid a slump in the stock, which fell 36.5% to a two-year low after reporting a loss of S$1.65 million in the fiscal fourth quarter. The purchases increased their stake by 0.67 percentage point to 67.63%. The stock has since clawed back, with PhillipCapital upgrading its call to "buy" from "accumulate" citing a key public waste collection contract that should put 800 Super on track to be free cash flow positive in fiscal 2020.

site_title: Data - the mummy of baby fairs
summary: Mummys Market, a tech and marketing firm, dominates Singapore's baby fair sector with 80% market share and 75% of pregnant mothers' data. Founded in 2014, the company has smashed sales records and expanded its offerings to include a marketplace app and agency work. With no external funding, Mummys Market has been profitable since 2014 and is now expanding into South-east Asia through acquisitions. The company aims to leverage its data-driven approach to drive online, offline, and exhibitions shopping experiences, eventually targeting other family-related segments.

site_title: Africa should be mindful of debt trap danger when accepting China aid
summary: African leaders have praised China's Belt and Road Initiative (BRI), which promises $60 billion in aid, investments, and loans. However, critics argue that the loans are often unsustainable and designed to trap countries in debt. BRI projects have not always worked out well, with many benefiting China's access to resources rather than local economies. China should consider partnering with local businesses and inviting international tenders to ensure better outcomes, rather than tying projects to Chinese companies and materials. This could help prevent debt traps and ensure that African countries benefit from BRI.

site_title: Helping others breathe easy
summary: AEVice Health, a Singapore-based company, aims to develop wearable devices for people with asthma, starting with a device for children. The device, "AireSone Junior," monitors vital signs and notifies parents of impending asthma attacks. AEVice Health has received over 1,000 pre-orders for the device, primarily from the US and UK, and plans to set up an office in one of these countries. The company faces challenges in navigating regulations and technological innovation, but its mission is to improve the lives of patients with asthma through early detection and treatment.

site_title: How Alibaba became Asia's most valuable firm
summary: Alibaba, founded in 1999 by Jack Ma with $60,000, became Asia's most valuable firm through strategic investments and innovative products. In 2000, the company raised $20 million from SoftBank Group Corp. and in 2003, Ma created Taobao, a consumer bartering site. Alibaba's success led to its listing on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange in 2004, making it the largest IPO in history at the time. Today, Alibaba's valuation is over $600 billion, solidifying its position as a leading player in the Asian tech industry.

site_title: BreadTalk opening Singapore's first Wu Pao Chun bakery in 2019
summary: BreadTalk Group is bringing the Wu Pao Chun bakery to Singapore, with the first location set to open at Capitol Piazza in 2019. The joint venture, held by BreadTalk and Wu Pao Chun Food, will operate bakeries in Shanghai, Beijing, Shenzhen, and Guangzhou. Wu Pao Chun, founded by Master Baker Mr. Wu, is known for its Asian-style soft buns and artisanal breads. The partnership aims to leverage BreadTalk's market knowledge in Singapore and Hong Kong to serve Wu Pao Chun's award-winning bread series.

site_title: HNA seeks buyer for US$1b container lessor Seaco
summary: HNA Group is seeking a buyer for its container-leasing business Seaco, which could fetch around $1 billion. The move is part of HNA's strategy to divest assets unrelated to its core aviation business and reduce debt. Seaco, which offers dry freight, refrigerated, specialized, and tank containers, may attract interest from global rivals in the container leasing industry. HNA has successfully reduced its debt pile by selling off dozens of assets, including Swissport Group and Deutsche Bank AG.

site_title: Roche faces UK pricing row over multiple sclerosis drug Ocrevus
summary: Roche faces a UK pricing row over its multiple sclerosis drug Ocrevus, following the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence's rejection of the treatment for the rare and severe primary-progressive form of MS. Despite previously endorsing Ocrevus for relapsing-remitting MS, Nice has denied approval for the drug due to its high price. This decision adds to Roche's ongoing pricing disputes in the UK.

site_title: Norwegian Air to scrap Singapore-London service in January 2019
summary: Norwegian Air will discontinue its direct Singapore-London service in January 2019, citing a lack of customer demand. This move may benefit other carriers such as Qantas and Singapore Airlines, which operate similar routes. Norwegian will redirect the capacity to other routes, offering customers alternative options or full refunds for bookings made after January 12, 2019. The decision is attributed to the challenging nature of long-haul routes for low-cost carriers, with high competition from full-service carriers and rising fuel costs.

site_title: LTA may allow taxi, private-hire car drivers to make deliveries on limited trial basis
summary: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) of Singapore may allow taxi and private-hire car drivers to make deliveries on a limited trial basis. Senior Minister of State for Transport Janil Puthucheary announced this possibility in Parliament, with the LTA to assess feasibility and ensure minimal impact on taxi and private-hire car availability. The trial would also need to safeguard commuter interests, including insurance coverage. This comes after e-commerce giant Amazon previously used taxi and private-hire drivers for deliveries, which was previously prohibited.

site_title: ST Engineering appoints new head of US headquarters amid US push
summary: ST Engineering appoints Tom Vecchiolla as head of its US headquarters, VT Systems, amid the company's push to expand its US presence, particularly in the defense segment. Vecchiolla, with 17 years of private sector and 24 years of public and military sector experience, replaces John Coburn as president and CEO starting Dec 1, 2018. The move comes as the US market becomes a critical role in driving the company's success, contributing over 20% to group revenue.

site_title: MindChamps' curriculum key to its success
summary: MindChamps, a Singapore-based early childhood education provider, has developed a unique educational model called the "3-Mind Revolution" which combines neuroscience, psychology, and theatre to equip children with the skills and mindset needed to thrive in a rapidly changing world. Founded in 2008, the model has won numerous awards and has been incorporated into the SMILES curriculum, which integrates research-based methods and multi-sensory learning activities. With over 100,000 students worldwide, MindChamps is expanding its operations and expects to launch new centres in Vietnam, Myanmar, and China by the end of 2018.

site_title: EY names 5 category winners of Entrepreneur Of The Year 2018 awards
summary: EY named five entrepreneurs as category winners of the 17th annual EY Entrepreneur Of The Year 2018 Singapore awards. The winners, selected from over 40 nominations, were recognized for their entrepreneurial spirit, financial performance, and innovation. They include Mr. Lee of Expand Construction, Mr. Tiong of Patsnap, Mr. Cheong of Pictureworks, Mr. Ng of Rigel Technology, and Mr. Junique of Teledirect. The winners will be honored at a gala on October 26 and one of them will represent Singapore at the annual EY World Entrepreneur Of The Year award in Monte Carlo next year.

site_title: China gives high priority to property tax that may rein in market
summary: China's legislature prioritizes implementing a property tax, considered a key measure to curb a runaway market. The tax was tested in Shanghai and Chongqing in 2011 and has been repeatedly mentioned by officials as a way to cool speculation. A national tax on home ownership could be passed before the end of 2019, with the government preparing for the levy since President Xi Jinping's second term began. The move aims to rein in the market, but may also risk market sentiment.

site_title: Aug daily average value traded on SGX down 5% year on year
summary: The daily average value of securities traded on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) in August was S$1.12 billion, a 0.3% increase from July but a 5% decrease from August 2017. Total market turnover stood at S$23.5 billion over 21 trading days, down 4% from July and 9% from August 2017.

site_title: Cold snap concerns boost Chinese soybean futures
summary: China's soybean futures surged 4.6% to a record high, reaching 3,793 yuan (S$762.48) per tonne, amid concerns of crop damage due to early frost in northeast regions. Investors bet on tight supplies following low temperatures in Heilongjiang and Inner Mongolia. The average daily temperature in the region fell to 8.7°C, below the normal 16.3°C. This move is expected to impact China's soybean yields and quality.

site_title: China's Aug producer inflation eases, reflecting slowing growth
summary: China's producer inflation eased in August, reflecting slowing growth, with the producer price index (PPI) rising 4.1% from a year earlier. Consumer inflation, however, picked up to 2.3% in August, the fastest pace since February. The economic slowdown is driven by softening domestic demand and trade tensions with the US. China's policymakers are trying to keep the economy on an even keel, loosening liquidity and speeding up infrastructure projects to support growth. Despite concerns, analysts expect moderate inflation and do not foresee interest rate hikes to address it.

site_title: UK firm Vertical joins race to build air taxis, inspired by aerospace advances
summary: UK-based energy entrepreneur Stephen Fitzpatrick's company Vertical Aerospace is developing electric Vertical Take Off and Landing (eVTOL) aircraft for short-haul, inter-city flights with multiple passengers. The company aims to launch piloted services within four years, leveraging lessons from Formula 1 racing and hiring aerospace experts. Unlike tech-focused rivals, Vertical plans to deliver piloted, fixed-wing aircraft that capitalize on existing innovations, targeting congested air corridors without requiring runways. The company has conducted a test flight and plans to work with regulators to win certification in 2022.

site_title: Breaking new ground in concrete
summary: Pan-United Corporation, a Singapore-based concrete company, has developed a centralized command center and digital platform, AiR, to optimize its operations and improve customer engagement. The company has also developed specialized concrete products, such as radiation-shielding concrete and self-compacting concrete, to meet the needs of various industries. Pan-United's innovation efforts aim to stay ahead in the market by developing unique products and processes, including a truck-hailing app, GoTruck!. The company's digital platform has the potential to transform the entire industry, reducing the number of plants and saving land, manpower, and truck journeys.

site_title: Most Americans get news from social media, despite doubts: survey
summary: A survey by the Pew Research Center found that 68% of American adults use social media for news, with 20% saying they get information "often" from these services. This usage remains unchanged despite heightened scrutiny over misinformation and online platform manipulation. The survey results contradict previous doubts about the accuracy of social media news sources, suggesting that many Americans continue to rely on these platforms for news.

site_title: ASME launches software for SMEs
summary: The Association of Small and Medium Enterprises (ASME) has launched a cloud-based software platform, SME Cloud Exchange Network Software (SMECEN), to support Singaporean small and medium enterprises (SMEs) with accounting, human resource, and compliance needs. The platform, launched on July 20, is supported by Enterprise Singapore, the Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority, and Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore, aiming to increase productivity and lower costs for SMEs, while facilitating compliance with legislative and statutory requirements.

site_title: Customer, not technology, remains king
summary: Singapore middle-market companies are investing heavily in artificial intelligence (AI), with 72% planning to introduce AI within two years. However, a recent survey found that these companies are focusing on operations rather than customer needs, with 55% aiming to improve process efficiencies. This approach may not deliver growth, as customer-centricity is crucial for success. Companies must adopt a customer-focused lens to create value for consumers and drive profitability. A customer-focused approach can help identify untapped markets and "sweet spots" for growth, both domestically and internationally.

site_title: UBS, CampVision mentor 100 youths
summary: UBS and CampVision partnered to mentor 100 youths aged 13-16 through the Lead Academy programme, which aims to develop effective communication skills and self-leadership. Over 40 volunteer mentors from UBS worked with the youths over six months, guiding them to set and achieve personal goals. This is part of UBS' youth engagement efforts, which also include the Race Around the Marina Bay team-building event. The programme is a cornerstone of UBS' community involvement, with over 230 staff and 700 youths participating since 2014.

images.alt_text: President Halimah Yacob with (from left) Westwood Secondary School student Dana Tan, Hua Yi Secondary School student Wesley Wee, UBS Singapore country operating officer Teo Lay Sie and CampVision chairperson Yeo Suan Wei.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Brokers are recommending buying shares of CapitaLand Mall Trust and Keppel Corporation. For CMT, analysts see a growth play due to strong pre-commitments and higher contributions from Westgate and Funan, which could drive up distributions per unit. For Keppel, the company's work on converting vessels into FLNG vessels is seen as a long-term opportunity, despite some market concerns. Meanwhile, NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was oversubscribed, and Singapore stocks are on a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: US consumers' 1-year inflation outlook highest in over 3 years
summary: US consumers' one-year inflation expectations rose to 3% in August, the highest level in over three years, according to a Federal Reserve Bank of New York survey. This marked a reversal from the previous four months, where expectations were at 2.98%. The three-year inflation measure also rebounded to 3.00%, the highest level since February. The Fed considers these expectations when assessing US price pressures.

site_title: US dollar, Swiss franc struggle as bond yields drop
summary: The US dollar struggled against the Swiss franc on Monday as bond yields in peripheral European countries, such as Italy, dropped. Investors sought riskier assets, including Scandinavian currencies, amid hopes for prudent fiscal policies. The Swiss franc fell half a percent against the dollar and euro, while the dollar struggled to build on its gains from last week.

site_title: Djokovic gets back his mojo after a break
summary: Novak Djokovic has regained his form after a transformative five-day hike in the French Alps with his wife, which he credits with inspiring him to win two Grand Slam titles. Since the June trek, Djokovic has added the US Open title to his resume, taking him to 14 career Grand Slam wins. He credits the experience with helping him reconnect with tennis and regain his motivation, going on to win Wimbledon, the US Open tune-up in Cincinnati, and the US Open itself.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Neo Group acquired a 51% stake in Ye Liang How Catering Service for S$4.4 million. Datapulse Technology CEO Wilson Teng resigned, and the company agreed to terminate its plan to acquire ICP's hotel subsidiary. Centurion Corporation bought South Korea's Benikea Hotel for S$16.6 million to refurbish as student accommodation. MS Holdings plans a strategic cooperation with LongRunn International Group to develop a US$80 million land parcel in South Korea.

site_title: Bill tabled to integrate insolvency, bankruptcy and debt revamp laws
summary: A new omnibus Bill, the Insolvency, Restructuring and Dissolution Bill, was tabled in Parliament to consolidate personal and corporate insolvency and debt restructuring laws into a single piece of legislation. The Bill aims to unify bankruptcy and debt restructuring laws, regulate insolvency practitioners, and strengthen debt restructuring regimes. Key changes include requiring secured creditors to notify the trustee within 30 days, allowing companies to seek judicial management without a court order, and providing temporary relief to companies undergoing restructuring. The Bill is part of a phased implementation of recommendations from the Insolvency Law Review Committee and the Committee to Strengthen Singapore as an International Centre for Debt Restructuring.

site_title: Business as usual for ICP as concerns raised about operations, business model do not impact management
summary: The ICP Group, a Singaporean company, has responded to concerns about its operations and business model, stating that its strategy to expand into hotel investment and management under the Travelodge brand is not mutually exclusive with being asset-light. The company has also addressed concerns about a proposed related-party transaction, stating that safeguards are in place to regulate such transactions. ICP has also discussed its investment in Tiaro Coal, which was placed into liquidation proceedings, and has filed a claim against Hudson Resources, the company's former controlling shareholder. The company has mutually agreed to terminate a proposed acquisition of a hotel by Datapulse due to lack of due diligence completion.

site_title: How Netflix conquered the world of comedy
summary: Netflix has revolutionized the comedy industry by signing top talent, committing to pay equity, and expanding its content offerings. Under the leadership of Lisa Nishimura and Robbie Praw, the streaming giant has transformed stand-up specials into a popular cultural phenomenon. Netflix releases over 1 special per week, and 50% of its 130 million subscribers have watched a special in the last year. The company's strategy is rooted in personalizing the experience through its algorithm, allowing it to cater to diverse tastes and expand its audience. Despite criticisms of oversaturation and representation issues, Netflix continues to grow, with plans to release 47 half-hour specials in seven languages next year.

site_title: East Court seeks S$19m in en bloc tender
summary: East Court, a 13,351 sq ft eight-unit development in Singapore, is up for sale via en bloc tender. The freehold site has achieved 100% consensus from owners and is priced at S$19 million, translating to S$1,031 psf ppr. The tender closes on Oct 26. Despite a cooling market, experts suggest that smaller sites like East Court can still be sold, provided sellers are realistic in their pricing and adjust downward to account for the risks under new cooling measures.

site_title: Gene-editing patent challenge rejected by US appeals court
summary: A US appeals court has ruled that the Broad Institute can keep patents on the CRISPR gene-editing technology, rejecting a challenge from the University of California at Berkeley. The court found that the Broad Institute's inventions were different from those sought by Berkeley, allowing both groups to be entitled to patents. The ruling allows the Broad Institute to potentially receive financial and reputational credit for the technology, which has revolutionized the field of genetics.

site_title: Singapore shares end lower on Monday
summary: Singapore shares ended lower on Monday, closing 13.47 points down 0.4% at 3,120.92. About 1.8 billion securities worth S$905.8 million changed hands, with losers outnumbering gainers 281 to 135. Despite this, the Straits Times Index (STI) had rallied 5 days prior to the close.

site_title: New construction boom threatens Spanish coastline
summary: A new construction boom threatens Spain's coastline, with numerous building projects underway along the 160km stretch of the Costa Brava. A 260-home residential development at Aiguafreda cove, one of Spain's last unspoiled Mediterranean coves, has been relaunched despite opposition from local residents and environmental groups. The municipality has vowed to limit the number of homes built to 100, but many similar projects are planned in surrounding areas, raising concerns about the impact on the region's natural beauty and ecosystems.

site_title: The Nun tops US box office with US$53.5m haul
summary: THE Nun topped the US box office with a debut of $53.5 million in 3,876 locations, surpassing the previous Conjuring series record. The film also generated $77.5 million overseas, bringing its global total to $131 million. This marks the fifth consecutive weekend Warner Bros has dominated the box office, with The Nun breaking franchise records for largest Thursday showing and biggest opening day. The Conjuring franchise has now earned over $1.1 billion globally, with The Nun's success expected to carry the film well into the fall.

site_title: Britain's Network Rail divests commercial property portfolio for US$1.9b
summary: Britain's Network Rail has agreed to sell its commercial property portfolio to Telereal Trillium and a Blackstone Group affiliate for US$1.9 billion. The portfolio, comprising 5,200 properties, primarily converted railway arches, will be used to fund railway upgrades. Telereal and Blackstone Property Partners will hold equal stakes and aim to be long-term owners of the estate. The sale is expected to generate significant revenue for Network Rail, supporting future infrastructure projects.

site_title: Tough predicting what the next global financial crisis would be like
summary: A potential global financial crisis is looming, despite reforms following the 2008 crisis. Shocks to the system occur frequently, but a crisis emerges when the system is unprepared. Global debt has nearly tripled since 2001, with over a third of developed economies having debt-to-GDP ratios above 85%. Central banks' quantitative easing programs are winding down, increasing vulnerability to interest rate shocks. Governments face limited ammunition to respond to a downturn, and passive investing may amplify investors' trading patterns. Global diversification remains key to managing risk, and investors should review their asset allocations regularly.

site_title: Abu Dhabi's largest developer Aldar hires banks for US$750m sukuk refinancing: sources
summary: Abu Dhabi's largest developer, Aldar Properties, has hired banks to arrange a US$750 million sukuk issue to refinance an existing US$750 million Islamic bond. The banks involved are JPMorgan, Standard Chartered, and First Abu Dhabi Bank, with Dubai Islamic Bank also participating. The sukuk will replace the existing bond due in December and could be increased in size based on demand. This follows a 28% fall in Aldar's second-quarter profit, attributed to a revaluation of its retail portfolio, and comes as the UAE economy faces a sluggish property market.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher as tax cut hopes outshine trade fears
summary: US stocks opened higher on Monday as hopes for a new tax cut outweighed fears of an escalating trade war with China. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.29%, the S&P 500 gained 0.34%, and the Nasdaq Composite increased 0.47%. Despite ongoing trade tensions, the market rallied on expectations of a fresh tax cut, pushing stocks to new records.

site_title: The worst is not over for EU integration
summary: The European Union is facing significant challenges, with storm clouds gathering over Brexit, Italy's eurosceptic government, and the growing populist surge in Eastern Europe. European Commission President Jean Claude Juncker warned that the EU's fragile state is increasing, and internal divisions are exposed, particularly on asylum and immigration. The ongoing Brexit negotiations and potential emergency summit in November could determine whether an exit deal is agreed. Additionally, the EU faces threats from rising anti-EU nationalism, weakening pro-European elites, and a new geopolitical reality with assertive Russia and instability in the Middle East and Africa.

site_title: Aston Martin names chairman ahead of October London listing
summary: Aston Martin has named Penny Hughes as its new chairman ahead of its planned October listing on the London Stock Exchange. The luxury sports car manufacturer will have a free float of at least 25% of its issued share capital and is targeting a valuation of £5 billion. The IPO will allow shareholders to cash out with a potential 10-fold return, months before the UK leaves the European Union. Hughes, a former Vodafone and Royal Bank of Scotland director, praised Aston Martin's turnaround, while the company's move to broaden its board with more women is seen as a step towards gender equality.

site_title: Keppel and Salim Group to develop and operate data centre in Indonesia
summary: Keppel Corporation has entered into a conditional agreement with the Salim Group to jointly develop and operate a high-availability data centre in Bogor, Indonesia. The 105,300 sq ft data centre, IndoKeppel Data Centre 1, will be developed in three phases and is expected to be completed by mid-2020. The joint venture will be 60:40 between the Salim Group and Keppel Data Centres, with the Salim Group managing the underlying land plot. This development aims to cater to growing demand for data centre space in Indonesia, with the potential for a larger seven-hectare campus development.

site_title: Changing hands
summary: Singapore's NTT DC Reit's public offer received 9.8 times oversubscription. Meanwhile, US stocks opened lower due to Trump's new tariffs on Canada. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and operating loss similar to H1. London's Heathrow plans to increase fees for its £10b upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a graft case. OCBC's incoming CEO, Tan Teck Long, was a former DBS veteran. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and PBOC agreed to deepen cooperation in green and transition finance.

site_title: Human costs of South African gold
summary: South Africa's gold mining industry has experienced a resurgence in fatalities, with over 50 deaths in 2018, similar to the previous year. Most deaths are caused by rockfalls triggered by frequent tremors as companies dig deeper for gold. The government is investigating Sibanye Gold Ltd, where over half the deaths occurred. The industry faces challenges, including geology, high costs, and competition from cheaper mines abroad. Experts warn that the industry's long-term viability is at risk, and technological advances may be necessary to reduce costs and improve safety.

site_title: Jack Ma to step down in 2019; names successor
summary: Jack Ma, Alibaba's co-founder and CEO, announced his plan to step down as head of the company next year, with Daniel Zhang set to take over. Ma will remain as executive chairman until his 55th birthday and stay on the board until 2020. Analysts say Zhang, who has been running the company's day-to-day operations, may not be as charismatic as Ma but has proven an able steward. Alibaba's business will not be significantly affected, but Ma's departure may test the company's ability to carry on his vision amid rising competition.

site_title: Apollo Global, Bain in early talks to buy UK packager RPC
summary: Apollo Global Management and Bain Capital are in early talks to acquire UK-based RPC Group, a leading plastics packager. RPC shares rose 25% following the announcement. The companies have until October 8 to make a firm offer or walk away. RPC has been under pressure from investors to raise cash and cut spending. This potential sale comes after the company explored strategic options, including a sale, amid declining share prices.

site_title: Sweden faces political impasse as polls reflect broad shift to the right
summary: Sweden's mainstream centre-left and centre-right blocs are in a political impasse after a closely contested election, with the far-right Sweden Democrats making significant gains on an anti-immigration platform. The ruling Social Democrats and Greens secured 40.6% of the vote, while the opposition Alliance held 40.3%. The Sweden Democrats won 17.6% of the vote, surpassing expectations, but fell short of their leader's predicted 20-30% goal. A fragile coalition government may be formed, with the Sweden Democrats demanding a say in policy.

site_title: Proposed changes to election deposit formula and payment methods
summary: Singapore's proposed changes to the election deposit formula and payment methods aim to simplify administration and improve the electoral process. The deposit will be pegged at one month of an MP's allowance, rounded to the nearest S$500, currently S$13,500. Candidates can pay electronically or via bank draft/cheque. Proposed amendments also include allowing only eligible candidates to participate in nominations and suspending proceedings in case of disruptions, with the Returning Officer having up to two hours to assess and decide on next steps.

site_title: EU Parliament holds 'last chance' vote on copyright
summary: The European Parliament is set to vote on a contentious copyright law, which aims to ensure creators of content are paid fairly in a digital world. The law, rejected in July, has been amended to address concerns over internet freedom. Traditional media and content providers, including AFP, support the law, while major US tech giants and online freedom activists oppose it, warning it could lead to censorship. If adopted, the law would make platforms liable for sharing copyrighted material and require news agencies to be paid for linking to their stories.

site_title: Centurion unit buys South Korea's Benikea Hotel for S$16.6m
summary: Centurion Corporation acquired South Korea's Benikea Hotel for S$16.6 million to refurbish it as a 208-bed student accommodation. The property, located in Seoul's Dongdaemun district, will be converted from a three-star hotel. The acquisition marks Centurion's first entry into the North Asia market, with expected earnings contributions by the first quarter of 2019.

site_title: British beef would be "uncompetitive overnight" after no-deal Brexit - food officials
summary: British food, including beef and lamb, would become "uncompetitive overnight" on foreign markets if the UK leaves the EU without a deal, according to food industry representatives. Agricultural tariffs could reach up to 50% under the World Trade Organization, making products like beef and lamb uncompetitive. The UK is due to leave the EU on March 29 without a full exit deal, leaving producers facing heavy tariffs. Industry officials say the UK's "Chequers" plan to accept a common rulebook is the least bad option, but a failure of this plan would lead to significant economic consequences.

site_title: Concrete improvements
summary: Concrete Pan-United has overhauled its dispatch operations, moving from manual, on-site offices to a centralized, paperless command center. The change, implemented in 2014, has improved efficiency, allowing for real-time data analysis and automated order collection. The new system has reduced time and effort, enabling supervisors like Puah Soon Chai to focus on data analysis and customer communication, rather than manual data handling. The centralized command center now handles all 30 of Pan-United's plants, providing a more accurate and timely delivery of concrete.

site_title: Mary Chia re-designates lead ID as non-executive chairman
summary: Mary Chia Holdings' lead independent director, David Yeung, has been appointed as non-executive chairman with immediate effect. Yeung, 69, has over 30 years of experience in public accounting. The re-designation replaces Mary Chia as non-executive chairman, marking a change in leadership for the beauty treatment firm.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks finish with big losses
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted on Monday, with the Hang Seng Index falling 1.33% due to investor concerns over Donald Trump's threat to escalate the US-China trade war. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also declined, with losses of 1.21% and 1.84%, respectively. The losses come as investors await the release of GDP data from Singapore and weigh the impact of US-EU trade talks.

site_title: Datapulse CEO resigns; firm ends plan to buy ICP's hotel unit
summary: Datapulse CEO Wilson Teng has resigned to pursue personal interests, with Lee Kam Seng taking on the interim CEO role. The company also appointed two independent directors, Sin Boon Ann and Loo Cheng Guan, to guide the company on mergers and acquisitions and growth strategies. Datapulse terminated its plan to acquire ICP's hotel unit, citing uncompleted due diligence. The company appointed Morgan Lewis Stamford as its compliance adviser to raise corporate governance and compliance standards, following the resignation of its previous compliance officer.

site_title: Putin ally re-elected Moscow mayor amid mass arrests
summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin's ally, Moscow Mayor Sergei Sobyanin, was re-elected with 70.02% of the vote, despite mass arrests during pension protests. The ruling party, United Russia, suffered its worst performance in regional elections in over a decade, with several regions going to a second round. The pension reform, which aims to raise the state retirement age, was widely unpopular and sparked widespread protests, with over 1,000 people detained, including journalists. Putin thanked voters for participating in the election, saying it demonstrated trust in the authorities.

site_title: Snap strategy officer khan is leaving to start tech investment firm
summary: Snap Inc is losing Chief Strategy Officer Imran Khan, who is leaving to start his own tech investment firm. Khan, one of the few remaining leaders of the team that took the company public in 2017, will remain in his role until a replacement is found. Snap has struggled to grow as expected, with recent losses or replacements of its heads of finance, legal, engineering, product, and sales. Khan recently put a positive spin on the company's direction in a memo to employees.

site_title: ST Engineering appoints new head of US headquarters amid US push
summary: ST Engineering appoints Tom Vecchiolla as head of its US headquarters, VT Systems, amid US expansion efforts. Vecchiolla, with 17 years of private sector and 24 years of public/military experience, replaces John Coburn as president and CEO starting Dec 1, 2018. Coburn remains non-executive chairman. The move aims to capitalize on the US market's growing importance in the company's growth and revenue.

site_title: So now you own a home. Do you know how to maintain it?
summary: First-time homeowners often struggle with basic maintenance skills after the initial excitement of owning a home wears off. Without proper tools and knowledge, simple tasks like hammering nails or fixing leaky faucets can be overwhelming. DIY shows and videos provide inspiration, but lacking fundamental skills and tools can be daunting. To overcome this, homeowners can invest in the right tools and practice basic skills to ensure their home remains well-maintained and secure.

site_title: European stocks steady at open
summary: European stocks remained steady on Monday, with London's FTSE 100 index down 0.1% and Frankfurt's DAX 30 nearly flat. The Paris CAC 40 remained almost unchanged. Markets were influenced by mining and healthcare sectors, while US-EU trade talks were in focus. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: SPH acquires UK student accommodation portfolio for £180.5m, featuring 3,436 beds in six locations. Five entrepreneurs win EY Entrepreneur Of The Year 2018 Singapore awards. A Singapore court orders the return of S$15.3m in 1MDB-linked funds to Malaysia. The Straits Times Index ends lower, down 0.4%, as the daily average value of securities traded on SGX increases 0.3% from July.

images.alt_text: SPH has acquired a portfolio of 14 purpose-built student accommodation buildings across six towns and cities in the UK for a cash consideration of about £180.5 million (S$321 million).

site_title: Crypto wipeout deepens to US$640 billion as ether leads declines
summary: Cryptocurrencies have plummeted to a 10-month low, with the market capitalization shrinking to $197 billion, down about $640 billion from its January peak. Ether, the second-largest virtual currency, slumped 8.9% to $199.05, while Bitcoin lost 2.1% to $6.313.51. US regulators suspended trading in two securities linked to digital assets, and Ethereum co-founder Vitalik Buterin stated that the days of explosive growth in the blockchain industry have likely come and gone.

site_title: Century after winning the vote, British women outnumbered in local govt
summary: Men outnumber women in 97% of local governments in England, despite the 100th anniversary of women's suffrage. Women hold only one in three seats in local councils, according to the Fawcett Society. The group's head, Sam Smethers, described the progress as "disappointing" and "stuck in the past."

site_title: Campbell Soup steps up CEO search, COO a contender: sources
summary: Campbell Soup Co's board is actively searching for a new CEO, with Chief Operating Officer Luca Mignini emerging as a top internal contender. The company's board, facing a proxy challenge from Third Point LLC, is preparing a list of internal and external candidates, with Mark Clouse, CEO of Pinnacle Foods Inc, also being considered. The board's search comes amid a turnaround plan and criticism of the company's lack of succession planning after CEO Denise Morrison's departure in May.

site_title: Crane rental firm MS Holdings plans diversification into South Korean integrated resorts construction
summary: MS Holdings, a crane rental firm, plans to diversify into South Korean integrated resorts construction through a strategic cooperation with LongRunn International Group. The proposed US$80 million project will include a casino amenity, residential complex, and commercial/tourism uses. MS Holdings will issue new shares for an 8% stake in the project, aiming to expand its business and participate in a world-class integrated resort destination, similar to Singapore's Marina Bay Sands.

site_title: Australian shares flat as healthcare, energy gains offset bank and materials losses; NZ down
summary: Australian shares closed flat on Monday, with the S&P/ASX 200 index falling 0.03% due to losses in banks and materials, offset by gains in healthcare and energy stocks. Westpac Banking Corp and National Australia Bank Ltd fell 0.4% and 0.7% respectively, while healthcare stocks rose 0.6% and energy stocks gained 0.8%. The benchmark declined for the eighth straight session, with New Zealand's benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index also dipping 0.5%.

site_title: British air taxi firm takes flight, inspired by F1 racing advances
summary: British entrepreneur Stephen Fitzpatrick's company, Vertical Aerospace, is developing electric Vertical Take Off and Landing (eVTOL) aircraft for short-haul, inter-city flights. Inspired by Formula 1 racing advances, the firm aims to offer piloted, fixed-wing aircraft within four years. With a team of 28 aerospace experts, Vertical plans to target congested air corridors and produce a fixed-wing, multi-passenger version of its eVTOL aircraft. The company is working with regulators to win certification and expand its routes, with a focus on incremental, existing innovations rather than autonomous flying cars.

site_title: Singapore court orders return of S$15m in 1MDB-linked funds to Malaysia
summary: A Singapore court ordered the return of approximately S$15.3 million ($11.1 million) to Malaysia, the first time assets have been repatriated to its neighbor in connection with the 1MDB scandal. The funds were recovered from 1Malaysia Development Berhad and its former subsidiary, SRC International, and will be transferred to a special 1MDB recovery account in Kuala Lumpur.

site_title: Parliament: Private developers may have role in Vers scheme for HDB flats
summary: Singapore's Government is considering involving private developers in the redevelopment of ageing HDB flats through the Voluntary Early Redevelopment Scheme (Vers). Minister Lawrence Wong stated he would study the suggestion, leaving room for private developers to potentially participate. The Vers scheme aims to pace out the redevelopment of old flats over 20 to 30 years.

site_title: China car sales drop as economic woes, US trade war hit buyers
summary: China's car sales declined 7.4% in August to 1.76 million units, marking the third straight month of drop, due to economic woes and the US trade war. The slowdown is attributed to consumers becoming cautious about spending on big-ticket items and pricing uncertainties caused by retaliatory tariffs imposed on US-made cars. SUV sales, which have fueled demand for years, fell 8.5% last month, with shoppers opting for cheaper models amid economic concerns.

site_title: Malaysia: Markets closed on Monday and Tuesday for public holidays
summary: Malaysian financial markets are closed on Monday and Tuesday due to public holidays, resuming trading on Wednesday. In contrast, Singapore stocks have notched a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, while traders are brushing off new US President Trump's threats to extend the rally. Meanwhile, eSIM platform Airalo has raised US$220 million in a new funding round, lifting its valuation past US$1 billion.

site_title: Tokyo's Nikkei snaps six-day losing streak on bargain-hunting
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei index rose 0.30% to 22,373.09, snapping a six-day losing streak, driven by bargain-hunting following recent losses. The broader Topix index also gained 0.20%. Despite this, investors remain cautious due to concerns over the US-China trade war. Major stocks such as Sony and Nintendo rose, while Rohm and Advantest fell. The Dow and Nasdaq in New York also ended down 0.3% on Friday, with worries over the US-China trade war lingering.

site_title: Five win accolades at EY Entrepreneur Of The Year 2018 Singapore awards
summary: Five Singapore entrepreneurs were named category winners in the 2018 EY Entrepreneur Of The Year awards. They are Von Lee (engineering and construction), Jeffrey Tiong (analytics intelligence), Cheong Chia Chou (media and lifestyle), Christopher Ng (sustainable bathroom solutions), and Laurent Junique (outsourced solutions). The winners will be honored at a gala on Oct 26, and one will represent Singapore at the EY World Entrepreneur Of The Year award in 2019. Dr. Stephen Riady and Sing Lun Holdings also received honorary awards.

site_title: Abu Dhabi's Aldar Properties hires banks for US$750m sukuk refinancing - sources
summary: Aldar Properties, a state-linked UAE developer, has hired banks to arrange a US$750 million sukuk issue to refinance an existing Islamic bond. JPMorgan, Standard Chartered, and First Abu Dhabi Bank have been mandated for the deal. The sukuk will replace an existing US$750 million bond due in December, and its size could increase based on demand. This move comes after Aldar reported a 28% fall in second-quarter profit due to a sluggish economy and property market in Abu Dhabi.

site_title: Daily average value of securities traded on SGX up 0.3% in August from July, but down 5% y-o-y
summary: The daily average value of securities traded on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) in August reached S$1.12 billion, a 0.3% increase from July and a 5% decrease from August 2017. Total market turnover was S$23.5 billion, down 4% from July and 9% from August 2017. The market capitalization value of listed companies stood at S$970.24 billion, and 94 new bond listings raised S$32.36 billion in August.

site_title: Saudi royal says jewels stolen at Paris Ritz
summary: A Saudi royal reported the theft of hundreds of thousands of euros' worth of jewelry from her hotel room at the Ritz hotel in Paris. The jewels, valued at 800,000 euros, were not in a safe and there was no sign of forced entry. This is the second reported jewel heist at the hotel this year, following a January incident where an armed gang stole an estimated four million euros' worth of jewels. An investigation has been opened by France's anti-organized crime brigade.

images.alt_text: A member of the Saudi royal family has reported the theft of hundreds of thousands of euros' worth of jewellery from her hotel room at the Ritz hotel in Paris, police sources said Monday.

site_title: Aston Martin adds FTSE experience to its board ahead of IPO
summary: Aston Martin has added experienced FTSE executives to its board ahead of its initial public offering (IPO) on the London Stock Exchange. Penny Hughes, Richard Solomons, Imelda Walsh, and Peter Espenhahn will join the board, bringing expertise from companies such as Vodafone, InterContinental Hotels, and Deloitte. The appointments aim to improve governance and avoid past mistakes, including bankruptcy. The IPO is expected to take place with at least 25% of the stock being floated, and the company forecasts vehicle production of 6,200-6,400 this year and 10,000 in 2020.

site_title: New iPhones aim for momentum in sputtering smartphone market
summary: Apple is set to unveil new iPhones, aiming to gain momentum in the premium smartphone market. The company is expected to introduce three new iPhone models, including an improved version of the iPhone X, and a lower-priced iPhone with some X features. Despite a saturated market, analysts say Apple has a formula that works with a loyal customer base and steady sales. The company's focus on online services and digital content is expected to continue, with a potential redesign of the Apple Watch.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Monday afternoon at 3,118.42, down 0.5% on day
summary: Singapore stocks resumed trading on Monday at 3,118.42, down 0.5% from the previous day, with 934.1 million securities worth S$394.7 million changing hands. The Straits Times Index declined 15.97 points, with losers outnumbering gainers 199 to 93. Meanwhile, Rex International gained 8.3% to S$0.09 with nearly 75 million shares traded.

site_title: Richemont reintroduces CEO role as sales rise
summary: Richemont, the world's second-largest luxury goods group, has reintroduced the CEO role with Jerome Lambert, who will oversee the group's future growth amid changing consumer habits. Lambert, who previously served as chief operating officer, will work with the heads of Cartier, Van Cleef & Arpels, and finance on a senior executive committee. Richemont reported a 10% rise in constant currency sales growth in the five months to August 31, driven by strong sales at its jewelry brands, particularly in Asia Pacific and the Americas, with constant currency sales reaching €5.67 billion.

site_title: Solar farms without subsidy sprout from gloomy Britain to Italy
summary: European countries, particularly Italy and the UK, are witnessing a surge in solar farms built without government subsidies. Developers are profiting from selling power at market rates or through long-term power-purchase agreements (PPAs) with big industrial consumers. This trend is expected to spread to other renewable technologies, such as offshore wind farms, as costs continue to decline. Governments are rolling back subsidies, and investors are becoming more comfortable with the market finding its own solutions, paving the way for a shift towards a subsidy-free renewable energy sector.

site_title: 800 Super's controlling shareholders bought almost S$1m of shares as stock slumped
summary: 800 Super Holdings' controlling shareholders, led by Lee Koh Yong, acquired nearly S$1 million worth of shares in a slump, increasing their stake to 67.63%. The purchases, made on Sept 6 and 7, followed the company's Aug 28 loss of S$1.65 million, which led to a 36.5% decline in the stock price. The stock has since recovered, closing at 86 Singapore cents on Monday. The transactions increased Yong Seong Investment's stake by 0.67 percentage points.

site_title: Parliament: Singapore introduces omnibus bill to update insolvency, debt restructuring laws
summary: Singapore's Parliament has introduced an omnibus bill to update insolvency and debt restructuring laws. The bill consolidates personal and corporate laws, repeals the Bankruptcy Act, and establishes a regulatory regime for insolvency practitioners. It also restricts ipso facto clauses in debt restructuring, aiming to facilitate restructuring for distressed companies. The reforms are the result of industry feedback and previous recommendations from the Insolvency Law Review Committee, with the goal of benefiting local businesses, positioning Singapore as a debt restructuring hub, and creating opportunities for insolvency professionals.

site_title: Japan government sees no rolling blackouts in Hokkaido despite power shortage
summary: The Japanese government has ruled out rolling blackouts in Hokkaido on Monday and Tuesday despite a power shortage due to a recent earthquake. The island has been experiencing power shortages since the earthquake, which killed at least nine people, and trade minister Hiroshige Seko has called on residents to save power by 20% during business hours. Power supplies were restored to nearly all customers after an island-wide blackout, and oil refiner Idemitsu Kosan Co resumed lorry product shipments at its Hokkaido refinery on Saturday.

site_title: Parliament: LTA may allow taxi, private-hire car drivers to do deliveries on limited trial basis
summary: Singapore's Land Transport Authority (LTA) may allow taxi and private-hire car drivers to perform deliveries on a limited trial basis. Senior Minister of State for Transport Janil Puthucheary announced the possibility, stating the LTA will work with operators to assess feasibility and ensure minimal impact on taxi and private-hire car availability. The trial will also safeguard commuter interests, including third-party insurance coverage. This move comes after Amazon previously used taxi and private-hire drivers for deliveries, and the LTA warned against such practices to maintain point-to-point services for commuters.

site_title: Death toll from Japan quake hits 44, power supply, Toyota output disrupted
summary: A powerful 6.7-magnitude earthquake in northern Japan has killed 44 people, injured 660, and disrupted power supply and Toyota production. The quake, which hit on Thursday, paralyzed the island of Hokkaido, cutting off access by air and train, and knocked out power to an island the size of Austria. Nearly all customers in Hokkaido have had their power restored, but residents are being asked to use 20% less energy to prevent further blackouts. Toyota has suspended production at 16 of its 18 domestic car assembly plants, with plans to resume production by Thursday.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks end 3-day losing streak; won falls
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index ended a three-day losing streak, rising 7.09 points or 0.31% to 2,288.67. The won fell 0.5% to 1,128.4 per dollar. Shares in companies related to the Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) and construction companies surged, while bond yields fell. The decline in the won was attributed to investors' skepticism about US tariffs on China. The Kospi index is down 7.5% this year, and the US dollar has risen 5.86% against the won this year.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on Monday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Monday, extending falls on Wall Street, as a higher yen weighed on the market due to concerns over trade issues. The Nikkei 225 index slipped 0.04% to 22,297.67, while the Topix index fell 0.11% to 1,682.52.

site_title: New York City subway station once buried by 9/11 opens again
summary: The Cortlandt subway station in New York City, which was buried under the World Trade Centre site after the 9/11 attacks, has reopened 17 years later. The station, on the Number One line, was rebuilt by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority starting in 2015. The reopening marks the final major piece in the city's rebuilding efforts, coinciding with the anniversary of the 9/11 attacks.

site_title: Indonesia restaurant chain seeks "rupiah warriors" as economic worries grow
summary: Indonesia's restaurant chain Ayam Geprek Juara is offering free meals to customers who exchanged US dollars for the rupiah, amid the currency's weakest levels since the 1998 Asian financial crisis. The move aims to "raise the spirit of love" for the rupiah, as it has shed 9% this year due to rising US interest rates and economic crises in Argentina and Turkey. The government has also implemented measures to cut the country's oil import bill and increase the use of biodiesel, but rising prices of imported goods are expected to affect ordinary Indonesians.

site_title: Chinese soybean futures rise as cold snap hits crops
summary: China's soybean futures rose nearly 5% on Monday, the largest daily gain on record, due to concerns about damage to crops from a cold snap in the northeast. The jump followed news of low temperatures in provinces such as Heilongjiang and Inner Mongolia, which could hurt yields and quality. The move also came after US President Donald Trump warned of tariffs on Chinese imports, further dampening hopes of an end to a trade war. The increase in domestic soybean futures was seen as a sign that China may rely more heavily on its domestic crop due to US tariffs.

site_title: 'Will I come back dead?' The human cost of South African gold
summary: South Africa's gold mining industry has seen a surge in fatalities, with over 50 deaths in 2018, surpassing the number of deaths in 2017.
