The change raises the STI's weightage of Jardine group companies to 15.4%. This move follows a quarterly review of the STI, which also includes consumer goods stocks such as Thai Beverage and Wilmar. Dairy Farm's inclusion will give consumer goods stocks a 6-7% weight on the STI.

site_title: India boosts purchases of Indonesian coal as prices drop
summary: India has boosted its purchases of Indonesian coal as prices drop, defying prior history of being a price-sensitive buyer. The main benchmark for thermal coal in Asia, priced at Australia's Newcastle Port, has gained 11.8% this year to US$114.66 a tonne. However, the price of Indonesia's lower-quality coal has been declining, dropping to US$37.72 a tonne in August. This has led to a rise in Indian imports of Indonesian coal, with 50.4 million tonnes imported in the first eight months of the year, up 10.6% on the same period last year.

site_title: First study on impact of declining HDB leases seen leaving out too many factors
summary: A study by UrbanZoom found that HDB flats would depreciate 0.67% per year over the first four decades as leases run down, but the study has been criticized for ignoring key factors in the Singapore property market. The study assumes a stagnant economy and property market with zero growth, which may not accurately reflect real-world conditions. Experts advise against using the study as a depreciation curve for resale flats.

site_title: Wear and peace
summary: A Singapore-based company, The Mindful Company, has released a new jewellery collection called "Places of Calm" inspired by the city's urban flora. The collection features earrings, necklaces, and bracelets made from 14-karat gold-plated sterling silver, 18-karat rose gold-plated sterling silver, and sterling silver, with semi-precious pearls and stones. The collection is priced from SGD 88 and aims to remind people to appreciate the natural beauty in their surroundings amidst the city's skyscrapers.

site_title: Indonesia's bourse to launch tech segment
summary: Indonesia's stock exchange, the IDX, plans to launch a tech segment in 2019 to host initial public offerings by startups, including ride-hailing giant Go-Jek. The new rules will allow startups to list with up to six years to become profitable, making it easier for them to access funds from local investors. The move aims to boost Indonesia's tech sector, which authorities hope will reach a value of $10 billion by 2020.

site_title: Mercedes-AMG GT R review: Open up and say R!
summary: The Mercedes-AMG GT R is a high-performance sportscar with racing DNA, distinguished by its wide body, carbon fibre roof, and adjustable rear wing. Weighing under 1.6 tonnes, it boasts explosive performance, thanks to its twin-turbo V8 engine producing 585hp and 700Nm of torque. The car's dynamic abilities and rear-steer system provide a "pathological sense of murderous intent" in corners, making it a thrilling drive. With only a few years left before the "Black Series" arrives, the GT R is a limited-edition model that combines driving fun with precision and control.

site_title: Bitcoin extends slump on Goldman Sachs report
summary: Bitcoin plummeted 10% since Wednesday to near a nine-month low, trading at $6,400.74, amid Goldman Sachs' reported suspension of plans to open a bitcoin trading desk due to regulatory uncertainty. Ethereum and ripple also fell by 20% and 10% respectively. The market capitalization of cryptocurrencies dropped around $40 billion in 24 hours. Other large financial firms have pulled back on digital money projects, with bitcoin prices declining this year.

site_title: Singapore shares end lower on Thursday
summary: Singapore shares closed lower on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index down 0.3% to 3,147.69, after a 5-day rally. About 920 million shares changed hands at an average unit price of S$1.08. Losers outnumbered gainers 225 to 142, with ThaiBev being the most actively traded stock, rising 3.2%. The decline follows a 0.4% gain on Thursday, with investors awaiting GDP data and US-EU trade talks.

site_title: Fall /Winter 2018 Trend Report
summary: This Fall/Winter 2018 trend report highlights key fashion elements, including the resurgence of beige, taupe, and chocolate hues, as well as the incorporation of sequins and shine in office attire. The season also sees a rise in utility-inspired coats, Western-themed outerwear, and bold colors. Key designers, such as Erdem Moralioglu and Giorgio Armani, showcase how to balance playfulness with sophistication. The report concludes that indulgent and high-quality pieces, like leather trousers and luxurious coats, are must-haves for the season.

site_title: Parkway Life Reit says Japan facilities unaffected by typhoon, earthquake
summary: Parkway Life Reit, a real estate investment trust, reported that its Japan facilities were unaffected by Typhoon Jebi and a magnitude 6.7 earthquake in Hokkaido. The Reit's Japan asset managers and residents were accounted for with no reported injuries. All properties comply with seismic safety standards and are insured against natural disasters.

site_title: US hiring drops off in August: ADP survey
summary: US companies hired 163,000 workers in August, a drop from July's 217,000, with moderation in manufacturing and services. The slowdown was expected, with the services sector hiring 139,000 and construction, business services, and healthcare seeing notable declines. Employers are struggling to fill open positions, leading to reports of rising wages and worker poaching. The ADP report suggests a potential concern for the Federal Reserve if wage increases become more widespread, potentially pressuring inflation.

site_title: Glencore seeks to grow Brazil fuel distribution unit -Ale CEO
summary: Glencore's acquired Brazilian fuel distribution company Ale Combustíveis SA aims to expand its networks through agreements with unbranded gas stations, without making acquisitions, according to CEO Fulvius Tomelin. The company has idle storage capacity, making acquisitions unnecessary for growth.

site_title: Facebook removes Burmese translation feature after Reuters report
summary: Facebook has removed a Burmese translation feature after a Reuters report showed it produced inaccurate translations, including a post that translated to "I shouldn't have a rainbow in Myanmar" when it read "Kill all the kalars that you see in Myanmar." The feature was switched off on August 28 amid criticism of Facebook's efforts to combat hate speech against Rohingya Muslims in Myanmar. The company is working to improve translation quality and has invested in AI to police posts violating its rules.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: ST Engineering secured a six-year contract worth S$18.8 million to provide engine maintenance services for Jet Airways' Boeing 737NGs. The aerospace company's order wins total S$3 billion for 2018, exceeding its 2017 record. OUE Limited reported a 24.6% decline in profit after tax due to higher finance expenses. Analysts believe OUE may consider divesting its office properties, given the potential for healthy rental reversions and improving sentiment in the central business district office market.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks suffer fresh steep losses
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted 0.99% on Thursday, extending a 2.6% drop from the previous day, amid emerging market crisis and the ongoing China-US trade row. The Hang Seng Index closed at 26,974.82, while the Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indices also declined. Investors sought safety, leading to fresh losses in the region.

site_title: Impatience with Philippine gridlock is growing: Ayala CEO
summary: Philippine companies can fund the country's US$170 billion infrastructure push, according to Ayala Corp CEO Jose Rene Almendras. The private sector has enough resources to fund projects, but the government must choose between lower-cost funding from China or fast-tracking with private sector involvement. Almendras cited the recent Xiamen Airlines plane accident at Manila's airport as a need for immediate upgrade and expansion. With growing impatience over timing, the private sector is ready to prove that projects can be completed faster, Almendras said.

site_title: Ford recalls 2 million trucks to address seat-belt fire concerns
summary: Ford Motor Co. is recalling 2 million F-150 pickup trucks in North America due to concerns over seat-belt fire risks. The issue involves seat-belt pretensioners, which can generate excessive sparks during deployment. The company is aware of 17 reports of smoke or fire in the US and six in Canada, but no injuries have been reported. Ford will address the issue through the recall, which is expected to be completed by the end of the year.

images.alt_text: Ford Motor Co said on Thursday it would recall 2 million F-150 pickup trucks in North America to address fire concerns relating to seat belts that have been linked to three serious incidents but no injuries.

site_title: Fintech firms need more scrutiny by regulators: DBS CEO
summary: DBS Group Holdings CEO Piyush Gupta emphasized the need for increased regulation of non-bank fintech firms, citing Ant Financial as an example of a company that requires oversight. Gupta stated that regulators must consider financial system stability and the consequences of unregulated players in a traditionally regulated industry. He believes that competition with large tech companies, such as Ant Financial and Tencent Holdings, poses a threat to traditional banks, but notes that banks have industry knowledge, infrastructure, and risk management capabilities that will help them survive the digital revolution.

site_title: US: Wall St opens flat as trade worries linger
summary: US stocks opened flat on Thursday, weighed down by concerns about potential China tariffs and a drop in energy stocks. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 1.97 points, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite opened higher, with the Nasdaq gaining 3.10 points. Despite this, the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged to fresh records, showing resilience in the face of trade uncertainty.

site_title: India's Supreme Court legalises gay sex in landmark ruling
summary: India's Supreme Court has legalized gay sex in a landmark decision, partially striking down a 158-year-old colonial-era law. The court's five-judge bench diluted Section 377 of the Indian Penal Code, which previously outlawed gay sex, bestiality, and other non-traditional relationships. This ruling is a significant milestone for LGBTQ+ rights in the world's second-most populous country, following a decades-long legal battle.

site_title: Toby Koh
summary: Toby Koh, managing director of Ademco, is a security expert with over 30 years of experience in the industry. Ademco, a major player in Asia, provides fire- and intruder-detection systems to keep people and places safe. Founded by Koh's father in the 1980s, the company has evolved to include command centre monitoring, security alarm systems, and biometric readers. With 65% market share in Singapore, Ademco has revolutionized traditional security ideas by introducing technology-based solutions, such as autonomous robot guards and AI-powered facial recognition. Koh emphasizes the importance of a balanced approach to security, highlighting the need for a visible deterrent and careful consideration of data privacy.

images.alt_text: ''I personally think that there is no such thing as ''too much'' security... There are still drive-by shootings in Hong Kong and parang attacks in Malaysia.'' - Toby Koh.

site_title: Ascendas Reit launches private placement to raise at least S$450 million
summary: Ascendas Reit plans to raise at least S$450 million through a private placement of 178 million new units at an issue price of between S$2.528 and S$2.606 per unit. The funds will partially fund a UK logistics portfolio acquisition, a build-to-suit facility in Singapore, and debt repayment and future acquisitions. Existing unit holders will receive an advanced distribution of 7.25 Singapore cents. The placement, fully underwritten by DBS and JP Morgan, is expected to increase the total number of units by 6.1% and be listed on September 18.

site_title: CGS-CIMB issues 'add' call on Synagie
summary: CGS-CIMB has initiated coverage on Synagie Corporation with an "add" call, targeting S$0.34. The brokerage believes Synagie, an e-commerce services provider to over 250 fast-moving consumer goods brands, will ride the wave of e-commerce growth. Synagie listed on the Singapore Exchange's Catalist board on Aug 8 and primarily serves clients in the body, beauty, and baby (BBB) sector.

site_title: Fugitive jewellers rob Indian business of trade-pricing edge
summary: India's trade may be affected by the US$2 billion fraud orchestrated by fugitive jewellers Nirav Modi and Mehul Choksi, who used fake Letters of Undertaking (LOUs) to obtain loans. The central bank's ban on LOUs has eroded margins and competitiveness for smaller enterprises, causing the cost of funds for exporters and importers to rise. Total gems and jewellery exports fell by 1.5% in the April-July period, while imports of precious stones dropped by 19.5%. A parliamentary panel has sought restoration of the trade finance tool with safeguards, citing risks for cost competitiveness and job losses.

site_title: Transocean to buy rival for US$2.9b to add drillships
summary: Transocean Ltd, the world's largest offshore drilling company, agreed to buy Ocean Rig UDW Inc for US$2.9 billion, gaining a fleet of nine ultra-deepwater drillships and two harsh environment semisubmersibles. The acquisition will boost Transocean's deepwater rig rates, expected to double in two years. The deal comes as the offshore oil drilling industry recovers from the price slump, with major oil companies canceling offshore projects and the US shale industry's resurgence.

site_title: It's about time: eBay now authenticates luxury watches
summary: eBay has expanded its Authenticate programme to include luxury watch brands, offering buyers an authenticated selection of over 30 brands, including Rolex, Omega, and Panerai. The programme, launched in 2017 for luxury handbags, verifies authenticity and includes new, vintage, and pre-owned watches. Sellers must submit watches for verification, and eBay will list and ship authentic items, while returning non-authentic ones. The programme aims to increase trust in high-value purchases and is expected to grow to feature over 10,000 luxury timepieces in the coming weeks.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Facebook plans to build its first data centre in Asia, valued at S$1.4 billion, in Singapore. The company will support hundreds of jobs and expand its presence in the region. Meanwhile, GIC sees buying opportunities in emerging markets amid market volatility. The Monetary Authority of Singapore proposes legally-binding cyber security measures for financial institutions. Fintech firms need more scrutiny from regulators, according to DBS chief Piyush Gupta. Singapore shares ended lower on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index down 0.3%.

site_title: US Q2 productivity growth unrevised at 2.9%
summary: US worker productivity rose at a 2.9% annualized rate in the second quarter, the strongest pace since 2015. The Labor Department reported moderate growth, surpassing economists' forecasts. Productivity growth remained unsustainable, with unit labor costs falling at a 1.0% pace, the weakest since 2014. The trend suggests moderate wage inflation, with labor costs increasing at a 1.9% rate compared to the second quarter of 2017.

site_title: Hong Kong passes New York as home to the most ultra-rich people
summary: Hong Kong has surpassed New York as the city with the highest population of people worth at least $30 million, according to a report by Wealth-X. The number of ultra-rich worldwide increased 13% last year, totaling about 256,000 people with $31.5 trillion in combined assets. Asia saw the fastest growth, driven by mainland China and Hong Kong, which now accounts for over one-fourth of the global ultra-wealth population. Hong Kong's rise is attributed to China's improving fortunes and enhanced trade links with the mainland.

site_title: World's biggest car markets reach end of the road
summary: Major carmakers saw declining US deliveries in July, with the annualised industry sales rate slowing to the lowest in a year. This trend is expected to continue, with demand peaking and potentially dwindling without higher sales incentives. Other countries, including China and Japan, also reported declining sales due to economic weakening and trade tensions. In Europe, while overall sales are up, the four largest markets saw zero growth in the first six months of the year, with some warning of further declines. Demand appears to be reaching its end of the road for growth.

site_title: YuuZoo subsidiary initiates judicial recovery proceedings in France
summary: YuuZoo's subsidiary, YuuLog France, has initiated judicial recovery proceedings in France despite being solvent. The move comes after the subsidiary lost several major customers, impacting its operations. YuuLog France had requested a cash injection from YuuZoo, but trading in the parent company's shares has been suspended. The judicial recovery proceedings will assess the subsidiary's financial position and assist in its management over a six-month period.

site_title: MAS proposes legally-binding cyber security measures for all Singapore financial institutions
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has proposed making six essential cyber security measures legally binding for all financial institutions in Singapore. The measures aim to protect IT systems from cyber attacks, including addressing system security flaws, deploying security devices, and restricting system administrator accounts. The move follows a major data breach at SingHealth and aims to enhance the security of financial institutions' systems and networks. A public consultation on the proposed measures will run from September 6 to October 5.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close lower after quake
summary: Tokyo stocks closed lower on September 6, 2018, after a big earthquake in northern Japan, with the Nikkei index down 0.41% and the Topix index down 0.74%. Investors retreated to look for fresh trading pegs, amid reports of damage.

site_title: Rare movie memorabilia on show for London auction
summary: Rare movie memorabilia from films like "The Empire Strikes Back" and "Back To The Future Part II" is on display in London ahead of an auction on September 20. Over 600 props and costumes, including Han Solo's jacket and Indiana Jones' signature hat, will be sold by the hammer. Viewers can see around a third of the items at the BFI IMAX complex before bidding. The auction features unique lots, including Marty McFly's hoverboard, and will take place later this month in the British capital.

site_title: Facebook to build its first data centre in Singapore
summary: Facebook plans to build its first data centre in Singapore, valued at S$1.4 billion, with construction set to begin in 2022. The 170,000 square metre facility will support hundreds of jobs and is part of the company's growing presence in the region. Singapore's robust infrastructure, access to fibre, and local workforce made it an attractive location. The data centre will incorporate the StatePoint Liquid Cooling system, reducing water and power consumption by 20%. The project is seen as a milestone in land utilisation and energy consumption.

site_title: Australian, NZ shares slide as trade tensions rattle investors
summary: Australian shares slid 1.1% on Thursday, posting the largest one-day loss in six months, due to concerns over emerging markets turmoil, global trade tensions, and local banking sector woes. The S&P/ASX 200 index fell to a two-month low and its worst one-day percentage decline since March. Investors are cautious and in a risk-off mode, with traders citing escalating trade disputes as a major concern.

site_title: China may face wider bans on pork as deadly pig virus spreads
summary: China may face wider bans on pork products as African swine fever spreads globally. The Food and Agriculture Organization recommends emergency measures to control the deadly pig virus, which can be 100% fatal to pigs. The virus is believed to have been introduced to China through contaminated food, and researchers warn of a "steep hill ahead" in controlling its spread. The Philippines has already ordered a temporary ban on pork products from China, Russia, and four European countries, and more nations may follow.

site_title: India's Supreme Court legalizes gay sex in landmark ruling
summary: India's Supreme Court has legalized gay sex in the country, partially striking down a 158-year-old colonial-era law. The landmark decision, made on September 6, 2018, dilutes Section 377 of the Indian Penal Code, which was enacted in 1860. The ruling, which came after decades of legal battles, prevents discrimination of gay employees and their partners in India, where activists say members of the LGBTQ community are singled out and blackmailed. The decision is seen as a step towards greater equality and brings India closer to other jurisdictions across Asia.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 3.07 points to 1,798.57, closing higher on Thursday. Volume reached 2 billion lots worth RM1.9 billion, with losers outnumbering gainers 553 to 297.

site_title: Manager of RHT Health Trust sells units to Fortis subsidiary
summary: The manager of RHT Health Trust sold 1.5 million units to Fortis Healthcare International at S$0.78 per unit, resulting in a 0.19% decrease in the manager's stake from 2.87% to 2.68%. The sale does not change Fortis Healthcare's total interest in RHT Health Trust, which remains at 27.82%. Units in the trust closed unchanged at S$0.755.

site_title: Fintech firms need more scrutiny by regulators, says DBS chief
summary: DBS Group Holdings CEO Piyush Gupta emphasizes the need for increased regulation of non-bank firms in the financial industry, citing the threat posed by fintech companies such as Ant Financial and Tencent Holdings. Gupta argues that these companies, which operate like banks, require oversight to maintain financial system stability. He believes that regulators must adapt to the changing landscape and take a more proactive approach in regulating these firms. Gupta also notes that traditional banks, despite their challenges, will not disappear due to their industry knowledge and risk management capabilities.

site_title: Thousands to feast royally to fete Thai cave boys' dramatic rescue
summary: Thousands of Thais will attend a government-sponsored dinner in Bangkok to celebrate the rescue of 12 boys and their soccer coach from a flooded Thai cave on July 10, 2018. The dinner, sponsored by King Maha Vajiralongkorn, will honor the rescuers and guests of honor, including foreign divers and cavers. The team, known as the "Wild Boars," had spent nine days trapped in the cave before being rescued, and had since resumed their routines, with one member still paying respects to a Thai rescuer who died during the mission.

site_title: Impatience with Philippine gridlocks is growing, says Ayala CEO
summary: Philippine companies, including Ayala Corp, can fund the country's $170 billion infrastructure push, while China's pledges are taking time, according to Ayala CEO Jose Rene Almendras. The private sector has sufficient resources to fund projects, and the government must decide between lower-cost funding from China or fast-tracking with private sector involvement. Ayala is part of a consortium proposing to modernize Manila's overcrowded airport, which it can complete faster than the government's proposed $14 billion project. Inadequate infrastructure remains the Philippines' biggest challenge, stifling economic growth if not addressed.

site_title: StarHub to be dropped from STI, replaced by Dairy Farm
summary: Dairy Farm will replace StarHub in the Straits Times Index (STI) starting Sept 24, with a 1-1.5% weightage. The Jardine group's weightage in the STI will increase to 15.4%, with Dairy Farm generating a 24.2% total return in the first 8 months of 2018. This change aims to give consumer goods stocks a 6-7% weight on the STI, with Thai Beverage, Wilmar, and Golden Agri-Resources also included. StarHub's CEO, Jeannie Ong, remains optimistic, stating that the company will work to regain investor confidence.

site_title: China warns of retaliation if US slaps new tariffs
summary: China's commerce ministry warned that it will retaliate with tariffs if the US implements new measures, amid an intensifying trade war between the two economies. US President Donald Trump threatened fresh tariffs on $200 billion in Chinese imports, which China vowed to counter with its own measures. The US has already imposed tariffs on $50 billion of Chinese goods, prompting China to retaliate with its own $60 billion list. The escalating trade dispute has raised concerns about its impact on global growth and business investment.

site_title: Lazada Singapore's Hari Vijayarajan moves to ONE Championship
summary: Hari Vijayarajan, Lazada Singapore's chief business officer, is moving to ONE Championship as its new chief business development officer. He will help scale and grow the martial arts organization across key markets. ONE Championship's chairman and CEO, Chatri Sityodtong, expects Vijayarajan to work with the leadership team to make the organization a multibillion-dollar global sports media property.

site_title: Asia: Investors fight to recover after emerging market rout
summary: Asian markets experienced a mixed day on September 5, 2018, amid concerns about emerging market contagion and US-China trade tensions. Despite some currencies experiencing a brief recovery, investors remain cautious, with warnings of further market pain to come. The Dow edged up, while the Nasdaq took a hit from tech firm sell-offs. Global markets await the outcome of US trade talks and the potential for further tariffs on China.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks, won tumble on trade anxiety
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index and the won fell due to emerging market turmoil and US-China trade war concerns. The Kospi closed 0.18% lower at 2,287.62. Hyundai Motor Group shares rose, with Hyundai Motor Co, Kia Motors, Hyundai Glovis, and Hyundai Mobis increasing 3.9%, 4.5%, 6.3%, and 2.2%, respectively.

site_title: Europe: Shares hit five-month low as tariff woes loom
summary: European shares fell to a five-month low on Thursday as investors awaited a decision on US tariffs on China, which could impact global trade. The STOXX 600 benchmark dropped 0.3% amid concerns over emerging markets and the ongoing US-China trade tensions. A consultation period on additional tariffs on China ended, paving the way for a potential decision, which could further weigh on the market.

site_title: Britain's web of cameras catches clues in poisoning
summary: British investigators used a vast network of surveillance cameras to identify two Russian intelligence officers charged with attempted murder over the poisoning of former Russian spy Sergei Skripal in March 2018. The cameras, combined with advanced software and a team of "super-recognisers" who can identify individuals by their faces, helped narrow down the suspects to Alexander Petrov and Ruslan Boshirov. The evidence, including security footage and perfume bottle images, led to the issuance of arrest warrants and charges against the two men, who were accused of using a nerve agent in the attack.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Thursday afternoon at 3,149.56, down 0.2% on day
summary: Singapore stocks resumed trading Thursday at 3,149.56, down 0.2% on the day, with about 450 million shares changing hands. Losers outnumbered gainers 156 to 120. The Straits Times Index was influenced by the decline in ThaiBev, which fell 1.6% to S$0.645, despite its competitor's 2.4% gain.

site_title: SembMarine bags contract to retrofit 13 ships from Maran Tankers
summary: SembMarine has secured a contract from Maran Tankers to retrofit 13 ships with marine scrubbers and ballast water management systems. The contract, valued but not disclosed, involves installing scrubbers on four Suezmax tankers and nine Very Large Crude Carriers between 2018 and 2020. The installations will take place at SembMarine's yards. The company has now outfitted a total of four marine scrubbers and 23 ballast water management systems for its customers, including major shipping firms.

site_title: HDB resale prices inch up 0.1% in August; volume drops 18.6%: SRX
summary: HDB resale prices rose 0.1% in August, marking the first full month since cooling measures took effect in July. However, prices remain down 1.7% from August last year and 13.5% since April 2013. Resale flat sales dropped 18.6% to 2,076 units, with prices varying by flat type and location. Median Transaction Over X-Value (TOX) showed buyers overpaying in some areas, such as Kallang and Whampoa, and underpaying in others, like Ang Mo Kio and Toa Payoh.

site_title: Novartis sells parts of Sandoz US to India's Aurobindo for US$900m
summary: Novartis AG has agreed to sell its dermatology and generic US oral solids portfolios of Sandoz US to India's Aurobindo Pharma Ltd for US$900 million. The deal includes 300 products and additional development projects, with an additional US$100 million in performance-based payments. The sale is part of Novartis' strategy to focus on higher growth areas. Aurobindo's shares rose over 5% on the news, while Novartis' stock remained unchanged.

site_title: Japan's Kansai airport to reopen partially after typhoon damage
summary: Japan's Kansai airport will partially reopen on Friday after being damaged by Typhoon Jebi, which made landfall Tuesday as the strongest storm to hit Japan since 1993. The airport, which was battered by waves and flooded runways, will resume domestic flights on Friday and international flights as soon as preparation work is completed. Thousands of passengers and staff were stranded after the typhoon and tanker collision damaged the only bridge connecting the airport to the mainland, stranding them by boat and bus. The airport is a major hub for flights, and the disruption could impact tourism and business in the region.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks extend losses at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted at the open on Thursday, with the Hang Seng Index shedding 0.64% and the Shanghai Composite Index losing 0.25%. Investors are concerned about US sanctions on Chinese imports, fueling emerging market fears. The losses come as global markets remain uncertain due to US trade tensions and the Federal Reserve's split views on interest rates.

site_title: Harvard doctors backed by Li Ka-shing try a fix for cancer care
summary: A pair of Harvard-trained oncologists, backed by Hong Kong billionaire Li Ka-shing, are developing a technology platform called Driver to revamp cancer care in China. The platform analyzes patient tumors and DNA records to match patients with the best treatments and clinical trials globally. With a $100 million investment, Driver aims to address the shortage of specialized cancer treatment in China, where patients often travel long distances to top hospitals. The platform has partnered with the National Cancer Center in Beijing and the US government's National Cancer Institute, and plans to formally sign up patients this week.

site_title: Keppel wins initial design contract for cooling system plant in Jurong Innovation District
summary: Keppel Corp's infrastructure arm, Keppel DHCS, won a S$275,000 contract for the initial design phase of a district cooling system plant in Jurong Innovation District. The plant, set to be completed by 2021, will supply chilled water to a 28-hectare area and has a capacity of up to 14,000 refrigeration tonnes. The contract does not affect Keppel's earnings per share and net tangible asset per share for the current financial year, with shares down 0.47% on the day. A final contract for the project, worth up to S$1.2 billion, may be awarded in the future.

site_title: Tech jobs with soft skills fastest-growing in Singapore: Linkedin
summary: Singapore's top emerging jobs in tech include data scientist, cyber security specialist, user experience designer, and head of digital and content specialist, growing at rates of 17, 5.5, 3.4, and 3 times respectively between 2013 and 2017. These roles require a mix of technical and soft skills, such as management and communication. The majority of talent pool for these roles comes from overseas, with the largest percentages coming from India, France, Australia, and the UK.

images.alt_text: Jobs in technology that also require management and communication skills are growing the fastest in Singapore but the talent shortage is driving hiring from overseas, a Linkedin report revealed.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on Thursday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Thursday due to investors retreating to the sidelines amid the aftermath of a big earthquake in northern Japan. The benchmark Nikkei index fell 0.58% to 22,449.38, while the Topix index declined 0.52% to 1,696.06.

site_title: Starbucks finally opens cafe in Italy, home of espresso
summary: Starbucks has opened its first cafe in Italy, a move seen as a significant step in the US coffee giant's expansion into the country's coffee culture. The Milan "roastery" aims to offer a unique coffee experience, targeting millennials, while also acknowledging the traditional Italian approach to coffee. Analysts believe that Starbucks' entry into the market may initially face resistance, but could eventually gain traction among younger generations who value specialty coffees. The company's Reserve Roastery is seen as a major attraction, with a 2,300-square-metre space offering a new coffee experience.

images.alt_text: US coffee giant Starbucks opens its first branch in Italy on Thursday, with the sprawling Milan 'roastery' at the avant garde of an ambitious plan to conquer the spiritual home of espresso.

site_title: CapitaLand is top real estate developer again
summary: CapitaLand has been recognized as the top real estate developer in Singapore for the second consecutive year in the Euromoney Real Estate Survey 2018. This marks the company's success in the real estate sector worldwide.

site_title: Broker's take: CGS-CIMB initiates coverage on Synagie, issues 'add' with S$0.34 target price
summary: Brokerage CGS-CIMB has initiated coverage on Synagie Corporation with an "add" call and a target price of S$0.34, citing e-commerce growth and expansion into new product categories. The analyst, Colin Tan, expects Synagie to become profitable by FY2020 despite current loss-making status. The company provides e-commerce services to over 250 fast-moving consumer goods brands, primarily in the body, beauty, and baby sector, with a compound annual growth rate of 551.8% from FY2015 to FY2017.

site_title: Why a stronger Indonesia is still Asia's most fragile market
summary: Indonesia, despite solid economic growth, remains vulnerable due to a mix of longstanding and new factors, including its high-yielding bond market, trade deficit, and current-account issues. The country's currency, rupiah, has lost nearly 9% this year, making it Asia's biggest loser against the dollar. Indonesia's stock market is also underperforming, with losses of over 10% in 2018. The government's efforts to address these issues, including imposing tariffs and raising interest rates, may have negative implications on consumer demand and growth.

images.alt_text: Notwithstanding solid economic growth, low inflation and a proactive central bank, Indonesia finds itself in the same uncomfortable position it had during the 2013 emerging markets sell-off - Asia's worst-hit market.

site_title: Malaysia shares open higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened higher on Thursday, rising 0.29 points to 1,795.79. Gainers outnumbered losers 82 to 65, with a total volume of 31.17 million lots worth RM9.65 million.

site_title: Mobile rewards platform Fave raises US$20m in Series B funding
summary: Mobile rewards platform Fave has raised over US$20 million in its Series B funding round from Sequoia Capital India, SIG Asia Investments, and Venturra Capital. This funding round follows its US$12 million Series A funding in 2016. Fave is the rebranded Groupon Singapore, acquired by the Malaysia-based Fave Group last year.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Manhattan Resources, Mapletree Industrial Trust, Federal International (2000)
summary: Manhattan Resources proposes a non-underwritten one-to-one renounceable rights issue at 2.45 Singapore cents per share to raise S$13.73 million. Mapletree Industrial Trust launches a S$2 billion euro medium term note programme. Federal International (2000) wins contracts totaling US$7.3 million in Indonesia.

site_title: Mapletree Industrial Trust sets up S$2b euro medium term notes
summary: Mapletree Industrial Trust (MIT) has launched a S$2 billion euro medium term note programme, with DBS Bank and OCBC Bank as joint arrangers and dealers. The net proceeds will be used for general corporate purposes. MIT closed flat at S$2.01.

site_title: Australia's Telstra Corp trims fiscal 2019 core earnings outlook
summary: Telstra Corp Ltd, Australia's largest telecom firm, trimmed its fiscal 2019 core earnings outlook due to differences in the National Broadband Network (NBN) rollout and migration. The company now expects core earnings between A$8.7 billion and A$9.4 billion, slightly lower than its previous range of A$8.8 billion to A$9.5 billion.

site_title: Landslides after powerful 6.6 magnitude quake hits Japan's Hokkaido
summary: A 6.6-magnitude earthquake struck Japan's Hokkaido, triggering landslides, collapsing homes, and killing at least one person with several others missing. The quake, which was followed by multiple aftershocks, also left over 110 people with minor injuries and caused widespread power outages. Prime Minister Shinzo Abe dispatched 4,000 Self-Defence Forces troops to assist in recovery efforts, with 25,000 more expected to join. The government prioritizes saving human lives while working towards reconstruction, with officials urging residents to remain vigilant for further quakes and updates.

site_title: GIC chief sees buying opportunity amid emerging market rout
summary: GIC chief executive Lim Chow Kiat sees buying opportunities in emerging markets amid the current rout, citing "idiosyncratic" factors driving market volatility. He notes that some emerging markets have taken corrective measures to strengthen fundamentals, and valuations are now offering opportunities despite overall strong economic growth expectations. Lim views the current market conditions as a "window of opportunity" and believes that the value will emerge over time, attracting international capital back into the region.

site_title: Ten people on board Emirates treated in New York hospital
summary: Ten people on board an Emirates flight from Dubai to New York were taken to a hospital in New York after falling ill during a 14-hour flight. US health authorities were notified and a team from the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention boarded the aircraft to evaluate the situation. Three passengers and seven crew members were transferred to hospital for further medical care and evaluation, with symptoms suggesting the flu. The return flight was delayed by approximately three hours.

site_title: Two Koreas agree to hold September summit in Pyongyang: Seoul
summary: North Korean leader Kim Jong Un and South Korean President Moon Jae In agreed to hold a summit in Pyongyang from September 18 to 20 to discuss nuclear disarmament. The third meeting between the two leaders will focus on "practical measures" to denuclearize the peninsula. South Korean envoy Chung Eui Yong delivered a letter from President Moon to Kim in Pyongyang, paving the way for the summit. This marks the third meeting between the two leaders, following previous summits in 2018 and 2019.

images.alt_text: North Korean leader Kim Jong Un (left) will meet with the South's President Moon Jae In in a summit in Pyongyang from September 18 to 20 to discuss nuclear disarmament, Seoul said Thursday.

site_title: BOJ's Kataoka urges more stimulus, criticises bank's flexible bond yield plan
summary: Bank of Japan board member Goushi Kataoka criticized the central bank's decision to make its policy framework more sustainable, arguing it should have increased stimulus to achieve its price target. Kataoka warned escalating trade frictions could slow global economic expansion next year, particularly for Japan's export-reliant economy. He emphasized the need for "no room for complacency" amidst intensifying global trade frictions.

site_title: Philippines to gradually boost reserves that's at 6-year low
summary: The Philippine central bank plans to gradually boost its foreign-exchange reserves, currently at a six-year low of $76.7 billion, as the year-end overseas remittance season approaches. Deputy Governor Diwa Guinigundo stated that the bank will be opportunistic in buying foreign exchange, aiming to rebuild its reserves without affecting the market-determined exchange rate. This move comes as other Asian countries, such as Indonesia and India, also drain their reserves due to currency slumps. The goal is to maintain a reserve level of 7.5 times the nation's overseas purchases, preventing a decline to the minimum 3 times import cover.

site_title: ExxonMobil signs deal to build petchem plant, LNG terminal in China: state media
summary: ExxonMobil has signed a deal to build a petrochemical complex and LNG terminal in southern China, marking the company's first investment in LNG infrastructure in the country. The $10 billion project is part of China's efforts to increase access to its massive chemicals market and reduce its reliance on coal. Exxon's plan comes after a similar agreement by BASF to build a $10 billion plant in Guangdong province, and is seen as a significant move by the US oil major to tap into China's growing demand for chemicals and energy.

site_title: Singapore shares open flat on Thursday; STI down 0.01% to 3,156
summary: Singapore stocks opened flat on Thursday, retreating 0.28 point to 3,156. The Straits Times Index (STI) had a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data. Gainers outnumbered losers 56 to 48, with 37.6 million shares worth S$117.2 million changing hands. US markets saw the Nasdaq fall 1% overnight due to tech stocks, while the Justice Department announced it would discuss social media platform concerns with state attorneys general.

site_title: Indonesia raises import taxes on 1,000-plus goods to support rupiah
summary: Indonesia's finance minister, Sri Mulyani Indrawati, announced plans to raise import taxes on over 1,000 goods, including cosmetics and cars, to 7.5% from 2.5% to support a weak rupiah and cut imports. The measures aim to reduce the country's reliance on imports and stabilize the currency.

site_title: Japan 'confirms first Fukushima worker death from radiation'
summary: Japan has confirmed its first worker death from radiation exposure at the Fukushima nuclear plant. A 50-year-old man who worked at the plant between 1980 and 2011 died from lung cancer in 2016, after being exposed to radiation during emergency work following the 2011 tsunami. This is the first time the government has acknowledged a death related to radiation exposure at the plant, with previous cases involving compensation for cancer contracted by workers.

site_title: British Navy warship sails near Beijing-claimed South China Sea islands: sources
summary: A British Royal Navy warship, HMS Albion, sailed near the Paracel Islands in the South China Sea, asserting "freedom of navigation" rights and challenging Beijing's "excessive claims" in the region. The 22,000-tonne amphibious warship passed by the islands, demonstrating Britain's recognition of international law and norms. The encounter was calm, with China dispatching a frigate and helicopters to challenge the British vessel, but both sides remained calm. The British Navy's action comes after the US Navy has conducted similar operations, with Britain and the US seeking to promote international participation in freedom of navigation operations.

images.alt_text: A British Royal Navy warship sailed close to islands claimed by China in the South China Sea as it headed towards Vietnam, asserting "freedom of navigation" rights and challenging Beijing's "excessive claims" in the region, two sources said.

site_title: Venezuela breaks monthly inflation record, opposition says
summary: Venezuela's inflation rate broke the 200% barrier for a single month in August, reaching 200,000% over the last year, according to the opposition-controlled parliament. This marks a significant increase from just two months ago, when prices had passed 100% for the first time. The International Monetary Fund had previously predicted inflation would reach 1 million% in 2018. The country's economic crisis, caused by the government's reckless printing of money, has led to widespread shortages and hyperinflation, with 1.6 million Venezuelans fleeing the country since 2015.

site_title: AmEx probed in US on forex pricing: source
summary: US officials are investigating American Express over allegations that the company misrepresented foreign exchange pricing to business clients, potentially boosting company revenues and commissions. The practice allegedly occurred since 2004, according to reports. American Express has denied the allegations, stating it believes its transactions are completed and reported in a fair and transparent manner. The company is conducting a review and will take "appropriate actions" if the allegations are found to be true.

site_title: How to dress the crazy rich part
summary: The article "How to dress the crazy rich part" from Weekend magazine discusses the style of wealthy individuals in Singapore, as seen in the movie Crazy Rich Asians. It provides tips on dressing like the "old money" and offers style ideas for the Fall/Winter Fashion Report 2018. To protect valuable ensembles, security expert Toby Koh shares advice on securing homes and belongings. The article also recommends new dining and cultural options in town, including a posh burger joint and the National Gallery's exhibit on Wu Guangzhong's writings.

site_title: Germany readies for all Brexit options, including no-deal
summary: Germany's government is preparing for all Brexit scenarios, including a no-deal, after its cabinet approved a draft law on a transition phase for Britain after it leaves the EU next year. Chancellor Angela Merkel's government will continue to negotiate with Britain, but has full trust in EU chief Brexit negotiator Michel Barnier. Germany has abandoned key Brexit demands and is considering all possible outcomes, including hiring new customs staff. A transition phase would give institutions and companies time to adjust to the reality of ending decades of integration with the EU.

site_title: Exit offer for Europtronic Group lapses; to consult SGX on delisting date
summary: The exit offer for Europtronic Group, a Singapore-based electronic components manufacturer, has lapsed. Despite receiving 320.05 million shares, representing 33.91% of issued shares, Project Goodwill Pte Ltd, the offeror, fell short of the 50% threshold. Europtronic Group will now consult the Singapore Exchange on the delisting date. As a result, the company's shares will remain listed. The offeror, Project Goodwill, now owns 49.81% of the company.

site_title: Facebook to build S$1.4b data centre in Singapore, its first in Asia
summary: Facebook plans to build a $1.4 billion data centre in Singapore, its first in Asia and 15th globally, with operations expected to start in 2022. The facility will support hundreds of jobs and contribute to the company's growing presence in the region. Located in Tanjong Kling, construction will continue after the initial start-up phase. This move aims to solidify Facebook's position in the Asian market and support its growing technology operations.

site_title: Internet firms in 'arms race' to defend democracy: Zuckerberg
summary: Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg stated that internet firms, including his own company, are in an "arms race" to defend democracy. This comes ahead of congressional hearings where executives from Facebook and Twitter will face questioning. Zuckerberg's comments reflect the growing concern over the role of social media in shaping democratic processes. The "arms race" implies a heightened focus on combating misinformation, improving content moderation, and enhancing user safety to protect democracy.

site_title: 2 Amoy St shophouses up for sale
summary: A pair of four-storey conservation shophouses at 87 and 88 Amoy Street in Singapore's Chinatown Conservation Area have been launched for sale via public tender. The guide price is S$3,415 psf or S$50m over a 14,641 sq ft gross floor area. The property, with a combined land area of 5,375 sq ft, features a passenger lift, reinforced concrete staircases, and a 14m-long road frontage. It is within walking distance to Tanjong Pagar and Telok Ayer MRT Stations and has full occupancy, with immediate rental income from a health and fitness group, multinational corporation, shipping company, and hospitality group.

site_title: Tourism board appoints new chief executive
summary: The Singapore Tourism Board (STB) appointed Keith Tan Kean Loong as its new chief executive, effective October 29. Tan, currently deputy secretary at the Ministry of Defence, will replace the previous chief executive.

site_title: Sustainable investing and the millennial investor
summary: Millennial investors are increasingly adopting sustainable investing strategies, driven by growing social and environmental concerns. Asia's infrastructure gap, driven by demographic change, urbanization, and climate change, is prompting governments and companies to prioritize sustainable development. Retail and institutional investors are allocating more portfolios to sustainable investing, with a focus on environmental and social factors. Infrastructure development and sustainable investing pose challenges, requiring upfront consideration of environmental and social risks. Governments and companies are structuring products and projects to cater to sustainable investors, with the development of green projects bonds and climate-resilient infrastructure expected to increase.

site_title: Brazil's museum fire is a global tragedy
summary: A devastating fire destroyed approximately 90% of Brazil's National Museum in Rio de Janeiro, resulting in the loss of about 20 million objects, including ancient artifacts, dinosaur bones, and indigenous languages recordings. The blaze, which was likely caused by a paper balloon or short circuit, also destroyed the museum's 5 million arthropod specimens and priceless collections. The loss is seen as a cultural tragedy, with many considering it a modern-day equivalent to the burning of the Library of Alexandria, and has sparked protests against the government's austerity measures and spending cuts.

site_title: Anonymous official says Trump staff working against 'amoral' president
summary: A senior White House official, who remains anonymous, claims that top staff members are working to undermine President Donald Trump's "erratic" and "amoral" behavior. The official, who is committed to the Republican agenda, states that they and other officials are actively working to frustrate parts of Trump's agenda and his worst impulses. The official describes a "two-track" presidency, where Trump says one thing and staff do another, and says the root of the problem is Trump's amorality. The White House has condemned the anonymous piece, calling it "pathetic" and "selfish."

site_title: Oil falls more than 1% as storm fears ease, demand concerns mount
summary: Oil prices fell more than 1% on Wednesday after a US Gulf storm weakened and moved away from oil-producing areas, easing concerns. Global trade disputes and Turkey's currency crisis also weighed on demand. US West Texas Intermediate crude futures fell $1.15 to settle at $68.72 a barrel, and Brent crude futures fell 90 cents to settle at $77.27 a barrel. The decline was partly due to reduced production estimates and the resumption of operations in the US Gulf Coast after Tropical Storm Gordon made landfall.

site_title: Bayer forecasts lower earnings on Monsanto delays as lawsuits pile up
summary: Bayer lowered its earnings forecast due to delays in its Monsanto takeover, citing rising legal challenges over Roundup weedkiller. The company reported a 5.7-5.9 euro adjusted core earnings per share for the year, short of analyst expectations. Bayer's consumer health arm saw a 18.5% earnings fall, while its Crop Science division's quarterly adjusted Ebitda rose to 631 million euros. The company faces years of legal battles over glyphosate-based weedkillers and is under pressure to strengthen its pharmaceutical division after setbacks.

site_title: Norway's US$1t fund to beef up scrutiny on sustainability, ocean pollution
summary: Norway's $1 trillion sovereign wealth fund is increasing scrutiny on companies' sustainability and ocean pollution. The fund, which invests in 9,000 companies across 72 countries, aims to follow the UN's Sustainable Development Goals, which include reducing plastic pollution and promoting responsible consumption. The fund may sell out of companies that fail to meet these goals, including those with significant investments in plastics producers and shipping companies. Norway's economy relies heavily on the oceans, and Prime Minister Erna Solberg has made sustainability of the seas a foreign policy priority.

site_title: Uber announces ramped up passenger security
summary: Uber is enhancing passenger security with new features in its app, including "Ride Check" that detects unexpected car stops and prompts drivers and passengers to order a courtesy ride or use an in-app emergency call button if a crash is suspected. These features are set to be added in the coming months.

images.alt_text: Uber chief Dara Khosrowshahi said on Wednesday the smartphone-summoned ride service is reinforcing safeguards for passengers and their personal information.

site_title: IFA tech show unveils slew of cool and quaint devices
summary: The IFA tech show in Berlin unveiled a variety of innovative devices, showcasing the latest advancements in technology. The event featured numerous "weird and wonderful" devices, catering to curious visitors. Meanwhile, recent articles discussed emerging trends in AI, including its potential to lie and threaten creators, and the establishment of AI-focused innovation hubs for education and research. Notable investments and partnerships in the field include Lazada's US$100 million creator commerce initiative and BHP's AI Hub in Singapore, highlighting the growing importance of integrated enterprise solutions and AI in various industries.

site_title: Europe: Shares dip on trade tensions, Italy banks buoyed
summary: European shares declined 1.1% on Wednesday, reaching a two-month low due to trade tensions and emerging market currency worries. Italian banks, however, saw a boost after Deputy Prime Minister Matteo Salvini expressed a willingness to follow EU budget rules. This lifted shares in UBI Banca, Banco BPM, and Mediobanca. Tech stocks were the biggest losers, with Temenos falling 11.3% after a rating downgrade, while BioMerieux rose 4.7% after better-than-expected results.

site_title: Canon joins Sony, Nikon in battle for pro-grade camera market
summary: Canon Inc is entering the full-frame mirrorless camera market, joining Sony and Nikon in a battle for professional-grade camera equipment. The EOS R will be sold in late October for 237,500 yen (S$2,935) with a target of 20,000 units per month. This move aims to capture a significant share of the market, challenging the dominance of Sony and Nikon.

site_title: Developing economies at risk of finance-related tantrums
summary: Emerging economies face risks of finance-related tantrums due to portfolio outflows and exchange rate devaluation pressures. The "dollar tantrum" in Argentina and Turkey, "political tantrum" in Mexico and Brazil, and "trade tantrum" in Asian economies have led to sudden bursts of fear among investors. The US Federal Reserve's rate hikes and dollar appreciation exacerbate these issues, threatening decelerating GDP growth and worsening the growth-inflation trade-off. Heavy dependence on external financing and low reserve adequacy in some countries make them vulnerable to shocks.

site_title: Dollar rises on fears of new US trade tariffs
summary: The US dollar rose against major currencies on Wednesday due to concerns over potential new US trade tariffs on Chinese imports. The dollar index reached a two-week high, with investors seeking the safe-haven currency amid a US-China trade war and a crisis in the Turkish lira. The dollar has gained over 2% against the South African rand and Argentine peso since Tuesday, and is up in 2018 against every major currency except the Mexican peso and Japanese yen.

site_title: Iraqi resort a macabre emblem of war and state decay
summary: Iraq's Lake Habbaniyah, once a tourist hotspot popular with Saddam Hussein and his entourage, has fallen into disrepair since the US-led military coalition toppled Saddam 15 years ago. The resort's state-run complex is now a ghost town with piles of garbage, drained swimming pools, and a merry-go-round featuring limbless horses. Despite attempts to revive it, the resort remains a symbol of war and state decay, with visitors coming to remember the good old times.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Vard Holdings' buyout offer has been extended by two weeks to September 19. Fincantieri is offering S$0.25 per share to take the shipbuilder private. Soilbuild Construction won a S$7 million contract for Changi Business Park and One-North. Oceanus Group entered a convertible loan agreement with Barramundi Asia for fish farming. Manhattan Resources is proposing a 1-for-1 renounceable rights issue to raise S$13.73 million.

site_title: UK market sluggish on Brexit run-in: Berkeley
summary: The UK housing market remains sluggish due to Brexit uncertainty, with high transaction costs and mortgage borrowing limits hindering growth. Despite this, London and the South East have seen robust prices and demand, with Berkeley Group Holdings buying five new sites and Barratt Developments reporting a 9% rise in full-year pre-tax profit. Both companies expect further growth, with Berkeley aiming for at least £3.38 billion in pre-tax profits between 2016 and 2021.

site_title: Kansai airport flooded following Typhoon Jebi
summary: Typhoon Jebi has caused significant damage in Japan's Kansai region, leaving nine people dead and hundreds of thousands without power. Kansai International Airport, a major transport and cargo hub, remains shut due to flooding, with about 5,000 stranded passengers being relocated. The airport's closure is expected to impact semiconductor parts suppliers, who are examining alternative export routes. The typhoon's impact on Japan's inbound tourism is also expected, with tourist numbers likely to decline.

site_title: HSR construction delayed to May 2020; KL to reimburse Singapore S$15m
summary: Singapore and Malaysia have agreed to delay the construction of the Kuala Lumpur-Singapore High Speed Rail (HSR) project until May 31, 2020, pushing the expected start of service to 2031. The original completion date was set for 2026. The two countries exchanged legal documents to vary the bilateral agreement, with Singapore to reimburse Malaysia S$15 million. The revised timeline aims to ensure the project's feasibility and completion.

site_title: Trade deficit rises to five-month high on declining exports
summary: The US trade deficit increased to a five-month high in July, rising 9.5% to $50.1 billion, driven by declining exports of soyabeans and civilian aircraft. Imports hit a record high, and the trade gap with China surged 10% to a record $36.8 billion. Economists attribute the widening deficit to the ongoing trade war with China, despite the Trump administration's "America First" policies. If the trend continues, trade could subtract from Q3 gross domestic growth, potentially weighing on economic growth.

images.alt_text: The politically sensitive goods trade deficit with China surged 10 per cent to a record US$36.8 billion.

site_title: Hopper's Chop Suey may fetch US$70m
summary: A collection of over 85 art pieces, valued at over US$300 million, from late Seattle travel entrepreneur Barney Ebsworth will be sold at Christie's in New York in November. The sale features American art, including works by Edward Hopper, Jackson Pollock, and Willem de Kooning, with Hopper's "Chop Suey" estimated to fetch US$70 million. The sale marks a significant event in the art market as Ebsworth's collection is part of a generation whose art is coming to market amid shifting wealth dynamics.

site_title: Toying around with urban culture
summary: Mighty Jaxx, a Singapore-based toy maker, has expanded its urban culture offerings to include designer figurines, apparel, punk brands, and licensing. Founded by Jackson Aw in 2012, the company has grown to over 50 countries and shipped thousands of limited edition collectibles, with revenue reaching S$6 million in 2018. Mighty Jaxx has also ventured into making apparel, which generated four times more revenue than the toys, and has developed a licensing arm and microbrands, such as a brand based on the late Japanese filmmaker Akira Kurosawa.

site_title: Mid-week gloom hits Asian markets
summary: Asian markets declined on Wednesday, with the Nikkei 225, Kospi, ASX 200, and Shanghai Composite all ending lower. The US dollar strengthened for a fifth session, contributing to the decline in emerging market currencies and stocks. The Hang Seng fell 2.6%, the Indonesian rupiah slid 3.8%, and the MSCI Emerging Market Index dropped 0.5%. Singapore's Straits Times Index closed 1.7% lower, with only one counter, Ascendas Real Estate Investment Trust, gaining. The decline is attributed to investor uncertainty over the US-China trade dispute and the potential impact on the global economy.

site_title: Eurozone growth picks up in Aug, PMI nudges up to 54.5
summary: Eurozone business activity showed a slight increase in August, with the Euro Zone Composite PMI rising to 54.5, just above 50, indicating growth. However, growing concerns over the global trade war and protectionism tempered optimism, with a near two-year low in optimism and a slowdown in retail sales. Despite this, the European Central Bank is unlikely to close its asset purchase program by year-end due to robust growth and inflationary pressures.

site_title: Times are changing in London as cash falls out of fashion
summary: In London, a shift away from cash is forcing street performers and vendors to adapt. Busker Charlotte Campbell, who relies on spare change, began using a contactless card reader, marking a change in the city's street-level economy. As contactless payments become more prevalent, performers and vendors must adapt to the changing landscape, with cash falling out of fashion.

site_title: Australia's economy powers ahead in Q2 as consumers keep spending
summary: Australia's economy expanded by 0.9% in the second quarter, surpassing market expectations of 2.8% and taking the annual rate of growth to 3.4%, the fastest pace since September 2012. Strong exports, consumer, and government spending drove the growth. The Australian dollar rose almost half a cent to 72.17 US cents.

site_title: Rupiah rout mauls Indonesia-linked Singapore stocks
summary: The Indonesian rupiah has fallen 9% year-to-date, reaching its lowest level in 20 years, amid a sharp sell-off in emerging-market assets. Singapore-listed firms with exposure to Indonesia have seen their average total return fall 8.8% from January to August, with key stocks such as Golden Agri-Resources and Lippo Mall Indonesia Retail Trust experiencing significant losses. The Indonesian authorities have intervened in the domestic FX and bond markets and raised rates four times since May, but the rupiah remains under pressure due to trade war concerns and rising US interest rates.

site_title: Riyadh aims to keep oil in US$70-80 band: sources
summary: Saudi Arabia aims to keep oil prices between $70 and $80 per barrel, balancing revenue maximization with price control until the US mid-term elections. This decision was influenced by US President Donald Trump's public pressure to keep prices in check. Despite the IPO being shelved, Saudi Arabia still needs cash to finance economic development projects and is unlikely to adopt an official price target. The kingdom may adjust output to influence the market, and its informal target of $70 to $80 is similar to that of other OPEC producers.

site_title: In Trump's world, costs of carbon pricing can be steep
summary: Singapore to implement its first carbon tax in 2019, amid a world where the US Paris Agreement pull-out has altered international climate change policy assumptions. 88 countries, including those in Asia, Europe, and the US, have adopted carbon pricing schemes, with 51 initiatives implemented, including 25 emissions trading systems and 26 carbon tax schemes. The carbon prices vary widely, from US$1/tCO2e to US$130/tCO2e. Singapore's initial tax will be S$5/tCO2e, with possible increases to S$10-S$15/tCO2e by 2030. This move aims to inform policymakers and citizens about the impact of carbon taxes on energy-intensive industries.

site_title: Typhoon third whammy for Japan's inbound tourism
summary: Japan's inbound tourism is expected to drop due to a series of natural disasters, including a recent typhoon and floods. The country's tourist numbers showed an abrupt slowdown in July, with the smallest year-on-year percentage increase since 2013. The typhoon has left Japan's third most-used airport flooded and isolated, further impacting tourist numbers. Analysts predict a drop in inbound tourists, which could weigh on third-quarter GDP. Visitor figures for August will be released on September 19, but the trend suggests a decline in tourism growth.

site_title: US: Nasdaq falls as tech companies grilled in Congress
summary: US technology shares fell as Facebook and Twitter faced tough questioning from Congress, leading the Nasdaq Composite Index to decline 1.2% to 7,995.17. The Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 ended mixed, with the Nasdaq's decline overshadowing the Dow's 0.1% gain and the S&P 500's 0.3% loss.

site_title: Sheng Siong's growing footprint, strong balance sheet could stave off headwinds
summary: Sheng Siong, a consumer stock, is expected to overcome headwinds due to its growing footprint and strong balance sheet. The company has secured leases for two new retail spaces, totaling 30,400 sq ft, to offset the closure of two stores. It also bid on two shop units in Bukit Batok and Woodlands, awaiting acceptance. With 52 outlets and 477,620 sq ft of space, Sheng Siong is poised for growth in the near-to-medium term, despite e-commerce and economic uncertainties.

site_title: Solar systems key to S'pore's renewable energy development
summary: Singapore is set to increase its renewable energy contribution to 12% of peak electricity demand by 2030, driven by its ambitious solar energy development plans. The country aims to deploy 650MWp of solar electricity by 2020 and has already made significant progress in harnessing solar energy. Despite challenges such as limited land space and high cloud coverage, recent advances in rooftop solar systems and digitalisation have addressed these concerns. Singapore is now the first country with solar energy available on the national grid and accessible to anyone, with the government encouraging greater cooperation between industry players to drive innovation and efficiency.

site_title: India soars above global average in hiring of female commercial pilots
summary: India has surpassed the global average in hiring female commercial pilots, with a growing number of women joining the aviation sector. Shweta Singh, a pilot who started her career 20 years ago, notes that it's now easier for women to pursue this profession due to equal pay, a safe workplace, and day-care services. The Indian aviation sector is booming, offering benefits and opportunities for women in a previously male-dominated field. This trend is expected to continue, with more women joining the profession and seeking better working conditions.

site_title: Nadal outlasts Thiem in marathon match
summary: Rafael Nadal outlasted Dominic Thiem in a marathon 4-hour, 49-minute match at the US Open quarterfinals, coming back from a 6-0 first-set loss to win 0-6, 6-4, 7-5, 6-7(4), 7-6(5). Nadal's energy seemed to increase after the rough start, and he adjusted his game to overcome Thiem's baseline bashing. The match was the longest of the tournament, with Nadal having played a total of 15 hours, 54 minutes through five matches. He will face Juan Martín del Potro in the semifinals.

site_title: Temasek, StarHub tie up for pure-play cybersecurity firm
summary: Temasek and StarHub have formed a joint venture, Ensign InfoSecurity, a pure-play cybersecurity firm in Singapore. The company will invest heavily in talent and R&D to become Asia's leading cybersecurity firm. Ensign will offer a comprehensive cybersecurity solution, combining expertise from Quann, StarHub's Cyber Security Centre of Excellence, and Accel Systems & Technologies. With over 500 cybersecurity specialists, Ensign aims to generate over S$100 million in annual revenues, driven by growing cybersecurity demands in Singapore, projected to reach S$1 billion by 2020.

site_title: Saudi wealth fund bets big to remake economy
summary: Saudi Arabia's Public Investment Fund (PIF) is scrambling to boost its funds to finance the kingdom's transformation to a tech-focused economy, following the postponement of the Saudi Aramco IPO. The PIF aims to raise its assets from $230 billion to over $2 trillion by 2030, and is taking radical steps to boost its treasure chest with much-needed cash. The fund has invested in big-ticket deals, including Uber and a $500 billion mega city on the Red Sea coast, but some analysts have voiced concern over its "spend to grow" strategy, citing concerns over flashy deals and job creation.

site_title: William Hill ups US stakes with Eldorado sports betting deal
summary: William Hill, a British sports betting firm, signed a 25-year deal with Eldorado Resorts Inc. to expand its US operations. The deal, worth $50 million, will see Eldorado take a 20% stake in William Hill US, which is already the largest sports betting business in the US. The move follows a US Supreme Court ruling in May lifting a ban on sports betting, and analysts expect the US sports betting market to reach $3.1 billion in revenue by 2023. William Hill shares rose 5.2% on the news, driven by a 19% fall in UK shares this year due to a crackdown on gambling machines.

site_title: Amazon crosses US$1t line, second US firm after Apple to do so
summary: Amazon has become the second US company to surpass a US$1 trillion market value, following Apple. The e-commerce giant's shares briefly reached US$2,050.50 on Tuesday, but fell back to US$2,039.51. Amazon's founder and CEO Jeff Bezos is now worth nearly as much as Bill Gates and Warren Buffett combined. This milestone marks Amazon's entry into the exclusive club of trillion-dollar companies, a testament to its significant impact on the global economy and its dominance in the tech industry.

images.alt_text: Amazon captures 49 cents of every e-commerce dollar in the United States, employing more than 550,000 people and generating US$178 billion in annual revenue.

site_title: Jump in Indonesia's govt bond yields signals rate hike
summary: Indonesia's two-year government bond yields surged 55 basis points, reaching 7.65%, signaling a possible rate hike by the central bank before its scheduled meeting on September 27. The Indonesian rupiah strengthened near the psychological threshold of 15,000 per US dollar. Indonesian stocks plummeted 4.1% in a fifth consecutive decline, while emerging-market sentiment remains bearish. The central bank has defended the currency and bonds through interventions, and some analysts believe an off-cycle rate hike could support the rupiah.

site_title: Economic pitfalls await next Swedish government
summary: Sweden is poised for a challenging parliamentary situation following the country's election, with investors and economists worried about a potential recession. The country's economic expansion has cooled, and the central bank is preparing to raise interest rates, which could exacerbate debt issues and impact the housing market. The opposition wants to cut taxes and establish a productivity commission to address the causes of the economic decline, while the government is under pressure to address the country's housing shortage and competitiveness. A new government faces significant economic hurdles.

site_title: Malaysia central bank holds rate amid subdued inflation
summary: Malaysia's central bank, Bank Negara Malaysia, kept its benchmark interest rate unchanged at 3.25% amid subdued inflation and tempered economic growth expectations. The decision is in line with predictions by 17 economists in a Bloomberg survey. The central bank cited downside risks from trade tensions and domestic policy uncertainty, but expects the economy to remain on a steady growth path. Inflation is expected to edge upwards through 2019, but underlying inflation is expected to remain stable.

site_title: UOB, Shanghai Pudong bank ink MOU to target Belt and Road companies
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) and Shanghai Pudong Development Bank (SPD) signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) to serve Belt and Road Initiative companies. The agreement covers investment advisory, cross-border transactions, syndicated loans, project and trade finance, and cash settlement. UOB and SPD will collaborate on providing comprehensive services and solutions in China and South-east Asia, strengthening interbank business and connecting startups with financial technology ecosystems. The deal aims to help companies tap into regional cross-border flows arising from the Belt and Road Initiative.

site_title: HSR project suspension, Malaysia to reimburse Singapore S$15 million
summary: Singapore and Malaysia have agreed to suspend the construction of the Kuala Lumpur-Singapore High Speed Rail (HSR) project until May 31, 2020, with service expected to begin in 2031, four years after the original start date. Malaysia will reimburse Singapore S$15 million for suspending the project, and if it doesn't proceed, it will also bear costs incurred by Singapore. The agreement was signed by Malaysian Minister of Economic Affairs Mohamed Azmin Ali and Singapore's Coordinating Minister for Infrastructure and Transport, Khaw Boon Wan.

site_title: Swiss government aims to sell PostFinance stake
summary: The Swiss government plans to sell a minority stake in PostFinance, a banking arm of the postal service, to ease pressure on the systemically important bank due to negative interest rates. The move aims to inject more competition into the Swiss lending market and allow PostFinance to develop a business model. The government will retain a majority stake and PostFinance will not be fully privatized. The changes will take effect next year, allowing PostFinance to start lending and offsetting the impact of negative rates.

site_title: The acquisition of Costa Coffee brings Coke back to its main street origins
summary: Coca-Cola has acquired Costa Coffee in a £3.9 billion deal, marking the company's return to its main street origins. The acquisition brings Coke back to its roots in serving coffee, a shift from its traditional soda business. This move aims to capitalize on the growing coffee craze, with coffee being a more social and community-driven experience compared to soft drinks. The acquisition will also require Coke to interact with customers and baristas, a departure from its previous remote business model.

site_title: COE prices slide across all categories
summary: COE prices in Singapore decreased across all categories at the latest bidding exercise. The prices for smaller cars (down 5.6%), larger cars (down 1.6%), motorcycles (down 10.2%), goods vehicles (down 9.7%), and open category vehicles (down 1.6%) were reported. The drop in COE premiums is attributed to the Hungry Ghost Festival and weaker demand, resulting in fewer bids and lower prices.

site_title: Global trade woes, cooling steps bite into 2019 GDP forecast
summary: Private economists in Singapore have revised their 2019 GDP forecast to 2.7% due to global trade woes and cooling steps in the domestic property market. However, they still predict 3.2% growth for this year, with a range of 3-3.9%. Manufacturing growth is expected to increase to 7.6%, while accommodation and food services growth is forecast at 2.9%. The construction sector is predicted to contract by 4.2%, largely due to delays in the high-speed rail project and cooling measures in the property market.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Singapore Hospitality Trusts' Q2 results were within expectations, with distribution per unit year-on-year growth coming in flat for Ascott Residence Trust and Far East Hospitality Trust, but disappointing for CDL Hospitality Trusts and OUE Hospitality Trust. Revenue per available room (RevPAR) growth was generally disappointing. Analysts expect robust leisure demand, soft corporate demand, and mid-tier hotel outperformance, pushing back RevPAR expectations to 2019. StarHub is forming a new JV company to grow its cybersecurity business, with a potential sale of a 20% stake to Temasek's Leone.

site_title: Focus will be on corporate governance
summary: The Securities Investors Association (Singapore) is hosting the 9th Singapore Corporate Governance Week 2018, focusing on whether corporate governance is a help or hindrance to businesses. 55 companies have joined the Statement of Support initiative for excellence in corporate governance, committing to uphold high standards to enhance shareholder value and promote responsible business practices. Participants include GuocoLand, Miyoshi, OUE, Sats, and Sembcorp Industries, who emphasize the importance of transparency, accountability, and integrity in their operations.

images.alt_text: Voicing their support are GuocoLand's group president Raymond Choong (above), Miyoshi's CEO Andrew Sin, OUE's CEO Thio Gim Hock, Sats's president Alex Hungate and Sembcorp's group president Neil McGregor.

Voicing their support are GuocoLand's group president Raymond Choong, Miyoshi's CEO Andrew Sin (above), OUE's CEO Thio Gim Hock, Sats's president Alex Hungate and Sembcorp's group president Neil McGregor.

Voicing their support are GuocoLand's group president Raymond Choong, Miyoshi's CEO Andrew Sin, OUE's CEO Thio Gim Hock (above), Sats's president Alex Hungate and Sembcorp's group president Neil McGregor.
